HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Counting Pesetas in Madrid

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
LIKE clockwork, when winter sets in, the airlines start advertising economical off-season packages (including accommodations, transfers and air fare) to all the European capitals on my wish list. I just can't resist these European deals -- which explains what I was doing, polishing off a split of Bandita Rioja 1991 on an Iberia Airlines flight from New York to Madrid last month.
 The ad for the "Discover Spain" package offered air fare, arrival transfer, breakfasts and accommodations for three nights at a tourist-class hotel in Madrid for $529 a person, double occupancy; but with taxes, a single supplement of $90, a $20 surcharge for flying on a Saturday, and an extra day at the Hotel Tryp Washington for $73, the total came to $735. I could have spent four nights in Barcelona for about the same price, but I chose Madrid because it is six and a half hours flying time from New York; to reach Barcelona, I'd have had to make a connection in Madrid. 
 Then, too, there has been an exciting buzz about Madrid, which enjoyed an economic and cultural blossoming (called the "Movida") after the death of Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975. The city's night life got wilder, with the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar documenting the scene in 8-millimeter film; two new major art museums, the contemporary Reina Sofia and the elegant Thyssen-Bornemisza, moved in; and, like a beaming beauty queen, Madrid won a yearlong stint as the Cultural Capital of Europe in 1992. Recession and spiraling unemployment put the brakes on the Movida, so I was a little late for the party. But I didn't care, because the Prado Museum, which opened in 1819, was still there.
 After I cleared customs at Barajas Airport at about 7:30 on a brisk, clear Tuesday morning, I spotted a woman holding a sign with my name written on it. She showed me to a van, along with three other Discover Spain package takers from the United States, and we were whisked to the center of Madrid in less than 30 minutes.
 When we stopped in traffic at the Plaza de la Cibeles on the Paseo del Prado, where a grandiose 18th-century statue of the goddess of fertility poised on a chariot seemed to be waiting for the light to change, a little frisson of pleasure jolted through me, because this part of Madrid reminded me of Paris.
 But my hotel was about 15 minutes away, at the northwestern end of the Grand Via, which looks more like Broadway around Times Square than the Champs-Elysees. The 144-room Tryp Washington (where the rack rate for my single room with a private bath was listed as $107) shares a busy lobby with the 120-room Hotel Tryp Menfis. Tacky decals of leggy female bellhops were plastered on the front doors, threadbare patches of carpeting in the halls bore witness to the fact that countless tourists had passed this way, and my darkish, interior room with a double bed, coin-operated safe and television set was exceedingly small.
 But a Discover Spain agent was on hand when I arrived to help me check in. She also marked the city's top attractions on my map, warned me about a rash of tourist-targeted thievery along the Gran Via, and took over the task of reconfirming my return flight 72 hours before departure. The staff of the hotel was helpful and the breakfast buffet more than adequate, including sliced ham and cheese, pastries, cereal, yogurt, and coffee from a machine. Actually, for a better morning cup of cafe con leche ($1), I made a habit of visiting a zany chain restaurant next door called the Museo del Jamon, decorated from wall to wall with legs of ham encased in fat.
NONE of the six hotels offered at the low end of the package were mentioned in any of the guidebooks I browsed through before I purchased the deal, though my Madrid map told me that they were all on or near the Gran Via. I chose the Tryp Washington because the Discover Spain agent who handled my booking said it had been renovated recently.
 But while I was in Madrid I stopped at the other hotels, finding the distinctions between them marginal -- though I preferred the decor of the rooms in the Tryp Rex and Tryp Capitol, and the fact that they occupied parts of buildings on the Gran Via that also held huge-screen movie theaters with old-fashioned, hand-painted billboards for international hits like Jane Austen's "Sentido y Sensibilidad."
 I also toured rooms at several hotels offered in the higher price categories of the Discover Spain deal. For instance, for a package price of $549, double occupancy, you could spend three nights at the luxurious Tryp Ambassador, near the Plaza de Oriente and the Palacio Real on the west side of the old city, where the rooms are tastefully decorated and gigantic (with a rack rate of $204 for a double).
 For $689, double occupancy, you could unpack in a handsome double at the landmark Palace Hotel, across from the Prado Museum (where the rack rate is $336). Or you could just sip a goblet of Tio Pepe sherry (for $5.40) beneath the marvelous stained-glass dome in the lobby of the Palace, and eschew the package altogether by staying at one of the simple but well-maintained hostels (with private-bath doubles for about $46) in the neighborhood around the Plaza Santa Ana, Madrid's theater district during the 16th-century Golden Age. The hostels aren't fancy, but for ambiance and location, I preferred them to the Tryp Washington.
 Compelled by the little accountant who lives somewhere in my soul, I calculated the real cost of my Discover Spain package by adding together the lowest round-trip fare offered by Iberia from New York to Madrid in March ($558, with a 21-day advance purchase), the price of a taxi from the airport to the city ($17), and the cost of a single at the Hotel Tryp Washington for four nights, including breakfast ($424), and arrived at $999 -- $264 more than the $735 I paid. Not bad, but if I'd traveled independently (taking the $3 bus from the airport to the city, breakfasting in cafes for about $1.70 and staying in hostels), I'd have spent $687.
 Still, I had few regrets about booking the package, because it gave me the chance to get to know Madrid. I even got to like the hustle of the hilly Gran Via, cut in a sweeping diagonal across the city in 1910 and known as Howitzer Avenue during the Spanish Civil War, when Franco's artillery used it as a target. Virtually outside the door of my hotel lay the imposing Franco-era Plaza de Espana, with fountains, plane trees and a monolith dominated by statues of Don Quixote and his hapless sidekick, Sancho Panza.
 From there it was about a 10-minute walk to three other Madrid hubs -- the commercial Puerta del Sol, a diamond-shaped plaza in the very center of town, where the action comes to a lull only during siesta time (from 2 to 4 in the afternoon); the quieter, arcaded Plaza Mayor, built in 1620 by the Hapsburg monarch Felipe III; and the snug Plaza de la Villa, where Miss Spain 1995 gave a short speech from a balcony to launch Madrid's Carnival on the night before I left.
NOR was my hotel far from most of the historical sights I took in, like the 16th-century Monasterio de las Descalzas Real (admission $5.50), hermetic and austere from the outside, but inside a treasure chest of trompe-l'oeil frescoes, 17th century-tapestries and tiny, closetlike chapels encrusted with gold from Spain's vast holdings in the New World; the timber-ceilinged house on Calle de Cervantes where the Golden Age playwright Lope de Vega spent the last 25 years of his life (admission $1.70); the Teatro Espanol, on a site at the east end of the Plaza Santa Ana that has been occupied by theaters since 1583 (a ticket to a production of Jose Zorrilla's "Don Juan Tenorio" there cost me $9.25); and the bombastically baroque Palacio Real (admission $7), which lines five blocks of the Calle de Bailen on the west side of town.
 Actually, I'd have done well enough touring central Madrid on foot, but with temperatures in the 40's, I often resorted to the Metro, finding stops all along the Gran Via. Before the sun set on my first day in Madrid I had bought an "abono" for $5.40, entitling me to 10 rides underground (a true bargain, since single trips cost $1 each). In three days I almost exhausted it, because the Madrid Metro is just as efficient and user-friendly as the one in Paris.
 Indeed, it was by Metro that I reached all three museums in Madrid's vaunted Golden Triangle, which line the Paseo del Prado from the Atocha train station to the Plaza de la Cibeles -- beginning with the Reina Sofia (admission $3.35), Madrid's new national museum of modern art. It occupies a smashingly renovated hospital built in 1781, fronted by two window-lined elevator shafts (offering rides worth the price of admission). But I stopped first in the Luis Bunuel Archives on the ground floor to watch a video of the Surrealist classic "Un Chien Andalou" but couldn't stick it beyond the early scene in which a man draws a straight razor across a woman's eyeball. In the permanent collection on the second floor, devoted to 20th-century Spanish art, I wondered what Salvador Dali was thinking when he painted "The Great Masturbator" and stopped to see Pablo Picasso's "Guernica" (which hung in New York's Museum of Modern Art until 1981 because the artist did not want it to be displayed in his homeland as long as Franco remained in power).
 There is a fine collection of modern art on the first floor of the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, too. But this exquisitely arranged gallery (admission $5), housed in the 19th-century Palacio de Villahermosa, takes a more catholic approach to painting, including canvases by Edward Hopper, Natalia Goncharova and Wassily Kandinsky, and on the second floor everything from Luca della Robbia terra cottas to a Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington's cook. Indeed, the collection, sold to Madrid by the Baron Hans-Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza three years ago, is so comprehensive that any medium-sized American city would be blessed to have it.
 But for me, touring the Reina Sofia and the Thyssen was like mounting a flight of steps leading to a shrine -- which is the Prado, of course. Despite continuing renovations, the museum (which owns some 8,600 paintings and costs just $3.35 to enter) still wears the musty air of an Old World exhibition hall, with marvels to discover at every turning. Facing the fact that I'd have to come back sometime to view the museum's Flemish and Italian masterpieces, I concentrated on the Spanish galleries, acquainting myself with Baroque painters like Zurbaran and Jose de Ribera before moving on to the show-stopping rooms devoted to Velazquez and Goya. The breadth of Goya's work seemed astonishing -- from gay, sensuous tapestry cartoons to the horrors of war with the French to his last, tortured "black paintings." But it was Velazquez's great painting "Las Meninas" that brought me up short -- a portrait of the poised little Spanish Princess Margarita and her ladies-in-waiting that suggests the artist's understanding of human nature.
AFTER spending long afternoons in all three of these museums (which stay open on weekdays until 7 P.M. or later), I generally felt like a zombie. But the means to revival was ever at hand -- were it a cup of strong Spanish coffee sipped while standing at a bar like the Cerveceria Santa Ana on the Plaza Santa Ana, an airy pastry from the friendly, old-fashioned Antigua Pasteleria del Pozo on Calle del Pozo, or a glass of Rioja accompanied by tapas in the form of delectable little open-faced sandwiches of mussels or Roquefort cheese and anchovies (for $1.70 to $2.50 each) at the tile-fronted Taberna de Dolores on the Plaza de Jesus. I also found reasonably priced menus of the day (including house wine) at modest storefront restaurants like El Corgo on the Calle del Rollo, where I chose a first course of paella, a second of veal in lemon sauce, and ice cream for dessert (for $7.60).
 I was just mastering the art of deciphering Madrid's menus and wondering if there were any way I could work in a day trip to Cordoba on the high-speed AVE train (for $46) when it was time to go home. In fact, the Discover Spain package really let me down in only one way: It was too short.
 
The bottom line
 
While in Madrid, I spent about $55 a day above and beyond the package price.
 Discover Spain Vacations, (800) 227-5858, is offering three-night packages to Madrid, Barcelona and the Costa del Sol beginning at $499 a person, double occupancy, through March 27.
 The lowest rate is for the Costa del Sol. Madrid rates start at $529 a person, double occupancy (including round-trip air fare from New York on weekdays, accommodations in a tourist-class hotel with tax and service charges, breakfasts and an arrival transfer); the per-person, double-occupancy rate for a three-night stay at the Ritz is $839.
 Iberia Airlines of Spain, (800) 772-4642, offers its lowest round-trip fares between New York and Madrid to those able to fly on weekdays, buy their tickets at least 21 days before departure, and stay at least seven days. Iberia's lowest New York-
Madrid fare in April costs $729.
 Cheap Tickets, a ticket consolidator, at (212) 570-1179 or (800) 377-1000, has fares of $644 to $688 in April, with many restrictions. Council Charter, (212) 661-0311, has round trips for $550 on Air France via Paris if you fly before April 1.
 
Information
 The Tourist Office of Spain, (212) 265-8822, fax (212) 265-8864, is on the 35th floor at 666 Fifth Avenue in New York.
 In Madrid the Municipal Tourist Office, 588-1636, is at 3 Plaza Mayor. You can pick up maps and English-language event listings there, but the best source for information about events is the weekly Guia del Ocio (in Spanish), available from news agents for $1.
 I took several guidebooks with me, but the best by far proved to be the "Time Out Guide to Madrid."
 The dialing code for Madrid is 34-1. Prices have been calculated at 120 pesetas to the dollar.
 
Getting Around
 Taxis from Barajas Airport, 10 miles east of the city, cost about $17; there is also a bus that runs between the airport and the Plaza de Colon every 10 to 20 minutes between 4:45 A.M. and 2 A.M. daily; the price for a one-way ticket is $3, and there is a Metro stop at Colon. I made my return trip to the airport on an Aero City shuttle, which I booked at my hotel for $7.
 The Madrid Metro has 11 color-coded lines, with maps available at ticket booths; single rides cost $1 and a 10-trip ticket $5.40.
 
Places to Stay
 The Hotel Tryp Washington, 521-8391, fax 521-7729, has 140 rooms with private baths that range from $107 to $184, including breakfast and 7 percent tax.
 I also looked at rooms in two homey, well-maintained hostels on the upper floors of buildings near the Plaza Santa Ana -- the Hostal Vetusta, 429-6404, 3 Huertas, and the Hostal Santa Ana, 521-3058, 1 Plaza Santa Ana, where singles and doubles with private baths range from $25 to $45.
 
Places to Eat
 El Corgo is at 8 Calle del Rollo, 547-1005; the Taberna de Dolores, 429-2243, is at 4 Plaza de Jesus; the Cerveceria Santa Ana, 429-4356, is at 10 Plaza Santa Ana; and the Antigua Pasteleria del Pozo is at 8 Calle del Pozo; 522-3894. S. S.

HEADLINE: A Taste of English Village Life

BYLINE: By J. RUSSELL KING; J. RUSSELL KING is a deputy news editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
WHEN my mother and I pulled up to the home of Theo Dobbe and Ben Kok for dinner, a bright-blue Oklahoma flag was flying atop their cliffside house in the fishing village of East Looe, Cornwall.
 That acknowledgment of our native state may have been the cleverest and most surprising, but hardly the only, concrete symbol of the extraordinary welcome we received as part of a weeklong Parish Holiday in the nearby inland village of St. Cleer. 
 A program begun by the Church of England, Parish Holidays provides a chance for small, rural parishes in England to raise money for the upkeep of ancient buildings by playing host to foreign visitors. (Parts of St. Cleer's church date to the 13th century, and it needs a new boiler.)
 More important from our selfish perspective, the program provides an unusual opportunity for Americans and others to see a corner of England in an up-close way that eludes the casual tourist.
 "Overseas visitors would come to share the life of a local community for a week, living in people's homes, as members of the family," said the brochure I stumbled across last year at the British Tourist Authority in New York. "Every day, in the company of their new-found friends they would visit places of interest, sample foods and customs, go to the theater or on picnics -- in short, do all the kinds of things that folks would do when they had a close friend or relative come to visit."
 It certainly sounded different. Too different? Instant intimacy with total strangers in a foreign country -- sleeping in someone else's home, sharing someone else's dinner table, being shepherded around with a pack of other, unknown tourists -- isn't exactly second nature, for me at least.
 Still, I've traveled to London and other parts of England several times, yet never felt as though I knew any people who lived there. And Mom (an Anglophile who had always wanted to visit Cornwall) was due for a vacation. And the price was right -- $975 a person would cover eight days of accommodation, meals, local transportation, sightseeing.
 So the next thing I knew, one day last May I was grabbing Mother off a Dallas flight at Gatwick Airport and rushing to the Plymouth-bound train.
 It didn't take long for the people of St. Cleer (a scattered parish of a couple of thousand souls, about 20 miles northwest of Plymouth) to put to rest any reservations we had about the trip. Our hosts for the week were Frances and Bob Foulkes, both lawyers in nearby towns, whose modernized farmhouse has empty bedrooms left behind by offspring in college. "New-found friends" they certainly were, in a matter of hours.
 Starting the next morning, when, along with nine other North American visitors taking part in the program, we all gathered at the parish church, we developed a whole village of friends.
 Over coffee at the vicarage, we tried to learn the names and faces of the other visitors -- largely retired couples from various points in the United States and Canada -- and their hosts. Then there were the volunteers who drove us on our daily sightseeing excursions or gave teas or dinners for subsets of the group. And the Rev. Maurice Friggens and his funny, Levi-clad wife, Carol, who was the chief organizer for the project and who fitted no one's stereotypical expectations of "the vicar's wife." (Probably not even the vicar's.)
 This get-together began a busy week.
 St. Cleer itself is of only modest touristic interest -- "It's not a picture-postcard village," Frances said when she picked us up at the station in nearby Liskeard -- but that was part of the charm: seeing something a little closer to real life than the prettied-up hamlets of the Cotswolds or the Lake District, or "quaint" seaside resorts with shop after shop of fast food and souvenirs.
 There is, however, the beautiful local church, which provides what little center the hilly village has, and the ancient Holy Well down the street, and the megalithic burial mound and stone circle up on the moor, and the relics of tin mining that powered the local economy for a century.
 Our daily excursions (in Cornwall and neighboring Devon) found much to explore within half an hour's drive: the market town of Tavistock, the cathedral city of Truro, the cliffs of the northern Cornish coast, the windy wilds of Dartmoor. The historic environs of Plymouth, with a museum stop detailing the history of the port, the voyages of Captain Cook and Sir Francis Drake, the devastation of World War II bombing. The beautiful house and gardens of Cotehele ("home of the Edgcumbe family from 1353 until 1947"). A boat trip between the fishing villages of Polperro and Polruan.
 The lasting memories, though, will be not the tourist sights but the evening we spent at the local pub with Bob and Frances, playing along with the weekly trivia quiz.
 Or the elaborate seven-course meal with Theo and Ben, preceded and followed by unfamiliar aperitifs and liqueurs from their native Netherlands, and accompanied by wide-ranging conversation about the summer traffic, the English character, the price of vestments, the keeping of bees.
 And a similar culinary night out at the home of Len and Sally Booth-Clibborn, an evening of Old World elegance combined with the informality of instantaneous friendship, and hilarious tales of work and play. (If you ever run into Sal, who restores fine china, ask her about the giant ceramic frog.)
 Or the awesome skill of our volunteer drivers, who seemed able to shift into reverse without braking when a car approached in the opposite direction on the single-lane hedgerow-sided roads.
 Or the evenings in the Foulkeses' sitting room, watching the BBC news, handicapping the coming elections in our country and theirs, asking about the fading faces in tabletop photographs, discussing the plight of well-educated 24-year-old children of the middle class who have trouble finding a purpose in life and trouble finding jobs in the big city.
 For Mom, a warm long-distance friendship began with tea in the immaculate garden of John and Nora Spence, just across the street from the village church. On our first day in St. Cleer, John sought Mother out; his Royal Air Force training five-and-a-half decades ago took place in Oklahoma, and he was almost giddy at the prospect of meeting a "fellow" Oklahoman. (It was John, needless to say, who managed to procure a state flag for Theo and Ben.)
 The Spences' 16th-century house is the oldest in the village; there's speculation that the roof beams were cut from timbers washed ashore after the defeat of the Spanish Armada. The Spences' son, a naval officer, bought the house several years ago and was killed in a car crash before completing its restoration; John and Nora moved to Cornwall to finish the job.
 For me, a couple of decades younger than the other visitors, the anniversaries of the Normandy invasion and V-E Day took on new meaning as I listened to the reminiscences of Mother and her new friends, for whom World War II happened only yesterday.
 These sorts of special memories are available at a dozen or so English villages that sign up for the annual program, each village picking one week out of the late spring or summer to welcome guests. The local church committees organize their own schedules of hospitality and sightseeing.
 Maria Borneo, the part-time coordinator of Parish Holidays, says that the parish committees donate most of the money paid by visitors to their church, with a small amount returned to the participating households to cover basic expenses.
 Sometimes as few as two couples sign up for a particular holiday, while another may attract 18 people or more, though everybody agreed that our group of 11 seemed an ideal number.
 SOME villages take part in the program year after year, though our group's visit was a first for St. Cleer. It wasn't difficult to understand why small English towns get a lot of repeat business -- both formal and informal. Tom and Mary Ellen Daggett of Basking Ridge, N.J., were taking part in their fourth Parish Holiday when we met them in St. Cleer, and they had just come from a visit with a couple who had been their hosts on a previous trip.
 Another St. Cleer visitor, Nancy Agar of Seattle, was going on to North Wales to visit her host from an earlier Parish Holiday. (Nancy pointed out that the program has particular appeal for solo travelers, providing companions and "guides" without the rigidity of commercial tours and with no extra charge for single accommodation.)
Are there drawbacks? Well, some travelers would obviously prefer to lie on a beach or tangle with a golf course than spend quiet evenings with people they don't know. The accommodations are homey and comfortable rather than luxurious; and visitors are likely to share a family bathroom. Even if the visitor has a positive attitude, the schedule can be tiring, and those who crave a bit of solitude may have to work at carving out down time. But organizers, drivers and hosts in St. Cleer all bent over backward to make the visit as comfortable and flexible as possible.
 Indeed, there seemed to be something for everybody.
 I'm the shy type; I could travel from now till the middle of the 21st century and never strike up more than half a dozen conversations with strangers, much less get any real window on how they think and how they live. But the arrangement at St. Cleer forced me out of my shell in a comfortable way, at the same time offering the opportunity of seeing magnificent old buildings and learning the history and geography of a new corner of the world. My mother is even more interested in history, particularly of the British variety, but she's also more of a "people person," and more willing to stop and look at the little things: while I'm asking who built the manor house, she wants to know what the purple flowers are by the front walk.
 Spending a full week in one spot, with people determined to extend a warm welcome, seemed to offer both of us the sort of trip we had hoped for.
 On our last night in St. Cleer, a farewell party was held at the village school, a chance to meet still more members of the parish, a chance to exchange addresses. There were toasts and thanks and picture-taking, and souvenirs for all (paperweights of local granite for the men, framed needlepoint monograms for the women).
 And promises that the friendships would continue.
 Mr. Friggens asked me to be sure to let them know if I was anywhere near their corner of England again. "You're always welcome at the vicarage," he said. "And that's not just English politeness."
 
Signing up for a Parish Holiday
 
 Information about the program is available from Parish Holidays, 4 Brook Cottages, Corston, Bath BA2 9BA, England; telephone (44) 1225-873-679; ask for Maria Borneo, the coordinator. Or fax (44) 1288-352-786.
 A dozen English villages are taking part this year, and places are still available with all of them. The number of participants taken by a parish depends on its size, and ranges from 2 to a maximum of 25.
 Each parish picks a week between May 8 and the end of September for its program. The cost for eight days, including accommodation, meals, local transportation and sightseeing (but not air fare), is $975 a person.
A free brochure is available from the British Information Center at 551 Fifth Avenue, Seventh Floor, New York, N.Y. 10176; (212) 986-2200. J. R. K.

HEADLINE: The View From: Hartford;
Forget Hannibal, Twain Wrote Here

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE three-story house on Farmington Avenue in Hartford sits on open ground, in pointed contrast to the pinched urban sprawl of the Capitol area just a few blocks away. If you gaze at it with narrowed eyes, and block out the sound of ambulance sirens and other passing traffic, you might sense the serenity of a century ago, when the house was part of a neighborhood called Nook Farm.
The mansion's spectacular appearance, a hodgepodge of jutting balconies, fringed gables and polychrome brick, is exceeded only by the renown of its most famous resident. In the surrounding commercial district, names like Twain Package Store and Hannibal Pizza are common. But the words "Mark Twain of Connecticut" just doesn't roll off the tongue the same way "Mark Twain of the Mississippi" does. 
 And so the Mark Twain House (its letterhead not only capitalizes the "The" but italicizes it, too) attracts only about 50,000 visitors a year, a fraction of the number who stop at the various Twain sights in Hannibal, Mo., where Samuel Clemens spend much of his boyhood.
It is the sort of thing Clemens, who took his pseudonym from a riverboat expression meaning "two fathoms deep," would have probably appreciated. Hannibal may have been the inspiration for "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" and its sequel, "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," but the house on Farmington Avenue was where Twain wrote those and other notable works, including "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court." The private, locally based Mark Twain Memorial Commission, which owns and operates the Mark Twain House, would like everyone to be aware of that.
"Hannibal gets about seven times the visitors we get," said Jenifer Huget, a Twain House spokeswoman. "We aren't disappointed with the attendance figures, but we know they could be better. Hannibal was his boyhood home, but this is the only place Mark Twain chose to live, in Hartford."
In an effort to boost the museum's public appeal, the state Bonding Commission last December allocated $1.5 million toward restoring it and adding a separate building to accommodate visitors and exhibitions. A second installment of $1.5 million is to be earmarked later this year.
A spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, Dean Pagani, said it was all part of the Governor's urban agenda. "There is a growing belief that economic revitalization is not going to depend on one major project or corporation coming in," Mr. Pagani explained. "The Governor is trying to find smaller projects that when put together as a whole, add up to the same thing."
Slated for completion in 1999, the project is expected to cost a total of $7.8 million, according to the Twain House executive director, John Vincent Boyer.
The public funds must be matched by private contributions before they are released. Although a fund drive has not formally begun, the United Technologies Corporation, has already donated $250,000.
One key goal, Mr. Boyer said, is "a little catch-up ball" in awakening Hartford to this landmark in their midst. Why the need for catching up? "Hartford has an identity problem in that everyone came to Connecticut at one time or another," said John W. Shannahan, director of the state Historical Commission. "When I think of Hartford, I think of Harriet Beecher Stowe, or Noah Webster. Twain is not someone you think of as being a Connecticut figure."
In recent years Twain House has been busy trying to lift its public profile, inviting the likes of Dan Rather and "Doonesbury" creator Garry Trudeau to lecture on Twain's lasting influence on public discourse. It plans to hold "Twain Days" in August with, perhaps, a jumping frog contest and a raft-building competition.
The house, commissioned by Twain after the success of his first book, "The Innocents Abroad," was occupied by the Clemens family from 1874 to 1891, his most productive years and a time he looked back upon as the happiest of his life. Long after financial troubles forced him to move, he wrote his friend and Nook Farm neighbor Joseph Twitchell: "Our house was not unsentient matter -- it had a heart, and a soul."
In his biography "Mr. Clemens and Mark Twain," Justin Kaplan summed up the building's exterior as "gingerbread Gothic" and called it "part steamboat, part medieval stronghold, and part cuckoo clock."
It took time for Hartford to take note of the Twain House. Sold by Clemens in 1903, the building was alternately a residence for another family, a boys' school and an apartment building. Some of those apartments were retained for income when the Memorial Commission bought the structure and an acre and a half of adjacent land in 1929. It wasn't until the 1960's, according to Marianne Curling, the curator, that the Twain House was cleared of residents.
Declared a national landmark in 1963, the Twain House became more widely known in 1974, when the Memorial Commission celebrated the building's centennial. By contrast, the Twain Boyhood Home and Museum in Hannibal was open for business in 1912, only two years after Clemens' death.
While the house's exterior suggests its former owner's potent imaginative powers, the interior is a resplendent reminder of what Twain himself dubbed "the Gilded Age." The entry hall, for example, is dominated by an elaborate Renaissance Revival staircase and high ceilings sectioned off into walnut squares. A rounded settee of tufted velvet stands near the center of the room, near a golden tray used for calling cards. The walls and staircase railings are colorfully and elaborately stenciled, part of a grand interior design Clemens commissioned from Louis Comfort Tiffany.
Dozens of the antique pieces on display were owned by the Clemens family, including the bed where Clemens and his wife, Olivia, slept, and a billiards table in the third-floor room where Twain did much of his writing.
In the basement, which now doubles as a visitors' center, one can see the only surviving model of a Paige Compositor, a type-setting machine in which Twain invested and lost a substantial fortune, ultimately forcing the Clemenses to move. "The irony of the compositor being here would not have been lost on him," Ms. Curling said.
Five and a half acres of adjacent city property was deeded over to the Twain House last year, and is to be occupied by the visitors center and a new parking lot. Also on the drawing board are separate administration offices. Presently the staff occupies the servants' quarters, which Mr. Boyer should be on public view. "People are fascinated by things like how the servants lived," he said.
Last summer, a team of researchers working under the aegis of the National Park Service began a close examination of the Twain House, compiling architectural drawings, taking photographs and boring holes into the layers of paint that cover the walls, to get a better idea of how the interior appeared in Twain's day. Outside, a carriage house where Clemens first worked on "Tom Sawyer" will be restored to its original state.
Mr. Shannahan said that, in terms of appearance, the Twain House is unique in the state, and worthy of comparison to Gillette Castle in Hadlyme, the former riverside dwelling of turn-of-the-century stage actor (and former Nook Farm neighbor of Twain's) William Gillette. So far, however, visitors are relatively scarce.
"If you're trying to get the casual visitor, my view is so many people have tunnel vision, on the highway they see Connecticut as a place you pass through," Mr. Shannahan said. The farther you get from the state's main travel artery, Interstate 95, the tougher the sell to tourists.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Garrell S. Mullaney;
Consolidated Care for the Mentally Ill

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
GARRELL S. MULLANEY is the chief executive of Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown, which will by the end of this year become the state's sole remaining hospital for the mentally ill.
Patients from Fairfield Hills Hospital in Newtown have moved in and Norwich Hospital is being closed as the state consolidates into a single operation. 
 But the move has generated considerable opposition from the community, because of concern that all the most serious cases of mental illness will end up in one area. The city of Middletown has taken the state to court over whether the consolidation plan requires a review of its environmental, social and economic impact.
Mr. Mullaney was superintendent of Norwich Hospital for 10 years, including one year when he was also in charge of Fairfield Hills, before he was appointed to his new job last year. He discussed the consolidation recently at his office in Dutcher Hall on the campus of Connecticut Valley. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. A lot of the opposition to the hospital stems from the 1989 stabbing of a girl by a mentally ill man. Are mentally ill people more violent?
A. Unfortunately, what happened in 1989 was a cruel and heinous crime by a person who was obviously mentally ill, so the argument that the mentally ill don't commit violent crime is not going to wash.
But the bottom line is the mentally ill are no more dangerous, on average, than the rest of the population.
The recent attack on nuns up in Maine was committed by someone who was mentally ill, manic-depressive, who also drinks. The combination of not taking his medications and his drinking caused this lethal result.
But two weeks ago, there were several people found in an apartment in New York who had been bludgeoned to death, and it was drug related. It doesn't always have to be the mentally ill.
Q. Then why do people have the perception that the mentally ill are more dangerous?
A. Because of our prejudices. We have this image, and when someone fits that image it reinforces it.
I'm a former Marine. Let a guy who used to be in the Army do something, and his background isn't in the paper. Let a Marine do it, and it's "Ex-Marine Shoots People From the Top of a Texas Tower."
But studies have shown there is no more violence, no greater level of violent crime, among the mentally ill than in the general public.
Q. Do you find it ironic that while Middletown opposes the consolidation, the communities where the hospitals are closing opposed their move?
A. It's very ironic. And not only that, Connecticut Valley was founded in Middletown because the city wanted it here. More than 140 years ago the city donated 130 acres of land to the state so the first state hospital could be built here.
Q. How large is the consolidation project?
A. When all the renovations are done, it's going to be between $15 million and $20 million. That will give us close to a million square feet of usable space, 615 beds, and employment will increase from about 850 to 1,350. We had 203 patients before consolidation; that will increase to about 530, including about 50 from Fairfield, and 70 from Norwich.
In addition to the hospitals, we're bringing together the three substance abuse treatment centers, and the Whiting Forensic Institute. That's seven different cultures that have to be integrated here.
Q. Has the state calculated the savings from consolidation?
A. We'll save, combined, about $14 million in operating costs just from closing the two hospitals. Then there's an economy of scale in terms of hospital staffing and overhead.
Our budget will be $75 million to $80 million. But we're expending $120 million a year now on the three hospitals, so you can see the savings are going to be significant.
Q. How many employees at the other two campuses are being transferred to Connecticut Valley?
A. That depends on them. We had 70 jobs go begging after we transferred Fairfield Hills here, and at Fairfield some of them were living a half an hour east of the campus, so many of them converted a half-hour east-to-west commute into a half-hour west-to-east commute.
In Norwich, I don't believe you're going to find a lot of people who are going to want to transfer. A lot of the people live north of Norwich, and there's no easy way here from there.
Q. What about the impact on the families of patients?
A. That's one of the reasons why Connecticut Valley was chosen, because it is in the middle of the state and nobody should have more than about an hour's drive.
But it is a concern that we're moving patients farther from the communities where they live, and we're going to address that. We will maintain communication with families through what we call local mental health authorities, and as addiction services begins to incorporate managed care into their routine they will develop managed care networks. Also, there will be free bus service from Fairfield Hills and Norwich for families who need a ride to Middletown.
Q. Why has the hospital opposed the city's suggestions that it thoroughly assess the impact of consolidation?
A. We're getting permits where it's appropriate. We're doing an impact statement for the Battell building, where we're renovating for 146 beds in six wards. The top two floors will be a program for acute forensic patients who are being restored to competency, so they can participate in their own defense in court. It's going to be a very secure operation, completely camera monitored.
The city says that consolidation and campus planning are one and the same. We say that they're different. We could consolidate without having to do any campus planning. But campus planning enhances our project.
Q. Does the hospital use a lot of city services?
A. Connecticut Valley owns 1,000 acres of land in the southeast part of town. We have our own reservoir system, so our water is our own. Our fire department, police department, power plant, sewage treatment plant are all our own. We rely on the city of Middletown for very little.
Q. Is the hospital going to use all the buildings that are slated for renovation in its campus plan?
A. No. Where possible, we're trying to promote joint ventures. We might have an architectural firm come in, or light industry, or biomedical research. Basically the state would lease the buildings on the basis of doing renovations in lieu of rent for a period of time.
The state wins by getting the buildings renovated, saving us about $4 million. The company will have great space. And we can sell them our excess power.
We also have a theater here, and there was no use for it proposed in the master plan. So it will be leased to Manderlee Productions, which is going to set up a program for the arts. It has letters of intent from some banks for financing.
We're trying to interest a commercial laundry in leasing a building on campus where they could provide laundry services here and to hospitals throughout New England.
Q. Why are you trying to bring the community onto the campus?
A. So that there will be interactions. People are afraid of the mentally ill because we've been brought up in a society that has kept them apart, out of the mainstream. They've never had the advocates that, say, the mentally retarded have had.
The mentally retarded are very well accepted now in the community, but when I was a kid they were all in institutions.
To try to get people to understand the mentally ill, we think we have to draw them onto campus. There are plenty of mentally ill people out in the community, but the ones who need the most understanding are the ones who are still here. So we want to use the campus and its assets to try to enhance the image of the mentally ill, by simple co-existence.
Q. Is it going to take a long time to overcome the local opposition?
A. I don't think so. We have to overcome some serious concerns. But I think the business community will be an ally to us, because they realize what we're trying to do could be good for the community. And I think the medical community will support us.
And I think we have to make people realize something else. Simple math tells you that these places used to have between 9,000 and 12,000 people total, and now we're talking 500 or 600. Where are the other people? They're living in communities around the state.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Garrell S. Mullaney, head of Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown, discusses state plans. (Joseph Kugielsky for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 42; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Rediscovering the Legacy of Brazil's Coffee Barons

BYLINE: By MARINA ISOLA 

 BODY:
BRAZIL'S ARCHITECTURAL identity has been defined by its Portuguese-influenced Baroque churches, Oscar Niemeyer's modernism and the high-rises that rim the beaches of Rio de Janeiro. But now the fazenda de cafe, or coffee plantation, once the seat of a powerful, slave-holding rural aristocracy and the source of Brazil's biggest export, is being rediscovered and newly appreciated as a significant part of the country's architectural legacy.
Built in the 19th century as vast, self-sufficient agricultural complexes, the fazendas are now status symbols for a new generation of wealthy gentleman farmers who have replaced coffee with thoroughbred Arabian horses and prize cattle. But more than just a beautiful country house, the fazenda has come to symbolize a new interest in Brazil's culture and history. 
 Not unlike the antebellum South, the Brazilian plantation era transformed small-time farming into a big agrarian business, rapidly creating a wealthy and sophisticated new social class.
"I compare 'Gone With the Wind' with our coffee society," says Fernando Tasso Fragoso Pires, who has written several books on the subject, including "Fazendas: The Great Houses and Plantations of Brazil," published in the United States last fall (Abbeville Press). "The architecture is different, but both believed that the economic splendor, as well as the slave system, would last forever."
The plantations are concentrated in Vale do Paraiba, a lush valley in southeastern Brazil covering an area slightly larger than Long Island. The landscape has not changed much since the coffee trade exploded in the 1830's. Approximately 100 fazendas are dotted along the Paraiba do Sul River, which winds through the states of Minas Gerais, Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro.
Tropical vegetation, some of the densest in the world, smothers tree trunks and branches and encroaches on unpaved roads. Royal palms, five stories high, poke through the undulating foliage like periscopes. Here and there, set against the green tapestry, are imposing two-story French neo-classical mansions, each with the typically flat, symmetrical facade and stone double staircase leading to the front door. But unlike the most traditional maisons, these may have ocher walls contrasting with bright blue window frames and a garden planted with coconut trees and hot pink hibiscus.
An easy, tropical chic combined with Old World sophistication typifies these country estates, attracting residents like Roberto Marinho, owner of the Brazilian media conglomerate Globo, or the art collector Sergio Fadel. But buying a fazenda is not the occasion to begin relaxing; it is the start of an arduous restoration odyssey.
"What is happening with the fazendas is exceptional for Brazil," says Isabel Rocha, an architect and professor at the architecture school of Barra do Pirai in the state of Rio de Janeiro. "Preservation is not a part of the culture, nor is it incorporated in the economy or in tourism. It's a luxury."
Until recently, only the renowned Baroque landmarks have been maintained, but now dozens of plantations are being faithfully repaired and refurbished, transforming the region's architectural landscape.
The dominant neo-classical style of the fazenda arrived in Rio de Janeiro directly from France with the architect Grandjean de Montigny in 1816, but not much is known about local architects. Though the fazenda's lines and proportions conformed to neo-classicism, the function and indigenous building materials were new, so invention and a certain eclecticism were common.
The need for a large area to wash and dry coffee beans led to the development of a quadrilateral plan, with a terreiro (dirt courtyard) flanked on three sides by warehouses, granaries and slave quarters. The fourth was occupied by the plantation master's residence and its chapel, slightly elevated to afford a sweeping view of the slaves and the fields.
Many great houses had two stories, with rows of windows arranged symmetrically. Ornamentation was minimal, mostly reserved for door and molding joinery, and thus reflecting a colonial influence rather than the purer neo-classicism found in France. Bonsucesso, a fazenda in the state of Rio de Janeiro, for example, combines a formal symmetry with an austerity of details rooted in a simpler architecture.
Compared with the plantations of the American South, with their wide porches, ponderous columns and Greek revival pediments, Brazilian houses look lighter and more delicate, mixing elements like rustic doors with imported china and tapestries.
"The interiors were wallpapered with strong colors -- lots of reds, gold, maroons," explains Rogerio Vianna, the owner of Santo Antonio do Paiol, a fazenda in Valenca in Rio de Janeiro. "Green was very popular abroad, but here, with all this green everywhere, we got sick of it."
SANTO ANTONIO DO PAIOL was built in 1852 and has undergone a painstaking three-year restoration. The one-story house has a typical full-story basement, so that it appears to be two floors. Exterior colors are influenced by Portuguese architecture: white walls, blue window frames, green shutters and yellow quoins.
The house is sparsely furnished with 19th-century pieces, which were discovered in the cellar and meticulously refinished. Among them are cane dining chairs in jacaranda, a rare hardwood; an Empire-style bed with lion's paws, and paintings of the original owners, the Estevez family.
Other plantations, too, overflowed with important antiques. The Sao Martinho da Esperanca plantation, dating from 1842, includes a rare Brazilian plate collection and a painted wood altarpiece by Antonio Lisboa, known as Aleijadinho, Brazil's foremost Baroque architect and sculptor.
Conversely, at Vargem Grande, a contemporary garden was designed in 1970 by the landscape architect Roberto Burle Marx, whose commissions included the gardens of Brasilia, the capital, and the plan for Biscayne Boulevard in Miami. At Vargem Grande, exuberant native plants are tamed into a pattern of squares and rectangles.
Rediscovering the architecture of the fazenda has uncovered much about the plantation society's attitude toward style, luxury and nature. The coffee barons were eager to distance themselves from the surrounding wilderness; the less "natural" their furnishings and accouterments the better.
"For instance, the interesting thing at the time was not just to refinish wood but to transform it into a work of art," Ms. Rocha explains. "Imagine, in one house someone painted a pinho de riga wood grain pattern over real pinho de riga wood because the point was esthetic appreciation."
With the demise of the coffee aristocracy, brought on by land depletion and the emancipation of slaves in 1888, the plantations were abandoned. Over the last 40 years, people have begun to buy and restore the great houses, but it was not until last year that these new owners banded together. Preservale, a nonprofit group founded to encourage preservation of the fazendas, now claims 60 members. Mr. Vianna, who heads the group, says Preservale plans guided tours of some of the plantations and a fund-raising campaign.
"In France or in Germany, the castles are open to visitors and are a part of the local culture," adds Mr. Pires. "Similarly, the fazendas are a great part of our national heritage. Paraiba is our Loire Valley."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The symmetry of Bonsucesso, above, exemplifies French neo-classicism. In an 1881 painting of the fazenda Retiro, right, a drying yard is flanked by outbuildings; the great house is on the fourth side. Columns added to Sao Martinho da Esperanca in the 1940's make it look like a plantation house of the American South. (Oil painting by Johann Georg Grimm/Abbeville Press; Photographs by Nicolas Sapieha/Abbeville Press)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
TV Turns to an Era of Self-Control

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
IT IS SEPTEMBER 1998, and in flickering family rooms around the country, viewers are tuning in for their first glimpse of the new television season. Situation comedies dominate the prime-time schedules of the six networks, but there is bold drama as well. "N.Y.P.D. Blue," in its sixth season on ABC, is more provocative than ever.
Parents can rest easy because their television sets have the V-chip, which makes it possible to prevent children from seeing shows that carry a rating denoting violence or sexual content. 
 And despite the cries of Hollywood's Cassandras, the rating system has not destroyed television but has burnished its new golden age, which some critics say started a few years back. As the American film industry did after adopting a ratings system in 1968, television has responded with its most inventive work; creative producers like Steven Bochco ("Hill Street Blues," "N.Y.P.D. Blue," "Murder One") feel free to push the envelope without worrying that young children will sneak a peek.
This, at any rate, is how some network executives and media scholars view the near-future of television. The only trouble is, practically no one in Hollywood agrees.
As the television industry begins the daunting task of creating the ratings system it promised to President Clinton at a White House meeting late last month, most producers and writers are predicting disaster. They say that ratings will be ruinous for a host of reasons, not the least of which is that few parents agree on what is or isn't suitable fare for children.
Dick Wolf, who produces the NBC crime drama "Law and Order," does not allow his 2-year-old son to watch "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers," the hugely popular children's show on Fox, because he believes that its cartoonlike violence is more dangerous than the real-world mayhem depicted on his series. "After my son watched 'Power Rangers' one day," Mr. Wolf recalled, "he came out and started giving me pretend karate kicks."
Haim Saban, who produces "Power Rangers" and eight other children's shows, including the often criticized cartoon "X-Men," says he encourages his 5-year-old daughter to watch "Power Rangers" but draws the line at "60 Minutes." "If V stands for violent, they better slap a V on '60 Minutes,' " Mr. Saban said.
These men have their own agendas, of course. One is a leading creator of true-to-life adult dramas. The other is the television industry's most prolific producer of children's shows. But the fact that they disagree so profoundly on what's suitable for children suggests just how difficult it will be to develop a television ratings system.

How Do You Rate 1,640 Hours a Day?
In pledging to adopt such a system for everything from "Power Rangers" to "Picket Fences" -- and in promising to do it by 1997 -- television has taken on a task that producers, network executives and advertisers liken to catching lightning in a bottle. The stakes are breathtaking because the Government has mandated that in two years all new television sets must be equipped with the V-chip, a microchip that's encoded to block selected broadcast signals (the V stands for violence).
"No matter what we do, we're going to be virulently criticized," said Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, who last month brokered an agreement between the four broadcast networks and the cable industry to adopt ratings for sex and violence. At the meeting between President Clinton and a delegation of media barons on Feb. 29, Mr. Valenti announced that he would lead the effort to devise the ratings for television.
Much has been made of how the television industry has capitulated to political pressure in agreeing to rate its programs. Most network executives acknowledge that with the passage in early February of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 and its V-chip provision, the broadcast and cable networks recognized they faced a stark choice: they could either rate their own shows or let the Government do it for them.
What is less understood, though, is that it may be well-nigh impossible for television to create a viable ratings system. Mr. Valenti notes that the average 70-channel cable system shows 600,000 hours of programming a year, or 1,640 hours a day. For the purposes of rating, that is the equivalent of 821 feature films per day; the M.P.A.A. rates only 600 films per year.
Moreover, many shows are delivered to the networks only hours before they are broadcast. And unlike theatrical releases, network television shows are underwritten by advertising. Already, some major advertisers say they may feel compelled to pull commercials from series or specials that have ratings indicating sex or violence.
Mr. Valenti must also persuade the networks and the cable industry to agree on a common ratings system. That would be hard enough given the subjective judgments that people bring to issues like sexual content, harsh language and violence. But also, the broadcast and cable industries approach the question of ratings from very different perspectives. CBS, NBC, ABC and Fox are loath to scare off advertisers; the USA Network, HBO and other cable services, less dependent on ad revenue, are less worried about the impact of ratings.
Whatever scheme he ends up devising, Mr. Valenti must proceed with the knowledge that he will probably never satisfy producers like Mr. Saban, who thinks ratings are simply unworkable, or Mr. Wolf, who contends they will drive sophisticated dramas off network TV and onto cable.
To Barry Diller, the former chairman of Fox who now runs Silver King Communications, the whole issue seems as unreal as a Saturday morning cartoon. "It is a terrible thing for this industry to promise the public something that we cannot, even minimally, deliver," he said.
Still, Mr. Valenti is assembling a task force of 19 to 25 people from all corners of the television industry, and it will meet weekly over the next eight months to research, debate and fashion a ratings system. He said the group would use the movie association's ratings as a template. Those familiar codes range from G (General audiences), PG (Parental guidance suggested) and its tougher cousin PG-13, up to R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent) and NC-17 (No one under 17 admitted). Network executives said the television ratings would probably be more specific about age suitability -- PG-8 or PG-10, for example -- but would be fuzzy about actual content.
As Hollywood's emissary to Washington, the 74-year-old Mr. Valenti is no stranger to the spotlight. He led the effort to rate movies 28 years ago under intense public scrutiny and pressure from theater owners. He has honed his pitch in years of after-dinner speeches and testimony before Congressional committees. "Is it a flawed system? You bet," Mr. Valenti said by telephone from Los Angeles, "But like Churchill said about democracy, 'It is the worst of all forms of governments, except for every other form of government.' "
Mr. Valenti has been drawing on his skills as a lobbyist to sell the idea of ratings to some of Hollywood's leading producers. Recently he had dinner with Mr. Bochco to plead his case. Mr. Bochco's "N.Y.P.D. Blue," the highly rated Tuesday night show on ABC, has become a bellwether in the debate over ratings. The network has placed a parental advisory on the series throughout its three seasons because of its steamy sexual content. "I don't approve of ratings," Mr. Bochco said last week. "But given that we have to live with them, I don't want to bury my head in the sand."

The Economic Costs, And the Political
For all his talents as persuader, Mr. Valenti will have a hard time bringing around much of Hollywood. Mr. Wolf, for example, noted that advertisers routinely cancel commercials on "Law and Order" when it plumbs sensitive topics like abortion or assisted suicide. In that show's first season, he said, NBC lost $800,000 in advertising on a single episode that explored the bombing of abortion clinics.
ABC was forced to discount commercial time on "N.Y.P.D. Blue" deeply for its first two seasons. In fact, while the series has consistently placed in the top 10 in the Nielsen ratings, several advertising executives said ABC was still selling commercials on "N.Y.P.D. Blue" at a slight discount.
Mr. Wolf and others said that placing ratings on these series would only aggravate the situation. With a PG-13 rating, he said, "Law and Order" and "Murder One" would become easy marks for special-interest groups that already go after companies that buy commercials on these shows. "I've yet to meet the CEO of a major corporation who has the intestinal fortitude to face down that kind of attack," Mr. Wolf said.
Pressure on advertisers has often generated more publicity than results. But the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, president of the American Family Association, a conservative political organization in Tupelo, Miss., that has put pressure on advertisers, said a ratings system could make it easier to scare sponsors. "Advertisers are becoming a little more leery about the programming they support," Mr. Wildmon said, "It could play out that if a program has an R rating, they won't want to be on it."
For at least one big advertiser, the prospect of ratings is unsettling. Philip Guarascio, the president of marketing and advertising at General Motors Corporation, said G.M. would have to give extra scrutiny to a show that carried a rating denoting violence or sex. G.M. already submits television series to episode-by-episode scrutiny before it advertises on them, but Mr. Guarascio said that an R rating would be a "red flag," which could make sponsors a target for pressure groups. "We want to sell our cars and trucks to a broad audience," Mr. Guarascio said, "but you cannot ignore external forces. We're a highly visible company, so we're under a magnifying glass."
Top network executives say they are unruffled. ABC loses roughly $20 million in advertising revenue every year because of sponsors' rejecting controversial programs, said Robert A. Iger, the president and chief executive of Capital Cities/ABC. But he believes that adding ratings to shows will barely affect the network's prime-time schedule. It won't lead ABC to ask for less provocative programming, he said.
As an example, Mr. Iger recalled that when Mr. Bochco proposed "N.Y.P.D. Blue" to ABC four years ago, he referred to it as an "R-rated" series. Mr. Iger told Mr. Bochco that if he created a high-quality adult-oriented series, ABC would schedule it -- and stick by it. "Let's say that it's a year from now, and we have a ratings system," Mr. Iger said. "If Steven came to me with the same request, I would give him exactly the same charge."
Indeed, some observers argue that a ratings system will create more ambitious programs and weed out the dross. "Ratings will probably be salutary from an esthetic point of view," said Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University. "A mild inducement to clean up your act can actually work to the betterment of the product."

Where the Networks And Cable Diverge
Whatever new products come along, few children between the ages of 2 and 11 tend to watch the shows that will receive adult ratings. In the case of "N.Y.P.D. Blue," only 4 percent of its audience is between 2 and 11, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company. For "Law and Order," the number is 3 percent. When young children watch prime-time television, they gravitate toward situation comedies, which dominate the 8 P.M. to 10 P.M. period. For ABC and its rivals, the question is, Does losing 4 percent of a program's audience make it unprofitable?
Common sense would say no, but network television is an odd beast. It makes its money by delivering the largest possible audiences to advertisers. Advertising executives said that even losing a small percentage of viewers could force some shows off network television and onto cable.
Cable networks are less vulnerable to swings in viewership and ad revenue because they get half their revenue from subscriber fees. That difference has stoked a protracted feud between the networks and cable. The networks contend that they have been unjustly tarred as purveyors of sex and violence when cable services like USA, TNT, Showtime and HBO show far more lurid material.
Even more galling to the networks, the cable industry has taken the lead in publicizing the depth of public anger about television violence. Most recently, the National Cable Television Association released a major study of television violence that found that the amount of mayhem on television -- both network and cable -- had escalated in recent years. "They get to posture on the side of truth, virtue and ratings when by far the most violent programming is on their channels," said one senior network executive, who would speak only anonymously.

Remembering The Children
Squabbles between broadcasters and cable executives obscure the central underlying issue: How can the industry improve television for children?
Given that so few young children watch television from 10 P.M. to 11 P.M., some people argue that Mr. Valenti should start by focusing his energies on daytime television, including talk shows and Saturday morning fare like "X-Men" and "Power Rangers." Animated series are particularly controversial because they are loaded with violence, though it is often of a stylized or fantastical nature. "As a parent, I am much more irritated by the violence in 'X-Men' than I am by the violence in an adult movie," said Peggy Charren, a longtime advocate of better children's programming.
Mr. Saban, not surprising, argues that his "Power Rangers" should receive a G rating because its violence is so clearly a fantasy. "We fight turtles with traffic lights on their heads," he said.
For all their spirited defense of prime time, network executives are oddly silent on children's programming. In part, this is because they acknowledge that they have no idea how sponsors would react if animated shows carried violence warnings.
Of all the issues that face Mr. Valenti, perhaps the most bedeviling is whether ratings can actually make television better for children. Several executives contend that "graduated" ratings will not work for television because viewing is a passive act, not a deliberate one like going to the movies. Others note the obvious: that ratings have done little to stem the flood of violence in movies. "Ratings will in no way influence the kind of programs that get made," said Michael J. Fuchs, the former chairman of HBO, "They'll put electronic barriers around certain kinds of shows."
For that matter, some experts point out that the M.P.A.A. ratings have flaws that would be magnified if they were adopted by to television. Barbara Wilson, a professor of communication at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and a researcher on the cable-sponsored violence study, said movie ratings tended to be restrictive on sexual content but lenient on violence. "The ratings focus more on what might be offensive to parents, as opposed to what poses risks to kids," she said.
Mr. Valenti has been listening to these arguments for nearly three decades. "I've stepped on many of these land mines in the past," he said.
Even people skeptical about the whole enterprise said that Mr. Valenti's experience would be a benefit as he leads the television industry through the ratings thicket. But given the complexity of the issues, the scope of the challenge and the shortness of time, it still may not be enough.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 45; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Islands of Peace in a Life Awash in Sadness

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith 

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, L.I.

 BODY:
The American visionary Ralph Albert Blakelock is known for softly Romantic paintings, made mostly in the 1880's and 90's, that depict moonlight glimmering through screens of leafy trees or hazy Indian encampments dwarfed by their natural settings. Blakelock, who was born in New York City in 1847 and died in 1919, is also known for a life of such suffering that it reads more like a soap-opera version of artistic sacrifice than the real thing, as a small exhibition at the Heckscher Museum here makes abundantly clear. Recognition had once seemed likely. A self-taught artist with exceptional gifts as a draftsman, Blakelock had seen his work exhibited at the National Academy of Design when he was only 20.
Nonetheless, however grounded his work may have been in the increasingly familiar styles of the Barbizon and the Hudson River Schools, it seems to have been deemed overly personal and idiosyncratic. He never found a gallery to represent him, exhibited rarely and usually to critical condemnation, struggled without relief to support a family that included his wife, Cora, and eventually eight children and, in desperation, frequently sold his paintings for ludicrously low amounts. In the catalogue to an exhibition at the Whitney Museum on the centenary of the artist's birth, Lloyd Goodrich, who was then associate curator at the museum, wrote that Blakelock once sold 100 paintings to a Third Avenue junk dealer for $33. 
 The strain of this existence soon brought intermittent nervous breakdowns, beginning in 1891: Blakelock became distraught when a collector would pay only $500 for one of his best and largest paintings, "Brook by Moonlight," instead of the $1,000 the artist was asking. He was found in the street burning the money from the sale and was briefly hospitalized. In 1899, at the age of 52, he received a diagnosis of dementia praecox, as schizophrenia was called then, and spent most of his remaining two decades in a hospital for the insane in Middletown, N.Y.
The final bitter irony, of course, is that success finally did arrive, if too late to help Blakelock or his family. The critics eventually softened toward his work, and public interest was further piqued by news reports of his sad predicament that began to appear as early as 1903. (The attention spurred a flood of forgeries that multiplied his output many times over and that still make it difficult to define and judge his achievement.)
Owners of his paintings profited in reselling them. In 1913, "Moonlight" sold at auction for $13,900, a record price for the work of a living American artist. (It is now in the Corcoran Gallery in Washington.) Three years later, "Brook by Moonlight," the painting that had brought only $500 in 1891, sold for $20,000, breaking the first record.
Blakelock is less well known for the works he made during his hospitalization, and more than 40 of these are featured in the Heckscher's touching exhibition on view through April 7. Works from this phase are not entirely obscure; in fact, one of the best tiny paintings in a New York City museum is the National Academy of Design's "Sunset," a postcard-size oil on cardboard shot through with red and yellow, that Blakelock painted in Middletown in 1916. But this exhibition, which contains many newly discovered works, is the first to concentrate so exclusively on these sad years.
Needless to say, there is much about the show that pulls at the heartstrings, including, initially, the cramped scale. Denied all but the most basic materials, and nothing as fancy as canvas, Blakelock usually worked on small bits of paper, sometimes not much larger than playing cards, often with brushes fashioned from bits of tree bark or hairs pulled from his own head.
Yet smallness can grow on you, in the visual sense. These works expand inward in feeling, achieving a power that far exceeds their size. A few images evince Blakelock's famous romantic melancholia, most notably the watercolor of the small, lost-looking figure flanked by towering trees in "Trees, Figure and Building," which may be a self-portrait. But otherwise, they reflect nothing at all of the artist's heart-rending tale, nor any discernible mental instability. Among other things, their control, economy and level of observation are quite amazing. Blakelock seems to get the most out of each grain of material and square inch of drawing or painting surface at his disposal. One never senses a wasted mark or gesture or an unsettled, delusional mind.
BEING BOTH SELF-TAUGHT and diagnosed with schizophrenia, Blakelock loosely fits the profile of an outsider artist, an idea considered but sidestepped by Abraham Davidson, the art historian who selected the exhibition and wrote its accompanying brochure. But these tiny landscapes don't fit easily into the outsider category, no matter how loosely you define it. They show an artist simply getting on with his work, and, in fact, continue the development of a more realistic, less visionary style that was evident in Blakelock's work before he was hospitalized.
Most of these paintings have a clarity of vision and a truthfulness to nature as well as a kind of physical precision that his earlier works often lack, at least judging from the handful of canvases from the 1880's and 90's that are included in this show.
Some, of buildings and bare trees, express a delicate yet commanding use of line that astutely converts bare paper into expanses of sky and ground, causing the whole image to vacillate between solidity and translucency. Others are relatively robust and developed landscapes, with rich colors and strangely physical surfaces that resulted from a buildup of paint as well as gouging, blotting or scraping. In between these two categories is a third, in which paint has been applied and then wiped away, leaving pale traces of color, as in the combination of faint bluish white that connotes both clouds and snow in "Trees and Buildings."
The degree of physical experimentation condensed into these surfaces sometimes creates a surprising degree of abstraction. They bring to mind John Marin's nearly abstract "Weehawken" studies from the same period, as well as the Abstract Expressionists, especially Jackson Pollock and Lee Krasner. But in the end, these works attest above all to Blakelock's quiet, almost joyous attention to nature, his ability to convey the effects of light hitting tree trunks, leaves and undergrowth, bare patches of ground and rocks, as well as the pools of water and streams so frequently found at the center of his images. They evoke the places and vistas that sustained the artist, enabling him to pursue and even develop his vision, despite the odds.
