SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: Descent Into SoHo

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Benedict; Elizabeth Benedict is a novelist whose latest book, "The Joy of Writing Sex: A Guide for Fiction Writers," will be published this summer. She teaches creative writing at Princeton University.

 BODY:

BRAIN FEVER
By Valerie Sayers.
308 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $23.95.
THE kingdom of madness is a destination we never visit voluntarily, and such are its shifting borders and evanescent landmarks that those who make the journey are often not sure where they are headed or when they have arrived. 
 For Gogol's madman, the St. Petersburg insane asylum to which he is committed is Spain, he is its king and the earth is about to land on the moon. For Tim Rooney, the unwitting trip he takes while narrating Valerie Sayers's immensely rich, readable fifth novel is a reprise of an earlier descent that led to his sister's suicide, a failed search for a monastery that would welcome "a recovering madman" and a prescription for Thorazine.
At 16, with an acceptance letter from Columbia University, Tim thought himself "a young Wittgenstein." At 45, he is a failed academic with a 27-year-old fiance, a history of breakdowns and a highly charged, deeply ambivalent relationship with the Roman Catholic Church. He lives, like most of Ms. Sayers's characters to date, in novels that include "How I Got Him Back," "Who Do You Love" and "Due East," in the once sleepy seaside South Carolina town of Due East (modeled on the author's hometown of Beaufort), a town "where even the poverty is picturesque."
In this novel Ms. Sayers plays with so many notions of sanity and insanity, and of tenderness and mercy, that this 40-day-long diary of a madman, with echoes of Christ's 40 days in the desert, is as much a case study as a lesson in faith through the eyes of an on-again, off-again Catholic and those of his jilted fiance (an atheist, former Baptist and unwed mother). Both have appeared before in Ms. Sayers's work, as have these themes of fidelity, apostasy and salvation. Tim is attracted to Mary Faith Rapple in part because she is "the daughter of dour fundamentalists, unwavering in her disbelief," while she admits to admiring the "fierceness of his religion. . . . If he were a Presbyterian or a Methodist, I don't believe I would have troubled myself."
Having been described at different times as schizophrenic, neurotic, manic-depressive and alcoholic, Tim is off his latest medication at the start of "Brain Fever" and begins losing touch with his fragile sanity on Holy Thursday. He's ignited by Mary Faith's declaration that she will join him in church on Easter Sunday. Suddenly, she wants them to marry in the church whose strictures she knows have caused him torment akin to madness: "She didn't say sexual torments, but she didn't need to."
Before long, carried off by tiny waves of paranoia and manic delusion, he decides to become a man of action instead of an unemployable philosophy professor. He abandons Mary Faith, her 11-year-old son, whom he is about to adopt, and Due East, and drives to New York City. He's got $15,000 stuffed into his socks and the cockeyed intention of settling a score with the wife who left him after six days of marriage in the early 1970's, when they were both practicing Catholics "and no one was in the church anymore, no one but us." Those few days were also part of an "hour of mass insanity," a time when "we all went crazy together" and "my hallucinations were exclusively chemical and always intended." Are you crazy if you are just keeping up with the Zeitgeist, Ms. Sayers wants us to wonder, or might madness have immutable properties, so many parts oxygen, hydrogen and carbon?
Outside Charleston, Tim picks up Angela Bliss, a young female hitchhiker -- another fugitive from her own upcoming wedding -- who is also bound for New York, where some rich South Carolina friends have a SoHo loft; conveniently there is an extra room for Tim, who tells them he is an actor about to audition with Sidney Lumet. From Spring Street he sets off every morning to Washington Square Park to look for his former wife, now an esteemed professor at N.Y.U., and to discover that some of his paranoia has nothing to do with brain fever; a former student, an African-American called G. B. Brights, spotted him in South Carolina on his own drive north and takes a sycophant's interest in him, inviting him to meet his aunt in Brooklyn. These two households become the antipodes of Tim's increasingly unstable universe, as he bounces from one to the other in search of solace, safety and sometimes sex.
In the meantime, aging Father Berkeley in Due East, another fixture in Ms. Sayers's earlier books, tries to corral Mary Faith into setting off to find Tim, whereabouts unknown, though she is smarting mightily from having been left, very nearly, at the altar. "He hasn't left you," he implores her. "He's left his senses."
This chapter, one of eight narrated by Mary Faith, is the most moving in the novel. It is Ms. Sayers at her very best: Mary Faith, the wounded lover, atheist and Hester Prynne of Due East, being pressed into service and self-sacrifice by a fragile old priest who smells of "mothballs and nicotine" and from whom she expects religious platitudes -- "But God will give you strength or Let us call on Him for courage" -- but who offers instead his almost steady hand on her head as she weeps.
"I was weeping," she tells us, "over priests sitting there on your father's old lounger and asking you to believe that this really is a woman's lot: to nurse men and to wait on them, to send them off to their crazy adventures and then, when they've made it too dangerous for themselves, to go fetch them and forgive them and be steady and faithful."
Mary Faith's occasional and very sane "Reports" are a wonderful counterpoint to Tim's often manic narratives. But what also makes hers so compelling is that they are tightly focused on the mission she undertakes with Father Berkeley. By contrast, Tim's entries, especially once he gets to New York, tend to be busy and hyperactive, as he is, full of destinations, new characters, paranoid fantasies and what were not long ago delusions of grandeur about bringing peace to Bosnia. In a way she could not have intended when she wrote the novel, Ms. Sayers has managed to suggest that madness can be a chemical imbalance and perhaps a species of prophecy too.
The principal weakness of "Brain Fever" is that the assortment of characters Tim moves among for most of it -- the hitchhiker, her SoHo friends and G. B. Brights -- are an aimless lot, not clearly motivated by much of anything except a tendency to commiserate about their heartache and troubled histories. They are there, it seems, to give Tim a setting and a support group in which to lose his mind. But this is a small quarrel about a novel of such large ambition, compassion and psychological depth, not to mention the pleasures of Valerie Sayers's graceful prose.

PUB-DATE: March 17, 1996

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1489 words

HEADLINE: The Literature of Resistance

BYLINE: By Thomas Flanagan; Thomas Flanagan holds an appointment this spring as Regents' Lecturer at the University of California, Berkeley.

 BODY:

INVENTING IRELAND
By Declan Kiberd.
719 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $35.
The program note at the opening night of Sean O'Casey's play "The Shadow of a Gunman" in 1923 informed the audience: "Any gunshots heard during the performance are part of the script." It was a sensible precaution. As Declan Kiberd reminds us in "Inventing Ireland," a critical study laced with wit, energy and an unrelenting adroitness of discourse, on that April night the civil war between the Free State and the Republic -- between the "moderates" who had signed a treaty with the British and the "die-hards" who rejected the compromise -- had another week to run, and sporadic rifle fire peppered the streets outside the Abbey Theater. 
 The second play in O'Casey's Dublin trilogy, "Juno and the Paycock" (1924), is concerned with the civil war itself, as though his art fed on history as it was being enacted in the streets. But with the third play, "The Plough and the Stars," in 1926, history moved into the aisles and onto the stage. It dramatized the Easter Rebellion of 1916, which had ignited a decade of revolutionary violence, bloodshed and, in the end, fratricide. Now it earned for itself an outburst that far surpassed the celebrated "riots" caused by J. M. Synge's "Playboy of the Western World" in 1907. In the audience were veterans of that rebellion, mothers and widows of others, and a new generation of rebels. They came prepared to battle O'Casey's brutal yet hilarious demythologizing of what had become sacred -- the blood sacrifice by Patrick Pearse and the other martyrs of Easter Week.
The only wonder is that the reaction was so slow in coming. Seamas Shields, the disillusioned and far from heroic former patriot in "The Shadow of a Gunman," had clearly been speaking for O'Casey himself: "I believe in the freedom of Ireland and that England has no right to be here, but I draw the line when I hear the gunmen blowin' about dyin' for the people, when it's the people that are dyin' for the gunmen! With all due respects for the gunmen, I don't want them to die for me!" "With all due respects" is authentic O'Casey, at once droll and deadly.
To O'Casey, a militant socialist, the Rising was suicidal and befuddled, and a betrayal of the working class. But in Ireland, as the matter is put by Mr. Kiberd, who has a weakness for aphorism, " 'socialism' never stood for much more than a fundamental goodness of heart," and O'Casey was a cardinal case in point. He thought with his heart rather than his head, and thinking with the more conventional organ, Mr. Kiberd suggests with delicacy, was not his forte. The powers of his art were of a different order.
Mr. Kiberd, a lecturer in English at University College, Dublin, and a distinguished critic, possesses a special gift for patient exploration of works of art in relationship to their surroundings. For example, he locates with precision the source of a powerful feeling we experience when we watch O'Casey plays. They are set in the Dublin slums, where in the early 20th century the death rate was higher than in Calcutta, and where the poor were crowded to overbursting in rotting slum houses that had once been the mansions of a vanished aristocracy. "Such a setting dictated the controlling mood of the Dublin plays, each of which is a study in claustrophobia, in the helpless availability of persons, denied any right to privacy and doomed to live in one another's pockets," Mr. Kiberd writes. "Many of O'Casey's poetic speeches are attempts by characters to create a more spacious world in the imagination than the drab, constricted place in which they are expected to live. In that respect, O'Casey is an heir to Synge, who had found in the rich idiom of the peasantry an implicit critique of a monochromatic world."
A joining of O'Casey's boisterously vulgar imagination with that of the oblique, private and often enigmatic Synge is made possible by one of Mr. Kiberd's unifying themes -- the variousness with which Irish writers have used language, including the particularities of dialect, to explore cultural identities. Through language, every Irish writer has conducted a dialogue between the often warring parts of his own being, and other dialogues with other Irishmen separated from him by class or religion, and above all else he has maintained a dialogue with that enormous colonizing empire that hovers, as fact or memory, over every Irishman's shoulder.
For Mr. Kiberd, the generating energy in Irish culture in recent centuries has been British imperialism (at first military, political and economic, but ultimately cultural) and the protean native resistance to that process. He is concerned with Ireland's literature as that of a post-colonial culture, but he gives that term a most elastic definition. A literature does not become post-colonial only after the occupier has withdrawn: "Rather it is initiated at that very moment when a native writer formulates a text committed to cultural resistance."
Thus Edmund Burke, writing in the 18th century, is a post-colonial, a defender of Ireland's necessary connection with England who was at the same time a mordant critic of Ireland's Protestant rulers as little better than "a junto of robbers," brutal and craven. This works well enough with Burke, but in its more universal application by Mr. Kiberd, it may best be described as highly convenient. He delights in paradox, and to speak of the Gaelic historian Seathrun Ceitinn (in English, Geoffrey Keating) as post-colonial, although he wrote at the very height of England's military triumph, must surely appeal to that delight, setting at defiance as it does the common meanings of words.
At times he stretches too thin his all-embracing formula, as with overly ingenious discussions of Wilde and Shaw. Wilde was very conscious of his Irishness, which afforded him occasions for wit. As when he declared that he had no religion: he was an Irish Protestant. Nevertheless the adroit attempt to make of him a kind of stylistic freedom fighter is one that not even the broad shoulders of his genius can support.
But the mention of Wilde and Shaw reminds us that wit, paradox and an almost indecent delight in verbal jugglery place Mr. Kiberd himself in a central Irish literary tradition, a tradition that also includes Swift, Joyce and Beckett. He resembles that stereotype of the Irish writer "invented" by Ireland's imperial masters -- impudent, eloquent, full of jokes and irreverence, by turns sardonic and conciliatory, blithely subversive but, without warning, turning to display wide and serious reading, generosity of spirit, a fierce and authentic concern for social and political justice. Rather like Wilde and Shaw.
In so headlong and many-branched a discourse, there are the inevitable slips, some of which the solemn and pedantic reviewer sets forth as his revenge upon wit. Of the two Government officials murdered by extremists in Dublin's Phoenix Park in 1882, Lord Frederick Cavendish was the Chief Secretary and Thomas Burke the Under Secretary -- not, as Mr. Kiberd has it, the other way round. And no allegations of homosexuality were made at the trial for treason of Sir Roger Casement in 1916. The British Government circulated such stories, supported by entries from his diaries, outside the courtroom and surreptitiously, with the intention of blackening his reputation.
In both instances, the facts could have served Mr. Kiberd's elaborate anti-imperial design. Lord Frederick Cavendish, an amiable and mild-mannered Englishman, was recently arrived with a mission of conciliation. But the actual tough work of evictions and political repression had been entrusted years before to Burke, his subordinate, who of course was a native Irishman serving the empire. And the whispering campaign against Casement, conducted with Cabinet knowledge, seemed almost to imply that transgression of the Victorian moral code was an offense more grievous than high treason.
Mr. Kiberd's remarkable achievement may seem to fall within the modish academic enterprise "cultural studies," which too often seems a kind of safe house where theorists with tin ears can give solace to one another. But his own ear is splendid, and he is careful to place a distance between himself and fashionable cultural theorists in words that a few years ago would have been unnecessary, but in the present climate are almost flamboyant: "It is wise to recognize -- despite current critical fashions -- that certain masterpieces do float free of their enabling conditions to make their home in the world. Ireland, precisely because its writers have been fiercely loyal to their own localities, has produced a large number of these masterpieces, and in an extraordinarily concentrated phase of expression."
It is heartening to find an academic critic talking about masterpieces and writing in celebration of them.

HEADLINE: Mass. Appeal

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is professor emeritus of economics at Harvard University. His latest book, "The Good Society," will be published next month.

 BODY:

While the Music Lasts
My Life in Politics.
By William M. Bulger.
Illustrated. 328 pp. Boston:
A Richard Todd Book/
Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.
Quite a few years ago, while representing the great Republic in India, I had a call one day from Jawaharlal Nehru. He was going on a short holiday and wanted to know if I had a good book to take with him. Indian resources could be limited even for a prime minister. After some thought I sent him "The Last Hurrah," by Edwin O'Connor, a book, at very slight remove, on James Michael Curley of Boston and Massachusetts. Nehru was delighted, called me to say so and on later holidays or journeys never failed to ask if I had something as good. This I rarely did. 
 Now, were I asked, I would offer him William M. Bulger. Mr. Bulger, known to all as Billy, is an accomplished writer, with a phenomenal memory that one suspects is refreshed on occasion in a moderate way by invention. He draws on a rich store of classical and general literary recollection. And he has an engaging subject with which to deal. It is the Great and General Court, as our legislature on Beacon Hill in Boston is denoted. For the last 17, repeat 17, years he was president of the Massachusetts Senate; before the Senate he was in the House, to which he was elected while still a law student. Over nearly all of these years he also practiced law in a marginal but not, evidently, a wholly unremunerative way. He somehow found the money to provide for his supportive wife, Mary, and to educate their nine children. He contends at some length that his public and private income were separated in an entirely wholesome way, which is something fairly rare in Massachusetts politics.
Once, when his law practice got extended to a politically unhealthy, if distant, association with a highly questionable real estate operator, Mr. Bulger made a point (here related in detail) of remitting roughly a quarter-million-dollar advance on his fee. That money he greatly needed, and he concludes his account by saying, "Money is not happiness, yet for at least a brief time it can offer a delightfully close imitation." On the evidence of this book and in a view not shared by his enemies, including his relentless critic, The Boston Globe, Billy Bulger was, at a minimum, a very careful man.
But Mr. Bulger himself is not the major attraction of this book -- or, more precisely, he would not be except for the political context. That is Boston, the Boston Irish and Boston politics. Elsewhere in the United States politics is a stolid affair of public service, public persuasion and, of course, basic honesty and the lapses therefrom. In Boston, politics is an art form. It is something to be watched, appraised and enjoyed; there are good players and bad, those admired and those rejected. It is a matter of local theater, and of nothing are the participants -- and the audience -- so aware as good or bad performance. Mr. Bulger performed wonderfully well over the years; he would not have received equal attention or written as engaging a book had he emerged in New York or Chicago or, needless to say, Los Angeles.
There was, to be sure, serious business. A good part of this book is devoted to Mr. Bulger's war on busing -- the taking of children from his beloved South Boston to other schools, especially in the neighboring black Roxbury, and bringing youngsters from there to his personal territory. It was his strongly held view that to each community belonged its own life and services and, particularly, its own schools. This was not racism, Mr. Bulger contends; it was the right of every community to its own. Here, as elsewhere, he is relentless in his condemnation of those who lacked this view, and especially of Judge W. Arthur Garrity, who supervised the busing. Judge Garrity, he observes, had been "appointed up the ladder until he arrived at his level of incompetence," adding that "it seemed to me our Neighborhood had become Judge Garrity's white whale, and that only its destruction would bring him peace."
The anger here lingers on. At the time, some 30 years ago, I would note, I favored the busing; now, with most others, I am not so sure. To the extent that race was not the controlling force, the case for community-based schools had undoubted merit.
"While the Music Lasts" is in sprightly English, with the allusions of an exceedingly well-read author. As this is written, Mr. Bulger has just become president of the large, sprawling, needful and sometimes troubled University of Massachusetts. As were many others, I was asked about his appointment when it was pending. I approved: education, and its guidance in the university, is the divine right of the faculty. No president can have much effect on that. The president's job is to get the money -- in this case from the legislature. For this Billy Bulger has the highest qualifications, a lifetime of experience.
But also, as this book shows, he could well teach a course on writing nonfiction, with perhaps an occasional touch of fiction. It would, with all else, show his superior talent for literary allusion and personal insult.

HEADLINE: Southern Discomfort

BYLINE: By Josephine Humphreys; Josephine Humphreys's novels include "Dreams of Sleep," "Rich in Love" and "The Fireman's Fair."

 BODY:

MOTHERS OF INVENTION
Women of the Slaveholding South in the American Civil War.
By Drew Gilpin Faust.
Illustrated. 326 pp. Chapel Hill:
The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.
"I long to be a writer of merit to be classed among those who can compose and write sentences which will startle and electrify the reader," wrote a Georgia schoolteacher, Abbie Brooks, in October 1865, confiding to her diary this rather surprising ambition. Brooks is one of the more than 500 Confederate women whose journals, letters and memoirs form the basis of Drew Gilpin Faust's "Mothers of Invention: Women of the Slaveholding South in the American Civil War," a dramatically revealing study of how the war altered these women's identities. Because so many of them did write, Ms. Faust has been able to draw from an extraordinary record of self-scrutiny in a changing social order, and the result is a book that will itself be sure to "startle and electrify." 
 A distinguished historian who teaches at the University of Pennsylvania and whose extensive studies have focused on the South, Ms. Faust wrote "Mothers of Invention" not for an academic audience but for a more general readership, her motives rooted in personal family history. "I have tried to write this book as if my mother and grandmothers were going to read it," she explains -- no simple task, as any Southern daughter will understand if her ideas of Southernness and womanhood differ from those of the family she loves.
During her childhood in Virginia during the 1950's and 60's, Ms. Faust says, "My mother taught me that the term 'woman' was disrespectful, if not insulting. Adult females -- at least white ones -- should be considered and addressed as 'ladies.' " Years later she would return to the topic of those early family arguments, aware that "the origins of this book lie somewhere in that youthful experience."
I came to "Mothers of Invention" with a natural interest -- as a novelist, drawn immediately to what Ms. Faust calls the "human drama of this war story," and as a Southern woman drawn by plain curiosity. But I read with unanticipated fascination, spellbound by the gathered voices, their passion and stamina, their gifts of introspection and observation. Each chapter leads further into the world of writing women, and their struggle to make sense of a nightmare. I also read with frequent surprise and occasional horror.
Before the war, Abbie Brooks might not even have thought of becoming a teacher or a publishing writer. Women of her class, the lady class -- white, well-bred, well-read and numbering about half a million across the South -- willingly embraced the idea of a female sphere, the circumscribed domesticity deemed to be the proper realm of women. To venture beyond a private, home-centered life was to risk one's status as lady and even one's femininity, to become mannish and "unsexed."
But the simultaneously privileged and limited position of the lady was possible only as long as white men provided wealth and guardianship, and black slaves provided labor. When the Civil War destroyed the hierarchy of the plantation economy, the rationale underlying ladyhood no longer held, and white women had to reinvent themselves.
This is a thesis voiced not only by the author but by the very subjects of the study. They have written their own history, with particular attention to the ideas Ms. Faust wants to investigate. "Will I ever have my dear husband at home any more or am I doomed to fight & buffet my way through this friendless world alone," wrote Julia Davidson in 1863. "God forbid indeed I do not think I could unless necessity were to make a different woman of me."
Writing to soldier husbands, women expressed loneliness, fear and frustration, finding themselves cast in new roles of authority and decision making that challenged their resources. Equally daunting were the most minor chores. Ms. Faust suggests that although antebellum plantation mistresses may have worked hard, they must have concentrated on "organizational or managerial tasks -- ordering food and clothing or planning and assigning work within the house -- for war and emancipation revealed that many white women felt themselves entirely ignorant about how to perform basic functions of everyday life."
One had, in her own words, never "so much as washed out a pocket handkerchief"; various others could not sew, knit or cook, or were shocked to discover "the trouble of children" when there was no nurse around. A particularly revealing remark is that of one South Carolinian whose family had gone without a cook for 10 days before finally finding a replacement: "Newport has taken the cooking," she wrote, "and we are all ladies again."
But others did not feel so confident. "I will never," Lila Chunn wrote to her husband, "feel like myself again," and Lucy Buck believed "we shall never any of us be the same as we have been." Many Confederate women did go to work, did teach and nurse; they entered into public discourse on political topics; they began for the first time to see themselves in groups rather than as isolated plantation mistresses; and they came to question many of the old ideals, particularly those of romance and marriage, because of the scarcity of men. Political and religious worries arose as well. Some even began to question the war itself. There can be no doubt that the various changes wrought by war combined "to impel Confederate women toward a new independence in the postwar world."
"Mothers of Invention" reveals, however, that it is possible "both to change and not change" -- to perceive the necessity for reinventing the self and to rise to the occasion but, in the end, to retreat from thorough transformation. Ms. Faust focuses on the successful changes, but steadily points out the tenacious hold of tradition over Confederate women in all aspects of life. Many did learn to sew and knit and weave, but their efforts had little effect on home textile production as a whole. The participation of Confederate women in nursing was not what its advocates had hoped for. An examination of the staffing records of hospitals shows that "for all their undeniable and important contributions, it was not the Confederacy's ladies but its African-Americans who cared for the South's fallen heroes."
Shortly after the war began, when white Southerners fully expected victory and, as we sometimes forget, considered the Confederacy a nation, the Southern journal De Bow's Review explained why writing was appropriate for the Confederate lady. "The circumstances are peculiarly favorable," De Bow's said. "The form of our society relieves her from that manual labor which falls to the lot of women in other nations, and thus ample time is left for literary employments." I had to read those sentences twice. It was a stunning, chilling thought, that the literary traditions of the South had origins in the leisure made possible by slavery, and that white Southerners themselves said so.
"Mothers of Invention" is full of such moments of revelation, many of them troubling. Most disturbing of all is the chapter dealing with slavery. By war's end, a number of plantation women who had initially supported the system were disillusioned, mainly because, in the absence of masters and with the promise of emancipation, slaves increasingly resisted the authority of mistresses. But what is of particular interest, beyond what white women thought of slavery as an institution, is what many of them had to say about the individual people who were their slaves. Some of these comments are impossible to read without flinching, so startling that even though they occupy a small space in the book they threaten to overshadow the rest.
But it is important to know these things. One of the peculiar difficulties of being a Southerner is that sometimes those we may believe to be wrong are often coincidentally those we love, and we sometimes seek a solution to that problem by ignoring or even hiding evidence. There are better solutions. Because Drew Gilpin Faust doesn't shrink from difficult truths, she is able also to see other, more hopeful aspects of Confederate women's inner lives. And perhaps this is what she wished her mother and grandmothers to know: that she can see the error and the hope, confronting what she calls "the paradox of being both a Southerner and an American" by looking directly at the past, with a daughter's hard, steady gaze, and with a daughter's generous heart.

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: New Immigrants Transforming The Population

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
AS immigrants continued to arrive in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in moderate numbers, an even larger number of residents departed, Census estimates for the first half of the 1990's show.
The estimates confirm that expanding ethnicity, led by increases among Asian and Hispanic people, continues to transform a region that was once predominantly native-born white, with native-born blacks as the largest minority segment. 
 The estimates depict an overall rate of change that lags far behind the upheavals after World War II, but they underscore profound challenges in employment, housing and education.
Planners and experts said net migration from the two counties involved departures by retirees and out-of-work or underemployed former military workers.
In a countertrend, the figures and anecdotal information suggest, some outmigration from Nassau involves retirees and families who are moving to Suffolk.
According to the regional planning board, eastern Suffolk has a higher percentage of retirees than Florida. One eastern Suffolk school district, Eastport, more than doubled in size from 1990 to 1995, in part because of the arrival of young families from western Suffolk and Nassau, according to Superintendent Robert R. Dillon.
"These are people trying to recapture the American Dream," Dr. Dillon said. "Our windows are still glass, and there's no graffiti."
Experts said another bloc of the departing included young adults and working people who could not afford or were repelled by housing and living costs in one of the most expensive, highly taxed regions in the country.
According to the estimates, which were released this month, the net international immigration to Nassau was 28,993. In the five years the net domestic migration was more than 47,000.
The disparity was even greater in Suffolk, notwithstanding retirees and young families who moved from Nassau. The figures showed that the net immigration of 18,229 was less than half the net migration of nearly 40,000.
Despite the deficits, the estimate showed that the population increased in both counties. The increases resulted from births at a record level in Suffolk and at the highest level since 1967 in Nassau, according to the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
The Nassau population increased, from 1,287,444 in 1990 to 1,305,722. That contrasts with the 2.6 percent decline from 1980 to 1990.
In Suffolk, where the 1990 Census showed an increase of 2.9 percent over 1980, the new figures show an additional increase, from 1,321,768 in 1990 to 1,353,704 last year.
The estimates show that the proportion of Nassau residents over 65 increased, to 15 percent in 1995, up 1 percent since 1990. In Suffolk, that group increased, from 10.6 to nearly 11.3 percent.
The executive director of the regional planning board, Lee E. Koppelman, said the figures for Hispanic immigration were too low, because they did not fully include illegal aliens. "The unofficial growth is even higher," he said.
He said the Hispanic population included people with Indian and black ethnicity, Latin Americans of predominantly European ancestry, Portuguese and Spanish Europeans and migrant laborers, including Mexicans.
The 1990 Census showed that Hispanic people had surpassed blacks in Suffolk, 87,852 to 77,303. In Nassau blacks outnumbered Hispanic people, 105,315 to 77,386. The planning board projects that the Hispanic total will eventually be higher in both counties.
Newer residents from Central and South America continue to cluster in communities where earlier waves of Hispanic immigrants had settled. Those communities include areas in Babylon, Glen Cove, Hempstead, Huntington, Islip, Long Beach and Patchogue, said Larry Meneses, executive director of La Union Hispanica in Islip.
Mr. Meneses, a member of the Nassau County Charter Revision Commission, said that Hispanic people were increasingly dispersing and that the number of Hispanic businesses on the Island was expanding. "There has been a real explosion of Hispanic-owned businesses," he said.
For lower-income Hispanic immigrants, housing continued to be an acute problem, the Census reports say. Several experts say many newly arrived Hispanic workers and families crowd into illegal rental units. Though smaller in numbers, the Asian population had the highest rate of growth for any group. From 1980 to 1990 it increased 33.8 percent, to 38,434 in Nassau, and 111.5 percent, to 22,415 in Suffolk.
Mr. Koppelman said Asian immigrants tended to be more affluent and widely dispersed, with most coming from China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam. Long Island has also had smaller contingents of Indians, Pakistanis and other groups, he added.
The Island is attracting business people from an array of immigrant groups, Mr. Koppelman said, adding, "What we are attracting are entrepreneurs who can afford to come here, and a good deal of that is migration from New York City."
Planners, elected officials and business groups have long supported so-called affordable housing in part because it might provide homes for a workforce that would include immigrants.
"The amount of affordable housing being built is minuscule, but at least it's beginning to happen," Mr. Koppelman said. "It's happening because a lot of communities are beginning to discover that they can no longer find people to do service work. When you can't find someone to cut the grass or fix your car, there is more acceptance."
The president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, Jim Morgo, said his group was reaching out to the Hispanic population.
"We do have a considerable number of Hispanic immigrants who inquire about our homes," Mr. Morgo said, "and they have an increased sophistication about qualifying for mortgages. The whole genesis of the housing partnership was economic, not philanthropic. What xenophobes often overlook is that immigrants are good for an economy."
But experts say large numbers of immigrants in rental units pressure some school districts that have had a rapid growth in students who speak English as a second language, if at all.
The legislative chairman of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association, Dr. Bruce Brodsky, said 15 of the 25 districts in the state with the highest levels of students with limited English were on Long Island.
Some Long Island districts report that students speak 30 or more languages and dialects. Most of those districts are on the South Shore, but North Shore areas like Port Washington are also affected, he said, adding:
"We are faced with 12-, 13- and 14-year-olds who are coming in not only illiterate in English. but in their own language. These kids are, of course, very high-cost kids to educate. We have been saying this for the past five years, but nobody has been listening to us."
The strain is greatest, Dr. Brodsky said, in districts that are not wealthy and where school taxes are already high and facing further increases in part because of extensive remedial and bilingual education.
Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget would eliminate state aid for bilingual education, he noted. Mr. Pataki has also proposed capping state aid for building classrooms as the State Education Department estimates that enrollment on Long Island is approaching an historic peak.
The new Census estimates do not include ethnic breakdowns of net immigration. Long Island's first immigrants, English Protestants, supplanted Indians and predominated from the colonial period to World War I.
After World War II, Levittown, other suburban housing and the development of aircraft industries led to a population explosion and rapid transformation as people of German, Irish, Italian, Polish, Russian and other ancestries moved in. Many Jews also settled on the Island, and Roman Catholics grew to outnumber Protestants.
"It was bedrock Protestant for all those years, and then after World War II the whole thing just turned around," said Dr. Roger Wunderlich, an adjunct associate professor of history at the State University at Stony Brook.
Dr. Wunderlich, also editor of The Long Island Historical Journal, said the region had recently been depleted by "an alarming migration of young college graduates."
He said he regularly asked students in his course on Long Island history whether they planned to remain on Long Island after graduation. The students' answers, he said, were always the same. "They say they don't see how they can live on Long Island because it's too expensive," he said. "They say it doesn't look good for staying here."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1232 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Home Seekers Buying More, Especially in Fairfield

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WEAKENING consumer confidence held back home sales and new construction in 1995, Connecticut real-estate professionals say, except in lower Fairfield County, which continued to attract a steady stream of affluent buyers. But the first two months of 1996 have produced a spurt of contracts that has raised industry expectations for a better, if not a banner, year.
Emerging trends in new construction include clustered homes in country settings, urban rental apartments with on-site recreational amenities and a variety of dwellings for residents over 55 who may no longer flee Connecticut now that its inheritance taxes are to be phased out between 1997 and 2005. 
 Building permits fell 11.5 percent in 1995 compared with 1994 and sales declined 7.6 percent, according to the state's Department of Housing. But Vincent M. Valvo, editor and publisher of The Commercial Record, a business weekly, said that 1995 "wasn't really a bad year, just worse than '94, which was very good." His figures show, for example, that sales of homes priced at more than $1 million rose to 470 in Fairfield County last year from 422 in 1994 and 355 in 1993.
Robert M. Becker, president and chief executive of Coldwell Banker Schlott Realtors, said "our sales were off by 4 percent last year across the board, but '96 has started out incredibly well, up 20 percent from the same period last year in Connecticut, 9 percent in New Jersey and 2 percent in Westchester." He attributed the Connecticut gain to "the corporate environment having a rebirth" due in part to the construction of the Swiss Bank's new headquarters under way in downtown Stamford.
William Raveis, head of William Raveis Real Estate, characterized 1995 as "a mixed bag," adding: "Fairfield County is still stoking the fires of real-estate companies. We had several sales of $5 million to $7 million in Greenwich and New Canaan because of Wall Street. People whose companies went public made lots of money."
While sales dropped in 1995, prices rose, especially in Fairfield County. The median cost of a home in New Canaan, for example, rose almost $26,000, to $768,267. Raveis's New Canaan office is marketing homes of 4,000 and 6,000 square feet on one acre for $800,000 to $1.5 million.
Stamford is experiencing demand for rentals from families and individuals who do not want to buy a house right now or perhaps ever. The Fairfield on Morgan Street, developed by Clay Fowler, charges $1,100 to $1,700 for one- and two- bedroom units with terraces, a free health club and a heated pool. Garage space is $60 a month extra. A third of 263 apartments are occupied and another section will be ready in April.
Avalon Properties will open a 400-unit complex on Grove Street in June. One- to three-bedroom units will rent from $1,200 to $2,150, including use of the pool, a computer-fax room, game room, racquetball and club room. A second Avalon complex will also open in June in Wilton, where 102 apartments will rent for $1,800 to $2,500 and include similar amenities. The first 40 units of Avalon's third venture, 340 one- to three-bedroom apartments in Trumbull, are leased. Priced from $950 to $1,500, they also offer many recreational amenities.
Strong interest in clustered subdivisions reflects "a wish to be closer to the neighbors, a desire for lots of mature trees, greens, and a secure play area for children," said Joanne Carroll, president of JMC Resources, her real-estate marketing and consulting concern in Guilford.
GREAT OAK FARM in Monroe, the winner of the 1995 Homebuilders Association Design Award, is just such an enclave. Seventy three- and four-bedroom homes have been sold and 68 more are to be built. Colonial exteriors and open-plan interiors with two-story entries, extensive landscaping and a single road in and out of the 207-acre site are among the features. Prices range from $230,000 to $280,000.
Similar subdivisions include Mr. Fowler's 48 clustered homes on 11 acres at Grumman Hill Road in Wilton, where 2- and 3- bedroom homes start around $300,000. William Pitt Real Estate is marketing 26 detached condominium homes at Somerset in Fairfield for $329,500 to $425,000; 36 homes with communal paddle tennis and a pool at Greystone in Shelton, where sales in mid-April will start at $219,900, and 22 clustered homes at Getner Farms in Norwalk opening next month in the mid-$300,000's.
Sales increases in Danbury were second only to Greenwich in the state last year. Buoyed by extraordinary retail activity spreading out from the Danbury Fair Mall, new businesses, a refurbished railroad station-cum-railway museum, new paving, lighting and restaurants, 1996 looks promising, said Richard Mancuso, a broker at Goodfellow-Ashmore Real Estate.
"Homes from $200,000 to $350,000 are moving well," he said, "but first-time buyers in the lower ranges have difficulty coming up with the 20 percent down payments that lenders are beginning to require again."
Farther north in Litchfield County, New Milford is growing so fast that last month it imposed new regulations limiting gas stations, fast-food restaurants and convenience stores on Route 7 to no less than one mile from each other. Halfway between I.B.M.'s installations in Somers, N.Y., and Southbury, Conn., it is attracting many corporate employees, according to Lydia Adams of the local Prudential Real Estate office.
"Sales were down by about 8 percent in '95, but prices rose by about $2,000 a unit," she said, "to an average of $146,500." So far this year, business has been brisk, and "the No. 1 choice is new construction," she said. Several subdivisions of 30 or more 4-bedroom homes are going up, for sale at $200,000 to $250,000.
AT the eastern end of the state, New London County is having a housing boomlet, sparked partly by the Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard. Kenneth Boyer, a principal at Re-Max Shoreline Real Estate, said "an influx of buyers has been developing for the past 12 to 18 months," and he expects increased activity when the Mohegan Sun Casino opens in October in Montville.
"Existing homes start around $80,000 to $90,000 in New London and Groton," he said. A subdivision of 218 new homes called Deerfield at Mystic will open for sales in April, priced around $100,000 for three bedrooms, one and a half baths. Garages are extra.
New Haven and Bridgeport are up in sales so far this year, and even in Hartford, where the weight of layoffs and population declines has been especially heavy, Steven Bailey, president of Dollar Dry Dock Heritage Real Estate, said, "the market is more active." He added: "There are multiple offers on houses -- something we haven't seen in the past nine years. Corporate downsizing seems about completed."
Accommodating the older population in a country setting are homes at Chapman Farms in East Lyme, where one member of the household must be at least 62. Sixty-five detached, clustered homes on 20 acres will be be available this summer. Two- or three- bedroom residences will cost $129,500 to $149,500.
City living for older people in Stamford will include various degrees of personal and medical assistance at two complexes that Marriott's Senior Living Services will open in 1998. Edgehill apartments will cost $245,000 to $545,000 with monthly fees of $1,950 to $3,100, and Brighton Gardens units will rent for $2,700 to $3,500 a month, including all meals.

HEADLINE: Rebound Reported In Office Occupancy

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE view to the east from Oxford Health Plan's new offices here show Westchester's rolling hills blanketed in snow. The west side affords a panorama of downtown White Plains. "You've got the bucolic on one side, and you've got the urban on the other," said Steve Daniels, regional director of operations for Oxford. "Of all of our offices, this is the nicest in terms of work environment."
Such words fall sweetly on the ears of beleaguered real estate agents in the county, who say that Westchester's office market is bouncing back as major corporations commit to the area, and vacancy rates continue to decrease. The improvement is particularly strong in downtown White Plains, which is considered pivotal to the county's overall economic health. 
 The county's office vacancy rate at the end of last year was 18.7 percent, down from 22.3 percent the previous December, according to Rostenberg-Doern, a real estate concern in Purchase. This is the third year in a row that vacancy rates have dropped, after reaching a high of 26.9 percent in 1993.
The arrival of Oxford, one of the country's fastest-growing managed-health-care plans, has played a significant part in resuscitating Westchester's ailing office market. The company signed a lease for 267,000 square feet in Westchester One, a gleaming office tower, which was once largely occupied by I.B.M. That transaction alone lowered the vacancy rate between 3 and 4 points, realtors said.
"A deal like Oxford's is a signal -- especially since it was downtown White Plains -- that it's a very viable marketplace.," said Michael H. Siegel, executive director of Edward S. Gordon's Westchester/Fairfield office. "It means that there are companies looking at Westchester because they have convinced themselves that economically it's a good decision. The labor is there, and the real estate to meet their needs is there."
Downtown White Plains is not the only market in Westchester that is rebounding. Vacancy rates in offices have declined in the Harrison, Rye and Purchase area along 1-287 as well as in the western part of the county along Route 119 in Elmsford and Tarrytown. Improvement is also visible in the northern part of the county, where in a recent transaction, the Mount Kisco Medical Group leased 68,254 square feet of space in an office complex in Mount Kisco, which formally housed the headquarters of Trans World Airlines.
Westchester's recovery has lagged behind other markets in the New York City area, particularly Fairfield County. Westchester came back more slowly because the office market was less diversified than that in Connecticut, realtors said. When International Business Machines and American Telephone and Telegraph and began downsizing, the county had very little economic base left.
"It's only in the last two years now that Westchester is trying to play catch up," said John Rostenberg, principal of Rostenberg-Doern. "Stamford has got a very diverse and broad range of types of companies located there, like Champion International, Xerox and G.E. Credit Corporation. It has rebounded earlier than Westchester has, but it is where Westchester will be in maybe two or three years."
Mr. Rostenberg said several other significant recent transactions have further strengthened and diversified Westchester's market. Mastercard and I.T.T. Industries moved to the county from Manhattan this year, and I.B.M. and Ciba both decided to stay in the area.
Also enhancing the market resurgence is the fact that many commercial properties had reverted to the lenders in the early 1990's. The banks invested more money in the properties and are now marketing them at competitive prices. "We're almost back to where we were in 1990," Mr. Rostenberg said. "We've gotten back to an equilibrium market."
The gains in office real estate have positive implications for the housing market, not only in Westchester but also in Putnam and Dutchess. It is also changing the face of rush hour -- Metro-North has seen a major upswing both in reverse commuters traveling from Manhattan to outlying suburbs and in commuters traveling from northern New York into Westchester. Currently, the railroad's fastest-growing route is between White Plains and Dover Plains on the Harlem Line.
At Oxford recently, workers were busy installing cubicles for the customer-service staff. Mr. Daniels said the company will be occupying six floors and expects to employ 1,500 people.

HEADLINE: State Has Big Role In Medical Research

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT has become one of the leading biomedical research centers in the country, according to a study by Connecticut United for Research Excellence, a consortium of state-based companies and researchers.
The study, issued last week by the Wallingford-based consortium, said that the state has not capitalized fully on a huge increase in pharmaceutical company spending and the presence of major educational research centers, including Yale University and the University of Connecticut, to create new products and jobs. 
 Most of the research is centered within Connecticut-based research centers operated by global pharmaceutical companies -- Pfizer Inc. in Groton, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in Wallingford, the Bayer Corporation in West Haven and Boehringer Ingleheim Inc. in Ridgefield and Danbury.
"For years, we have been saying that biomedical research was important to the Connecticut economy, but we never had real numbers," said Debra K. Pasquale, president of the consortium. "Now we can document the importance of this enterprise in the state."
The state now receives more than $1 billion annually, or 10 percent of all money spent by pharmaceutical companies in the United States for research and development, according to the consortium.
In addition, Connecticut ranks fourth among the states in research spending per capita by the National Institutes of Health, the major Federal source of medical research funds.

HEADLINE: Pothole Patching, Budget Woes Follow the Snow

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
SPRING arrives this week, and it's none too soon for municipal officials across Connecticut, who have measured this winter's snowfall totals in record levels of red ink.
But the spending on plowing is likely to the followed by a torturous spate of potholes and pothole mending, roadway managers say. It's bound to further test the patience of people already frazzled by snow shoveling and fender denting. 
 Cities and towns headed into March having overspent snowplowing budgets by several times the amounts allocated, forcing their finance and public works officials to use money set aside for other purposes to pay for overtime, hiring plowing crews from private contractors and extra heaps of salted sand.
And March promptly added to the problem by delivering another one-two punch of snow.
The winter of 1995-96 will leave an aftermath of reduced or delayed public services, and tax increases in a few communities. These effects, however, will vary substantially between municipalities, some of which were lucky or well-prepared, others unlucky or improvident.
For the record, this has been the snowiest winter in the Hartford area, 107.7 inches recorded at Bradley Airport through February, and the second snowiest for Bridgeport, 61.7 inches at Sikorsky Airport, less than 10 inches from that location's record of 71.6 inches, set in 1933-34.
The average snowfall totals through February for the two locations are 36.3 inches and 20.3 inches, respectively, although meteorologists and public works officials agree that there is no such thing as an average winter.
"Climatologically, it's quite normal," said Paul Wethington, weather observer at Sikorsky Airport, who noted that in the last five years Connecticut has had two of its coldest, snowiest winters and two of its warmest, driest winters on record.
In municipal government, politicians who are alarmed by heavy snows and budget deficits one year are lulled when the following year's snows are light, so snow budgets swing up and down, year to year. Not surprisingly, interviews showed that cities coping best financially with their snowplowing costs were those that resisted pressure to reduce budget accounts after the warm, dry 1994-95 winter left surpluses. Those in the worst shape tended to be those that succumbed to that pressure.
The plague of potholes began to appear in late February and will not abate until April when asphalt plants begin selling hot patch, which forms durable roadway hole patches. Until then, repair crews must rely on cold patch, a mixture that adheres in cold weather but erodes easily.
State residents welcomed two midwinter thaws, in late January and late February, but now they must pay for them. The thaws caused frost heaves that cracked road surfaces, also worn by plow blades and tire chains. Water leaked into the cracks, froze and opened the potholes. "It's like having two springs," said Ronald Manning, Superintendent of Public Works Operations in Fairfield.
Thomas Johnson, Public Works Director in Hartford, said he had already notified the city manager that potholes will add to the city's winter woes. Waterbury's Superintendent of Streets, Robert Carroll, said this year might set a record for the cost of pothole repair in his city.
Both cities have substantially overspent their snowplowing budgets. Hartford had planned on$400,000, but spent more than $900,000, Mr. Johnson said. So far his department has been able to absorb the extra expense by postponing purchases, leaving employee vacancies unfilled and transferring funds from other accounts.
Hilly Waterbury, on the other hand, spent more than four times the $500,000 it had budgeted for snowplowing. Already troubled by a large budget deficit, revealed in a recent audit, the city government is hard-pressed to find the money for the snowplowing bills.
"There was a lot of weeping and gnashing of teeth" when budgets for other city departments were combed for money to transfer to public works, Mr. Carroll said. "Nobody in the other city departments will talk to me. I've been avoiding the park superintendent for weeks." He added that last year he returned $347,000 unspent from snowplowing accounts.
Stamford overspent its budget by more than seven times. "We were underbudgeted to start," said Mickey Docimo, the administrative officer. To meet the cost, supplies will not be purchased, vacancies will not be filled, some services will be reduced, and there may need to be a tax increase next year, he said.
Many other cities and towns set similarly optimistic allocations for snowplowing, hoping to keep taxes down, and are facing similarly grim consequences.
Mr. Docimo said the city set aside $490,000 for 1993-94, a snowy winter when it actually spent $1.54 million. After dealing with that deficit, and acknowledging that it spends $680,000 in an average year, the budget was raised to $545,000 for 1994-95. But last year was warm and dry, and spending was low -- only $280,000. So for 1995-96, the budget was cut to $311,890. By the end of February, Stamford had spent more than $2.2 million.
John Marsilio, Bridgeport's Director of Public Facilities, said Bridgeport used to have similar problems before its financial crisis forced reform. A state-mandated Financial Review Board required higher funding for snowplowing accounts and rigorous internal accounting practices. Although the city spent almost twice what had been set aside for snow, the reformed budget accountability will allow him to absorb the extra costs, Mr. Marsilio said.
Bridgeport also benefited by procedural reforms spurred by past embarrassments. Its response in a massive storm on March 13, 1993, and in the snowy 1993-94 season that followed was both fumbling and excessively expensive. Mr. Marsilio, who took charge of the department in 1992 and admits to his early mistakes, joined with his department managers to establish a new system and for the first time in memory, Bridgeport streets were well-plowed this winter. And in a study done by Stamford in January comparing plowing costs per roadway mile, Bridgeport had spent $2,214, far less than other cities (New Haven $2,416; Norwalk $3,958; Stamford $3,445).
Mayor Richard Borer of West Haven was criticized by opponents in his 1995 election campaign for allocating too much for snowplowing this year because the city spent $40,000 in 1994-95 of a $50,000 budget. Nevertheless, Mr. Borer the plowing budget to $65,000. Even that wasn't nearly enough; West Haven has spent close to $400,000. Nevertheless, with a combination of economizing, transfers from the city's fund balance (a standing reserve that is not part of the operating budget) and aid from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Mr. Borer said West Haven will make do.
Federal funds will be distributed to many cities and towns to help pay for the blizzard in early January. Other cities will tap into their fund balance accounts, but that money must be restored or their bond ratings may be lowered costing taxpayers even more in the long run.
The experience has made Mr. Borer consider snow insurance for West Haven, something that other communities have tried. Cheshire expects to claim $12,000 from its insurance, a modest, but helpful amount. That is less than $2,000 profit over the two years Cheshire has purchased the policy, and Finance Director Michael Milone is thinking of revising the coverage.
Derby did better, purchasing a more expensive, seasonal policy, rather than the month-by-month policies that Cheshire chose. Mayor Alan Schlesinger said Derby will claim $50,000 from insurance through February. The $9,300 policy pays $25,000 per snow storm beginning with the fifth storm of the season.
It could have been $125,000 had the city's tax board followed his recommendation last spring to buy the policy, but when the insurance paid nothing last year, the board balked at renewing it. That decision was reconsidered in time to start coverage as of Jan. 1, but by that time three storms had occurred not applied toward the deductible.
Mr. Schlesinger said after the insurance claim and Derby's Federal aid, his city will have overspent its $60,000 snow plowing budget by about $75,000. "Of course, the winter's not over with," he observed.
March, in fact, roared in like a lion with two snowstorms in the first week and colder than normal temperatures. Mel Goldstein, a meteorologist for WTNH-TV, called March "a belligerent month" that commonly hosts notably bad nor'easters and blizzards.
"It's not named after the Roman god of war for nothing," Dr. Goldstein said.

HEADLINE: When 'Made in Connecticut' Counted

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IF any one piece of real estate in Connecticut best represents the history of the Industrial Revolution it would have to be a couple of acres on Capitol Avenue in Hartford near the state capitol. Starting in the mid-19th century, the factory buildings on the site were passed along from company to company. As one industry faded, or moved elsewhere, another came to take its place.
On the site have been, in turn, a rifle manufacturing company (Sharps), a sewing machine company (Weed), a pioneer precision tool maker (Pratt & Whitney), the biggest high-wheel bicycle company in the world (Columbia), an early automobile plant (Pope-Hartford), an aircraft engine plant (Pratt & Whitney again) and, finally, as the 20th century was drawing to a close, a high-tech, computerized adjunct for an insurance company (Aetna). 
 "It's the Industrial Revolution in a nutshell," said Dave Corrigan. "It's a unique story." Mr. Corrigan comes by his opinions with some authority. He is curator of the Museum of Connecticut History, in the State Library Building a few blocks east of the historical cluster of factory buildings, which in part celebrates Connecticut's illustrious past as a world leader in manufacturing.
Now one more chapter is being added to the story of the buildings on Capitol Avenue. The State of Connecticut, pressed for adequate space for workers, bought the huge (431,000 square feet of space) old factory complex from the Aetna Life and Casualty Company early last year.
For the past several weeks, some 1,100 state employees have moved in: The Department of Mental Health to 410 Capitol, the Office of Policy and Management to 450 Capitol, the Department of Mental Retardation to 460 Capitol. A fourth major building, at 470 Capitol, contains meeting rooms and a large restaurant.
What the state employees are discovering is that behind the grim brick facades are well-lighted work areas with huge exposed beams overhead, wide corridors, wainscoting, decorative and architectural touches that have led to such accolades as "neat," "a fun place to work" and that ultimate accolade, "cool." Said Reginald L. Jones Jr., secretary of the Office of Policy and Management and generally known as the Governor's budget director: "The architecture and the beauty of the building are impressive to us as new tenants."
The real miracle of the factory buildings is less that they are so dramatic inside but that they managed to survive at all. Two decades ago, they almost went. They were shabby, grim reminders of another age, in a time when Hartford was in the midst of an economic boom, razing old buildings in a near frenzy of redevelopment.
What saved the buildings was their location: Relatively close to Aetna's home office on Farmington Avenue, which runs parallel to Capitol Avenue. In the 1970's the insurance giant, needing more space for its then-growing number of employees, bought the buildings and turned them into a workplace quite unlike any other insurance company, anywhere.
The guiding spirit behind the transformation was Jack Dollard, a Hartford architect with a sense of time, and also with a sense of humor.
Basically, Mr. Dollard left the exterior of the buildings intact -- they still look grim and foreboding -- but he opened up the interiors, letting sunlight come in through huge windows, exposing century-old beams, adding decorative touches that made the buildings, now connected by huge underground corridors, an adventure to walk through.
He put a huge teacup on the wall, for instance, to alert workers that they are approaching the company restaurant at 470 Capitol, a place where he hung a dozen tapestries to tell about the industrial giants that once occupied Capitol Avenue. Also overhead, swinging from the 61-foot-long beams, went three papier-mache trapeze artists that Mr. Ballard obtained when the Danbury Fair shut down.
Before the renovations were complete, people at Aetna were skeptical of the industrial setting. "They were calling it 'Factory Mutual,' " Mr. Ballard said. After they saw what had been accomplished, he added, they changed their minds. "Then they all wanted to work there."
The overhaul was not inexpensive. Mr. Dollard, on a recent first visit to the place, said the costs to the insurance company were $26 million in the go-go 60's and 70's. When Aetna, which has been downsizing in the 90's, sold the complex on Feb. 16, 1995, the price was $10,259,520, according to State Department of Public Works records.
One question that has arisen since the state took over the new-old buildings is what will happen to "the museum."
Under Aetna, the centerpiece of the Capitol Avenue project was a little museum Mr. Dollard designed inside the entrance of 450 Capital Ave. to demonstrate the products that had been produced on the site. They included a car made by Pope-Hartford, two 19th-century high-wheel Columbia bicycles and one turn-of-the-century Columbia safety bike, two machines used to make the first Pratt & Whitney Wasp engines in the mid-20's and one of those engines.
In December 1994, just before Aetna sold the building, it donated many of the museum artifacts to the Connecticut Historical Society. "We called them Santa," said Betsy Fox of the Historical Society. She said the articles would go into a new permanent gallery the Historical Society plans to open at the Old State House.
In addition, Aetna gave the Pratt & Whitney Wasp engine to the air museum at Bradley International Airport and retained for itself a huge canvas painting by the Pulitzer Prize-winning artist Rudolph Zallinger. The painting details the history of the Capitol Avenue buildings and the nearby Frog Hollow neighborhood. It now hangs in Aetna's main building.
What basically remained after the state purchased the buildings were a few items that had been lent to Aetna by the state's Museum of Connecticut History. The most important of these, the Pope-Hartford vehicle, is a story unto itself.
Albert A. Pope, a Colonel in the Civil War, became one of Hartford's leading entrepreneurs in the latter decades of the last century.
Colonel Pope, as he was commonly known, put America on wheels by establishing the country's, and the world's, biggest bicycle factory on Capitol Avenue. By the early 1880's, it had 3,000 workers turning out 60,000 Columbia high-wheel bicycles a year.
Colonel Pope later went into production of the safety bike with two equal-sized wheels but, as the century waned, developed a new interest: the automobile.
He moved the bicycle business to Massachusetts and started in on Pope-Hartford cars, both gasoline and electric. For a time, it appeared that Hartford might become the automobile capital of the world, but that dream was crushed by another industrial pioneer, Henry Ford.
In a legal fight over what was known as the Selden Patent, a plan for a wheeled vehicle with a gasoline engine, Ford sued Pope-Hartford and an organization of licensed automobile manufacturers of the time that charged royalties on the patent. Ford did not want to pay royalties for building cars. He lost the suit, but won on appeal and went on to mass produce little inexpensive cars and make a fortune. Colonel Pope made big splendid cars and went bankrupt.
In connection with the Ford suit, Pope-Hartford created one vehicle known as the Selden, a strange affair that looked like a horse-drawn vehicle with a small engine substituting for the horse. Today that vehicle stands in almost solitary splendor in the little museum at 450 Capitol. But fear not, neither the bizarre old contraption nor the museum itself are in jeopardy, according to T. R. Anson, the state's Commissioner of Public Works. Mr. Anson said that "absolutely and without question," the museum will be continued under state ownership. The Selden vehicle will remain and the present empty spaces near it will be filled with other manufactured items culled from storage at the Museum of Connecticut History at the nearby state library.
In addition, Mr. Anson said, he has been so impressed by the quality and quantity of material available backstage at the library that he is entering into "partnering arrangements" with other state agencies to show off more of the artifacts in other state buildings. The history of Connecticut's former claim to fame might finally be getting its due.

Albert A. Pope produced bicycles and motorcycles there before losing a car-marketing war with Henry Ford and going bankrupt. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Help for Social Security

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Can Retirees' Safety Net Be Saved?" (Feb. 18) does not mention one solution to Social Security's peril -- rapidly raising the retirement age to 70. 
 Social Security went into effect in 1935. Today, 61 years later, people are entering the work force later and living much longer. We're in an entirely different economic and social era. In 1983, Congress acted timidly in gradually raising the retirement age to 67 by 2027.
The solution is clear -- rapidly raise the retirement and Medicare age to 70 and continue to raise it as life expectancy increases.
 
MELVIN L. GOLD
West Orange, N.J., Feb. 19
 
The writer is a consulting actuary.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Housing Industry Sees a Repeat of Listless '95 Sales

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Last fall Joseph Morrison, a computer programer for AT&T, and his wife, Elizabeth, a teacher, decided to move from their town house in Hillsborough to a $250,000, four-bedroom house at a subdivision being built in Montgomery Township.
Then came the announcement that his company would lay off 7,000 employees in New Jersey. 
 "We asked ourselves if buying a new house was the smartest thing to do," said Mr. Morrison, noting that when AT&T downsized two years ago he and his wife had put off buying a home and instead purchased the town house to minimize their risk. "I was not affected then and I feel confident I won't be again. With interest rates low and home prices good we forged ahead."
The couple sold their town house in December for $112,000 and will move into their new home the end of this month.
Like the Morrisons, many purchasers today are weighing the odds of favorable mortgage interest rates and stable home prices against the health of the economy and job growth. Those issues chilled last year's home-buying market, which saw a solid start spiral into a near comatose stretch last fall and end up flat. New home construction also was down.
But many industry professionals are betting that in 1996 more buyers, nudged off the fence by attractive rates and the belief that the worst of the downsizing is over, will respond as the Morrisons did and buy. They feel that this will boost sales, which began on a weak note, through the spring and summer. But the consensus is that this year will wind up a repeat of last year.
The wild card, many said, is jobs. The state is expected to gain a net of 40,000 jobs in 1996 -- still less than the 50,000 jobs a year it has averaged. "As long as rates remain low home sales will match those of 1995," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.
"The '95 market wasn't dead or robust, it was a steady, meat-and-potato year" said Michael Ford, president-elect of the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison. Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro, called it "listless."
The anxiety sparked by the restructurings and the state's slower economy and job growth did not devastate home prices. But buyers were cautious, owners trimmed expectations of price appreciation, and builders worked harder for sales.
The active markets were, and will be, communities that offer good schools and hold their appreciation and those in high growth corridors, like those in Middlesex, Ocean and Monmouth Counties, said David Schoner, a housing consultant in Sparta.
While sales of existing homes fell to 138,000 from 145,000 in 1994, said the realtors' group, the median price stayed relatively steady at $148,000. But there were regional differences: In central New Jersey the median price remained stable at $140,200, but in the northern counties it fell to $187,900 from $190,100. It also dropped in south Jersey to $106,700 from $107,800.
ABOUT 43 percent of the sales were for $100,000 to $180,000, showing that mortgage rates worked magic for first-time buyers, Mr. Ford said. Also, 17 percent of the sales were for $200,000 to $300,000 homes -- those geared to move-up buyers, mostly baby boomers with children who, in terms of demographics, will again be a market focus this year.
The market for houses priced over $300,000, was thinner and is not expected to improve this year. Despite this general pattern, some builders of upscale homes, among them Toll Brothers of Huntington Valley, Pa., which in 1995 started 10 projects with a total of 702 houses priced from $300,000 to $700,000, report good sales.
Yet the state ended 1995 issuing 7 percent fewer permits than the previous year's total of 26,986. A recent Rutgers report showed that the number of permits was unlikely to top 30,000 for each of the next four years since the state's "slow recovery and the aging baby boom and the advancing baby bust generations have led to a drop-off in household formations." And in the second half of '96 production will slow "because there are not enough approved projects," said Mr. O'Keefe of the builders' association.
The market began the year with an six- to nine-month supply of resale homes, which may grow as people who received pink slips decide to sell. Some analysts, for example, say the AT&T layoffs will have an impact on Morris, Somerset, Middlesex and Union Counties, where many of its employees work. But brokers say the cuts will not flood their markets with homes and depress prices.
Peter Mosca, spokesman for the state's realtors' group, said the active spring and summer market that his association foresees "should cut into the supply," and keep prices stable. He said his group expected 137,000 to 140,000 homes to be sold in 1996.
Many brokers say sales have begun to improve. Weichert Realtors, the state's largest broker, said 30 percent more contracts for new and resale homes had been signed by its clients through the first week of this month than the 8,174 signed in the same period last year. Phyllis K. Bixon, a Weichert regional vice president, added that people would buy if they perceived value and that houses realistically priced would sell. Yet some sellers remain frustrated. "People come, but not in droves," said Jeanne Oates, who with her husband, Alvaro, has been trying to sell their three-bedroom colonial in Fair Lawn since November.
"I have to believe there is just too much inventory," Mrs. Oates said. She said the couple had dropped the sales price three weeks ago to $207,000 from $214,000, "But if we don't get a price that will let us put some equity into a new house," she added, "we will have to wait."
Developers say new homes sales are picking up and that they are moving ahead with projects. From Feb. 1 through the second week of March, sales at Toll's projects averaged 32 percent per community over last year, said Wayne Patterson, senior vice president at the developer.
HE said his company planned to start eight projects this year with a total of 934 dwellings, mostly $300,000-plus houses. Most will be in the north central part of the state and one -- Laurel Creek Country Club, with 470 town houses and detached single-family homes -- is in Moorestown in Burlington County. Since Feb. 1, 55 Laurel Creek single-family homes were sold for an average of $400,000, he said.
Merle Huseth, president of the northeast region for K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest developer, said: "There's been a lot more traffic lately, indicating pent-up demand." Hovnanian, which dropped its production estimates for 1996 by 10 percent, is now revising it upward, he said, adding that "we are cautiously optimistic."
Mr. Huseth said that for Hovnanian -- which continues to focus on town house and detached single-family home projects for entry-level and move-up buyers -- north central counties, including Monmouth and Morris, remain good markets. He said his company was also putting an emphasis on Burlington County, where it will open two projects in Burlington Township, totaling 262 homes priced from $110,000 to $190,000.
Mr. Schoner, the consultant, said 537 single-family home developments were under way in the state's 14 north and central counties; the most, 89, are in Morris County. There are also 106 town-house projects under construction.
Ms. Bixon of Weichert said more move-up buyers were entering the market. But for many such buyers, given today's economy, there will be "less up in move-up," said Dean Hughes.
Though Mr. O'Keefe, of the builders' association said homes priced at $200,000 to $250,000 are most in demand, the state's long approval process and limited land for small lots makes building them difficult.
Developers like Hovnanian who are able to respond do well. At Woodland Estates, a 75-home project it opened last month in South Brunswick, 39 of the $225,000 to $275,000 homes, with 3,200 square feet, have been sold, said Mr. Huseth.
Among the buyers are Ben and Jennifer Shapiro. He is a commercial real estate broker, she is a physical therapist. "We have concerns," said Mr. Shapiro, referring to the economy and job market. "But we feel we are taking an educated risk and that we're getting value for our money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph and Elizabeth Morrison, moving from Hillsborough, examine new Montgomery house. Woodland Estates in South Brunswick offers houses like this one. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)
