HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Low Rates Are Turning Lookers Into Home Buyers

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
WITH six months to go before their new house in a development called Dix Hills Farms is completed, Donald and Ginny Casadonte are not overly worried that they still have to sell their existing home, a three-bedroom ranch in Huntington.
"My house is in a very nice neighborhood, it's totally redone and professionally landscaped, and houses here are not staying on the market that long," said Mr. Casadonte, a stock trader in Manhattan. 
 The couple intend to put the Huntington ranch up for sale for $210,000 once the foundation for the Dix Hills house is poured later this month. The new house, a four-bedroom colonial, will cost close to $500,000 with extras.
The days when homeowners were fearful of buying another house before selling an existing one appear to be over, with most sellers confident that there now is a market for their houses.
"The majority of my buyers are move-up buyers, but none of my transactions is subject to people selling their houses," said Marylin Larsen, owner of Lane Realty in Great Neck, a brokerage that represents only builders, through whom the Casadontes are purchasing their house. "People feel the market is now strong enough so they are not risking losing their deposit."
Brokers say buyers are still cautious because of concerns over the economy and job security, but generally stable house prices, lower interest rates, the strength of the stock market and changing family needs all contributed to higher house sales last year, especially in the later months. This has continued into 1996.
"Last year, sales got off to a very slow start, but they picked up so much in the last quarter after interest rates came down that it made up for the whole year," said Kathy Kreicas, owner of the ERA Gatewood agency in Syosset.
Wende and Randy Savitch recently signed a contract to buy one of Mrs. Kreicas's listings, a three-bedroom ranch in Syosset, in large part because of the lower interest rates. They are now renting a one-bedroom apartment in Forest Hills, Queens.
"We've been saving up to buy a house for two and a half years, and now that interest rates are so low, we felt it was a good time to buy," said Mrs. Savitch, a manager for a brewing company. Her husband is an electrician for a television studio.
The house is costing them $207,000. Their monthly payments will be about $2,000, compared with a current $900-a-month rent, but they will have tax-deduction benefits, Mrs. Savitch said. "A lot of our money goes for taxes so we might as well own and invest in our future," she said.
"The buyers that are out," said Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive of the Long Island Board of Realtors and the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, "are serious buyers, inventory levels are coming down and there is a shortage of good houses."
NEVERTHELESS, prices have remained flat in Nassau County and they are down in Suffolk County.
"Our sales were strong in 1995, but unfortunately the average sales price dropped," said Ralph Bove, a senior manager for Prudential Long Island Realty. The company, which has 24 Long Island offices, sold 5,314 houses last year, up from 4,984 in 1994, he said,adding that the average price dropped to $201,000 from $210,000
January figures provided by the Multiple Listing Service, which has 1,300 broker members, show that houses on the market in Nassau and Suffolk fell to 17,915 from 19,242 in January 1995 and houses under contract rose to 4,659 from 4,286. However, the average contract price of a house in Suffolk was $145,944, down from $150,331 in January 1995. In Nassau, the average was up slightly to $201,973 from $197,086.
Stagnant house prices are a reflection of Long Island's changing economy said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the business group.
Since 1993 the region has added 44,000 jobs, thus regaining almost half the 88,500 jobs lost between 1990 and 1992. Despite government cutbacks and corporate mergers, job growth is expected to continue this year with the creation of 10,000 to 15,000 new jobs, Dr. Kamer said. However, highly paid military jobs with an average annual salary of $40,300 are being replaced by retail and service-industry jobs paying much less, she said.
"One reason that house prices have not appreciated even though we have had considerable job growth is because net salaries have been declining because of the type of jobs we are getting," she said. "It's very difficult to pass on potential increases in housing prices if buyers don't have the incomes to buy at those prices."
Christopher Tighe, an insurance broker who recently sold his six-bedroom high ranch in Woodbury for $466,000, was forced to reduce his asking price by more than $100,000 to find a buyer. The house was originally listed at $590,000 and had been on the market five months when he switched brokers and lowered the price, Mr. Tighe said. His new broker, ERA Gatewood, recommended an asking price of $485,000 and found him a buyer within a month.
Across the marketplace, demand is strongest for recently updated houses. "At one time, people were willing to fix a house, but now they have to work so hard to meet today's cost of living that they don't have the time," said Katy Anastasio, a broker in Huntington.
For a well-located house in good condition that is properly priced, "I have 20 buyers," said Evelyn Atanas, the owner of Atanas Realty in Williston Park. In some cases, such houses are being snapped up overnight, she said.
ONE recent seller, who asked that her name not be used, listed her three-bedroom Tudor in Mineola with Atanas Realty on Feb. 29 for $225,000. The next day she had an offer for $210,000, and three backup offers. She later accepted the $210,000.
"I was totally surprised that I could sell this quickly," the homeowner said.
Sales of houses in affluent areas of the North Shore, which were particularly sluggish, have also started to pick up.
"We haven't seen activity like this since 1989," said Louise Brooks, manager of the Douglas Elliman-Jane Hayes agency in Locust Valley, who attributed some of the renewed interest to "last year's windfalls in the stock market." A 15-room brick manor house on 5 acres in Matinecock on the market four and a half months recently sold for $1.9 million.
Demand in the Hamptons is for houses selling at $350,000 to $750,000, while there is a large inventory of lower-priced houses, said Melanie Ross, president of the Cook/ Pony Farm real estate agency, which has five East End offices. "People are selling their $250,000 house because they want to trade up," she said.
Builders are finding a mixed market. "Prices have come down, but you need an income of $50,000 to buy a $130,000 house, so affordability is still the problem," said Peter D. Klein, a partner of Klein & Eversoll, developers in Commack. He characterized the new-house market as "very modest," with most of the demand coming from buyers trading up from an existing home.
Although building activity in Nassau and Suffolk showed only a moderate 5 percent increase last year, it was strong compared with New York State overall, which had a 7 percent decline. In Nassau and Suffolk, 3,500 building permits were issued in 1995, down from 3,720 in 1994, according to Census Bureau figures. In New York State, permits issued dropped to 19,010 from 22,170.
Michael Dubb, a partner of the Beechwood Organization of Williston Park, who is president of the Long Island Builder's Institute, called sales "fairly brisk," fueled by buyers moving out from Brooklyn and Queens. "The American dream is still to buy that house in the suburbs," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fifteen-room brick manor in Matinecock sold recently for $1.9 million. Donald and Ginny Casadonte with children on their Dix Hills Farm plot. Model house at right is the colonial that they will be building. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Brokers See a Continued Crest in Housing Sales

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
LAST WEEK, before 500 realtors at Houlihan/Lawrence's annual meeting, Donald Trump announced his intention to acquire the 144-acre Briar Hall Country Club in Briarcliff Manor where he wants to refurbish the golf course and build 144 town houses in clusters and a new clubhouse.
He also discussed plans to develop Seven Springs, a 200-acre property he purchased last year in the Towns of North Castle, Bedford and New Castle. There he plans to build a "world-class golf course with about 24 mansions," he said. 
 Mr. Trump was also committed to developing David's Island, in New Rochelle. But that project was abruptly abandoned on March 9, he said, when it was discovered that there was a hazardous-waste problem and Consolidated Edison had ownership rights to 10 percent of the island.
The entrance of Mr. Trump into Westchester's real estate market follows two record-breaking years for home sales and sales so far this year show the trend is continuing.
"Early indications show that sales are running a bit ahead of last year's performance countywide," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. He added that the interest shown by such high-profile developers as Mr. Trump "can only enhance our image."
Among those developers is Toll Brothers, of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., a well-known builder in the Northeast, which began building in Westchester in June 1993. It now has a total of eight projects in the county, and is at the proposal stage for two more, according to Rob Parahus, vice president for the company's New York division.
"We saw a lot of opportunity in Westchester, especially in already approved projects that we could move in and complete," Mr. Parahus said. He also noted that land prices had become more favorable than they were in the 80's.
In 1994, the county had the best sales year ever, with a total of 7,076 transactions. Last year was the second-best year, with 6,466 sales -- a drop of 9 percent, but 13 percent above 1993. "People should remember that 1994 was out-of-sight," said Antoinette Emerson, last year's president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "It shouldn't be held out as the norm."
Some brokers, however, did better than they expected last year. Nicholas Wolff, president of Century 21 Wolff, with offices in White Plains and Thornwood, said that in 1995 "we surpassed what we ever did in the 1980's and we did 20 percent better than in 1994."
Savo Fries, manager of the Somers office of Coldwell Banker Schlott, also surpassed her expectations last year. "They say sales were off, but not for us," she said. "We did better than in 1994."
Single-family homes represented 70.5 percent of all county sales in 1995. A total of 4,561 houses were sold, down 12 percent from 1994, but up 7 percent from 1993.
Prices have been "relatively flat," for the last five years, said Joseph Monaco, branch manager of Coldwell Banker Schlott's White Plains office. "The median price in 1990 was $283,000," he pointed out, "and it was $280,000 in 1995."
Co-ops constituted the only housing category that posted an increase in number of sales last year compared to 1994. Sales volume went up 6 percent, but the median sale price plummeted to $61,000 from $71,000.
"The increase in numbers sold was mainly due to the drop in value," Mr. Monaco said. "But that market is trying to stabilize."
Condominium sales dropped 9 percent from 1994, but rose 13 percent from 1993. The median price dropped to $158,000 from $163,000 in 1994.
Ms. Fries, who is also president of the Wetchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service, said that the spring selling season has already begun in the lower part of the county, "where sales have already translated into dollars," she said. "In the northern part of the county, it takes longer. I don't know why." She added that trends usually start in the south and move north.
REALTORS say that in some respects the Westchester market seems immune to economic downturns such as the extensive layoffs by companies like International Business Machines. "When I.B.M. came to Somers 10 years ago, we thought there would be a lot of new business," said Ms. Fries. "But the customers never materialized. Then when they closed a division last year we didn't feel that either."
Mr. Wolff predicted that a shortage of houses on the market in 1996 could help drive up prices. "The steady demand is a very good indication," Mr. Wolff said. "Even in the severe weather, we were oversaturated with customers. And there's a limited supply of product."
Ebie Woods, a regional manager for central Westchester for Houlihan/Lawrence, said that the most active price category was "in the range of $300,000 to $399,000," she said. "But the high-end market has also done well, especially in new construction."
Houlihan/Lawrence's Chappaqua office sold six houses in January at Hardscrabble Lake, a 93-detached home development in Mount Pleasant. In 18 months, 24 houses have sold, said Barbara S. Brown, sales agent for the project.
The 4- and 5-bedroom, custom-built colonials on one- to two-acre lots are priced from $759,900 to $875,000.
Jeffrey A. Lempert, and his wife, Aiko, were among the first families to move in last summer. "I always wanted a custom-built house," said Dr. Lempert, a physician. "This house has all the amenities. We could entertain 20 people in our bathroom. It has a cathedral ceiling and a steam shower."
Toll Brothers specializes in a more "middle of the market," product, said Mr. Parahus, which in Westchester translates to the $400,000 to $600,000 range.
"We've been successful with the move-down buyer," Mr. Parahus said. "This buyer has sold the family home and is looking for a more maintenance-free life style."
Hillair Estates, a 36-unit single-family development in White Plains, is nearly sold out. "There's only one lot left," Mr. Parahus said. "The appeal of that community is the diverse housing styles. There are Federal-style homes, Provincials, colonials, and people bought all of them."
He is now starting two new projects -- the Greens at North Street, in White Plains, a development of 32 single-family homes that are expected to sell for $539,900 to $591,900 and Mount Kisco Chase, an 86-lot development of single-family homes, selling for between $524,900 to 608,900.
Aliza and Harrison Wills have been shopping for a house in Westchester and have looked at several Toll Brothers projects, both in White Plains and in Ardsley. "We decided on new construction after looking at resales and realizing we could get a better deal with a brand new house," said Ms. Wills.
"Since the first of January, sales have been up 25 percent from this time last year," Mr. Parahus said. "I think it can be attributed to interest rates and the greater visibility of our product. We're further along in the county now and have more models to show."
"We're definitely still looking for additional ground," he continued.. "We believe demand is still high."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Richard Kahan, Katherine Lobell

 BODY:
Katherine Swenson Lobell, a civic volunteer, was married yesterday to Richard Alan Kahan, the urban developer and a former president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the couple's home in New York.
Mrs. Kahan is a board member and a former president of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, the social service agency. She is also a member of the board of the New York Women's Foundation, which aids low-income women in New York City. The bride graduated from Smith College and received a master's degree in English literature from Columbia University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Swenson Jr. of Coral Gables, Fla. Her father owns Edward F. Swenson & Company, investment counselors in Coconut Grove, Fla. 
 Mr. Kahan, a former real estate developer who was also the chairman of the Battery Park City Authority, is now the chairman of the Riverside South Planning Corporation, the nonprofit organization that oversees the design and planning of Donald Trump's Riverside South building complex on the Upper West Side. He is also the president of the Urban Assembly, a nonprofit urban redevelopment organization.
The bridegroom received a joint bachelor's degree from Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., and the London School of Economics, and a law degree from Columbia University. He is the son of Mrs. Myron Gordon of Irvine, Calif., and the late Milton Kahan, who was a publisher of trade magazines in New York.
The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.

HEADLINE: IN SCHOOL;
Language Proposals Confound Officials

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
School officials are still slogging through the thick book of curriculum standards that the New Jersey Department of Education released last month. But at least one recommendation -- to teach foreign languages to every child starting in kindergarten -- has already created a ruckus.
The proposal fits into a new set of curriculum standards that the State Department of Education is hoping to adopt this spring. New Jersey is under a State Supreme Court order to equalize spending in its 600 school districts by September, and the standards are part of the state's strategy. Leo F. Klagholz, the Commissioner of Education, plans to use the standards to determine exactly how much education should cost each district. 
 Besides foreign languages, the standards cover the arts, health and physical education, literacy, mathematics, science and social studies. But the language category has stirred the most controversy, mostly because educators around the state are worried that they will never have enough money to provide language instruction in every classroom.
Although most high schools and many middle schools in New Jersey teach foreign languages, only a handful of elementary schools do so.
"There is no question that every student would benefit from learning a foreign language," said David Nash, a spokesman for the New Jersey Principals and Supervisors Association in Trenton. "But if we are really serious about this, there are implications for the length of the school day and especially for staffing."
None of the 56 curriculum standards specify how schools must teach various subjects, but they broadly outline what students are expected to know to pass standardized tests in the fourth, eighth and twelfth grades.
For example, fourth graders should be able to express emotions and describe people using short phrases and sentences in a foreign language, while eighth graders should be able to give directions and describe places in detail. By high school graduation, students will be expected to converse "with increasing linguistic accuracy," among other things.
Some Education Department officials say the standards will not require every elementary school to hire new language teachers, because they will be able to use technology and provide existing teachers with basic training. But Lynn Maher, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, the largest teachers' union, says new teachers will be essential if the program is to succeed.
"There's no research that says you can learn a language with CD-ROM, and in-service training is an inappropriate way of teaching a language," she said. "Teachers who are certified in a certain language are the ones who should be teaching that language."
In an interview last week, Mr. Klagholz said the language standards might be refined or even overhauled before the state Board of Education votes on them in May. But he stressed that before education officials fret over the details, they must decide whether foreign languages really belong in the state's core curriculum.
"The right sequence is deciding first whether this is an essential part of a kid's education," he said. "Then we can get to the practical issues, including how to reorganize to include world languages in every grade."
(After that, there is the problem of making sure wealthy districts do not offer many more language classes than poor ones, in keeping with the court order to equalize spending. "We don't want some districts to have eight languages and others to have just one," Mr. Klagholz said.)
Like a number of states, New Jersey has seized on foreign language instruction as a way to increase children's understanding of other cultures and their chances of finding a job in an increasingly global economy.
But other states that have introduced foreign language standards have struggled to find enough teachers for every elementary school.
North Carolina, which has required language instruction starting in kindergarten since 1987, has started intensive teacher-training programs and recruited a number of foreign-language teachers from abroad, said Fran Hoch, who oversees language programs in the North Carolina Department of Education. The need for Spanish teachers is especially acute, she said, since that language is by far the most popular.
North Carolina has struggled to keep its foreign language program afloat, Ms. Hoch said, because the state has not been able to provide sufficient funds.
At its peak, 60 percent of public school students were studying a foreign language, she said, but the number has dropped to 50 percent and probably will not increase.
"Standards mean the schools will do a much better job because they're being held accountable," said David Edwards, executive director of the Joint National Committee for Languages, a lobbying group in Washington. "But because of money problems and teacher shortages, the standards are not always enforced."
In New Jersey, a few districts offer language instruction at the elementary level, but classes are generally offered once a week.
Mr. Edwards says he doubts that elementary schools will be able to offer anything more substantial in the next few years.
"If you had asked me two years ago, I would have said the chances were great," he said. "But all of a sudden, the political pendulum has swung back to tax cuts and deficit reductions, and language instruction will inevitably suffer."

HEADLINE: Brothers' Mission Is to Aid the Poor

BYLINE: By JAMES V. O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
WHEN Edmund Rice founded the Irish Christian Brothers in Waterford, Ireland, in 1802, his mission was simple: to raise the Irish from abject poverty through education. Although the economic conditions of the Irish people have changed since then, the Christian Brothers still put their stamp of Irish practicality and sense of community on students at places like Iona College.
More than 50 brothers live in New Rochelle in three different religious communities, whose main occupation is providing elementary and high school educations in working-class communities. Iona is the only college outside of Ireland run by the Brothers. The Irish Christian Brothers changed their name to Christian Brothers in 1964 to reflect the diverse communities that they serve. 
 "It started out working with poor Irish boys in Ireland, but then Brothers were sent around the world to follow the Irish migration," said Brother Jim Moffett, the provincial leader of the Eastern American Province who lives in New Rochelle. "As the Irish became part of the mainstream culture, the emphasis switched from poor Irish boys to poor children of all ethnic backgrounds."
The Brothers in New Rochelle teach at many elementary schools, including Iona Grammar School, Prep School and College and Blessed Sacrament and St. Gabriel's High Schools. A convalescent center for senior brothers is next to the Iona College campus.
Edmund Rice was a wealthy merchant whose wife died young. After her death he decided to dedicate his life to spirituality and work with the poor. His followers were volunteers, most of them also wealthy. Pope Pius VII named him the superior general of the congregation in 1820.
The congregation started teaching boys in homes and warehouses even though it was in violation of English law to educate Catholics. This law was largely overlooked, and the number of schools and brothers grew. As the Irish emigrated throughout the English-speaking world, the congregation went with them and established Iona College.
To become a Christian Brother, one must be in college or have a bachelor's degree. Brothers spend two to three years living in the community for religious training. After six years they take their vows to become a brother; many were educated in Christian Brothers schools, either in Ireland or the United States.
The Irish influence remains strong at Iona College even though many of the Brothers today are American born. The school has a bagpipe band. which offers partial scholarships, an Irish step-dancing club and a course in Irish history.
Originally, the mission was to teach boys but now girls are welcome. "We didn't necessarily change for philosophical reasons," Brother Moffett said. "We were in areas where two single-sex institutions would be closed if we didn't combine them as in the case of Blessed Sacrament and St. Gabriel's."
By following the Irish migration, the Christian Brothers found themselves in inner cities where they still teach a predominantly black and Hispanic population. They operate Rice High School in Manhattan, named after Edmund Rice, and in the South Bronx, All Hallows, Monsignor Farrell and Cardinal Hayes high schools as well as Archbishop Curley in Miami.
The congregation has also maintained strong ties to Ireland, and teach in schools in North Ireland. Iona College has a semester abroad in Ireland, which combines classes at the Marino Institute at St. Mary's College in Dublin, which is a Christian Brothers institution.
They send about 30 students a year to Ireland to study and travel throughout the country. Part of the semester is spent in Belfast living with families that have children in Christian Brothers Schools.
Brother Harry Dunkak, who runs the Irish Semester Abroad program, said: "We are not in a position to buy a villa in Italy and put up students there. So the natural thing was to take advantage of our Irish background. It is amazing the appeal Ireland has. These are not just Irish kids who want to go there."
The Christian Brothers concentrate on strong liberal arts skills like mathematics, writing and business. When the oganization was founded, the brothers taught courses that were appropriate for the time, like shorthand, navigation and surveying. They have established a strong computing and technology base in their curriculum and global studies.
"Right from the beginning, the Christian Brothers would take kids and help them raise themselves an economic notch or two," Brother Dunkak said.
Helping students get a job is not the only mission. "If we have been successful, people come out of our schools with a wider sense of community," Brother Moffett said.
Edmund Rice will be beatified in Rome in October, the first step in attaining sainthood. This event has created a sense of reflection and renewal within the Christian Brothers community.
The Brothers are struggling to deal with the problems of working in communities with fragmented family structures, Brother Moffett said. "We need to be faithful to traditional values in new areas and new ways in the future," he said. "Our future is to make the changes to serve the poor people in the way we did when we started out."
The Christian Brothers will have a 150 Brothers, students and bagpipers marching in the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manhattan. "Most Brothers march or watch because it is not just an Irish celebration, it is the patronal feast day of the Christian Brothers," Brother Moffett said. "We also enjoy a good party."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christian Brothers at Iona College attending an evening service of prayers and readings. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Crunching Numbers Beyond the Border

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Fund managers who rely on quantitative analysis -- meaning that they use computers to analyze reams of data and come up with good stock prospects -- have had a mediocre record abroad.
Citing poor performance, the Vanguard Group recently dismissed Batterymarch Financial Management as the adviser to its Trustees Equity International fund. When it came to foreign stock markets, Batterymarch's quantitative approach proved disappointing. Over the last five years, the fund's 8.6 average annualized return trailed the 9.7 percent of its benchmark, the Europe Australia Far East index. The fund is now managed by UBS International Investment London, a unit of Union Bank of Switzerland. UBS looks for large and midsize stocks using a traditional value approach. 
 With the Vanguard fund out of the ring, only a few international funds still use a quantitative approach, according to analysts from Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Among them are Japan Alpha, which focuses on only that country; Quantitative Foreign Frontier, which covers only the emerging markets, and Zweig Managed Assets, which buys bonds as well as stocks around the world.
The only two diversified funds comparable to the Vanguard fund are Quantitative International Equity and Fidelity Diversified International. Fidelity's fund beat the foreign fund average by nearly three percentage points for the three years ended in February and by more than seven percentage points for the year, according to Morningstar. Quantative International trailed the average in both those periods, and by a striking 10 percentage points last year.
Can a conclusion be drawn from such a small sample? Probably not. But the fact that the number of funds is so small suggests that fund companies are not convinced of the usefulness of the quantitative approach outside the United States.
Quantitative models depend on solid company and market information that may be harder to come by abroad than in the United States, said John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar. Moreover, he said, people haven't figured out how to adjust their computer models to compensate "for accounting differences between markets or for currency and political risks."
 
Tobacco Holdings
A consumer group is urging nonsmokers to take note of just how much money they have in tobacco companies through mutual funds. But if funds reduce those holdings, it may well be because of liability, not shareholder, concerns.
Last week, the Liggett Group moved to settle a smoking liability lawsuit, the first such settlement attempted by a tobacco company. The market immediately pushed down the prices of other tobacco stocks, except for RJR Nabisco, considered a takeover candidate.
Many tobacco stocks pop up in the biggest funds. Nine of the 15 biggest funds recently listed tobacco stocks among their 10 largest holdings, according to a study by Co-op America, a consumer group based in Washington, which provides information on the social and economic consequences of investing. The data were based on the most recent complete shareholder reports from each fund at the time, and in some cases are now many months old.
Together, the nine funds owned 70 million shares worth about $3 billion. The heaviest concentrations were at the Fidelity Growth and Income fund and the Investment Company of America, each of which listed Philip Morris as its biggest holding.
Six of the 15 biggest funds held no tobacco stocks at the time of the study, including the Fidelity Magellan fund, the nation's largest.
A search for the funds with the biggest stakes in Philip Morris and RJR, using Morningstar's data, turned up many of the same funds. Because the funds hold such large positions, if they start to sour on these stocks, their selling could depress the shares' prices significantly.
 
A Tax Question
After paying 1995 taxes, fund investors should add the reinvested distributions reported by the fund company to the "cost basis" of their shares.
But exactly what type of distributions should be included, asks a reader in Connecticut who is confused by the reference to "undistributed capital gains" in Internal Revenue Service Publication 550, which covers taxation of mutual funds and other investments.
Mutual funds have two ways to handle realized capital gains. Generally, they pay out the gains to shareholders, who then pay the appropriate taxes.
But funds may keep the gains and pay the taxes themselves, a tack that might be appealing if a fund doesn't want to liquidate securities in a bad market to pay out cash distributions to shareholders, said Frederick W. Haas, a tax partner with Coopers & Lybrand in Baltimore.
In this second case, the amount is reported to shareholders on I.R.S. Form 2439, and shareholders can take a credit on their Form 1040's for taxes paid on their behalf by the fund. Because the fund pays tax at the 35 percent corporate rate, shareholders can add 65 percent of the undistributed gains to their basis in their shares.
With funds that distribute all their gains, the paperwork is simpler. Investors who reinvest these gains add all the distributed income and capital gains reported on their Form 1099-DIV's to their cost basis. The higher the cost basis, the less tax that will be owed when the shares are sold.
 
New Funds
Federated Investors has started five foreign funds that aim for long-term capital growth. They are Federated Asia Pacific Growth, Emerging Markets, European Growth, International Small Company and Latin American Growth. The funds levy sales charges of 5.5 percent of the amount invested.
The Vanguard Selected Value Portfolio seeks to provide long-term growth of capital and income by investing in companies whose stocks are undervalued or out of favor and which have a market capitalization of $750 million to $5 billion. The adviser is Barrow, Hanley, Mewhinney & Strauss, which also advises Vanguard Windsor II.
 
New Managers
Richard Cryan, manager of Keystone Strategic Income, picks up Keystone High Income from Donald Keller, who retired.
Mary-Kay Bourbulas, who manages Strong Municipal Bond and Insured Municipal Bond, took over Strong High-Yield Municipal Bond from Tom Conlin, who left the firm.
 
In Brief
Strong Funds has a home page on the Internet (http://www.strong-funds.com). It offers investing and retirement information, fund performance data and more.
The 100 Percent No-Load Mutual Fund Council has an updated version of its directory of 200 funds. Copies are available for $5 from the council at 1501 Broadway, Suite 1809, New York, N.Y. 10036.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 913 words

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Last Picture Show

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
FOR many aficionados of Hong Kong action films, the last week of February was a time to exult. The most popular movie in America was a dubbed version of "Rumble in the Bronx," starring Jackie Chan, the comic daredevil who reigns as Asia's box office king. "Broken Arrow," a Hollywood movie made by John Woo, Hong Kong's gangster film auteur, was second. And a running weekend film festival called "Hong Kong Action at Midnight" continued to sell out at the artsy Angelika Film Center on Houston Street.
But in Chinatown, once the city's only venue for Hong Kong thrillers, the mood was grim. On Feb. 29, the Rosemary Theater showed its last picture, joining darkened movie houses like the Sun Sing and the Essex. 
 Some say their demise was caused by the proliferation of videotapes, both pirated and legal; others point to an economy that leaves potential audiences with less leisure time and money, gang members whose presence in theaters intimidated other patrons, and fewer blockbusters as the Hong Kong film industry looks forward uneasily to the British colony's reversion to Chinese rule in 1997.
Walking through the Rosemary's desolate aisles, past its 469 empty seats, bare glass candy cases and barren lobby whose only sign of life glistened in a goldfish tank, the former manager, Zhao Zheng Shi, shook his head. "The biggest problem was videos," Mr. Zhao said. "A ticket is $6, so for a whole family that's $24. Add car fare and lunch, that's $80. So everyone watches videos."
The only remaining movie theater in Chinatown is the Music Palace, a slightly ramshackle auditorium on the Bowery where double features cost $6 and the concession stand sells shredded squid, prawn crackers and drink boxes of soy milk alongside candy bars and Cokes. "There should be more Chinese theaters," said Hao Hoang, a 27-year-old medical resident who checked its marquee for upcoming martial arts films. "This is Chinatown, right?"
It is a different story uptown, where Hong Kong movies have made their way into art houses. Under the safe cover of subtitles and themes of honor, chivalry and national identity, the flying shadow kicks of kung fu films and bloody fusillades of gangster movies appeal to a broad audience. "There is rarely a shortage of mind-blowing action, emotionally wrenching plots, pulse-quickening tempo and wildly extravagant fantasia in Hong Kong films," said Peter Chow, a producer and distributor whose annual Hong Kong film festivals and star retrospectives draw lines around the block at Cinema Village on East 12th Street.
But theaters like the Music Palace must rely on a few hit movies a year to make up for weeks of B movies. Last week the bill was a gangster movie and "Infatuation," a remake of "Fatal Attraction" in which the scorned mistress douses the wife's face with acid, gives her an infection leading to a double amputation and tries to immolate her family.
The audience was mostly single men, with a few couples and groups of teens. A stocky security guard, wearing a nightstick, patrolled the aisles. Schedulers are not wedded to round numbers; an evening feature was slated for 8:29. Weekends are the most crowded, followed by Mondays, when many restaurant workers get the day off.
In his office off the theater's balcony, the manager, Oscar H. Watt, said that his theater was able to survive because it is part of a chain of Chinese theaters with branches in San Francisco, Vancouver and Toronto. But he worries that as big companies like New Line Cinema distribute Jackie Chan films, small theaters will be priced out of the market. And then there is the vicious cycle: a lack of money for advertising the films means smaller audiences and less money for future ads. "Ten years ago we had a full house every day," he said. "There were eight movie theaters then. I miss the competition."
The grandest theater in Chinatown was once Sun Sing, a 900-seat auditorium underneath the Manhattan Bridge whose stage was rented to Chinese opera companies when the screen was not showing big action movies. It closed in 1993.
Now it has passed into history. Sushan Chin, an archivist at the Museum of Chinese in the Americas, led an expedition by flashlight there two weeks ago to collect documents and artifacts. She found plastic placards from a more prosperous era, with "Full House," "Standing Room Only" and "Front Row Seats Only" printed in Chinese and English. But there was also a memo from the management to projectionists apologizing for renting out their parking spaces. "This had to be done in order to keep the theater going," it read.
The Sun Sing went out of its way to attract English-speaking fans, even handing out English synopses of its films to help those who had trouble following subtitles. One synopsis, for Jackie Chan's "Police Story 3 -- Super Cop," did justice to the genre's quick transitions. "The group moves to Thailand where they are joined by the pirate Chaibat," it says in the middle. "A series of gangland fights ensues. They soon find themselves in Kuala Lumpur trying to rescue Chaibat's kidnapped wife."
These days, pirated videos of Jackie Chan's upcoming film, "Thunderbolt," are already for sale on Canal Street and around Times Square. But in the cavernous Rosemary, Mr. Zhao said that they just cannot match the thrill of the big screen. "You enjoy it more in the theater, where the screen is bright and the color is sharp," he said. "You share the happiness and the sorrows."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 4163 words

HEADLINE: A Surge in Second Second-Chance Finance

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
THE neon signs promising "fast cash" flicker from dusty brick storefronts as they have for 50 years on this narrow stretch of Church Street known as Loan Alley.
It's lunch hour on a brisk but sunny winter day as a handful of people line up at World Finance to borrow a few hundred dollars or to drop off a few $20 bills as payment on their old loans. 
 World Finance's customers are too financially strapped to be welcomed by Nashville's big banks just up the hill. But Angela Myers, the loan officer behind the counter, greets each one by name with a warm smile -- and offers to lend cash on the spot to the most creditworthy among them. Never mind that the company charges an effective interest rate of close to 90 percent.
On Loan Alley, as all across America, the business of making loans to poor credit risks at high interest rates is growing rapidly. And as more companies discover the huge profits that can be made from the economically downtrodden, national lenders are invading a field that was once the province of mom-and-pop operations. In just the last few years, growing national chains have snapped up half of the independent loan offices here on Loan Alley.
They are discovering a virtual army of the walking credit-wounded, as the casualties of the last decade's corporate downsizings join the millions of low-income Americans who have always lived on the edge. Thirty percent of American adults fail to qualify for traditional credit cards, according to Equifax, the credit-reporting agency. And the ranks are growing as personal bankruptcy filings surge to near-records and continuing corporate layoffs turn more people with previously pristine credit into unwilling deadbeats.
As business picks up for these high-cost loans, dozens of new finance companies have issued stock to the public, and many banks and other top-tier lenders have started wooing borrowers they would have snubbed a few years ago.
The profit margins can be two or three times those on ordinary bank loans. But default rates are generally much higher, too, and if lenders miscalculate, they can quickly find themselves as financially vulnerable as their customers.
"This is a business that is not for the faint-hearted," said Edward A. O'Neal, executive vice president of the Bank of Boston, which owns several finance companies that aim at lower-quality borrowers.
The fastest-growing sector of high-risk lending these days is the used-car business. Dealers have been searching for ways to unload swollen inventories, and a raft of new finance companies, led by Mercury Finance in Northbrook, Ill., are providing the capital. Meanwhile, established financial-services giants, including Keycorp in Cleveland, Bank of Boston and Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C., have bought their way into the business, while the Ford Motor Company and General Electric are starting up their own operations to cater to high-risk borrowers.
Another growing area is home loans to troubled borrowers. Contifinancial of New York City and the Money Store of Union, N.J., two specialists in this business, have grown briskly over the last five years by lending to people whom most banks wouldn't touch. But mainstream banks are taking a mixed approach to what can be a tough business. Barnett Banks of Jacksonville, Fla., for example, recently bought a finance company that caters to high-risk customers, while Fleet Financial of Providence, R.I., is selling out after taking heat for evicting low-income home-loan customers.
And credit-card issuers from First Union Bank in Charlotte to the Fingerhut catalogue empire in Minnetonka, Minn., are mailing cards to people who declared bankruptcy and to others they had previously snubbed.
For the borrowers, this trend is a decidedly mixed blessing. There are people who can now own homes and drive cars who just a few years ago would have had to rent apartments and take the bus. Moreover, those with blemished records have the opportunity to re-establish a good credit rating and thus qualify for lower rates in the future.
But the interest rates on these loans are shockingly high.
For mortgages, they generally run around 12 percent, compared with 8 percent for standard borrowers. Car loans often exceed 20 percent and can go as high as 30 percent. Credit cards and personal loans carry rates well in excess of 20 percent. What's more, fees, insurance charges and other hidden costs can pile up, making the effective interest rates truly exorbitant.
For example, car dealers often pay a fee of 5 to 10 percent to finance companies, and pass the cost on to the buyer in the form of a higher price.
Take Diane and Kevin Cunard of Brentwood, Calif. They say they unwittingly failed to pay $3,500 in medical bills on time for their daughter's broken arm. Though their tardiness didn't hinder them from getting a mortgage on a home last December, it disqualified them from bank credit for a new car and forced them to take out a finance company loan at 21 percent.
"I figured once you pay your credit bills they would give me a second chance," said Mrs. Cunard, 33, a cafeteria worker in Oakland. "They do give you a second chance -- at 21 percent. We're paying $5,000 interest on a $10,000 truck."
Of course, the higher losses generated by such loans justify some of the higher rates. Just as inner-city residents pay more than suburbanites for everything from groceries to appliances, so are the the most economically distressed Americans least able to shop around for the best financing deals.
And not only do they pay more for loans, they get harsher treatment if they fall behind on payments. Collection calls start the day after the due date and are more frequent, and more insistent, than for bank borrowers. And the finance companies play hardball, repossessing from one to three of every 10 cars they finance, often in the dead of night.
Many of the people who work in these companies become inured to the stream of human tragedy they encounter. Some justify the rates they charge by convincing themselves that they are giving people down on their luck a second chance.
"Few customers blink over the rate," said Diane Hunter, who approves car loans for the Nashville office of First Merchants Acceptance Corporation. "They need a car to get to work to pay bills, so they do whatever they have to do."
Does that bother her? Not at all. "The higher the interest we charge, the more money the company makes and the faster we grow," Ms. Hunter said matter-of-factly.
J. Dan Walters, the regional manager of the Loan Alley office of World Finance, takes a populist line, saying his company is lending a helping hand to the forgotten man and woman. "People say charging 24 percent is outrageous, but we're providing a necessary service," Mr. Walters said. "Remember, our average loan is only $500 for 10 months. Most banks won't talk to you if you don't want at least $1,500."
Mr. Walters sits in a small office with green walls and orange shag carpeting on the second floor of an aging Loan Alley building. Behind his desk is a map of Tennessee with 18 pins marking the locations of the offices that his holding company, the World Acceptance Corporation of Greenville, S.C., has bought or opened since coming to the state in 1993. The company serves clients who typically earn $12,000 to $17,000 a year, he said. Two-thirds previously had credit problems.
World Acceptance is bringing big-business techniques to a once-sleepy business. For example, it has expanded beyond straight loans into consumer goods, and offers customers a mail-order catalogue of TV's and stereos and the like that they can buy on the installment plan.
YES, Mr. Walters acknowledges, the goods are marked up by 50 percent over the retail price in most stores.But, he said, that is still a better deal than going to rent-to-own shops, located mostly in poor areas, which charge high monthly "rental fees" for televisions, stereos and other appliances. These payments typically mount up to two or three times the products' retail value by the time a customer earns the right to take possession -- assuming the items haven't been repossessed and rented out for a second or third time.
While loans and payments at World Finance are still recorded on tall manila file cards, they are now entered into a computer as well, enabling company employees to tell clients how much more they can borrow when they come to the office to reduce their debt by a few dollars. The secret of a finance company's success is repeat business.
Down in the storefront, a man in late middle age wearing a plaid shirt and a blue baseball cap approaches the desk and plunks down a handful of bills.
Ms. Myers, the loan officer, calls his name up on the computer screen and makes a quick calculation. Then she announces his new credit limit, enough to pay for a night on the town if he watches his pennies. "Robert, are you ready for some money today?" she asks brightly."You can have $61."
This time, at least, Robert passes. "It's not enough," he says.
Enough of World Finance's customers have taken the bait, though, to make it a remarkably profitable business. In Tennessee, the company charges the state's maximum interest rate: 24 percent. But various application and monthly fees often triple the effective annual percentage rate -- or A.P.R. -- as calculated by the Federal government. And the company tries to add on high-margin insurance policies as well.
"Robert is on disability and Social Security," Mr. Walters said after the customer had left. "He's never going to get a loan from a bank, but he can get one from us. We're the poor man's credit card."
The poor man and woman today, however, can get a credit card much more easily than in the past. Fingerhut became the fastest-growing credit card company last year by offering Mastercards to the generally working-class shoppers who buy from its catalogues. Many of them would not have qualified for bank credit in the past, but Fingerhut and others like it protect themselves by requiring some of the poorest customers to secure the cards with a savings account.
First Union even offers credit cards to people who have declared bankruptcy, if they are willing to pay rates approaching 20 percent.
"There are ways to identify people who had a bankruptcy that was not within their control, as opposed to someone who is a born spendthrift," explains Fred M. Winkler, the head of the bank's credit card unit. First Union programs its computers to search for hints of good people caught up in bad circumstances. "If you see someone in California who made $100,000, paid their bills on time, then went bankrupt in the last few years, it's a good bet they worked in aerospace when the defense industry went away," he said.
That willingness to take a chance with such people pays off handsomely on the bottom line. "These tend to get excited that someone is offering them a credit card again and they work hard to restore their credit history," Mr. Winkler said. As a result, their default rate is well below the average for all card holders.
Some companies specialize in saving down-and-out homeowners from bankruptcy court by making first and second mortgages at above-market rates. Such lending increased 54 percent to $5.8 billion last year at the Money Store, the fast-expanding finance company that focuses on people graded "B" -- their credit is only slightly blemished -- on the scale used by bankers. Also booming are the "hard money lenders" like the United Companies of Baton Rouge, La., which goes for people closer to the edge -- "C" and "D" borrowers.
Nowhere has the boom in high-cost, high-risk financing made a greater impact than on car lots. Ten years ago, potential buyers with black marks in their credit history couldn't even shop at the dozen sprawling dealerships on Gallatin Road north of Nashville.
These potential deadbeats were forced to turn to smaller used-car dealers that made their own loans, like Arrow Motors a few miles south on Gallatin. Arrow still caters to the down-and-out -- and makes no bones about it. A 20-foot statue of an Indian out front proclaims "We Tote the Note." Some dealerships are known as tote-the-note lots or buy-here-pay-here lots because customers drop off their car payments in person. The lots also have a reputation for selling old, cheap cars at high markups.
Bill Hall, Arrow's flinty founder, will not comment on his markups, but nonetheless he says he is providing a service by customizing terms for his clients. Arrow often requires weekly or biweekly payments.
"Most of these people can't budget," he said. "So if you know you get paid on Friday, you know you come here after work or Saturday morning to make your car payment."
Arrow charges interest of 24 percent interest, which is also, coincidentally, the percentage of the cars it repossesses from its customers.
OVER the last decade, a lot of companies have found a profitable niche going after car buyers whose credit rating is too iffy for bankers but not so awful that they must pay the interest that places like Arrow Motors charge. One of the first of these was Mercury Finance, which pioneered the practice of buying loans from dealers and assuming all risk of default -- in return for a fee of 5 to 10 percent of the purchase price. That fee, and interest rates of more than 20 percent, cover the company's inevitable bad loans.
Mercury, which has grown to $2 billion in loans outstanding, specializes in loans for the least expensive used cars, averaging $6,000. Mercury has built its auto-lending empire like a finance company, with sales, credit decisions and collections all handled by local managers -- a far cry from the computerized credit-approval process used by most banks. And Mason Croft, manager of the company's Nashville office, said that was a big plus for borrowers with honest hearts and empty wallets.
A credit bureau will not tell you a person stopped paying his credit card bills after his daughter got leukemia," Mr. Croft said. "And it won't say that she died after a year and a half of medical bills and now he's fine. A bank simply won't lend to that sort of person." In contrast, he says, Mercury calls every applicant to ferret out the story behind their troubles.
The same sort of sleuthing has the extra advantage of spotting deadbeats that banks might miss, Mr. Croft said. "I just got an application from a guy whose car was repossessed yesterday," he said. "The application looked fine, except no current car was listed, so I got suspicious." So he called around until he found the dealer who had just taken back the car.
Skepticism is a survival tool for companies like Mercury. Loan applications, after all, come from used-car dealers, whose interest is only in making a sale. Lenders say they frequently catch dealers inflating the collateral value of their cars and even coaching applicants to overstate their income. In a particularly pernicious practice, called "pick pays," the dealer secretly lends customers money, also at a high interest rate, to use as down payments. Because the borrowers haven't used their own money, they are less likely to keep up with their payments.
Dozens of companies have sought to replicate the success of Mercury, a company whose stock has returned 40 percent annually since the start of 1990, compared with 13 percent for the overall market. Many have emerged to serve buyers of the more expensive late-model used cars that are flooding the market because of the leasing boom. For relatively creditworthy customers, companies like the Money Store will charge 17 percent interest and no fee. For more questionable borrowers, lenders like First Merchants and Americredit charge from 18 to 23 percent and tack on a fee of 5 to 10 percent for the dealer. The dealer, in turn, steers the client toward cars that can be sold with higher markups.
For the least creditworthy, firms like Credit Acceptance Corporation of Detroit concoct complicated formulas that force the dealer to share some of the risk.
BUT no matter how high the risk -- and 30 percent of these highest-risk loans are delinquent at any given time -- somebody always seems ready to step in and take it. In a windowless, wood-paneled office above the Crencor used-car dealership just north of Nashville, Tim Artist, the general manager, yanks open a heavy file-cabinet drawer and starts tossing notebooks, file folders and faxes on the floor.
All, he says, were sent by companies that want to lend to Crencor's less creditworthy customers.
"There are hundreds of lenders," Mr. Artist declares. "Some of them say that if the customer can fog a mirror and has zero dollars down, they'll do business. Most of them won't be around in a year."
When Crencor was started a decade ago, no more than 5 percent of its customers were in the low category known as "sub prime." Today, the figure is 25 percent.
After a customer agrees to buy a car and fills out a generic loan application, it is Mr. Artist's job to choose potential lenders. This afternoon, the fax has bad news: two applications he sent out earlier in the day have been turned down by all three companies he sent them to. Mr. Artist picks up the phone to call Alan Esstman, the Nashville manager of one of the three, Americredit.
"Alan will do this one," Mr. Artist said. "He doesn't know it yet, but I'll wear him out. I know how to work lenders."
The client wants to buy a 1994 Toyota pickup for $14,247 (including tax, title and a warranty), and had agreed to a loan at 21 percent interest with payments of $369 a month, after allowing for his trade-in.
The lenders concluded that this payment was too high, given his $1,600 monthly income as a waiter and his other living expenses. Making the deal more risky, the client had declared personal bankruptcy several years earlier.
"Alan, I'm calling to beg," Mr. Artist said. "I know he only works at Red Lobster, but he's been there for 10 years. Just think of when you are 60 years old and have been working at Red Lobster for 10 years."
Mr. Esstman says he won't approve a loan with payments of more than $287 a month. But as a compromise, he lowers the interest rate to 19 percent, from 21 percent, allowing that payment to cover a higher loan amount. Tapping away at a computer, Mr. Artist figures that if he increases the trade-in allowance by $500 and eliminates the $750 additional warranty the customer had agreed to buy, the deal would work, although Crencor's profit on the truck would be cut to $500, from $1,500.
There is a reason why the red-hot center of this business is in Nashville. Tennessee has the highest rate of bankruptcy filings in the country, one for every 50 households, more than twice the national average of one for 104.
IN the bright offices of First Merchants Acceptance Corporation, in a low-slung Nashville office tower near the airport, the air is filled with nagging, cajoling and downright threatening conversations as a dozen collectors call tardy clients. A white magic-marker board is scrawled with slogans: "Take Control." "Make it Count." "$ is up to you." "Push."
"They will not let you keep this Mustang unless I get payment," said Sandy Cummings, in a sweet Southern drawl that barely hides a razor's edge. "You were supposed to see me today. If you come in today you will save yourself the late charge."
"You have to find everybody's weak spot," she explained after the Mustang owner promises to send in a payment. "You stroke them, if that's what they need. I had a guy who just got divorced literally crying on the phone. The younger people need some authority and discipline, so you make a threat."
The goal of First Merchants Acceptance is to make sure that no more than 6 percent of loan payments are more than a month overdue.
For those two months late, it's time to consider the "repo man."
"If someone missed one payment, they are going to have a hard time catching up with two extra payments," said Dane Weems, the company's collections manager. "At three payments, their car is pretty much toast."
LEANING on the chronically broke requires equal measures of charm, incredulity and a strong stomach for human tragedy. "Some of these people have more problems than a soap opera," said Mr. Weems, who started collecting and repossessing two decades ago after he got tired of dock work. Referring to the pain he sometimes feels in dunning economic basket cases, he added, "You can't take it home with you."
Sometimes that's difficult, he concedes. He recalls the time at a previous job that he evicted a woman and her children from a mobile home after her husband was killed by a drunk driver. "The kids sat on the couch and asked, 'Why do you want to take our home?' That was hard," Mr. Weems said.
Mostly, however, he sees a challenge. "The fulfillment I get out of it is to get someone to do something they didn't want to do and still have a good feeling," he says.
Some people don't have the stomach for such work. The Beneficial Corporation, no stranger to those with credit problems, looked hard at entering the low end of the auto-loan business and then backed off. Others in the business predict that the same squeamishness will drive new contenders like Ford Credit and Keycorp from the scene.
"We may not be J. P. Morgan, but we have a reputation for fairness, so people turn to us time and time again," said Finn M. W. Caspersen, chairman of Beneficial. "If you are out there yanking cars and foreclosing on houses, that changes the attitude of your core customer base."
The dark heart of "sub prime" auto lending is the long diesel tow truck rumbling slowly through a neat development of town houses in the Nashville suburb of Hendersonville on a moonlit night just before midnight.
"There's a Honda. It's gray. That's it," says Matthew, the repo man. He doesn't give his last name. This is a business that doesn't make any friends, after all, and he has a 9-year-old daughter. Indeed just the week before, someone whose car he "pulled" chased him in a friend's vehicle and ran his truck off the road. He's been shot at a few times, but never at close range, he says.
Through a big picture window no more than 20 feet from the Honda, two men can be seen watching television. Matthew quickly checks the vehicle identification number visible through the windshield. Then he backs the truck up to the car and straps its front tires into two steel cradles that lift the front end up. No one emerges from the house, and Matthew quickly pulls the car away. The procedure takes five minutes.
"I could see him in there, but he never looked at me," Matthew says. "People get so wrapped up watching television." Even so, he says, "It's hard to sneak up on someone with this truck." He drives a "rollback" -- a huge flatbed Ford -- so he can pick up two cars before dropping them off at the repo lot. His record is 10 cars in a night, although four -- for payments of $100 or more each -- is more common. If he continues to do well, Matthew says, he dreams of buying a new truck especially designed for repo work. "It's got hydraulic arms, so you can back up and pick up the car without ever getting out of the car," he said with enthusiasm. "It's much safer that way."
The truck, Honda in tow, pulls up to the lot of the Auto Recovery Bureau, a small brick building with an A-frame garage, all surrounded by a barbed-wire fence. There are cars and trucks everywhere, including a lot of mini-vans and four-wheel drive vehicles.
"Anything that's real nice, I keep inside," explains Roy Williams, the repo lot's owner. This night, that includes a Porsche and a Nissan Sentra. "We had a couple of Mercedes recently, including one from a linebacker who played pro ball," Mr. Williams boasts.
Mr. Williams sees a deterioration of standards among both borrowers and lenders. "As more people get into the lending business, the looser the standards become," he says from his office after returning from his rounds a bit past midnight. "Look at the people who have credit cards today that couldn't get one 10 years ago."
Still, he says, "People just don't care about their credit anymore. When I first got into collections, when we sent people the very first notice that their bills had gone to a collection agency, one-third of the people would pay. Now it's maybe 5 percent."
At just about that moment, Michael Shores turned from his television and noticed that his gray Honda was no longer in the driveway.
"I was both angry and happy the car was gone," Mr. Shores said in a telephone interview a few days later. Wal-Mart had laid him off after Christmas, he said, and his new job as a waiter at a steakhouse does not pay enough that he can make the payments. For now, his girlfriend drives him to work.
"I will have to save some money up to make a down payment on a new car," he said. When the time comes, does Loan Alley ever have a deal for him.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 36; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Help for Social Security

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What Social Security and Medicare need most are: 
 * Replacement of the payroll portion of F.I.C.A. taxes by a value-added tax, or V.A.T. Because employers pay almost 8 percent of wages when they hire someone, but don't when they hire a machine or labor-saving process, the payroll tax has become a substantial barrier to true full employment. It discourages the very hiring that is the key to saving the system and, arguably, America.
When supported by a V.A.T., the future of Social Security and Medicare would be tied to overall economic health, rather than to the number of people employed. Current Social Security taxes contribute to the foreign trade deficits dragging down our economy because they add to the cost of our exports but not to the cost of imports.
Improved education and employment for the poor. The future of our economy (and Social Security and Medicare) depends on the poor leading productive and responsible lives; this is the rising tide that will raise all boats.
 
JAMES A. BUSH
Detroit, Feb. 19

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1294 words

HEADLINE: Trickle Down;
It's a Slow-Growth Economy, Stupid

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
SO much goes unsaid when Bob Dole calls for a balanced budget and less regulation to get the economy booming again. Or when Bill Clinton offers his formula of more public spending on job training and education to bring back the old prosperity. As the chief rivals for the Presidency, they are engaging in a rather traditional campaign debate -- one that assumes the American economy can go back to the high growth of another era.
That is what goes unsaid. The candidates challenge each other with conflicting nostrums for generating growth. Push the right policy buttons, they say, and presto, the economy will boom. What they don't debate is whether strong growth -- the sort that would raise living standards and make layoffs less frequent -- is in fact possible. 
 Such growth is not possible, according to the great majority of American economists. No campaign formula, whether from Republicans or Democrats, Steve Forbes or Patrick J. Buchanan, will change that stark reality in the rest of this century. "The candidates are promising what no President can deliver," said Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Nobel laureate in economics.
History and circumstances, in sum, have locked the United States into a level of economic growth that, measured against expectations raised by the 1996 Presidential campaign, is politically unacceptable. "It might be good for our politics if some candidate acknowledged this," said William Kristol, editor of the Weekly Standard and a Republican strategist, addressing an issue that most politicians don't, in public.
 
 
 
Living Modestly
 If the candidates did, and the public accepted the verdict (Mr. Kristol says Americans, being hard-headed and practical, probably would), then a new set of policies and campaign promises would almost certainly have to arise. They would focus not on how to make the economy swell, lifting all boats, but how to live with the modest growth that is possible. What is possible, the economists say, is much less than what the Presidential candidates seem to promise.
That discrepancy has not surfaced yet in the election campaign. But it is implicit in some of the Administration's proposals. While Mr. Clinton's economists don't broadcast the view that economic growth has its ceiling, they push for policies that in effect recognize that belief. For example, they advocate a proposal that is gaining bipartisan support: if layoffs are to be endemic, then workers should be equipped, by law, with "portable" benefits, meaning they would keep pensions and health insurance whatever their job status.
"It is another version of unemployment compensation," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's National Economic Council.
Portable benefits was hardly a front-and-center theme in the primary elections just ending. Instead, the economics reflected in the political rhetoric has been this: pull the right policy levers and the economy will grow, as it did in the 1960's, a hugely generous decade that Mr. Dole, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Buchanan suggest can be resurrected.
 
 
 
Happy Faces
 "In a Dole Administration," the candidate said recently, "we're going to liberate the great engine of free enterprise." Neither Mr. Dole nor President Clinton quantifies his ideal growth rate. The President, spotlighting the present, says instead, "Our economy is the healthiest it has been in three decades" -- ignoring the fact that three decades ago, in the 1960's, the economy expanded at more than twice today's growth rate. Still, the President paints rainbows for the future.
Pushing to spend more on education, for example, the President suggests that corporate America would spew out high-paying jobs for growing hordes of the college-educated. Mr. Buchanan would generate more jobs through policies that kept out imports and immigrants and penalized companies for relocating operations abroad.
In the booming economy that would result from their solutions, the wage stagnation that has lasted more than 20 years would disappear. And the layoffs, so widespread today and so troubling, would become far less noticeable as employers hurry to recruit workers to expand and join in the flourishing times.
That's a roughly accurate description of the way life was in the 1950's and 1960's. Then, economic growth, as measured by the gross domestic product -- the GDP adds up what the nation's citizenry produces in a given year -- grew by more than 4 percent a year, on average. That is nearly twice as much growth as the economy is capable of generating in this decade, even operating full-tilt.
 
 
 
Point of Agreement
 What is striking is how widely this view is held among economists. The reasoning varies, depending on political or philosophical outlook, but the conclusion is surprisingly unified: the upper limit of healthy growth is between 2.2 percent and 2.5 percent a year, which has been the actual level of average growth since the early 1970's.
Not since the Civil War has economic growth been so weak for so long. Generations of Americans had got used to better performance, and changing that expectation, even after 20 years, is not easy, especially for Presidential candidates.
Economists think differently. Only marginal improvement is possible, they say. If the Federal Reserve would tolerate lower interest rates, for example, then perhaps the upper limit of economic growth might rise a bit for a while. Senator Dole's balanced budget and Mr. Clinton's education and job training proposals might each add two-tenths of a percentage point to the growth rate -- five or ten years from now.
And why can't we get more growth? Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has argued that the nation lacks the capacity, in manpower, machinery and efficiency, to produce much more without causing bottlenecks and shortages that drive the inflation rate to unacceptable levels.
Productivity is the key to expanding capacity. When workers are equipped with the right machinery and know-how, their productivity rises. The same workers can produce 104 widgets this year, up from 100 last year, and 108 widgets next year, all at essentially the same cost. Replicate this rise across the nation, and the phenomenon known as the booming 1960's occurs.
But investment in machinery has been concentrated in recent years in computers. And so far computers have not yielded the rapid growth in production that came from investments in railroads, autos, highways, electric power and aircraft -- all huge outlays, involving government as well as the private sector, that changed the way Americans lived and worked.
That raises the question of what might someday allow greater productivity and, as a consequence, a return to 1960's-style economic growth. The two favorite answers are more public investment, despite the deficit, and a huge swing away from consumer spending. What now pays for jeans and Caribbean vacations would be saved instead, and used for machinery and the other tools of a busy economy.
 
 
 
Bad Investment?
 There are flies in these answers, duly noted by economists. Why, for example, invest in machinery here when the same equipment, placed in China or Spain, might earn a better return now that these nations' workforces are becoming as proficient as Americans? And why try to raise the potential growth rate of the U.S. economy if all the extra production can't be sold?
Whatever the answers, the conclusion is the same: much less economic growth well into the 21st century than the candidates are suggesting in this election year. "That is a sobering outlook," Mr. Kristol said, "and maybe some of that sobriety should be introduced into the political debate."
