HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

WEARING OF THE GREEN
Stamford wears the green today for its first St. Patrick's Day Parade, stepping off at noon from St. John's Church at Atlantic and Bell Streets. Winding through Bank and Main Streets, back to Atlantic and up Bedford Street, across Forest Avenue, and down Greyrock Place, it will conclude at the Hibernian Hall, 186 Greyrock Place. 
 More than 40 organizations have signed up to march, almost a dozen of them musical, including the Celtic Pipe and Drum Corps of Greenwich, Stamford Police Emerald Society, Stamford Yankee Drum and Bugle Corp, Trumbull Pipe Band and the Academy of Irish Dance.
A reviewing stand has been placed at Bedford and Forest Streets and the grand marshals, chosen by the Stamford Ancient Order of Hibernians, are William McNamara and Kathleen Walsh.

INTERACTIVE ART
Real Art Ways opens another of its unusual public interactive installations at various sites in Hartford today through May 3. The principal venue is the art center's 56 Arbor Street headquarters, and the satellite locations are City Hall, the Civic Center, Connecticut State Museum, Connecticut Historical Society, Old State House and all nine public libraries.
"The Museum of National Dialogue" is the project's title and Robert Peters is the artist, but it is not art in any of its customary disciplines. Mr. Peters has set up what he calls questionnaire podiums at all the locations.
The questions, which will change week to week, are "Does ownership preclude free speech?" "Can complex ideas be made simple?" "Are you one of US or one of THEM?" "Why do we expect those in power to lie?" "Does speech control reality?" and "Can anything be said if it is said politely?"
The public is invited to record answers on slates at each podium. The slates retain the answers in their waxy surfaces even though other answers are written over them. At the end of each week the slates will be collected and placed at Real Art Ways as part of the Peters installation, which includes a newsprint replica of the floor of the legislative office building, a six-foot flounder camouflaged into the floor, a frieze of blank television sets lighting up the ceiling and several sculptural forms.
The installation has been supported by the National Endowment for the Arts. Hours at Real Art Ways are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Friday, noon to 5 on Saturday. The number to call for more information is 860-232-1006.

 HADLEY ON DESIGN
Albert Hadley, who with Sister Parish formed the Parish-Hadley interior design firm in New York, will speak today at 2 o'clock in the Pequot Library, 720 Pequot Avenue in Southport.
Acknowledged to be the leader in the field for decades, the partners were probably best known for their work in the Kennedy White House. In addition, they created interiors for an imposing clientle that included Rockefellers, Gettys and Astors. But Mr. Hadley also has a penchant for working on homes for clients of modest means, challenging himself to produce economical miracles of decor.
His talk will be illustrated with slides of some of the 168 photographs in his new book, "Parish-Hadley, Sixty Years of American Design," published by Little, Brown.
Admission is free, and the library phone number for more information is 259-0346.

GAY TEEN-AGERS
A two-day conference on the issues of gay and lesbian teen-agers will be held in West Hartford on Friday and Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the UConn School of Social Work, 1789 Asylum Avenue West.
Sponsors include the Connecticut Departments of Education, Public Health, and Children and Families; the Connecticut Federation of Teachers, the Urban League of Greater Hartford and the AIDS Interfaith Network, among others. The conference is open to teachers, social workers, health care and mental health professionals, families and young people.
Workshops will be held addressing the needs of youthful gay, lesbian and bisexual people in school, at home and in society. Registration costs $45 a day for adults, or $65 for two days. Individuals under the age of 22 will be charged $15, or $20 for two days. More information may be obtained by calling 860-344-1777.

ARTISTS' MODELS
A payment of $9 is all that's required to take advantage of a rare opportunity in the suburbs -- to draw or paint from the live model.
At the Ridgefield Guild of Artists Barn, at the end of Halpin Lane, artists are invited to bring their materials and drop in any Tuesday evening from 7 to 9:30 or on Thursdays from 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. Easels and drawing tables are provided. Call 438-8712 for more information.

SUMMER BLOOMS
Four lecture-workshops are scheduled this week at the Greenwich Garden Center on Bible Street. On Monday from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. Brent Heath will give a slide-talk and demonstration on summer-blooming bulbs in the garden and in containers. To plant your own, bring a container or buy one at the lecture along with such unusual specimens as calla, nerine, lycoris, hymanthus, acimenes, prima donna lilies and calladiums. The fee is $35.
Sowing seeds for herbs, vegetables and flowering annuals in a flat to take home, with instructions for care and feeding, will be the subject tackled by Gail Egol at 10 A.M. on Wednesday. The cost is $25.
Also on Wednesday at 10 A.M., Georgia Spratt will rush the Easter season with a program on pysanky, the age-old Ukrainian method of decorating eggs. The fee is $45.
A session on Friday at 10 A.M. will be conducted by Caroline Holmes, chairwoman of the Herb Society of England, manager of her own herb nursery and lecturer on cooking with herbs for the National Trust and the BBC. Her slides will illustrate the history and styles of herb gardens and the many uses of herbs. The fee is $25. Call 869-9242 for more information.

VERY BIG MOVIES
An Imax film festival is scheduled at the Maritime Center in Norwalk on the next two Saturdays and Sundays. Saturday's programs run consecutively from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. feature "Fires of Kuwait," about the containment of 600 flaming oil wells during the war in the Persian Gulf; "Into the Deep," a look at the denizens of the Pacific Ocean, and "Destiny in Space," lifting off and spacewalking with NASA's astronauts. "Survival Island," where huge collections of seals, penguins and albatross summer off the coast of Georgia, and "Africa: The Serengeti," following a million wildebeest as they migrate, are the others.
Sunday's features during the same hours are "Antartica," "The Fiddle," a fictional journey through five generations of owners of a single Ozark fiddle; "Beavers," "The Living Sea," a 1996 Oscar nominee, and "Search for the Great Sharks."
Tickets are $6, $4.50 for children 2 through 12 and adults 62 and older. The center, at 10 North Water Street, overlooks the mouth of the Norwalk River, and the phone number for more information is 852-0700, extension 206. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In the Region, Strengths Amid Softness

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
LIKE an automobile with one leaky valve, the New York metropolitan region's residential real estate market clattered through last year, losing some of its momentum from 1994.
The analyses of those who keep tabs on the market -- academics and even institutionally optimistic industry representatives -- are peppered with such adjectives as "sluggish," "uncertain," "muddled" and, at best, "modest." And if affordable interest rates were -- and still are -- what kept the car rolling, the knock in the engine that sapped buyer confidence was fear, real and sublimated, of corporate downsizing. 
 Scanning the latest headline about this company or that announcing a retrenchment, "people say, 'Oh, well, that's a couple of thousand jobs, but I'm still working,' " said Stanley Duobinis, forecasting director for the National Association of Home Builders. "But the problem is that when they see job cuts there's a sort of fear that builds up. Their worries about their own jobs prevent them from moving up into that new house. There's a domino effect."
To be sure, there have been areas of relative strength in the regional market, particularly in communities just north and west of New York City -- traditional bedroom communities in Bergen, southern Westchester and Fairfield. Prices throughout those areas reflected increased demand in 1995.
But swaths of Long Island, northern Westchester and central New Jersey experienced price declines that etched a portrait of a soft -- though hardly precipitous -- market. And those areas offered a clearer picture of the entire region. None of the counties surrounding New York City enjoyed border-to-border robust sales or price appreciation, and all three states in the region experienced sales and price declines.
"We had an upswing in '94, a bit of a yielding in '95, and that leaves us with a lot of uncertainty in '96," said Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
Beyond sales and prices, the pattern was apparent in another measure of the market -- housing starts. "If we compare construction today with what we had 10 years ago, it's noticeably reduced," said Mr. Duobinis. "It's not a disaster, but it's very, very sluggish."
Mirroring Dean Hughes's assessment, Mr. Duobinis said, "We're talking about a market that grew a little in '94, then slid a bit in '95."
The home builders association, using data collected by the Census Bureau from local government agencies that issue construction permits, estimated that New York State recorded 18,500 single-family housing starts in 1995, down from 22,900 in 1994; New Jersey had 20,200 housing starts last year, down from 22,400, and Connecticut had 8,100 starts, slightly down from 8,200.
Viewing the regional market as in a stall rather than a dive, Dean Hughes saw 1994 and 1995 as "somewhat mirror images of one another."
Two years ago, coming out of the recession of the early 90's, he said, "we had rising interest rates all through the year" -- normally a drag on sales -- "but that was counteracted by improved job growth in all three states. It produced a reasonably good resale market, the best in the 90's, so far."
Last year, job growth slowed, which normally would weaken demand, Dean Hughes said, "but that was counteracted by falling interest rates" throughout the year. Thirty-year fixed mortgage rates stood at about 7 percent at the start of 1994, but rose to 9 percent by year's end. So, 1995 rates started at 9 percent, but dipped to 7 percent by December. "The housing market should have responded strongly," he said, "but it was held back by weaker job growth."
Which altitudinal direction the real estate industry takes in coming out of the stall this year will be powered -- or not -- by the performance of the regional labor market. "Interest rates are where we want them; 7 percent is a precondition for a strong housing market," Dean Hughes said. "But it must be matched by job growth and consumer confidence."
Prospects for job growth were boosted last week when the Federal government announced an increase of about 700,000 in the number of people employed across the country in February, compared with January, along with a drop to 5.5 percent from 5.8 percent in the nation's jobless rate in those same months, as measured by the number of people applying for unemployment insurance. Ironically, the immediate effect of the improvement in employment statistics was a case of the jitters in the securities markets, with a sharp decline of the stock market the day the figures were announced.
Whether or not the national job improvement played out in the New York region could not be determined because statistics for the tri-state area will not be available for two weeks, said John L. Weiting, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
At least through January, however, the regional job picture was decidedly static. New York State's unemployment rate stood at 6.2 percent at the end of January, up slightly from 6.1 percent in January 1995. New Jersey's rate went down, from 6.8 percent in January 1995 to 6.5 percent this year, but has hovered there since the early fall. In Connecticut, the rate was 5.3 percent in January of both years. If those levels hold, "you're just not going to see an economy that's strong enough to further reduce the ranks of the unemployed," Mr. Weiting said, "and that will have a lot of implications for the real estate market."
The implications are already keenly real for members of the baby-boom generation, post-World War II offspring who are approaching their 50's, had delayed starting families during the 1970's, have achieved professional peaks and whose children are now teen-agers needing their own rooms.
"The baby boomer who has just seen officemates lose jobs is not about to trade up to a larger house," said Dr. Susan Wachter, a professor of real estate and finance at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. "These are people who normally, in previous cycles, would be trading up. But they are worried now. And they are more likely to save that money for their children's education. That's what's happening. And this is the portion of the market we are losing out on, particularly in this region where we have an older population."
Michael Carliner, an economist with the homebuilders association, estimates that 2 of 3 sales in the nation have been trade-ups to baby boomers in recent years, and that the proportion is larger in the tri-state region. Uncertainty among those potential buyers is apparent in the market.
In all New York State, said Charles Staro, executive vice president of the State Association of Realtors, there was a decrease in home sales, from 124,819 in 1994 to 115,604 last year, with a slight increase in average prices, from $111,700 to $115,240. The data was compiled by the association's 43 local realty boards. "With additional interest rate cuts and any hint of stabilization in the job market, this could reverse 1995's trends and bring buyers back," Mr. Staro said.
T HE slippage was also apparent in New Jersey, where that state's Association of Realtors tracked 138,000 sales in 1995, down from 145,000, as well as a decrease in median prices, from $145,400 in 1994 to $138,300 last year. "When you speak of New Jersey," said Robert Kinniebrew, president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors, "that's AT&T, and they were going to let go of 11,000 across the country" -- including 7,000 in New Jersey alone.
And in Connecticut, according to Vincent M. Valvo, publisher of The Commercial Record, a real estate and banking newspaper, there were 50,750 single-family home sales in 1995, down from 54,354. Median prices were also down, to $125,000 in 1995 from $128,000. The data came from deeds and mortgages filed in town halls.
Defense cuts have taken their toll on Connecticut, particularly in the central portion of the state, Mr. Duobinis said. "And the insurance industry is going through the same sort of consolidation that we're seeing in banking," he added. "It's not so much big mergers and takeovers, but companies are getting out of certain lines of insurance. Cigna Insurance got out of auto insurance a few years ago, and that allowed them to cut people in Hartford and Philadelphia."
Discerning real estate trends by the numbers is an inexact science, at best. Sales of single-family homes are usually reported by local boards of realtors, based on data from their multiple-listing services. But not all real estate agents are members of the boards, and not all sales in a given area are recorded. Some boards include co-ops and condominiums in their data, while others only count single-family homes.
One local board may calculate median prices -- meaning that half of the sales are above that figure and half below -- while other boards use an average. Some state boards do not compile statistics county by county, but by region within the state.
Still, the numbers can provide indications of market trends. And the numbers for the communities immediately surrounding New York City show a consistent pattern of a slightly slackening market last year.
The New Jersey Association of Realtors provides data by region. In Northern New Jersey, which includes Bergen, Bloomfield, Hudson, Hunterdon, Morris, Passaic, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties, there were 55,500 sales in 1995, down from 59,900 in 1994. The median price was $187,900 last year, compared with $190,100.
Central New Jersey, which includes Monmouth, Middlesex, Mercer and Ocean Counties, reported 45,900 sales last year, down from 46,500. And the median price in Central New Jersey was $140,200, compared with $140,100. "Most people are staying put," said Mr. Kinniebrew.
In Westchester, according to the county Board of Realtors, there were 6,466 residential sales recorded in 1995, down from 7,076 in 1994, the rebound year in the regional market, but still well ahead of the 5,738 sales in 1993. Of the 6,466 sales last year, 4,561 were single-family homes, 790 were condominiums, 759 were co-ops and 356 were 2- to 5-family houses. The median price in Westchester last year was $235,000, slightly down from $239,500 in 1994. Gilbert Mercurio, executive officer of the Westchester Board of Realtors, said he believed 1996 "is going to be like 1995, maybe a little less active."
"That 1994 year really satisfied a lot of the pent-up demand," Mr. Mercurio said. "By no means all of it, but to the extent that it was a very high-volume year, we should not expect to see it repeated soon."
The Long Island Board of Realtors provides a county-by-county breakdown. In Nassau, according to Randy Kaplan, a board official, 6,951 single-family home sales were tracked in 1995, down from 7,505 in 1994, and the median price was $175,000, down from $177,000. Suffolk reported 8,992 sales last year, up from 8,679 in 1994, with a median price of $136,000. Comparison prices for Suffolk in 1994 were not available.
D ATA gathered by The Commercial Record show that Fairfield County, Conn., had 15,233 single-family, co-op and condo sales in 1995, down from 15,720 in 1994, with median prices slipping to $188,000 from $189,900. Dr. John M. Clapp, a professor at the University of Connecticut's Center for Real Estate and Urban Economic Analysis, said that western Fairfield County, closest to New York City, outpaced the rest of the county, particularly in price appreciation.
"Employment has grown, office vacancy rates have fallen and they got the Swiss Bank Corporation to build space in Stamford," Dr. Clapp said. "It's not occupied yet, but it's helped stabilize confidence." He said Fairfield "has gotten a lot of spillover from New York City. Firms that can substitute telecommunications for face-to-face contacts in the city will move portions of their activities into lower Fairfield County."
Dr. Clapp's assessment of a price-appreciation trend in western Fairfield is bolstered by data from an alternative measure of the market -- the repeat-sale survey devised by Case Shiller Weiss, a real estate statistics firm in Cambridge, Mass.
The survey is based on a table showing the average price of all single-family homes sold in zip code areas year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1995, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each zip code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price the house brought the last time it was sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier price to what it likely would have been had the house sold in 1994.
Particularly striking about the pattern of price fluctuations in 1995 was a nearly unbroken band of appreciation that stretched northeasterly from Bergen County across the Hudson River through the southern tier of Westchester and well into Fairfield County. That band stands as a sort of demarcation line for a block of northern Westchester where prices consistently registered declines. Specifically, in Bergen County, where there are 61 zip codes, 19 areas experienced price increases of 4 percent or more over those in 1994, and none had decreases exceeding 2 percent.
In Westchester, where there are 64 zip codes, 32 experienced increases of 4 percent or more -- all of them across the southern tier, including Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, White Plains and Yonkers. But in the northern section of Westchester, 15 areas had price drops of at least 2 percent, and 13 others experienced slight drops.
And in Fairfield County, where there are 45 zip codes, 16 experienced price increases of 4 percent or more, including all of Norwalk and Stamford, while there were no areas with declines of more than 2 percent.
Asked why there was a clear demarcation between northern and southern Westchester, Mr. Mercurio said, "It may be that northern Westchester contains a higher proportion of more highly priced properties, such as estates, that have lagged behind in the post-1990 recovery period."
There was another distinctive band, this one experiencing price declines, though slight. It formed an uneven ring in the counties of New Jersey that surround Staten Island, including the eastern portions of Monmouth and some areas of Middlesex, Union and Hudson.
Robert Shiller, a professor of economics at Yale University and a founder of Case Shiller Weiss, said he "wouldn't get alarmist about these numbers."
"We've seen much bigger swings in the past," he said. "There were times in the 80's when we saw 30 percent increases in a year in the Northeast, and after the boom, prices fell 10 percent in many places. So it's nothing like that."
In Nassau County, according to Case Shiller Weiss, 5 of the 63 zip code areas -- Floral Park, Garden City, Hewlett, Mineola, West Hempstead and Williston Park -- showed price increases of 4 percent or more, while none had decreases exceeding 2 percent. And in Suffolk County, prices also remained stable, with only 3 of 78 zip codes experiencing declines of more than 2 percent and only 1 area -- Lake Grove -- showing an increase of more than 4 percent.
The numbers, said Dr. Wachter, the real estate and finance professor, do not forebode an impending downturn. "But," she said, "we're talking about slow growth."
Employment, population and per-capita income in the region are all growing more slowly than elsewhere in the nation, she said, because higher costs send jobs elsewhere, "so we must go with our strengths."
Infrastructure is one regional strength; population density can be another. "We have a pretty good transportation system, and high-density population can provide a greater market," Professor Wachter said. 'So we need to increase access to the market to overcome the effects of traffic congestion, and that means infrastructure."
Dr. Wachter said prospects for the region in the 21st century "are not so promising" unless there are "major investments in infrastructure and human capital -- labor force skills. "Those are long-term needs," she said, "and residential real estate prospects reflect these larger, global forces."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page map last Sunday depicting changes in housing prices from 1994 to 1995 mislabeled a highway in Westchester County. It was Interstate 684, not 687.

GRAPHIC: Maps: "The Ups and Downs of Housing Prices"
 The map shows changes in prices of single-family houses sold in 1995 compared with the previous year. Much of Bergen County in New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut showed relatively high increases. HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN BEACH/SHEEPSHEAD BAY;
Lundy's Leads a Street's Revival

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
The restaurant is one of glee-evoking legend, where families devoured pink chowders, nibbled on light biscuits and dined on lobster. And now when people enter the new Lundy's, they saunter across the clay-colored floor and often smile nostalgically as they witness the shucking at the clam bar, the soft lights on the golden pillars and the waiters resting large plates of food on the white-clothed tables.
"I'm hoping they still have the french fried onion rings," said Margarita Garcia, as she scanned the multilevel restaurant from the hostesses' desk during a visit with her husband. "It is quieter." 
 The interest in Lundy's has translated into a resuscitation of Emmons Avenue, the commercial strip running along Sheepshead Bay. New restaurants have opened, desolate lots are being developed and vacant apartments are filling up. Property owners say real estate values have doubled. "This has started a chain reaction of development in Sheepshead Bay," said Donald Lentnek, who owns property in the area, including a 49-year lease on the Lundy's site. "The overflow has helped the other businesses."
The scene on Emmons Avenue has indeed changed since Lundy's reopened on Dec. 6. Calls have come in from all over to see if the restaurant is really running, diners have had to make reservations a month in advance to get a table for the weekend and hosts clock about 11 miles on busy nights running around the 800-seat restaurant.
After the restaurant, which once sat 2,500 people who came from all over the city, closed in 1979, the building had become a crumbling and graffitti-scarred hulk. Other stores withered and closed as the number of visitors to the neighborhood dropped. Peter Romeo, the co-director of the Sheepshead Bay Beautification Group, believed that Lundy's was inextricably linked to economic activity along the bay. So for the last five years, he has been trying to bring it back.
He started with the outside of the empty stucco building. He got local artists to cover it with murals. Then he lobbied neighborhood developers like Mr. Lentnek to take over the property and reopen the restaurant, which is now run by the TAM Restaurant Group.
"Mmm, taste this apple pie," Mr. Romeo said from inside the restaurant, after taking a scoop from a pie that he was bringing home. "We predicted that when Lundy's opened, there wouldn't be a vacant lot. And there isn't. The ones that seem vacant, people are negotiating on."
Despite some community opposition, many plans are underway. A shopping plaza anchored by Loehmann's is being developed on the avenue. A shopping mall, sports bar and parking lot are under construction. And a businessman has put in a bid to open a Mississippi-style riverboat on the bay with six restaurants.
"We might be making a monster in terms of traffic and people," Mr. Romeo said. "But were not going to let this community become a ghetto."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday with an article about the revitalization of Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, misstated the addresses of a restaurant and of a shopping plaza that is under construction. The restaurant, Lundy's, is at 1901 Emmons Avenue; the shopping center, Loehmann's Plaza, is at 2027-2063 Emmons Avenue.

HEADLINE: We Do Remember Example of the Elders

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert's March 11 column "Bullet to the Heart" notes the disappointment of William Manchester, the historian and biographer, in this generation's failure to heed the example set by the American men and women who fought in World War II. Mr. Manchester, who at 73 is recovering from open heart surgery, says the experiences and the wisdom of elders "are treated so cavalierly in a society that worships the young." 
 Take heart, for not everyone of the current generation has forgotten the contributions and sacrifices of your generation. Like you, my father was a marine who served in the South Pacific, and I have always been impressed by the men and women who survived the economic and psychological scars of the Depression, overcame their fears and led this country to victory over Fascism in World War II, and who then made this country the economic and military superpower it is today.
The lessons your generation taught us are many: a willingness to sacrifice for the common good, a refusal to quit even in the face of fear, deprivation, and defeat, and a commitment to defend the weak from the aggressor.
Get well, Mr. Manchester. Some of your younger readers have not forgotten your generation's shining example.
 
JOHN T. McCORMICK
New York, March 11, 1996

HEADLINE: William Warne, 90, Specialist In Irrigation and Reclamation

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
William Elmo Warne, a specialist in land reclamation and irrigation who served the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations and who directed a phase of California's immense California Water Project, died on March 9 at a convalescent home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 90.
Mr. Warne had been a resident of Sacramento and Palo Alto. 
 He joined the Interior Department in 1935 as an editor in its Bureau of Reclamation. He became an assistant commissioner in the bureau in 1943 and was named an Assistant Secretary of the Interior in 1947.
Among his responsibilities were water, drainage and power development. He helped design and develop the Columbia and Missouri River Basin projects and had a hand in Indian affairs and in preparing Hawaii and Alaska for statehood.
After President Harry S. Truman created the Point Four program of technical assistance, a forerunner of the Agency for International Development, he sent Mr. Warne to Iran in 1951. For the next four years, he directed the program to modernize the country's agriculture.
In the late 1950's he took up similar tasks for the State Department in Brazil and in South Korea.
The state of California enlisted him in 1959 as director of the Departments of Fish and Game, Agriculture and Water Resources. Heading the water resources agency from 1961 to 1967, he oversaw a major phase of the California Water Project that, once completed, produced a 444-mile network of aqueducts and coffer dams channeling water from Northern California to the Los Angeles area.
He returned to private life in 1967 after Ronald Reagan defeated Gov. Edmund G. Brown. He later ran a consulting firm and became a farmer, raising walnuts and almonds. He remained a farmer until his death.
Born in Seafield, Ind., Mr. Warne graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1927.
He is survived by two daughters, Jane W. Beeder of McLean, Va., and Margaret W. Monroe of Palo Alto; a son, William R., of Arlington, Va.; three brothers, Merrill, of Burlingame, Calif., Everett, of San Diego, and Milton, of Honolulu. His wife of 65 years, Edith Peterson Warne, died in 1964.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Most Sinister Gathering Of Not-So-Usual Suspects

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
Almost everybody loves a good mystery play, even those people who read mystery novels only when nothing else is available: you're spending a weekend in the country, it's late, everybody else is asleep, you have a choice between a tattered copy of June Bride and a stack of Agatha Christie paperbacks. Christie wins. At any point you can turn to the back of the book, find out who did it and go to sleep, the mind as barren as a looted tomb.
You can't do that in the theater. Since there's no possibility of jumping ahead, you're stuck with the playwright as turnkey. Yet every now and then the discipline pays off. That's if the writer is able to construct a puzzle with such economy and wit that you leave the theater experiencing a completely unexpected, ephemeral high. Think of Christie's "Witness for the Prosecution" and Anthony Shaffer's "Sleuth," or even of "The Last of Sheila," the densely clued, bitchily funny film written by Stephen Sondheim and Anthony Perkins. 
 Not for years have we had any theatrical mysteries as satisfying as these. And never has the time seemed more right for the kind of cerebral puzzles Mr. Sondheim constructs when he's not writing music and lyrics. Thus the great expectations for -- and great disappointment in -- the new Sondheim-George Furth comedy-thriller, "Getting Away With Murder," which opened last night at the Broadhurst.
"Getting Away With Murder" is like a board game that might better be called Group, in which the rules read like the instructions accompanying a VCR imported from the Far East. The dialogue is in English, but it's without character, largely made up of explanations that wouldn't be necessary if the mechanism itself had been more efficiently thought through.
The situation is this: It's a Saturday night in October; a fierce thunderstorm is in progress. Seven patients of an eminent psychiatrist, who's also a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, meet for their weekly group therapy session. The place is the doctor's suite on the top floor of a crumbling old Manhattan apartment building on West End Avenue. Because the building is scheduled for renovation shortly, it's otherwise empty, tended only by a Hispanic super whose language disabilities are aggravated by his fondness for pot.
Six of the patients have been in the group for some time. They are: a rich, high-profile real-estate promoter, responsible for the deaths of five workers on a construction site; a Connecticut society woman who shot a prowler later identified as her husband; a New York City police detective on suspension after fatally bungling a drug stakeout; an overweight Greek fellow who, supplied by Zabar's, is eating himself to death; an Asian-American woman who resents being Asian, a woman and a second-rate academic, and a pretty, lusty restaurant hostess who wants to become a mistress -- anybody's.
The group's new member, dressed in black tie like the real-estate man, is a powerful political consultant in line to become the next Mayor of New York.
As they gather in the doctor's waiting room, delivering so-so one-liners between great heaps of exposition, it becomes clear that something is wrong: there is no doctor. What the audience knows, and they don't, is that he's in a heap in his inner office, having been bludgeoned to death with a blunt instrument.
After the discovery is made, do they call the police? Foolish question. Having good reason to suspect that one of them did it, they conduct their own investigation amid power blackouts, sightings of phantom figures on the terrace outside and enigmatic messages on the doctor's answering machine. None of them need any more publicity. They keep the ghastly business in camera even as their numbers dwindle.
Good setup, clumsily executed. It seems at times as if the writers were longing for the freedom that a film affords. Cutaways to brief scenes in other locations, played in a cramped area downstage right, add information but take away from the tension that should be mounting within the principal set.
Mr. Sondheim and Mr. Furth, the collaborators responsible for "Company" and "Merrily We Roll Along," also write themselves into corners from which they escape only by introducing more characters. Yet they do know how to build suspense in short takes. There's some comic business involving an open elevator shaft, and a hoary if amusing trick played on the audience midway through. Unfortunately, just about everybody knows the identity of the killer long before the end, which thus becomes less apocalyptic than anticlimactic.
The biggest shock is the flatness of the writing. "The Last of Sheila" may not be high comedy, but it has lines that sting. Its picture of Beautiful People misbehaving is good, wisecracking, satirical entertainment. Though at least two of the characters in "Getting Away With Murder" suggest real-life models (Donald Trump, Anne Woodward), most of them are merely functions of the game Mr. Sondheim and Mr. Furth are playing. They're mouthpieces.
As directed by Jack O'Brien, who staged Lincoln Center's excellent and even more complicated production of "Hapgood," the principal performers are all good: John Rubinstein as the political consultant, Terrence Mann as the real-estate hustler, Christine Ebersole as the would-be mistress, Jodi Long as the Asian-American woman, Frankie R. Faison as the cop, Josh Mostel as the glutton and Kandis Chappell as the killer-socialite.
There's also something nuttily impressive about the demented profligacy with which "Getting Away With Murder" has been produced. It looks as if money were burned. Douglas W. Schmidt's great, atmospheric set seems to have a life of its own as, at one point, it revolves slightly to show the audience the body no one else yet knows about. Also first-rate are Kenneth Posner's spooky lighting and Gregory Mech's special effects.
It's possible that Mr. Sondheim and Mr. Furth had great fun weighing the many possibilities their original idea suggested. The audience is not so privileged. It can only consider the end result in which the final decisions play like desperate compromises. They're never inevitable.
 
GETTING AWAY WITH MURDER
By Stephen Sondheim and George Furth; directed by Jack O'Brien; sets by Douglas W. Schmidt; lighting by Kenneth Posner; costumes by Robert Wojewodski; sound by Jeff Ladman; special effects by Gregory Meeh; fight director, Steve Rankin; general manager, Marvin A. Krauss; production stage manager, Jeff Lee. Presented by Roger Berlind. At the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Van Gordon Sauter: Back in TV (in a Small Way) and Still Making People Mad

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Is Van Gordon Sauter a TV visionary? Or is he a destructive provocateur?
That question once divided the media industry into two camps. It has not been heard much, however, since Sept. 11, 1986, when Mr. Sauter left CBS after a controversial and tumultuous reign as its news chief. 
 But now the debate, albeit in a somewhat more muted form, may be flaring up again. Mr. Sauter is once again at the controls: this time of a public television station. And he is once again stirring up controversy with his views.
"I just think that public television is in dire trouble," said the bearded Mr. Sauter, wearing his trademark tweed suit, bow tie and suspenders and smoking a cigar on the patio behind the headquarters of KVIE Channel 6 here. "You know, public television was created in the 1960's and fundamentally has been frozen in Lucite. The audience has changed, the medium has changed and the competitive picture has changed. And now, it, too, just has to change."
For the last nine months, thanks to a surfeit of free time and some fortunate political connections, he has been general manager of KVIE, the Public Broadcasting System affiliate serving California's semibucolic seat of government.
Mr. Sauter himself appears on KVIE frequently, both as an enthusiastic pledge-drive host and as a co-host, two or three nights a week, of "Express," the half-hour public affairs program he started.
His local Sacramento celebrity, if not his new status as PBS gadfly, marks yet another unexpected twist in a life and career already full of them. Mr. Sauter, 60, describes himself as a conservative libertarian. He is married to Kathleen Brown, the liberal Democrat who in 1994 made an unsuccessful run to be governor of California. He is financially independent, lives in a comfortable house beside the Sacramento River and plans on seriously pursuing his true love, fly fishing, after a maximum two-year stint in his current post.
To be sure, his diagnosis is shared by most public broadcasting executives, struggling with competing cable television networks and the threat that the Government will "zero out" its support of public broadcasting.
Where Mr. Sauter differs is in his prescription: he advocates an end to the annual PBS budget battle by swearing off government funding entirely; abnegating all support from the federally-funded Corporation for Public Broadcasting -- and, indeed, eliminating the Corporation entirely.
"I don't think a single channel supported by the Government is going to survive," Mr. Sauter said. He said that PBS should look to the private sector for funding; trading the cachet and prestige of public television for veiled, or more blatantly commercial, support.
"I just think that what the company needs to have is, first of all, effectiveness in the marketplace," he said. "It needs to have the resources which would allow it to do more programming, more promotion, more advertising, which would allow it to become an international supplier of programs in a consequential way.
"PBS has one of the most valued brand names in America. I don't think one can say that it's a brand name that's being effectively merchandised," he said.
Mr. Sauter is uncertain about how such a private industry-public television partnership would work: whether, for instance, a media giant like Time-Warner or Gannett would "adopt" PBS or whether an entirely new corporation should be formed.
"I haven't really gotten that far," said Mr. Sauter, who said he believed the details could be worked out.
What is certain is that Mr. Sauter's views have received less than enthusiastic support. In fact, the response to him evokes echoes of the reaction the CBS News old guard had when Mr. Sauter did what he felt was necessary to prepare that operation for the future.
"I totally disagree with him," Sharon Rockefeller, the former Corporation for Public Broadcasting chairwoman, said. Ms. Rockefeller is now president of WETA, the PBS affiliate in the District of Columbia.
"Federal money is the core of our economics," she said. "We simply could not produce the national programs we do without Federal support. I don't see how a public-private partnership would have the same goals and purposes that we do. Private ownership would totally change the nature of what we do. I don't understand what he means by it, and I'm not willing to find out, either."
Mr. Sauter acknowledges that he has received a "terrible" response to his views. But he intends to continue speaking out, to anyone who cares to listen.
It was through his wife's political connections that Mr. Sauter met David Townshend, a partner in Townshend, Hermocillo, Raimundo & Usher, a Sacramento-based political consulting and public relations firm. Mr. Townshend was a member board of directors of KVIE, which had recently dismissed its station manager of 15 years.
"We wanted to go in a different direction," Mr. Townshend said. "We were for all practical purposes just a very big satellite dish sitting on top of a building that does fund-raising. We wanted someone to run it like a business."
Mr. Sauter has carried out extensive changes at KVIE. Prime-time ratings have risen somewhat since his arrival, and figures provided by the station show a 4 percent increase in memberships.
In the short time he has run the station he has authorized additional local programming, including "Express." He has instituted more aggressive fund-raising efforts, including hiring a new director of membership with extensive direct-mail experience. He has also hired several staffers he unabashedly calls "sales people," assigning them to raise money from local businesses.
Along with a handful of other PBS stations, KVIE has begun running 30-second promotional spots from underwriters. He has also revamped the stage set for the station's pledge drive and has improved its pledge premiums and on-screen graphics, unabashedly emulating the Home Shopping Network.
After he became president of CBS News in 1981, Mr. Sauter made drastic changes. Among them were budget cuts and the layoff or forced retirement of many longtime CBS News reporters and producers and a shift away from straight reporting from Washington and New York and toward more soft features.
To many CBS News staffers, the changes were appalling, epitomizing the triumph of style over substance.
The day after the financier Laurence A. Tisch gained control of CBS, which is now owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Mr. Sauter was asked to resign.
Mr. Sauter said he rarely watches network television these days.
In retrospect, the changes in television and TV news since 1986 have dwarfed anything Mr. Sauter or his allies at CBS began. Moreover, many of his disputed innovations are now standard practice at all the major network news operations.
"Some of the criticism of Van is justified, but a great deal is not," Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, said recently of his friend. "Sure, he made some mistakes -- but so did we all."

HEADLINE: Phone Plan Is Attracting Immigrants In New York

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Danny Coronel, a bartender from Elmhurst, Queens, lost his telephone when a former friend used it for calls to Hong Kong -- $1,900 worth. Jose Ramos, a livery-cab driver, and his wife, Jackie, never had a phone, even though they moved to Washington Heights in Manhattan from the Dominican Republic more than two years ago. "We didn't have anything in our name in this country," Mr. Ramos said. "It was just too hard."
They are by no means alone in New York, where the percentage of homes without phones is higher than in any other metropolitan area in the country. Tens of thousands of New Yorkers, most of them recent immigrants, go for long periods without a home phone, an appliance as common in American households as a refrigerator or a front door. The experts cite a variety of reasons -- credit problems, language barriers, lack of identification or simple fear of the system. Some people get phones only to lose them quickly to homesickness as unpaid bills for international calls mount. 
 Instead, in many neighborhoods like Washington Heights and the Lower East Side, Flushing in Queens and Sunset Park in Brooklyn, thousands of people have cobbled together a kind of alternative telephone existence. They carry beepers and cut-rate international calling cards, forage for working pay phones and, for the last several years, have flocked to a growing number of phone parlors, storefront businesses that let customers call overseas from private booths.
But now a tiny midtown telephone company that operates more than 150 phone parlors believes it has found an innovative way to begin changing that and at the same time build itself into a minor player in the local telephone market in New York.
In early January, the four-year-old company, Microtel Communications, began installing special phone lines in the homes of customers who have lost Nynex service or cannot get it. Working something like long-distance pay phones, the line allows users to make local calls and reach directory assistance and 911 for $23 a month. When customers want to make calls outside the New York area, however, they must pay in advance at one of the centers the company has set up throughout the city, particularly in Queens, the Bronx and Washington Heights. They can talk until their time runs out, and then the call is cut off.
"Because there's no risk, we don't need to protect ourselves -- no questions, no credit applications," said Robert A. Manghir, the company's president. "It's a great marriage. We're giving people service who couldn't get it, and that's wonderful -- and play the violins -- and we're making money at it, too." Telecommunications experts say they believe it is the first service of its kind in the country.
In the shadows of the recent deregulation of the telecommunications industry, with long-distance giants now racing into local markets, Microtel has quietly seized a head start on a sizable share of potential customers long ignored, largely because "Baby Bell" companies formed by the breakup of the AT&T monopoly, like Nynex, have not had a cost-effective way of providing service while also controlling risk. While some Baby Bells, like Bell Atlantic, have provided services like Microtel's, they have done so only on a limited basis. Microtel intends to make the service the heart of its business.
Using leased Nynex lines, the company sets up a switching system that connects customers to a central hub. Even though the phones are scattered in different locations, they are essentially extensions of the same system, much like the phones in a business office. Microtel then provides the long-distance service by buying millions of minutes of long-distance time from other carriers at wholesale prices and reselling the time to their phone parlors and home-phone customers.
The potential for the business is huge. As of November 1995, the Federal Communications Commission and the Census Bureau estimated that more than 350,000 homes in the New York metropolitan area, or nearly 12 percent, lacked telephone service. That is the highest percentage of any large metropolitan area in the country, the agencies found.
Nynex has a program called Life Line that allows elderly and welfare recipients to get phone service for almost no money, but many of the customers Microtel hopes to reach miss that safety net. They are largely working-class immigrant families from the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Mexico, Pakistan, Bangladesh and India who are not on public assistance but who also cannot afford to pay deposits or erase a debt left on a phone by a previous user.
While their jobs are often tenuous and their income fluctuates, they also tend to spend much more on long-distance because many of their loved ones are in the countries they left behind.
"It's a nice, lucrative little niche if they can convince the people out there in this situation that they are reliable," said David J. Roddy, chief telecommunications economist for the accounting and consulting firm of Deloitte & Touche.
He added that the company was anticipating strategies that other local providers would probably take under deregulation, such as aiming at specific pockets of customers and offering nontraditional service and payment plans. "I think they're going to have plenty of competition before long," he said.
The company has signed up a little more than 1,000 customers since it began advertising the service late last year on radio, in Spanish-language newspapers and in fliers and banners proclaiming, "Todos Califican" or "Everybody Qualifies."
Microtel relies on small neighborhood businesses, like its own phone parlors or video stores or bodegas, to serve as agents, who enroll customers, collect their long-distance money and at the same time use the service as a magnet to draw more customers into their stores. On Sherman Avenue in Washington Heights, for example, Jose Caba, who has owned a clothing boutique for 17 years, runs the service out of his basement and has signed up several dozen longtime customers.
The company's sales strategy so far has been a mixture of brash car-lot hucksterism and carefully planned ethnic marketing -- Pakistani salesmen knocking on doors in heavily Pakistani Flushing, print ads tailored for Ecuadorean weeklies. In a move to solidify its credibility in Washington Heights, its most promising neighborhood, the company hired a businessman well respected in the Dominican community, Nelson Acosta, and recently promoted him to a vice presidency.
Mr. Manghir, whose mother, Faye, owns the company, dwells little on the social or cultural aspects, however. "You want dial tone?" he asked in a recent interview, going into one of his stock sales speeches. "We'll give it to you no questions asked, in the basement, the bathroom, the attic, one room, two rooms, three rooms, wherever you want it. Pay up front and call wherever you want. Pay your bills, or we'll shut it off. Simple as that."
Some consumer advocates are wary that the company will end up exploiting those it purports to help. "While it's good that at least someone is willing to come in to give them something, we think this is basically second-class service," said Robert Ceisler, executive director of the New York Citizens Utility Board. "And there's danger that profiteering companies are going to come in and try to take advantage of people just because they have trouble getting a phone."
But the company appears to be gaining popularity in the neighborhoods it serves. Its long-distance rates are sometimes better than those of bigger carriers -- 65 cents a minute to Colombia, compared with 74 cents with MCI or about 81 cents from AT&T, for example. "I'm telling everybody to sign up," said Mr. Ramos, the 29-year-old livery driver from Washington Heights, who added that he does not mind that he has to hand over the money before he calls his mother in Santo Domingo.
"It's a good idea for people with only so much money: I can only talk what I can pay," he said. "My sister has had her phone cut off twice because she talks too much and then she can't pay. She gets on and just can't hang up."
Agustin Garcia, president of the Dominican Chamber of Commerce of New York, had a line installed in his headquarters in Washington Heights in January and his staff uses it frequently to call Santo Domingo, he said.
"There has been a vacuum in phone service in this community for a long time," Mr. Garcia said. "Anyone who comes here and provides an alternative to New York Telephone and speaks to us in our own language is going to be welcomed with open arms."

HEADLINE: At 27, a Talk Star Sets Out To Transform Chinese TV

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Yang Lan traveled from Shanghai to New York City to attend graduate school because, she said, her fans back home in China would not have left her alone to study. Oprah Winfrey could sympathize.
Like Ms. Winfrey here, Ms. Yang has been one of her country's most popular television talk-show hosts. Her weekly program, "Zheng Da Variety Show," was the top-rated talk show in China from 1990 to 1993. Unlike Ms. Winfrey, Ms. Yang quit her gig in 1994 to enroll at Columbia University, where she is about to earn a master's degree in international relations. 
 Two weeks shy of her 28th birthday, Ms. Yang is plotting a return to the small screen when she goes home in June. She is developing a weekly syndicated series, "Yang Lan Horizon," which will be devoted to Western popular culture and the influence that people like Steven Spielberg and Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber exert on Chinese culture.
With her polished manner, telegenic looks, and razor-sharp grasp of the economics of show business, Ms. Yang is emblematic of a new generation of Chinese who are taking the first steps toward transforming Chinese television from a creaky, Government-controlled public utility into a more entrepreneurial American-style business.
With the support of her new husband, Bruno Z. Wu, a Shanghai television entrepreneur, and a little help from a well-financed former music executive, Robert J. Morgado, Ms. Yang even hopes to develop and star in programs that would be broadcast in the United States -- reversing, if only slightly, the tide of American television that flows into Asia.
"I'm only getting started," Ms. Yang said over lunch recently at Tang Pavilion, a Shanghai-style restaurant in Manhattan, "but I want to start early."
As a television personality, Ms. Yang has already shown her ability to appeal to a mass audience. Now, she and her husband are using Western-style business practices in an effort to make Ms. Yang a one-woman television franchise in China.
By Hollywood standards, Ms. Yang is already a major star. She was selected to host "Zheng Da" in an open audition at the age of 22, while still a senior at the Beijing Foreign Studies University.
The program, which Ms. Yang described as a cross between "Good Morning America" and "Donahue," became an instant sensation: Its frothy mix of interviews with Chinese celebrities and games involving a studio audience routinely drew the highest ratings of any program on Chinese Central Television, the Government-owned national network.
Ms. Yang, who carried on a spirited repartee with her older, male co-host, Zhao Zhong-Xian, also became a favorite of Chinese Government officials, who asked her to act as a host at various events, including the United Nations women's conference in Beijing last September.
By the age of 25, though, she felt burned out. Ms. Yang, who is a native of Beijing and whose father is a professor of linguistics at her old university, said she wanted to attend graduate school to gain the intellectual resources to tackle more serious topics on television.
At Columbia, Ms. Yang has been in the International Media Communications program, which is part of the School of Public and International Affairs. To hone her skills as a journalist, Ms. Yang also took classes in reporting and writing at the Graduate School of Journalism.
Donald H. Johnston, a Columbia professor and the director of the media communications program, recalls the day that Ms. Yang came as a prospective student for an interview. "She knocked me over because she was dressed like someone from Fifth Avenue, and she was as poised as anyone who ever came out of American television," he said.
Ms. Yang's academic pursuits faithfully reflect her professional interests. She said, for example, that she was researching a term paper about American talk shows.
"These shows seem to be very liberal and progressive on the surface," she said in flawless English, "but when you listen to the hosts talking, they are actually reinforcing stereotypes about people."
For all her criticism of American talk shows, Ms. Yang studiously avoids controversial issues as they apply to her country. She describes herself as basically apolitical and said that in her new series she would eschew politics for coverage of cultural issues.
"I'm in a position to do something beyond ideology," she said.
Ms. Yang met Mr. Wu at a lunch with friends in New York last year. They were married in October in a lavish ceremony at the Plaza Hotel -- and have forged a partnership that may prove as important to her professional future as anything she learned in graduate school.
Mr. Wu, who is 29, owns a syndication company that distributes American and Australian programs to Chinese stations. His big break came in late 1993 when Time Warner's music division signed a deal with his company, Youban Entertainment Group, to distribute a music-video program called "Warner Music Stars" on Chinese television.
Mr. Morgado, who was then the chairman of Warner Music Group, played a key role in negotiating the deal. And when Mr. Morgado started a firm this year to invest in small overseas media companies, his first move was to acquire Warner's minority stake in Mr. Wu's company. Mr. Morgado has pledged to invest further in Youban, and Youban is helping to finance Ms. Yang's series.
Mr. Wu said his company had syndicated "Yang Lan Horizon" to 51 regional and municipal television channels in China, which reach about 80 percent of the nation's 200 million television households.
For now, China is still dominated by Government-controlled broadcasters: Chinese Central Television, with its five channels; 30 regional networks based in the provinces; and more than 700 local channels operated by the major cities.
But experts on Asian media said that emergence of cable and satellite television would inexorably expand that market -- and create a keen desire for programs like Ms. Yang's. "Once the change in leadership stabilizes and the Government liberalizes, there will be tremendous new demand," said S.K. Fung, the president of NBC Asia.
Those are big uncertainties, of course. But Ms. Yang means to be ready in any event. She has returned to China during each break in classes to tape specials. "I keep appearing on the TV so they won't forget me," she said with an easy laugh, sounding for all the world like Oprah.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: IN THE CROWD;
In Michigan, Blue-Collar Support Is Drifting From G.O.P.

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Mich., March 17

 BODY:
In a shot-and-beer tavern hazy with cigarette smoke, a couple of auto workers relaxed on bar stools after cashing paychecks fattened by overtime, and toasted a politician neither had supported four years ago.
"I wouldn't have my job if it wasn't for Bill Clinton," said Gregg Schulte, 36, a $22-an-hour electrician at a Chrysler engine plant here that has increased production during the past four years. 
 His pal and co-worker, Richard Pasik, 30, put it squarely: "If you're a working man and you don't vote for Clinton, you're just not thinking things through."
Both men cast protest votes for Ross Perot in 1992, when each was bitter about working at much lower-paying, no-benefits, nonunion construction jobs. But when the economy began to pull out of a recession -- soon after Mr. Clinton took office -- they landed coveted Chrysler jobs.
Trenton is one of the heavily industrial towns south of Detroit, a stretch known as Downriver that is emblematic of the white, working-class swing vote that Ronald Reagan successfully courted in the 1980's, and that Senator Bob Dole will need in November if the Republicans are to take back the White House.
Republicans once were as scarce here as foreign cars, and about as popular. Sizable numbers of industrial workers have been defecting from the Democratic Party for more than two decades, starting with the law-and-order campaign used by Richard M. Nixon to rally "the silent majority" in 1968.
In one sign of the changing times here, Jim DeSana, the longtime Democratic Mayor of Wyandotte, recently switched to the Republican Party to run against Representative John D. Dingell, a Democrat who entered Congress 40 years ago.
To Republicans here, the Democratic Party and the labor union hierarchy that supports it are wildly out of step with a conservative rank-and-file that is fed up with welfare abuse, affirmative action and gay people in the military.
But if the Republicans are counting on red-meat cultural issues to inspire waves of angry white men in hard hats to reject the Democrats for Mr. Dole, they would probably be disheartened by the talk in the Trenton Taproom, a popular haunt among auto workers, construction tradesmen and police officers.
Talking politics after the first-shift closing whistle on Friday, just about everybody at the horseshoe-shaped bar said they were going to vote their pocketbooks in November. And if anyone here intended to vote Republican, it went unsaid.
"Oh, there are a few guys at the plant who say they'll vote against Clinton," Mr. Pasik said, snuffing out a cigarette. "They start making big money, you know, and they think they're Republicans. But I tell 'em, 'Don't forget your background. It wasn't the Republicans who brought good money to union workers.' "
Voter surveys illustrate the situation facing Mr. Dole. White male blue-collar voters backed Republicans over Democrats by two to one in the 1992 and 1994 elections. They now favor Mr. Dole over Mr. Clinton, but by 49 percent to 41 percent. Among union voters, they back Mr. Clinton 53 percent to 35 percent for Mr. Dole.
To be sure, it is a long time to November, and some economic indicators suggest a downturn that could affect the political picture. But for now, judging from interviews with about three dozen voters in the vast industrial corridor along the Detroit River, Mr. Clinton has solid support.
Almost everybody here seems to be looking past the primary on Tuesday, with Mr. Dole expected to trounce Patrick J. Buchanan, who once had high hopes for Michigan, where his protectionist stance on trade might be expected to score points. But Mr. Buchanan is viewed with suspicion among many auto workers, who have not forgotten the revelation four years ago that the made-in-America populist owned a Mercedes-Benz.
Sandy Verduce, 50, who works part-time as a clerk in a Trenton clothing store, said she would vote for Mr. Dole on Tuesday, calling him "the least offensive Republican."
Mr. Buchanan, she added, "runs around in a cowboy hat, saying things about certain ethnic groups that really cross the line -- I mean, the man could be sued."
At the Sunrise Donut Shop in Southgate, John Simko, a 72-year-old retired auto worker, put down his cherry turnover at the mention of President Clinton, grimacing as if he had lost his appetite.
"I'm not crazy about Dole, but I'll vote for any Republican ahead of Clinton," said Mr. Simko, who added that he quit the Democratic Party when it nominated George McGovern in 1972. "I myself was a card-carrying Democrat. The Democrats are giving away the country -- all this welfare."
Only one thing could stop Mr. Simko from voting Republican. "If they pick Colin Powell for V.P., no way!" he said. "I can't tell you why -- but it's not because he's black."
Mayor DeSana of Wyanodotte, the Democrat-turned-Republican, first won office here 38 years ago, and then served as state senator and county commissioner, before returning to City Hall, said the class-based politics of Representative Dingell and President Clinton was outdated.
"People around here are really upset about welfare," said Mr. DeSana, the son of a tavern owner. "You want to see a working-class guy get upset? Go stand outside the factory gates, and wait for some tired fellow to walk out after his shift, and then ask him about people who sit home and collect welfare."
But right in the Mayor's own office, Terry Martin, a 28-year-old union laborer mending some electrical wires, scoffed at the notion that blue-collar people belong in the Republican Party.
"The Republicans just try to divide working people," Mr. Martin said. "And the Republicans are very preachy. They want to stick their nose in personal issues. When I was younger, I was involved in an abortion. And God only knows where I'd be if I had to become a husband and father when I was 22 -- when I shouldn't have been."
Nancy Collier, 45, whose job in a warehouse was recently eliminated in a corporate downsizing, said she had been "dead-set on voting Republican." But she is now thinking about backing President Clinton, although she would "have to keep quiet around my husband."
"I'm really concerned about health care now," Mrs. Collier said. "At least the Democrats wanted to do something about it. Hillary tried. And she got such a bad rap. People were against her because she was a strong, intelligent woman who was a true partner with her husband."
Mrs. Collier, describing herself as deeply religious, also said she was offended by Republican talk that seems to assert support from God. "I mean, is Pat Buchanan more Christian than the rest of us?" she asked.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;
Holiday Push Into Territory Of Democrats Gleans Little

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 17

 BODY:
In an emerald turtleneck and a union jacket, Patrick J. Buchanan plunged into his two adopted cultures today, knocking back a beer at a St. Patrick's Day parade and softening a long-held view on strikers' rights at the urging of organized labor.
He might be genealogically more German than Irish, and historically more scold than ally to labor, but Mr. Buchanan tried to set aside such incongruities today, visiting a union hall this morning and parading with union members this afternoon. 
 "It's just an overwhelming Irish Democrat area," Mr. Buchanan said, as he ambled up Western Avenue, occasionally waving his shillelagh and doffing his plaid cap. "They're good Irish folks, they probably agree with me on a lot, and they've disagreed with me in the past."
Some still disagreed. "Kiss Me I'm Irish," read one sign, "and Buchanan's a Bigot." Mr. Buchanan was booed along much of the parade route. To obscene gestures flashed repeatedly from one balcony, he returned only a broad grin and a wave.
Some in the crowd said that Mr. Buchanan faced an insurmountable hurdle: he was a Republican marching through Chicago's overwhelmingly Democratic South Side, right past the 19th Ward Democratic headquarters.
"He's got courage coming here, but I don't think anybody'll be impressed," said Mari Anne Wolf, a housewife.
Stressing his concern for working people, Mr. Buchanan has been asking Democrats here, in Ohio and in Michigan to cross over and vote for him in primaries on Tuesday. But as today's events demonstrated, it is an uphill struggle.
This morning, Mr. Buchanan visited Local 150 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, the workers who operate heavy machinery. From the union hall, Mr. Buchanan appeared on the ABC News program "This Week" and declared that he would rethink his opposition to legislation considered critical by organized labor.
"I think that we Republicans ought to take a look at our position," Mr. Buchanan said, "and not contribute anything that increases the economic insecurity of working men and women in this country."
He was referring to the striker-replacement bill, which would keep companies from permanently replacing workers who strike because of economic concerns.
Although the local's president, William E. Dugan, stopped short of endorsing Mr. Buchanan, he said that the Republicans could easily break the Democrats' hold on labor. He added, "This concept of labor's jumping aboard just because a person's a Democrat -- I think those days are over."
Mr. Buchanan's positions on issues like gun control appeal to working people, added Mr. Dugan, whose office was decorated with the head of a stuffed giraffe -- with about seven feet of neck -- that he had shot in Botswana.
But Mr. Buchanan had trouble winning over even Irish-American Republicans today. Before the parade, from behind the bar at the Summer West Beeftsro, Mr. Buchanan handed Marge Mullarkey, a Republican, a soft drink and a green carnation. But Ms. Mullarkey confided that she would vote for Senator Bob Dole because she thought he had a better chance of becoming President. Mr. Buchanan, she said, "would be elected in a few years, not now."
As Mr. Buchanan emerged from behind the bar, he assured Bob Lille, a plumber and union member, that he was considering supporting the striker-replacement legislation. "You back us on that, we'll back you 1,000 percent," Mr. Lille said.
But as Mr. Buchanan moved on, beer in hand, Mr. Lille admitted that he would never support a Republican. "I've supported Democrats my whole life," he said.

HEADLINE: Explosion Levels Old Power Plant And Lifts City's Hope of Renewal

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 17

 BODY:
At a time when this city is struggling to revive its fortunes, blowing up a building has become an occasion for celebration.
Hundreds of people gathered this morning to watch a blast that destroyed a 73-year-old power plant that had once provided the electricity for more than a dozen factories. But the factories have long since closed, and in three seconds, at about 8:50 A.M., the United Illuminating Company's 16-story Steel Point Generating Station collapsed with a muffled boom, disappearing in a black cloud of dust. 
 The crowd whistled and applauded.
"That was beautiful," said Mario Marcano, 54, whose family had gathered on his porch a few blocks away to watch.
"Totally cool," declared 9-year-old Steven Greytak of Newtown, standing across the Pequonnock River from the plant with his father, George, a United Illuminating employee, and a host of other utility employees, past and present.
It was a bittersweet moment in Bridgeport history, an event that some said marked the passing of an era. The Steel Point Station, a coal-powered plant, has not operated since 1983, when it was placed in "deactivated reserve status." It was permanently retired nine years later.
Another power plant in the area, one with greater capacity, the Bridgeport Harbor Station, opened in 1957 and continues to operate.
In its heyday, Steel Point had lines that went directly to Bridgeport Brass and Carpenter Steel and supplied electricity to General Electric's small appliance division, Remington Arms and Jenkins Valve.
All of these factories are now empty shells in the landscape of this Long Island Sound city, which has lost 70 percent of its manufacturing jobs over the last 25 years, among them the 160 positions at the Steel Point power plant.
United Illuminating, the New Haven-based utility, hopes to sell the 15-acre waterfront Steel Point site, and the land has already become the source of dreams for Bridgeport's future. Only last fall it was being touted as the ideal location for a new casino, until the legislature rejected the idea. Donald J. Trump has mentioned it as a good spot for an amusement park.
"This is prime real estate," said David W. Hoskinson, a United Illuminated vice president who has overseen the site's cleanup and demolition. Over the last year, he said asbestos and lead were removed from the buildings, and in the next few months the remaining walls and boilers will be knocked down, and other contaminants removed.
Mr. Hoskinson said, "We've turned a brown field into a green field," terms referring to the improvement of polluted industrial sites.
By about 7 A.M. today, dozens of former and current Steel Point employees had come to a party at the Bridgeport Harbor power station to watch the explosion. They were armed with cameras, video recorders and binoculars. Doughnuts, orange juice and coffee had been laid out by the company. Many people were wearing green carnations and shamrock stickers to mark St. Patrick's Day. It felt like a company picnic.
About 130 pounds of explosives had been placed in 360 spots throughout the old plant, positioned to sever the steel supports for the boilers and building.
Before the charges were detonated Gus Lawrence, 59, once an assistant control room operator at Steel Point, was awash in memories.
"I'm retiring in 10 days, and I'm taking this building with me," Mr. Lawrence, now an electrician with the company, said. He recalled starting in the coal room in 1961 and working his way up. Next to him was Charlie Belletsky, a wiper at the plant who was the best man at Mr. Lawrence's wedding.
"Remember how I used to polish the brass tubes?" Mr. Belletsky said.
"That place was immaculate; it shined," Mr. Lawrence answered.
With half of its exterior falling off and its frame bared to the elements, it was difficult for a visitor to imagine the plant as the sparkling wonder that Mr. Lawrence described.
A few minutes later, a cloud of smoke emerged from Steel Point. "I think they fixed the boiler," Mr. Lawrence said. The plant suddenly exploded. The smoke stack tumbled down. Mr. Lawrence's face grew ashen, and he took a few deep breaths.
People clapped. Mr. Lawrence's eyes were moist.
"Are you all right?" his wife asked.
"I'm just a little mad at the applause," he said. "I guess I'm just getting old."
The crowd began to leave, and Mr. Hoskinson, the vice president, declared the explosion a success. He waved goodbye to a friend.
"It doesn't take much to gather a crowd in Bridgeport, does it," he said.
