HEADLINE: Goldman Has Threefold Rise In Pretax Profit

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company got the welcome news of an earnings turnaround yesterday afternoon, hearing that their business, buoyed by booming financial markets, earned pretax profit of $565 million in its fiscal first quarter ended Feb. 29.
That is more than a threefold increase from pretax profits of $160 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier, Goldman partners were told at a meeting at their Broad Street headquarters in downtown Manhattan. 
 This latest quarter was the firm's fourth best quarter ever, surpassed only in 1993 when the first three quarters of the firm's fiscal year, which ends on Nov. 30, registered even higher earnings. The strong results by Goldman for its most recent quarter -- its fifth consecutive quarter to show improvement -- reflected its continued turnaround after a particularly difficult year in 1994 when Wall Street's earnings slumped and Goldman's top leaders left.
"It was a very positive quarter for all divisions, there was very consistent profitability," said a Goldman partner who declined to be identified. Unlike corporations, partnerships are not taxed directly; rather, the firm's partners pay taxes individually on their shares of the firm's profits, making it is impossible to state meaningful after-tax earnings. Wall Street's last big private partnership, Goldman, which was founded in 1869, decided earlier this year to remain a private partnership after several senior employees spent months studying the firm's capital structure and needs.
"We have had favorable markets; we have had a relatively attractive environment to execute a turnaround," Jon S. Corzine, Goldman's chairman and senior partner, said in a recent interview. Lauding his employees, Mr. Corzine maintained that the firm had really pulled together during 1995. He even contended that the upsets of 1994, when successive interest rate rises roiled the bond markets and hurt Goldman's earnings, may have been good for the firm. "We were a little too comfortable with where we were and what we were about," he said.
Mr. Corzine and his deputy, Henry M. Paulson Jr., Goldman's vice chairman and chief operating officer, began running the firm almost 18 months ago, and have led it back to robust health. Goldman, which has 174 partners and more than 7,000 employees, made $1.37 billion in pretax profit in the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1995 -- a strong recovery from $508 million earned in its previous year. "We must be on 12 cylinders now; the momentum has increased," Mr. Paulson said in an interview earlier this year.
In its first quarter, Goldman had revenue of $1.464 billion and expenses of $899 million, according to a partner who attended yesterday's meeting. That compares with revenue of $906 million and expenses of $746 million for the quarter a year earlier. Rising compensation accounts for the increase in expenses, the Goldman partner said. Goldman's financial statements will not be completed for another few weeks, but they are expected to show that the firm's capital grew to well over $5 billion at the end of its first quarter, from $4.9 billion on Nov. 30.
Despite the banner earnings, Goldman has recently failed to maintain all its momentum in some important markets, according to statistics from the Securities Data Company, a New Jersey statistical concern that monitors the financial markets.
From the beginning of the year until March 15, for example, Goldman has slipped to fifth place as a manager in the United States equity issue market, with a 6.6 percent market share, according to Securities Data. A year earlier Goldman was in first place with a 28.5 percent share of the market for domestic equity issues, a ranking it retained for the whole of 1995 when it held a 17.3 percent market share. Morgan Stanley, Smith Barney, Merrill Lynch, and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette all ranked above Goldman as managers in the domestic equity issue market so far this year.
In the 11 weeks of 1996 ended March 15, Goldman managed a total of $1.1 billion of United States equity issues. This was far below Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney, each of which managed more than $2 billion of such issues.
And, as an adviser of announced United States mergers and acquisitions, Goldman ranked No. 8 in the first 11 weeks of this year with a 4.9 percent market share, working on six announced transactions with a value of $4.14 billion; in the first quarter of last year, Goldman advised on 14 announced transactions with a value of $5.35 billion to rank No. 7 among its peers.
Goldman, however, may be hiding some of its achievements when it comes to its current standings in the league tables. Brokerage firms often report large amounts of business at the end of the quarter, raising their league rankings substantially, according to Richard Peterson of Securities Data.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries' Prices Rise a Bit; Long-Bond Yield at 6.70%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved moderately higher yesterday.
The small rise followed a week of declines that were prompted by a March 8 employment report showing that a surprisingly strong number of jobs were created in February. But yesterday's gain was seen as mostly technical in nature. 
 Comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at a bankers' forum in New Orleans yesterday did not affect the market. Most market participants have ruled out another interest-rate cut at next week's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-setting group.
Reports indicated that Mr. Greenspan told the bankers' forum that the Fed had not changed its view of the economy, despite the strong February jobs data, and that inflation remained in check with the economy moving forward.
The next important economic report for the market to digest will be tomorrow's report on retail sales in February. The numbers could provide the market with more evidence of whether economic growth is at a pace that threatens to raise the rate of inflation.
Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said that after the tumult of last week, "we still see the economy as soft, not strong."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 14/32, to 91 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.70 percent, from 6.73 percent on Friday.
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction yesterday, demand was mediocre, traders said, as rates increased from the previous week, reflecting the downturn in market sentiment. The average rate for a three-month maturity was up 7 basis points, to 5.02 percent, and a six-month issue up 6 basis points, to 5.06 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Bond prices were bolstered by a covering of short sales at the outset of the session and then again near the close of the futures market in the afternoon. In a short sale, an investor borrows a security hoping to sell it then buy it back at a lower price, making a profit. If prices rise, the short-seller faces a loss and may buy other securities to limit his losses.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston, said that the market appeared to be trying to establish a base from which to rally.
"The first time the June bond futures contract hit a price of 110 - 110 17/32, we witnessed an extremely strong reaction rally, a combination of taking profit in the form of short covering and the initiation of new long positions," she said. "But near the close today, we retraced back to 110 17/32."
Trading in the futures market often affects the Treasury cash market.
In the market for corporate debt, investor demand for high quality has not evaporated even though prices of corporate bonds have declined along with those for Treasury securities, if to a lesser degree.
A $200 million two-part bond offering through by the Appalachian Power Company, a unit of the American Electric Power Company, was priced through Lehman Brothers to yield 6.456 percent for first-mortgage bonds due in 2001, at a spread of about 32 basis points more than a comparable five-year Treasury note, while an equal amount of Appalachian Power first-mortgage bonds due in 2006 was priced through Morgan Stanley to yield 6.873 percent, or about 46 basis points more than a comparable Treasury issue.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Weapons Industry Turns to Latin America

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 15

 BODY:
Of the hundreds of billions of dollars spent each year on arms and weapons worldwide, Latin America has not been among the big buyers because of its weak economies and a United States policy that restricts the sale of high-technology military equipment.
But recent cutbacks in spending by major industrialized nations have forced military contractors to chase whatever business they can get, no matter how small, and developing countries with newly stabilized economies like those in Latin America have increasingly become the new target customers. 
 Perhaps that explains why so many secretaries of defense, generals, colonels and weapons contractors from around the globe participated in Chile's 1996 International Air and Space Show last week.
While the name suggests an exhibition akin to a family weekend outing, the event was without question the largest display of technology to make war that has ever been staged in Latin America. As advanced jet fighters, bombers and transport planes performed skillful maneuvers in the sky above, contractors and vendors demonstrated the lethal workings of helicopter gunships, tanks, hand grenades, radar systems, machine guns and rocket launchers.
A total of 400 companies from 43 countries participated in the show, seeking a share of the estimated $2 billion in weapons sold to Latin America last year. The United States Defense Department estimates that between 1994 and 2000, Latin American countries will spend $3.6 billion to $5.2 billion annually, or about 3 percent of the worldwide sales.
"The days of the big sales are gone and companies are being pressed by shareholders to chase any possible lead," said Brett Lambert, vice president for Defense Forecasts Inc., an arms consulting firm in Washington. "Six or seven years ago, half the countries down there wouldn't have sent a representative, but companies are so hungry for sales that they are willing to go anywhere and to cut very favorable deals."
Industry analysts and executives said that such a big turnout for a relatively small market illustrated how desperate weapons dealers had become. But it also shows growing optimism that Latin America will become a major arms market as its economies continue to grow and countries seek to replace outdated equipment.
The analysts said that Latin America's three richest nations -- Brazil, Chile and Argentina -- would be the region's biggest spenders on weapons, with priority being given to equipment improvements as these countries seek to maintain their security with limited funds. But analysts do not rule out emergency spending to combat regional conflicts, insurgencies and drug trafficking.
The United States brought the largest contingent to the weapons show this year. Indeed, American weapons contractors said that for the first time, United States Defense Department officials actively encouraged them to attend the event and provided the contractors with valuable assistance in transporting goods to be displayed.
The Defense Department brought a B-2 bomber, two A/F18 fighter planes, two F-16 fighter planes, a C-17 transport and various other military aircraft. The Secretary of Defense, William J. Perry, and the Secretary of Transportation, Federico F. Pena, were among the top American officials who attended the show.
At a news conference, Mr. Perry said that with the end of the cold war, the United States was considering waiving some of the rules that currently restrict Latin American countries from buying advanced military weapons.
Thomas E. Williams, vice president for communications for McDonnell Douglas, which makes the C-17, said: "You can't go to all air shows. You have to pick and choose, but we knew that we had to be here in Santiago."
Russia, which demonstrated a variety of military aircraft at the 1994 show, returned without wings this year, saying that financial constraints and a lack of orders from last year's show had forced it to concentrate on selling ground weapons, like multiple rocket launchers, T-80U tanks, and small arms.

HEADLINE: Executive Defends Downsizing

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 18

 BODY:
Robert J. Eaton, the chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, defended companies today against "the ongoing demonization of corporate America by some of our most prominent politicians and news organizations."
Speaking to the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Eaton said that the huge layoffs criticized by politicians and the news media came because companies believed that they must cut costs to compete in increasingly global markets. 
 "Downsizing and layoffs are part of the price of becoming more competitive," Mr. Eaton said. "The price for not doing it, however, is much higher in both economic and human terms." He said that his company's priority was "perpetuating ourselves so we can serve all our constituencies."
Mr. Eaton said that "American executives are not the ogres portrayed by the press in recent weeks." He cited news reports in The New York Times' series, "The Downsizing of America," and Newsweek's cover article, "Corporate Killers," in its Feb. 26 issue.
Politicians have also criticized layoffs as companies are reporting profits. Mr. Eaton said, "Big business has become an election-year straw man for those who like to pit American against American by promoting the politics of fear and envy." He said such attacks were leading the country toward "class warfare."
The Chrysler executive said that other chief executives shared his concerns. "I don't know of anyone that doesn't," he added.
Corporations are under pressure from shareholders who are taking an increasingly active role in company business. Institutional investors who control larger and larger stakes have changed the focus of businesses to increasing short-term profits and dividends. Rather than selling the stock of companies whose managers they disagree with, Mr. Eaton said, the investors pressure the company to change, even ousting a number of chief executives in the process.
And standing behind those institutional investors are American workers who have sunk their retirement savings into mutual stock funds and are fighting to be sure they get the best returns possible, he said. Those are some of the same workers who in turn have been laid off as their employers struggle to please investors, Mr. Eaton said.
"So if we don't like the kind of pressure these funds put on our companies, we can't point fingers," Mr. Eaton said. " 'Them' is us."
Mr. Eaton argued that the turmoil may be for the best.
While the Labor Secretary, Robert E. Reich, and others have debated the definition of corporate responsibility, Mr. Eaton said that "companies that focus on making money become more competitive, and that in turn means more economic growth, and more jobs, and all the other results that stakeholders care about."
As an example, Chrysler has hired more than 15,000 blue-collar workers in the last five years, he said. But it did not set out to create more jobs. "Our goal was to get more competitive," Mr. Eaton said. "New jobs and more security for the existing ones are simply results of being more competitive."
Mr. Eaton quoted a popular country song to describe the atmosphere he and other executives face.
"Remember the song, 'Mamas, Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys,' " Mr. Eaton said. "Today, apparently the shame is raising a son who grows up to be a C.E.O."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE WHITE HOUSE;
PRESIDENT DRAFTS 1997 BUDGET PLAN OFFERING TAX CUTS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
When he presents his election-year budget to Congress on Tuesday morning, President Clinton will call for roughly $100 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, fleshing out several of his proposals to benefit the middle class and to close a number of loopholes enjoyed by American business.
With the presentation of the 2,000-page document, Mr. Clinton will be putting forth some of his main campaign arguments against Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican nominee. But there are few surprises in the fiscal 1997 budget proposal, which is drawn from Mr. Clinton's last offer to Republicans before negotiations broke down two months ago on the still-unresolved 1996 budget. 
 The largest share of the cuts will come from a tax credit of up to $500 for families with at least one young child, and a deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition and other degree programs -- proposals that Mr. Clinton first made in December 1994.
Under the plan Mr. Clinton will submit on Tuesday, almost all the cuts would peak in the 1999 fiscal year and then disappear the following year, unless the deficit was reduced considerably more than the Congressional Budget Office's projections. Assuming the deficit reduction is not ahead of schedule, taxes would increase again just as the next Presidential election cycle begins four years from now.
Mr. Clinton's $100 billion in tax cuts are roughly half of the amount proposed by Congressional Republicans when the jousting over the 1996 budget came to a temporary end, forcing the Federal Government to operate on a series of short-term resolutions. The two sides are still far apart on issues ranging from Medicare and Medicaid to welfare overhaul, and the Administration's fiscal 1997 proposals will go nowhere, Congressional leaders say, until the parallel debate on this year's budget is resolved.
"In the next few weeks, everyone's going to have to make a decision about whether or not to give up on the 1996 budget and just limp along, or try to put something together with Dole," one senior Administration official said late today. "And until we get past this year's problem, the 1997 budget is just a debating point with the Republicans."
Campaigning today in Illinois, ahead of the primaries on Tuesday in the Midwest, Mr. Dole again questioned whether Mr. Clinton truly wanted a budget deal this year, or whether he saw political advantage in playing out the stalemate. "Mr. President, if you want a real balanced budget, if you want to make fundamental changes, I'm willing to sit down with you," he said. If an agreement is reached, he said: "You'll get credit. I'll get credit."
White House aides said today that Mr. Clinton planned to meet on Wednesday with Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Dole to discuss several issues, including the budget impasse. But they said the scheduling of the meeting did not signal a breakthrough in the budget talks. Also invited to the meeting were Representatives Dick Armey, the House majority leader, and Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, as well as Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader.
The presentation of the budget gives the President a chance to flesh out many proposals that are whipped around in campaign speeches, and copies of budget summaries being faxed around Capital Hill today detailed some proposals for the first time. It would, for example, close a series of highly technical corporate tax breaks that save companies roughly $10 billion a year. It would tighten the rules for expatriate millionaires, so that the Treasury could claim part of their earnings even if they renounce United States citizenship.
But in the budget proposals, Mr. Clinton is continuing to resist Republican efforts to reduce the capital gains tax. Instead, he would end the practice of allowing investors to identify which shares of stock they are selling, which often enables them to pay a lower tax by declaring that they are selling the shares that initially cost them the most to purchase. Under the new rule, they would be required to compute profits based on the average cost of the shares they hold in a specific stock.
Perhaps the most striking statistics in the new budget arise from the one area of agreement between Mr. Clinton and the Congressional Budget Office: the slow-growth future of the American economy. Both project 2.3 percent annual growth over the next six years, though the Congressional Budget Office predicts that interest rates will be somewhat higher than the White House does.
Those economic assumptions are the underpinnings of the estimates about when the budget will finally be in balance. But several months ago, June E. O'Neill, the director of the budget office, conceded that the figures for the distant budget years, after 1998, were based on "straightlining the numbers," or taking the last projection and assuming each successive year would be the same, and did not take into account what would happen if a fairly severe recession hit in the interim.
Even if those projections are unreliable -- and most economists say long-term estimates of the economy's health are unreliable by definition -- they are the common ground on which Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole will battle over the next eight months. Each has a balanced budget, and each is out to persuade voters that the other's approach is either fraudulent or dangerous.
Charts accompanying Tuesday's budget proposal show that the Administration project a $164.2 billion deficit in the 1997 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. It would turn into a $7.6 billion surplus in 2002. If the budget is actually balanced that year, it would be the first time since 1969.
In fact, the President's proposal carries the oneupmanship of budget-balancing to a new height: It promises a surplus by 2001, a year before the Republican plans would yield the same result. But those are based on the Administration's economic assumptions, which are slightly more optimistic than those of Congress.
Mr. Clinton's aides said today that he would use the budget to highlight tax proposals that are the centerpiece of his "Middle Class Bill of Rights," first announced in the days immediately after Republicans seized control of both houses of Congress in 1994.
Under the new budget, for example, the $500 tax credit for families with children would fully phase in during the 1999 tax year. But it would not be available to families with adjusted gross incomes of more than $75,000. Initially, Mr. Clinton proposed that the deduction should be available to families earning up to $100,000.
Similarly, the $10,000 tax deduction for higher education and training -- the main proposal growing out of Mr. Clinton's argument that the Government should encourage investments in people as well as factory equipment -- would not be fully available until 1999. And it would be reduced for families earning $100,000 a year and eliminated for those receiving $120,000 or more a year.
The new budget would also allow couples earning up to $100,000 to deduct from their taxable income contributions they make to an Individual Retirement Account. Currently, they cannot deduct contributions if their income is over $50,000. The income limits for individual tax filers would also be increased, to $70,000.

HEADLINE: G.M. Strike May Be Worst Blow For the Midwest Since '93 Floods

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 18

 BODY:
Government and private economists said today that the 13-day-old strike at two General Motors brake factories here has delivered the worst blow to the Midwest economy since the floods of 1993.
The strike has already reduced the nation's production of goods and services by $5 billion to $7 billion, wiping out a third of the already-weak economic growth in the first quarter, several economic research firms said today. 
 And the effects of a crippling shortage of brakes continued to ripple across the country today, as G.M. announced that it was temporarily laying off another 25,350 workers, bringing the company's total to 150,050. Even G.M. has not tried to keep track of the layoffs at its 1,600 suppliers, but their job losses also appear to be extremely heavy.
"I think this is the biggest single economic event in the Midwest since the flood," said Everett Ehrlich, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Statistics.
Negotiators from G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union have been meeting around the clock here since 9:30 A.M. Sunday in an effort to settle the strike, caused by a dispute over job security and safety for almost 3,200 workers here. Both sides continued today to observe an agreement not to discuss their differences publicly, but some participants in the talks have been privately optimistic that a deal may be reached in the coming hours or days.
Examples of the strike's effects are easy to find.
Jim Domin, the general manager of Jamestown Industries, stood at the entrance to his company's immense steel warehouse here this afternoon as two of his crew supervisors, Jeff Hatton and Darrell Campbell, shut off the endless rows of fluorescent lights high overhead. Until early this month, 63 people here sorted and shipped the doors and carpets of Chevrolet Blazers to a G.M. assembly plant in nearby Moraine, Ohio.
But when the assembly plant closed on March 9, Mr. Domin shut down most of the operations here the same day. Metal racks 15 feet high full of car doors still stand on the warehouse's concrete floor, where the workers left them.
"We laid off all our people, 60 people sitting home and waiting to come back, with no income coming in," Mr. Domin said.
Mr. Hatton and Mr. Campbell continued doing maintenance work until today, when Mr. Domin also laid them off with a promise that he would hire them back when the strike ends. "I like to take my family out to eat, and we won't be doing that," said Mr. Campbell, standing in his blue jeans, blue denim jacket and gray T-shirt near the warehouse's darkened entrance.
As people like Mr. Campbell stop going out to dinner and defer other purchases, the strike here affects workers in many other industries. DRI/McGraw-Hill, which runs a large computer model of the economy, estimates that the virtual shut-down of G.M.'s North American operations has resulted in a loss of up to $2.4 billion in output from the auto industry and up to double that in other industries.
If the strike continues, the biggest effect may eventually be felt in the confidence of businesses and consumers to continue spending money, said Scott F. Merlis, an independent analyst in Westport, Conn. "You are hurting business confidence and consumer confidence wherever there is an auto plant or an auto-supply plant and that is why this confrontation is unfortunate -- that's a lot of communities," he said. "There are a lot of communities that are reading about this on the front pages."
The strike's widespread effects have illustrated the continuing economic importance of the American auto industry, which exceeds that of many industries that have been receiving more attention lately. During the fourth quarter of last year, for example, the sales of G.M. were 19 times the sales of the Microsoft Corporation.
Mr. Ehrlich at the Commerce Department said that G.M. accounts for slightly more than 1 percent of the nation's economic activity.
Economic losses have been heavily concentrated in the Midwest, said James E. Annable, the chief economist at First Chicago NBD, the biggest bank in the Midwest. "It really is the biggest single economic jolt to the Midwest since the great floods," he said, adding, "It's big enough that it's changing the overall" economy.
The effects have rippled across all of North America, as 25 of G.M.'s 29 assembly plants, from Ramos Arizpe, Mexico, to Oshawa, Ontario, have shut down for lack of brakes. Another factory had been closed before the strike for retooling.
Just as the 1993 flood produced extra economic activity during the subsequent cleanup, the G.M. strike is likely to produce catchup work in the second quarter. Mr. Ehrlich said that at least half of the output lost in the first quarter would be made up in the second quarter.
Paul D. Ballew, the chief economist at J. D. Power & Associates, the auto consulting firm, said that G.M. would be able to catch up on car production. But G.M. will not be able to make up for lost time in the production of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks because the factories making them were operating at full capacity before the strike, he said. Sport utility vehicles and light trucks are G.M.'s most profitable models.
The strike would have to last several more weeks to exceed the economic harm of the 1993 floods, Mr. Ballew said.
 Because the strike is about job security for the workers here, it may have captured the national imagination at a time of already-considerable concern about layoffs, Mr. Annable said. If consumer and business confidence is seriously hurt by the strike and the widespread layoffs, then the economy will not bounce back quickly, he warned.
Even if a settlement is reached this week, the strike will have reduced first-quarter growth in the gross domestic product to an estimated annualized rate of six-tenths of 1 percent, down from previous estimates of nine-tenths of 1 percent, Mr. Annable said.
The striking workers here want G.M. to reverse plans to buy more brakes and brake parts from outside companies.
While waiting for the strike to be settled, many workers across the country could be cautious about spending money. As Mr. Hatton prepared to leave Jamestown Industries today, he said he was planning to start buying cheaper gasoline.
"I'm just going to be a little more conservative in everything" involvng personal spending, he said.

HEADLINE: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Taxes and Election Fervor;
A Silent Wave of Anti-Tax Emotion Holds Sway in Perry Township, Ohio

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: PERRY TOWNSHIP, Ohio, March 18

 BODY:
Denny Fulk, a precinct captain canvassing Citadel Avenue, rang the bell, and as soon as the door opened a crack, launched into his pitch. "Hi, I'm Denny Fulk, I'm one of your neighbors, I live over on Banyan and I'm on the committee to pass the Perry school levy," he began. "We have an important vote coming up on the 19th and I'd like to give you some literature. Any questions I can answer?"
"I don't think so," said the woman, peeking out from behind her door. 
 "Passing this tax levy is important for the schools and the children and for our property values," Mr. Fulk said.
"O.K.," said the woman.
"Would you have an idea how you might vote?"
"O.K., I guess I'm leaning for it."
"That's great," Mr. Fulk said. "So we can count on your vote?"
"Probably," said the woman. Mr. Fulk thanked her, she smiled, he smiled, and as he got to the bottom of her walk, he whispered, "That's a no vote." After several more houses, Mr. Fulk caught up with his wife, Linda, who was canvassing the other side of the street.
"Everyone has been positive," said Mrs. Fulk.
"How many you think are lying to you?" asked Mr. Fulk.
Here in Stark County in northeastern Ohio, fighting the anti-tax vote is like chasing shadows. Anti-tax voters usually do not organize, do not show up at public meetings in large numbers, do not spend lots of money to defeat school levies or sales tax proposals. But come election day they slip into the polling booths and roar, "NO!"
Perry, a blue-collar and middle-class suburb of 30,000 near Canton, has passed just one tax levy in 17 years and is now $8 million in debt. If the tax increase fails on Tuesday, most busing will end immediately, the high school swimming pool will close and the board will consider shutting schools or disbanding the district.
This is not unusual here. For years Stark County voters slipped into the polls and roared "NO!" to a half percent increase in the sales tax, causing a financial crisis that closed down much of the county jail. At present there are 6,000 criminals convicted of misdemeanors who are out in the streets, on a waiting list to serve jail time here.
Such strong anti-tax feelings have a lot to do with why the Democratic President is proclaiming the end of big spending and big government. Perry is a suburb that has been "right" in picking the President every year since 1964. Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans, 8 to 5, here but they are Reagan Democrats, having deserted their party through the 1980's, before coming back to the Democratic fold in 1992, for President Clinton.
Tomorrow, these Perry voters will come face-to-face with the consequences of the anti-government, pro-business Reagan Revolution they helped spur. One of the reasons they are being asked to ante up more is that big government (in this case, the state of Ohio) and big business (in this case, the Timken Company, a steel and bearing manufacturer) are paying a lot less toward the schools.
In the last decade, the state's share of financing for the Perry schools has shrunk from 55 percent to 37 percent. This, along with tax breaks given to Timken, the largest local employer, set off the crisis.
In 1982, as an incentive to build a state-of-the-art steel plant in Perry instead of down South, Timken was given a 15-year real estate tax abatement, saving the company about $8.5 million. Also, over the last decade, the State Legislature reduced all corporations' personal tax rate from 35 percent to 25 percent.
And Timken, like most companies, has been more aggressive in recent years about cutting its inventory (further reducing its corporate tax) and about fighting its tax bills. This year, Perry has had to refund to Timken $1.4 million in overcharges made by state assessors.
The result is, Timken's annual tax payment to Perry has dropped from $4.5 million a year to $1.5 million in a decade.
It is a sign of the times, that even in Democratic Perry, after months of public hearings on the levy and scores of letters to the newspapers, there has rarely been any anti-Timken, or anti-corporate squawking.
"I don't blame Timken, you can't really blame Timken," said Mr. Fulk, as he went canvassing door to door in 12-degree weather. And Peggy Hrach, who has overseen the entire canvassing operation, poring over computer printouts precinct by precinct and street by street, volunteering weeks of her time to pass the levy, says, "Everyone gives tax abatements nowadays, so you know you can't count on industry any more to support the schools."
"I've had a good experience with the Perry schools," Mrs. Hrach said. "But do I have to pay for it? Yeah."
The mobilization to pass the levy is an impressive exercise in grass-roots democracy, in marked contrast to the Presidential primaries, which have spurred no local get-out-the-vote effort. Perry officials have held four public hearings on the levy, a lecture by a state expert on school financing, a pancake breakfast and weekly Perry pride pep rallies at the elementary schools.
The Perry teachers, who average $40,000 a year, a little above the county average, have donated $25 each to finance the campaign and gave back a negotiated 3 percent raise in hopes of gaining support.
By matching voter lists with school registration lists, Mrs. Hrach pinpointed 738 families that were not registered and had children in the schools. "We know who the people are, but we're discreet about it," she said. "We don't say, 'You're not registered to vote.' We say, 'By the way, if you're not registered, here's how you can do it.' "
Virtually every registered voter in the district has been visited by the canvassing volunteers.
After a public meeting in early February, Mrs. Hrach reported, "We registered 30 to vote at Little League last Saturday; we had three more tonight." Perry also registered 358 students to vote.
The message at the meetings has been simple: The state's not going to bail us out, industry's not, we have to do it ourselves. Certainly by East Coast standards, property taxes are a bargain here. While Perry is a similar community to Levittown, N.Y., taxes here on a typical house are $1,200, about one-fifth of Levittown's. The levy would add about $200 to the typical Perry resident's tax bill.
Still the betting here is that passage tomorrow is an uphill battle. The opposition remains in the shadows. The tax expert's lecture in February was attended by about 100 people. Bill Hammen, a Perry administrator, looked out over the audience and said, "When you take away the teachers and principals, it's discouraging."
After canvassing, Mrs. Fulk said, "You have people who tell you they voted it for it last time, they'll vote for it again, then you check and they're not registered."
Richard Capuano, the owner of the Donut Kettle here, says his customers aren't talking about the Presidential candidates, they're talking about the levy. So he invited them to his shop one night not long ago for a get-together with Perry school officials, sweetened by free cream sticks, powdered jellies and coffee. "I expected the place would be jammed," he said.
More school officials showed than citizens. The few who came, like Roland Arnold, a retired Republic steelworker, complained about teacher salaries, and said a freeze was not enough, there should be salary rollbacks. "Why pay more for a master's?" Mr. Arnold said. "It actually don't make a better teacher. What does a third grade teacher need with a master's?"
Jim Johnson, who has 26 years as a steelworker at Timken, said: "Myself, I'd like to see the checks and tallysheets. You can't expect the retired people to use their savings to pay taxes."
Mr. Arnold asked, "Why don't you put out some programs explaining this?"
Ken Hartwick, the superintendent said the district had put out 15 programs and fliers. "I never seen one," Mr. Arnold said.
They wanted to know why the public schools had to pay for students to be bused to private schools like Massillon Christian School. The superintendent said it was required by law, but Mr. Johnson shook his head and asked, "Why doesn't their parents take them?"
They wanted to know how often the schools bought new books. When Mr. Hartwick said the state recommends changing every five to seven years, Mr. Johnson said, "Books don't change that much."
On the way out, Mr. Arnold was stopped by a reporter and asked how he planned to vote. "You with the newspaper?" he asked. "I'll probably vote for it."
 
An American Place
Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades.

Clinton to Seek Tax Cuts, But Not on Capital Gains
President Clinton, presenting his 1997 budget to Congress today, will call for $100 billion in tax cuts during the next five years -- notably a tax credit of as much as $500 for families with at least one young child, and a deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition and other degree programs -- while making business bear the brunt of the cost of those breaks. [Page A1.]
 
Capital gains taxes, in effect, would rise under the Administration plan. Rather than cut the gains tax as Republicans have demanded, the Administration would close what it sees as loopholes. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]
 
G.M. Strike a Brake on the Midwest
Government and private economists said that the 13-day-old strike at two G.M. brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, had delivered the worst blow to the Midwest economy since the floods of 1993. The strike has cut the nation's output of goods and services by as much as $7 billion. Because of the brake shortage, G.M. has laid off 150,050 workers. [A1.]
 
Chrysler's chief, Robert J. Eaton, complained of the "demonization of corporate America" by politicians and news organizations, telling the Economic Club of Detroit, "Downsizing and layoffs are part of the price of becoming more competitive." [D4.]
 
Regulators Focus on Bad Brokers
Securities regulators announced a new effort to rid the securities industry of bad brokers. "You only have to hire a few clowns to make the industry look like a circus," Arthur Levitt Jr., the S.E.C. chairman, said. [D2.]
 
Leslie Fay to Spin Off Sassco
Leslie Fay Companies decided to spin off the Sassco unit to creditors, rather than sell it to a management group led by Sassco's president and founder, Arthur S. Levine. [D22.]
 
2 Scientists Cite Philip Morris
The F.D.A. released affidavits of two former Philip Morris research scientists detailing the company's efforts to study nicotine's appeal to smokers. A former executive testified that the company added tobacco byproducts to raise nicotine to specified levels. The company's shares fell $4.125 to $91.25. [A18.]
 
Gasoline Additive Shunned
The Environmental Defense Fund announced that some large petroleum companies had said they had no plans to use a controversial ethyl additive that raises gasoline octane. [D5.]
 
TCI to Buy Knight-Ridder Interest
Knight-Ridder agreed to sell Tele-Communications Inc. its 50 percent share of a jointly owned cable company. TCI will pay about $400 million in cash and stock and will assume more than $400 million in debt for Knight-Ridder's cable holdings. [D7.]
 
Elan to Acquire Athena
The Elan Corporation, an Irish company specializing in drug delivery technology, said it would acquire Athena Neurosciences for stock valued at $625 million. [D2.]
 
Boeing to Raise Aircraft Output
Boeing said it would increase production of its 737, 747 and 757 jetliners next year, reflecting the continued rebound in demand for commercial aircraft. Boeing shares rose $4.75 to $85.625, a 52-week high, on the New York Stock Exchange. [D4.]
 
Latin American Arms Sales Up
With industrialized nations cutting back on military expenditures, some 400 companies from 43 countries participated in Chile's 1996 International Air and Space Show, seeking a share of the increasingly important $2 billion Latin American weapons market. [D6.]
 
Time Warner's Head Softens Stand
Gerald M. Levin, Time Warner's chairman, testified that he was willing to consider putting part of Turner Broadcasting System, except its Cable News Network, into Time Warner's troubled partnership with U S West, which is suing to block Time Warner's planned acquisition of Turner. [D7.]

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Panel Backs Longer Benefits

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The State Senate Appropriations Committee yesterday voted to extend unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 32 1/2 weeks to win support from labor leaders for a plan to solve the impasse on the financing of hospital care for uninsured New Jerseyans. The bill would allow the state to continue tapping into the unemployment insurance fund for so-called charity care for the next two years, but would cut financing from its 1995 level of $400 million to $275 million. Since the most recent charity-care financing plan expired on Dec. 31, the state has missed two $33 million payments to repay hospitals for treating the uninsured.

HEADLINE: Clothing Donations Go First to U.S. Poor, Not Africa Market;
Displaced Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Clothes You Gave Away Are a Hot Item in Africa" (news article, March 14): The job opportunities that this trade in discarded clothing provides for low-income people is at the expense of Africans who used to have better jobs in local textile and clothing manufacturing. 
 The Kenyan Government's restrictions on the importation of "mutumba," or bales of used clothing, is an attempt to protect livelihoods and to stanch the flow of capital from that third-world economy to the more vibrant economies of Europe and North America.
If devastation of African economies and obstruction of the difficult path toward African self-sufficiency is the price that American charities feel is appropriate to pay, they should reconsider the use of the term "charity."
 
MAURA GATENSBY
Vancouver, Canada, March 14, 1996

HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Land Decree Is Illegal and Risky

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"With Land Sale Edict, Yeltsin Opens Way to Longed-For Era" (front page, March 17) is in error regarding what was accomplished. 
 President Boris N. Yeltsin created a constitutional crisis with his decree. According to the Constitution -- the one he wrote -- land rights are a subject of federal law, not presidential decree. The legislature has gone to court to have the decree annulled.
When the land code got its first reading last summer, the deputies endorsed it only after "freezing" Chapter 17, on the land market. Its details were to be debated this spring, the intention being to consider if land should be leased, Hong Kong-style, or sold outright.
But the bill approved in the summer was surreptitiously replaced by a different draft, presented by the Agrarian Committee on Nov. 14. This new draft left only one option: the "capitalist" land market.
When the new legislature convened in January, the shenanigans were discovered. The Natural Resources Committee intervened and the original draft was restored. Four days later, Mr. Yeltsin intervened with his unconstitutional act.
The Natural Resources Committee deputy chairman, Vyachislav Zvolinsky, has asked me, Ramsey Clark and others to testify for the legislature to help prepare a land law calling for leasing. Under today's conditions, sales or mortgages would involve substantial fraud and pave the way for loading down Russia's land with mortgage debt, leading to widespread insolvency and a foreign exchange drain.
 
MICHAEL HUDSON
New York, March 18, 1996
 
The writer is a research associate at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College.

HEADLINE: New York Plans to Stop Investing In Tobacco

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall announced today that he would stop investing state pension funds in tobacco stocks.
But to the dismay of antismoking groups, Mr. McCall said he would not completely sell off tobacco company stocks from the $74.5 billion fund's portfolio. 
 Mr. McCall said his concerns were economic rather than moral or social. He maintained that increasing legal and political attacks on the tobacco industry have raised questions about the risks of investing in tobacco companies.
"My actions today are not meant to conduct public policy through the investment process," said Mr. McCall, who is the state fund's sole trustee. "My actions are intended to prudently limit the fund's exposure to risk for the nearly one million retirees and members of the fund."
New York's pension fund is the second largest in the nation, after California's, covering 850,000 current and retired workers. It has $636 million invested in Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco and American Brands, among others.
Mr. McCall's decision highlights the broad pressures that tobacco companies are coming under, from Congressional scrutiny of industry practices to government bans on smoking in public places.
It is also an attempt by Mr. McCall to allay the concerns of anti-tobacco groups, which have been pressuring the state to divest itself of tobacco holdings.
Still, Mr. McCall can hardly afford to give up all the fund's tobacco stocks because they have been extremely profitable in recent years. Between 1985 and 1994, the fund earned $624 million from its tobacco investments, according to the Comptroller's office.
Mr. McCall said he would continue to monitor the impact that regulatory and legal actions against the tobacco industry have on stock prices.
"Given my fiduciary responsibilities," he said, "my concern about the fund would not be whether it was good for one's health but whether or not this can be a profitable investment."
The decision drew a mixed response from anti-tobacco advocates, who said that Mr. McCall did not go as far as they had hoped he would.
Blair Horner, the legislative director of the New York State Public Interest Group, a government-reform lobby, said the state's profits from tobacco investments pale in comparison to the $2.6 billion spent each year in New York to treat lung cancer, emphysema and other smoking-related illnesses.
"We applaud the fact that the Comptroller is trying to deal with the problem," Mr. Horner said. "But he should have gone a step further. The fact is that the state will continue to invest in companies that cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in health care costs each year."
But Mr. McCall maintained that the state, as a major shareholder of tobacco stock, could pressure tobacco companies to change bad practices, like marketing cigarettes to teen-agers.
"As a major institutional investor," Mr. McCall said in a statement, "I will encourage management to address the underlying causes of the industry's problems."

LENGTH: 1636 words

HEADLINE: Making the Shoe Fit, Perfectly;
Companies Use Technology to Sell to a Market of One

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
When the Custom Foot shoe store opens its doors in Westport, Conn., for the first time tomorrow, it may be hard to judge how business is going: even shoppers making a purchase will be leaving empty-handed.
That's because this is a shoe store without shoes. Well, not exactly -- the store can draw on a potential inventory of more than 10 million pairs, with every style in every possible size. It's just that none of them have been made yet. 
 Instead of trying on shoes until they find some that fit reasonably well, shoppers at Custom Foot will have their feet scanned electronically, with the scanner capturing even the slight differences in size and width that typically distinguish the right foot from the left. The data will be transmitted to factories in Italy, where the shoes will be made to order and delivered in about two weeks. The price? An average of about $140, comparable to high-quality mass-produced shoes but well below the $500 or more that a handmade pair usually commands.
The store on Main Street in the affluent commuter suburb is the latest -- and in some ways most ambitious -- experiment in what marketing experts call "mass customization." This seemingly contradictory term describes the process of using computers, flexible manufacturing techniques and sophisticated marketing approaches to narrowly target products and services to the needs of the individual buyer.
Mass customization gives individual customers "exactly what they want, without creating overwhelming choice complexity or pushing costs up to the point that a company prices itself out of the market," Christopher W. Hart, a consultant who is president of the Spire Group in Brookline, Mass., said.
Some electronics products, such as computers made by Dell and Gateway 2000 and pagers made by Motorola, have been mass-customized for several years, with customers specifying the types of components to be used or the features desired. Large trucks are mostly custom built as well, with buyers detailing the type of engine, transmission and other major components to be included.
Mass customization is also catching on in the service sector. By studying demographics and individual credit histories, some financial services companies now offer customized deals for credit cards, for instance, varying the interest rates, credit limits and other terms, customer by customer. And certain luxury hotel chains, like Ritz-Carlton, compile detailed lists of each client's likes and dislikes. A traveler who registers at any Ritz-Carlton anywhere in the world does not have to ask for a nonsmoking room, a nonallergenic pillow or her favorite newspaper; her desires are already known.
But it is one thing to keep track of individual tastes or make a product from standard parts taken off the shelf. It is quite another to make something fit as snug as, well, a shoe.
"Clothing is a sterner test because everybody is unique," B. Joseph Pine 2d, the president of Strategic Horizons Inc., a consulting company in Ridgefield, Conn., said.
Levi Strauss & Company has been selling custom-fit jeans at its Original Levis stories, including those in New York, for more than a year, but the measurements are done by hand. By relying on an electronic scanner, the Custom Foot takes fashion customization to the next level in holding out the prospect of a more perfect fit.
"Mass customization is the wave of the future," said an enthusiastic Jeffrey Silverman, president of the store's parent company, the Measurably Better Corporation, and a veteran of the shoe business. The company, also of Westport, plans to open other Custom Foot stores in the next few months at the Short Hills Mall in Millburn, N.J., the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, L.I., and the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.
Whether shoppers will be similarly enthusiastic is not yet known, of course. For one thing, how exact the fit will be is not clear, since the shoes will not be made, as true custom-made products are, by craftsmen who work on them from start to finish. Instead, these shoes will be made on an assembly line whose equipment is fine-tuned to the specifications captured by the scanners.
Some marketing specialists also caution that the two-week wait for delivery may slow sales, particularly to customers who like the instant satisfaction of walking out the door with their purchases.
"This may be an idea whose time is not here yet," John Deighton, an associate professor at the Harvard Business School said. "Delay is the No. 1 enemy of impulse shopping."
But in the limited tests so far, customers, particularly women, have shown they are willing to pay a little more and wait a while to get clothes that really fit. Levi Strauss drew widespread attention in 1994 when it introduced its Personal Pair jeans for women, even though they cost $15 more than regular jeans and involve a wait of two to three weeks.
"In the focus group studies we've done, we found that women were very eager to get made-to-measure clothing at ready-to-wear prices," said Peter N. Butenhoff, the president of the Textile/Clothing Technology Corporation, an apparel research organization. "And they said they would be willing to wait up to two weeks to get the garments."
In fact, the textile research group is developing a system that uses a body scanner, computerized pattern modification and high-speed, single-ply fabric cutting to produce customized clothing in a factory, rather than at a tailor's store. The intention is to produce custom clothes at prices close to off-the-rack with an acceptable wait.
"It is our belief that it should be possible to do most apparel in a week and a man's suit in about two weeks, rather than the six or more weeks that it takes now," Mr. Butenhoff said.
Advocates of mass-customized systems say the approach sharply cuts distribution and handling costs, because almost no inventory is needed. And because every product is sold before it is produced, there is no need for profit-squeezing markdowns to sell slow-moving goods.
Other industries are also bullish on customization.
For example, Mr. Pine reports that a Japanese company, Paris Miki, uses a digital scan of a customer's face to produce a customized eyeglass lens shape to enhance the wearer's appearance. The shape is then used to make a pair of frameless glasses, typically within three days. The glasses are now being test-marketed in Bellevue, Wash. Eventually, the company expects to provide glasses with frames as well.
On another front, the Lutron Electronics Company of Coopersburg, Pa., has developed a family of lighting controls that are customized in a wide variety of shapes, colors and sizes in response to the needs of interior designers.
And auto makers, notably BMW, dream of taking sales prospects on virtual reality "test rides" while they custom-order a vehicle.
Such an approach could free dealers from the hugely expensive need to stock hundreds of cars to meet the different needs and tastes of consumers. It might also eliminate the need for high-pressure sales tactics to "move the iron" that is already on the dealer's lot.
A virtual reality simulator could change the whole car-buying experience, Mr. Hart of the Spire Group said.
"Imagine 'feeling' the performance differential of different engine options," he wrote in a paper describing the approach. "How about 'seeing' the different color options on the model you are interested in. Want to take a drive down the California coast? Just a moment while I push a few buttons. Want a premium stereo built into the car, as opposed to spending $2,000 at an after-market stereo shop? No problem."
Nothing quite so dramatic will greet shoppers at the Custom Foot, a modest, 850-square-foot store with shoe samples on the walls. Once the customizing concept has been explained by salespeople, interested customers will don white socks for the measurement process.
Two silhouette views are taken of each foot, from the bottom and from the side, generating 13 measurements for each foot.
Mr. Silverman describes the system as "about 10 percent technology" with the rest of the effort focused on marketing and customer handling. As the system was originally designed, for example, only the operator of the scanning device could see the computerized image of the customer's feet on a video screen. But an early test found that customers also wanted to watch. So now a separate monitor faces the seated customer.
After the scan, customers go to another terminal in the store to pick colors, styles, types of leather and other features and to check the price.
At the end of the day, the foot scan information and consumer choices for each order are to be sent to Measurably Better's nearby corporate office and then forwarded to its office in Florence. From there, the order data are distributed to the seven factories signed up to produce the shoes.
In addition to being able to produce custom shoes at close to off-the-shelf prices, the system allows the company to respond more quickly to changes in fashion, Mr. Silverman said. "Most Italian factories started working on shoes for the fall of 1996 a year ago, and American companies start 18 months in advance," he said. "I can go from a new style to shoes in the store in four weeks."
But what if the customer gets cold feet when the shoes arrive from Italy? After all, this will still be the first time the buyer tries on the shoes.
No problem, Mr. Silverman says, pointing to the store's guarantee to take back any pair, no questions asked.
But what happens then to an expensive product that has been made for one person, and one person only? Mr. Silverman says the rejected shoes will be donated to charity, where the intended recipients may be more willing to make a stretch.

 Several companies have adopted a precess of "mass customization," in which products and services are narrowly targeted to the demands of a specific customer. Unlike pure custom work, this is done without creating overwhelming complexity or dramatically pushing up costs.
 
JEANS -- Levi Strauss makes jeans to a woman's individual measurements.
 
NEWS -- Individual, Inc. scans 600 news sources to compile a different report for each customer.
 
HOTELS -- Ritz-Carlton records customer preferences in a central data base available to all hotels.
 
COMPUTERS -- Dell Computer uses software to translate buyer preferences into components for tailor-made machines.
 
LIGHTING -- Lutron Electronics makes custom lighting systems in a variety of shapes, colors and sizes.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Strong Start, But Bonds Back Down

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bonds gave up an initial gain and were little changed yesterday as investors debated whether a jump in oil prices and signs of stronger economic growth would bring about an increase in inflation.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 5/32, to 90 28/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 6.71 percent. 
 "It looks like the economy is going to do a little better, and there are some things, like rising oil and other commodity prices, that suggest inflation will start to grow a little bit," said Denny Niedringhaus, who manages $300 million in bonds for Southwest Bank of St. Louis. "We could see bond yields over 7 percent this year."
Not so, other investors said. "I still think we'll see lower interest rates sometime over the next 6 to 12 months," said Jan Terbrueggen, who manages $1 billion in bonds for Flagship Financial in Dayton, Ohio, adding that yields were likely to fall back to 6 percent.
Pat Sheehan, who manages $4.5 billion at Smith Barney Asset Management, said that he saw no reason for yields to be as high as they were. "It's still a low-growth, low-inflation environment," he said.
The debate boils down to whether inflation, which erodes the value of bonds, will head higher this year; it has slowed since 1990. The prices of consumer goods last year climbed 2.5 percent, after 2.7 percent increases in both 1994 and 1993.
In one sign that economic growth and inflation could soon pick up speed, the price of oil jumped $1.07 a barrel yesterday, to $24.34, the highest since January 1991, when the Persian Gulf war began.
Recent signs of growth also include the jump in employment last month. In February, 705,000 jobs were added to payrolls, the biggest one-month increase since 1983.
Bonds initially gained yesterday after the Government said housing starts rose 3 percent in February, to an annual rate of 1.49 million. Economists, on average, had expected a 2.6 percent drop.
Analysts attributed much of the rise in February to a recovery from the depressing effect of snowstorms in the Northeast during December and January. Also, the Government cut its figure for January's gain in housing starts to 1.5 percent from the initial estimate of 4.4 percent.
To some traders, the bond market's behavior recently has supported the view that investors will need striking confirmation that inflation and economic growth are not accelerating before they will buy more fixed-income securities. "The market is reading bad news anywhere it can," said John Fath, a trader at Nationsbanc Capital Markets in New York.
Treasury yields, the benchmarks for borrowing costs on everything from credit cards to corporate loans, have risen sharply, reflecting expectations that a rebounding economy will keep the Federal Reserve from cutting rates next week at its next policy meeting. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds has risen about three-fourths of a percentage point this year.
The average rate for a 30-year mortgage climbed to 7.83 percent in the week that ended March 15 from 7.38 percent the previous week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Yesterday, Treasuries with shorter terms than the 30-year bond also showed little movement. The discount rate on the three-month bill rose to 5.04 percent from 5.03 percent, a bond-equivalent yield of 5.19 percent. The six-month bill's discount rate also rose a basis point, to 5.05 percent, for a yield of 5.27 percent.
The price of the three-year note was unchanged at 97 14/32, for a yield of 5.97 percent. The price of the five-year note was also unchanged, at 97 26/32, for a yield of 6.14 percent. The yield on two-year notes held steady at 5.85 percent.

HEADLINE: Measuring the New Clinton

 BODY:
If voters were choosing between the Bill Clinton who ran for office in 1992 and the President who issued his budget plan for 1997 yesterday they would find enormous differences. That is not surprising, given that the political landscape has changed so sharply. As the Republicans have gained strength, the President has retreated from some of the core principles and programs he once embraced. One can complain that Mr. Clinton has made some regrettable concessions, but in a broad sense he had to retreat.
Even so, the choice this year is not between the old Clinton and the new Clinton. It is between Mr. Clinton's watered-down budget and Bob Dole's even worse budget plans that were blocked by the White House. 
 The broad outlines of Mr. Clinton's concessions have been known for months. Some of his ideas to balance the budget in seven years are fanciful. He would cut spending largely after leaving office, in 2002, and would cut taxes only temporarily while he is in office. Political reality suggests that Congress will do the opposite by reneging on the huge spending cuts when they come due and by extending tax cuts in 2000, an election year. A balanced budget is not in the offing.
Some of the budget-cutting is misguided. The President reneges on his 1992 campaign promise to boost spending on training, education and scientific research by $20 billion a year. In this budget, public investment barely stays ahead of inflation. The only answer to inner-city blight is a modest embrace of an unproven idea -- tax cuts for businesses that locate in urban ghettos. The plan makes little effort to reform the politically charged Medicare program. But the worst concession to the Republicans is the plan's embrace of a five-year limit on cash assistance to welfare enrollees. Mr. Clinton proposed time limits two years ago, but in those days he also proposed providing public-sector jobs to parents who could not find work on their own, an idea he has now abandoned.
Mr. Clinton's budget for education and training is inadequate, but it is far better than the G.O.P. plan to cut these programs by about $30 billion and cut science programs by 30 percent by 2002. On welfare, Mr. Clinton, unlike the G.O.P., would preserve federally guaranteed Medicaid and welfare payments. He would also provide vouchers that welfare enrollees could use to buy housing and some other necessities for their children after they hit the five-year time limit on cash benefits.
The Republicans want an unwarranted cut in taxes on capital gains -- the profit from selling stocks and other investments -- but Mr. Clinton wants to close loopholes that allow wealthy investors to evade this tax. The Republicans want the Environmental Protection Agency to largely disappear. Mr. Clinton wants to increase its enforcement budget by more than 20 percent.
Many analysts dismiss the President's budget as an irrelevancy because the Republican-controlled Congress will not give it a second look. But budgets, especially with seven-year horizons, are more a statement about priorities than policy. There is much to be learned from the document issued yesterday. Mr. Clinton's policies are far from what he promised four years ago. But they are also far better than what Mr. Dole and his colleagues have in mind.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Lower, With Dow Falling 14.09

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market took a breather yesterday, with prices lower after Monday's record-setting performance.
"There was a little bit of profit taking, but that was not surprising after the Dow went up almost 100 points the previous day," said Richard C. Pell, chief investment officer of Bank Julius Baer. "And the big story was Philip Morris." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average -- which rose 98.63 points, to an all-time closing high of 5,683.60 on Monday -- slipped 14.09 points yesterday, to 5,669.51. Philip Morris, which fell 4 7/8, to 86 3/8, accounted for the Dow's overall decline by itself.
Other key market indexes fell by even smaller amounts. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks eased 0.96 point, to 651.69, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.92 points, to 1,112.50.
Market breadth, though, was positive on the New York Stock Exchange, with advancing issues outnumbering decliners, 1,295 to 1,090. Turnover on the Big Board rose slightly, to 440.1 million shares, from 437.1 million shares Monday and well ahead of the three-month daily average of about 420 million.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that housing starts rose 3 percent last month to the highest annual rate in more than a year. This news helped to push bond prices down; the 30-year Treasury bond was off 5/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, inched up to 6.71 percent, from 6.70 percent on Monday.
"The rotation among stock groups, which has been the pattern in the last couple of weeks, continued," Mr. Pell said. "People moved towards cyclical stocks and away from defensive issues."
Tobacco companies, led by Philip Morris, were once again buffeted by liability concerns, following disclosures on Monday by former workers in statements to the Food and Drug Administration detailing research into nicotine's attraction to smokers. RJR Nabisco fell 1 3/8, to 29 3/4; American Brands dropped 1/2, to 43 1/4; and UST declined 1 1/8, to 31 5/8.
Technology stocks were hit by a selloff after scoring gains in recent sessions. I.B.M. closed at 121 3/4, down 2 7/8; Hewlett-Packard closed at 101 1/4, down 1 3/4; Digital Equipment closed at 67 1/4, down 2, and Silicon Graphics closed at 25 1/8, down 3/4.
In contrast, airline stocks surged higher and the Dow Jones transportation average advanced 30.46 points, to a record of 2,215.21. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, forecast better-than-expected profits for the first quarter and jumped 8 7/8, to 213 1/8. Delta Air Lines increased 2 1/8, to 82, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 3/4, to 91 3/4.
Oil services companies gained as the price of crude oil climbed to more than $24 a barrel. Schlumberger closed at 78 1/4, up 3/4; Rowan closed at 11 3/4, up 3/4, and Helmerich & Payne closed at 33 7/8, up 1/4.
The auto sector, composed of economically sensitive stocks, was generally strong. Chrysler rose 1 5/8, to 63 1/2, andGeneral Motors advanced 1 1/4, to 54 1/4. But Ford Motor slid 1/4, to 33 5/8.
Also finishing lower was Walt Disney, which slumped 1 7/8, to 65. McDonald's, a typical defensive stock, gave up 1 3/4, to 50 3/8. And Pacific Telesis dropped 1 1/8, to 26 3/8, amid investor worry over its ability to increase earnings and continue to pay its current dividend.

HEADLINE: Fight Over Picking Up Tab For S.&L. Bailout Renewed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The savings-and-loan crisis may have passed, but the fight over who picks up the bill rages on.
Six and a half years after Congress passed sweeping legislation to clean up $150 billion in losses from a decade of mismanagement and fraud at the nation's savings and loans, savings institutions and their commercial bank competitors are arguing anew over how much responsibility each industry has to make up a share of the losses. 
 At stake is not just the cost to financial institutions, but the growing possibility of default on $8.2 billion of bonds issued by the Financing Corporation, an arm of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which was established in 1987 to help pay for an early bailout package. And in the long run, Federal regulators including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned in testimony to the House Banking committee today, the hard-won stability of the savings-and-loan industry and of its deposit-insurance fund could be undermined.
The survivors of the financial carnage in the savings industry are now very healthy, and though regulators said another recession could create some problems, no one is worried about systemic failures.
Rather, regulators said, the main problem now is that savings institutions are forced under terms of the bailout package to pay hefty premiums into the industry's depleted deposit-insurance fund, while banks pay little or nothing into their industry's fund. As a result, healthy savings institutions are moving deposits into affiliates that qualify as banks.
Because the bank insurance fund is fully capitalized, healthy banks now pay only a token $2,000 a year into their fund.
Savings institutions, by contrast, pay 23 cents for each $100 of deposits into their deposit-insurance fund. That means an institution with $100 million in deposits -- relatively small by industry standards -- would pay $230,000 a year.
As the amount of deposits covered by the savings industry's insurance fund declines, so does the total of premiums the fund takes in. The remaining savings institutions will probably tend to be those with a higher risk of financial problems, the regulators said, potentially putting more strain on the fund.
In total, the savings industry's fund is required to have $1.25 on hand for every $100 of deposits held by the industry, but at the end of last year had only 47 cents for every $100.
Indeed, the fund has only $3.4 billion in it. That's a little more than a third of the reserves it is supposed to have -- and a level that the Treasury said could be wiped out by the failure of a single large savings institution or several medium-sized ones.
Not only is the fund left badly undercapitalized, but because nearly half of the premium income is used to pay holders of the Financing Corporation bonds, regulators said that the risk of the fund defaulting on the bonds was also increasing.
"We're looking at a deteriorating process where as healthy institutions leave, then the burden falls on, by definition, less healthy institutions," Mr. Greenspan said. "It's a cumulative downward spiral which seems to me inevitable in the long run, although the time frame is difficult to judge."
Asked at the hearing by Representative Bill McCollum, a Florida Republican, whether time was of the essence in dealing with the problem, Mr. Greenspan replied, "Unquestionably."
A measure passed last year with support from both parties and the White House was meant to solve the problem. But the measure was attached to the vetoed balanced-budget bill, making the savings-industry legislation the victim of a bigger and more politically charged dispute.
The measure would have charged savings institutions a one-time assessment of $6 billion to lift the insurance fund to its required level. It would also have spread responsibility for paying interest on the bonds across both the banking and savings industries -- a step that commercial banks said would cost them $12 billion in the next 25 years.
With the issue now reopened, banks are lobbying hard against it and their pressure has stalled if not killed efforts to revive last year's legislation.
Citing heavy opposition from banks around the country, James M. Culberson Jr., the president of the American Bankers Association, told the committee: "Bankers are extremely upset with the prospect that having rebuilt their fund at no cost to taxpayers they may be asked to pay approximately $12 billion to help relieve an obligation of one of their principal competitors."
The savings industry's survivors said they were happy to shoulder the heaviest share of recapitalizing their insurance fund and paying interest on the bonds. But they said they should not be held solely responsible, especially since as survivors they constitute the savings industry's most conservatively run institutions.
James F. Montgomery, the chairman of America's Community Bankers, the savings industry's trade group, urged the committee to try again to pass the legislation.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Surged 3% in February

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Builders started work on new homes last month at the highest rate in more than a year as they prepared for a rush of buyers eager to lock in mortgage rates before the rates move higher.
All regions except the Midwest reported increased construction, the Commerce Department said today. The increases pushed national housing starts 3 percent above the January level, to an annual rate of 1.49 million. The February rate is the highest since December 1994, when the rate was 1.51 million. 
 Relatively low mortgage rates, which remain below 8 percent even after a recent rise, and increases in employment are fueling demand for houses, analysts and home builders said. "Job growth is what drives the housing market," said Ted Mahoney, president of Windjammer Construction in Plainville, Mass.
The report "fits the very optimistic tone" reflected in a survey by a home builders' group that was released today, said Raymond Worseck, chief economist with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. The National Association of Home Builders said its housing market index for March jumped 10 points, to 60, the highest level since May 1994.
Mr. Mahoney said the survey was consistent with his experience recently. "I'm sold out," he said. "I put my last house under agreement this weekend."
For the industry as a whole, these are still nervous times. Recent Government figures showed that new-home sales rose 4.2 percent in January, but the supply of new homes for sale rose eight-tenths of a percent, to the highest level in 16 years.
If the economy stumbles and home sales wither in coming months, builders will find themselves saddled with the carrying cost of unsold homes that may require price cuts to sell.
Today's report showed that housing construction was not as strong in January as earlier reported. The January increase was 1.5 percent, not the 4.4 percent that the Government had estimated a month ago.
Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected starts to decline about 2.6 percent in February, as winter storms slowed commerce on the East Coast. In fact, starts in the Northeast recorded the biggest gain, surging 33 percent, to 127,000. Starts increased 5.7 percent in the West, to 425,000, and rose 4.2 percent in the South, to 647,000. The Midwest was the exception, showing a decline of 11.6 percent, to 291,000.
The outlook suggests an acceptable year for housing even though mortgage rates have surged since February, when the rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage averaged 7.08 percent. Last week, the rate was at 7.83 percent, a seven-month high, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That is still relatively low, analysts said. At February's mortgage rate, the average monthly payment on a $100,000 loan was $670.68, up from $667.32 in December. By contrast that payment would have been $822.68 in December 1994, when mortgage rates were at their recent peak of 9.25 percent.
