HEADLINE: Pataki Aide's Claim of Secrecy for Inaugural Funds Is Contradicted

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19

 BODY:
As part of an effort to block the State Assembly's investigation of Gov. George E. Pataki's inaugural fund, a lawyer for the corporation that raised money for the event told a state court today that the names of the contributors would not be turned over to investigators because the donors had been promised secrecy.
But officials with two corporations that gave money to the event said today they were never told of such a policy. 
 Virginia Gold, a spokeswoman for AT&T, which contributed $10,000 to the event, said the solicitation for an inaugural fund-raiser came in a letter from Charles A. Gargano, then the chairman of Mr. Pataki's inaugural committee and now the State Commissioner for Economic Development. Asked if there was any promise of anonymity in the letter or in follow-up phone calls, she said no.
Bob Fauteux, a spokesman for Pfizer Inc., which gave $5,000 for the inaugural, said officials at his company also were not told of any policy of anonymity by inaugural fund-raisers.
In interviews with The New York Times last fall, 16 other companies and individuals acknowledged that they had donated money, goods or services to the inauguration. None said anything about being promised anonymity by N.Y. Inaugural '95, as the fund was called. What is more, the names of more than 50 companies and individuals who contributed services or money to the inaugural were listed in a program given the 13,000 people who attended the Governor's swearing-in ceremony.
N.Y. Inaugural '95 and a sister corporation, N.Y. Transition '95, are the focus of an investigation by the Assembly, whose Democratic leadership has contended that contributors to the two profit-making corporations may have received special favors from the Pataki administration. The Assembly has estimated that the two corporations raised at least $1.4 million, and the court hearing today was to hear the corporation's challenge to the Assembly's subpoenas for records and information about the fund.
Mr. Pataki's supporters established the fund shortly after his election in November 1994 to raise money privately for his transition and lavish three-day inauguration. At the time, Mr. Pataki's aides promised to keep all contributions within state campaign finance limits and to disclose the names of all donors.
But they did neither, first allowing corporations to contribute much more than the $5,000 limit set by state election law for corporate campaign contributions. Then, after repeatedly promising to disclose the identities of contributors, when they received a formal request from The Times last November, they refused.
In November, Mr. Pataki's aides said they were keeping the names secret because they wanted to shield the Governor from knowing who had given to his inauguration. That way, they argued, Mr. Pataki would not feel obligated to help those contributors.
But today, the lawyer, Michael J. Hutter, offered a different reason for keeping the contribution list secret: to protect the contributors. In arguments before Justice Joseph Harris in Supreme Court in Albany, Mr. Hutter said that revealing the names of donors could open them up to harassment or stigmatization by Mr. Pataki's enemies.
In an interview after the hearing, Mr. Hutter said secrecy "was a conscious policy that was explained to contributors." He said he thought that many contributors gave to the corporations because they were told "there was not going to be disclosure."
Mr. Hutter asked Justice Harris to invalidate the Assembly subpoenas for records. Justice Harris did not issue a decision today.
Though he said that people soliciting money for the inaugural were expected to tell all contributors that their names would be kept secret, Mr. Hutter said he could not explain why some contributors did not recall being told of the policy. A spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, Zenia Mucha, said she was not involved in the inaugural corporations and could not comment on its activities.
Asked why Pataki aides kept telling reporters that contributors' names would be disclosed even though the two corporations had established a policy of secrecy, Mr. Hutter replied, "I just don't know what was going on with the second floor," where the Governor's office is in the State Capitol.
Mr. Hutter said officials at the two corporations sent several letters to the Governor's office telling them that the corporations would not release the names.
But when Ms. Mucha, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, was told of Mr. Hutter's comments this evening, she said the Governor's office was never sent any such letters.
Several minutes later, Mr. Hutter revised his account, saying he had been mistaken. The inaugural money had not sent any letters to the Governor's office explaining their policy of secrecy until November, when Ms. Mucha formally announced that the names of donors would not be disclosed. Then, however, she said the secrecy was to protect the Governor and his aides, not the donors.
At today's court hearing, the lawyer for the Assembly Democrats, Evan Davis, told Justice Harris that detailed information about the inauguration was needed to help the Assembly draft legislation to regulate inaugural money.
But he also said it was in the public's interest to know who gave money to the event. "The abuse, or appearance of abuse, we're dealing with here is quid pro quo: give to get," said Mr. Davis, who was a lawyer for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

HEADLINE: Survival Of the Nastiest;
Manhattan Lab Draws Fame For TB Bacteria in Freezer

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
In a ninth-floor laboratory on the East Side of Manhattan, there is a white chest-style storage freezer that is home to some of the nastiest little Darwinian survivalists on the planet. Packed in plastic vials and suspended at 70 degrees below zero centigrade, this is New York City's own private hot zone: the lethal drug-resistant tuberculosis bacteria that flared in the city in the early 1990's came to rest here as the outbreak subsided.
It is one of the largest collections of its kind in the world, with more than 4,500 samples, many of them all but immune to medicine's front-line antibiotics. 
 Nobody wants these bugs. But public health officials, researchers and drug company scientists cannot afford to forget about them. And Dr. Barry N. Kreiswirth has them.
"When scientists think of multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis, they think of New York," Dr. Kreiswirth said.
That is, in fact, the good news and the bad news rolled into one. The city became a point on the map for epidemiologists and bacteria hunters as a place where -- for a complex array of reasons -- tuberculosis began to stir and evolve beyond the reach of traditional medicine. Now, largely because of Dr. Kreiswirth's collection, and his computer database analyzing the bacteria's every genetic nuance, the city has become a kind of tuberculosis research clearinghouse. From a public health crisis has come a new asset.
"It's not exactly a business everybody wants to get into, having a collection of drug-resistant tuberculosis," said Dr. Bruce Montgomery, a senior vice president at Pathogenesis, a Seattle-based pharmaceutical company that has a contract with Dr. Kreiswirth's lab, the TB Center at the Public Health Research Institute, to test antituberculosis drugs. "I haven't heard of a lot of people saying, 'Boy, we need to get that.' But they got there first, and that makes them a big plus for New York science."
How the strains of TB bacteria came to be at an obscure 54-year-old private institute, on First Avenue near 26th Street across from Bellevue Hospital Center, that most New Yorkers have probably never heard of is one part of the story. Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia figures prominently in that tale, believe it or not.
But this is also a detective drama, as Dr. Kreiswirth's researchers, using DNA fingerprinting techniques, have homed in on the New York tuberculosis strains. The institute helped confirm, for example, an early hypothesis by physicians at Columbia University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine who had traced a particular strain to a men's shelter, since closed, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where a mutation in the bacteria apparently occurred in one unknown human host and spread from there. Institute workers call that moment the Big Bang.
There are also some odd economic implications to TB and its treatment, in which the institute again is playing a central role. Tuberculosis, historically one of mankind's great scourges, is today overwhelmingly a disease of the poor, falling heavily among immigrants, intravenous drug users, people with AIDS and third-world populations. Because the number of cases, at least in developed countries like the United States, had been falling for decades through most the 20th century, many drug companies had quietly stopped making TB antibiotics.
But the outbreak in New York City, which in 1991 and 1992 had more multidrug-resistant tuberculosis cases than all the rest of the nation combined, has dramatically refocused attention on the havoc that TB can still bring and the staggering financial costs to a sophisticated, modern medical care system. Since the outbreak began, the total cost in New York City alone has been about $1 billion, mostly from extended hospital stays by patients, according to the city's Health Department estimates.
So far, six companies have sent some of their best drugs to test against Dr. Kreiswirth's worst bugs, and two compounds that arose from those tests, both from Pathogenesis, are now being tested. If the drugs are approved for use, the company specifically hopes to recoup some of the development costs from urban public health agencies that would be prime financial beneficiaries.
"If you had a drug that would shorten the course of therapy or prevent drug resistance," Dr. Montgomery of Pathogenesis said, "the amount of money that drug could save the city of New York would be phenomenal."
The backdrop is that the tuberculosis outbreak in New York has receded. New York City health officials are expected to report on Friday that new TB cases fell in 1995 for the third year in a row, though there are still far more than in the late 1970's, which will probably be remembered as the disease's low ebb in this century.
Dr. Kreiswirth's work is a kind of postscript to that ordeal. But it also is the starting point for what medical researchers say will be a resurgence of the disease sooner or later, although no one really knows when, given the disease's unpredictability. It is a war that Dr. Kreiswirth believes cannot be won. He compares it to the old Mad magazine comic strip, "Spy vs. Spy," in which every move by one spy is counteracted by the other in a never-ending dance. Every new advance by science only pushes the bacteria, among the world's oldest life forms, toward some new evolutionary twist.
"We're training these bugs," Dr. Kreiswirth said. "We're making them better at what they do. They've been around for three and a half billion years and we thought we were going to win? Who were we kidding?"
The disease re-emerged in New York as a close ally to the AIDS virus -- people with weakened immune systems started getting many diseases that had seemed all but conquered. The bacteria evolved into drug-resistant strains partly because patients, many of them homeless, did not continue the months of drug treatment necessary to kill all the bacteria. Taking antibiotics only for a while, or only periodically, killed only some TB bacteria. The survivors could then multiply and spread and were stronger in facing the antibiotic the next time around.
But there are also some profound mysteries. The strain traced to the men's shelter, called the C strain in the institute's nomenclature, can be treated by regular medication. It has not become drug-resistant like the notorious W strain, for example, and yet it has continued to spread, apparently because of some biological advantage that researchers have not been able to pin down.
How the institute built its collection is itself a kind of survival-of-the-fittest story. Founded in 1941 by Mayor La Guardia as a liaison between city health agencies and the academic world, but belonging fully to neither, the institute inhabits a niche all by itself -- no other major American city has anything quite like it, said Jack T. Crawford, chief of diagnostics and molecular epidemiology in the TB section at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.
In late 1991, the institute's odd-duck status -- private but dedicated by its charter to a mission of public health -- paid off. Its president, Lewis M. Weinstein, a nonscientist who is a former chief executive at Kinney System, the parking company, reached out to the corporate community from which he came. Within a year, using more than $1 million in corporate donations, mainly from Pfizer Inc. and Hoffmann-La Roche, the institute's tuberculosis lab was up and running.
Being able to take and test patient samples free of charge got the database going. And once he had the largest database, Dr. Kreiswirth said, it only got easier to get more. The Federal Department of Veterans Affairs, for example, recently agreed to send its TB samples to the institute.
Samples have also arrived for testing from seven countries in South America and Africa. Recent reports in medical journals that some strains associated with the New York outbreak had been diagnosed in other cities around the world are expected to further increase the number of requests for DNA comparison -- and thus provide more samples for the freezer.
Dr. Kreiswirth said the next breakthrough in his TB detective work would come out of the blue, a phone call perhaps from a physician who remembered a weird case years back and just happened to save a sample.
"I'm in search of that historical collection that I know is out there," he said. "Then we can take these questions another 10 years back in time."

Court Lets Workers Sue If Tricked of Benefits
The Supreme Court ruled that workers whose employers trick them into giving up benefits can sue to have the coverage restored. The 6-to-3 decision gave new teeth to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
The case involved former employees of Massey-Ferguson, a subsidiary of Varity, who were encouraged to transfer to a new subsidiary that quickly closed, leaving them without health care coverage. [Page A17.]
 
Will Tobacco Stocks Rise Again?
Philip Morris stock continued to plunge, losing almost $5 yesterday, and it has fallen $20 since a small competitor agreed to settle tobacco litigation. Analysts say that represents a buying opportunity in the company, which also makes products like coffee and beer. But opponents of the tobacco companies state that a fundamental change has occurred. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Executives From Taiwan Worry, but Stay in China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, March 19

 BODY:
Like many Taiwan businessmen who live and work in this city, Chiang Yu-min likes to relax by leaving his steel factory at the outskirts of town to meet friends for a meal at Taipei City or one of the other hip, upscale restaurants that cater to "tai shang," as Taiwan businessmen are known in mainland China.
But it is hard for Mr. Chiang to relax when all his friends are talking about what they see as the possibility of war. 
 "We're nervous every day, so we're used to it," he said, smiling wearily. "None of us really expect war to break out, but it's on our minds all the time."
With Taiwan and China closer to military conflict than they have been in decades, investors from Taiwan are on edge here, torn by two seemingly conflicting actions: China's efforts to encourage investment at the same time that it conducts military exercises near Taiwan just before the presidential election is held on Saturday.
More than 100,000 business executives from Taiwan are believed to be in China. They have brought a surge of investment, some $25 billion, second only to money from Hong Kong and more than from the United States, demonstrating China's economic stake in avoiding a serious showdown over Taiwan.
Most Taiwan businessmen here prefer to focus on the positive, saying that they cannot imagine that any blood will be spilled and that business opportunities are still good. It would be unwise to express political opinion, they say.
But talk of war has highlighted their uncertain status in the mainland, where they are neither foreigners nor natives.
In recent years, China's Government has welcomed executives from Taiwan not just for their investments, but also for the web of personal and financial ties that Chinese leaders suggest will help keep Taiwan, which they consider a renegade province, from becoming too independent.
In blaming its current troubles with Taiwan on President Lee Teng-hui, China favors increased contact with ordinary Taiwan residents.
"Although relations are getting tense and complicated, we want to promote more trade and investment from Taiwan," said Zhang Zhichun, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office in Shanghai. "New investors may hesitate, but the ones already here can see what a good environment it is."
Though that environment has been good in recent years, it is now under threat from the current dispute. Most businessmen seem to doubt that armed conflict will occur, but some express fear that they could lose their stake in the mainland.
"All that has been achieved over the last 5 to 10 years could disappear," said Kent Liu, chairman and general manager of Shanghai Taylor Food Company, which makes ice cream. "If there were a war, the Taiwan economy would collapse, and so would the economy in the coastal areas of China."
Not long ago, anyone from Taiwan visiting China was suspected of being a spy for the Nationalist Government, which fled to the island in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists.
Executives from Taiwan began entering the China market 10 years ago and, by emphasizing common language and ignoring political history, became savvy and aggressive investors. By the end of 1995, they had committed an estimated $25 billion in all kinds of enterprises in China.
But today, with politics threatening to undercut China's prosperity, the Taiwan businessmen occupy a somewhat precarious position: they are insiders, but they do not quite belong.
"The Government has assured us they will protect our rights," said Yang Ta-cheng, chairman of Shanghai's Taiwanese Businessmen's Association. "I believe them. Our interests are deeply intertwined."
Yet Mr. Yang described how, despite having the same language and cultural upbringing as mainlanders, he felt like a complete outsider when he arrived here in 1992, and how it took three years before he got used to living here.
He was welcomed by the Government as a compatriot, but has to pay a higher "foreigner" price in hotels and on airplanes. He was free to head his own company, but cannot speak freely with his staff for fear of political "misunderstandings."
Like many of his colleagues from Taiwan here, Mr. Yang left his wife and children in Taipei, Taiwan's capital, and travels to Taiwan to see them for a few days each month. He is in China to make money.
Chinese officials estimate that there are more than 30,000 companies in China with Taiwan investors, and though no one counts exactly how many Taiwanese live here, Mr. Yang suggested that it could be more than 100,000.
As an indication of the role that Taiwan businesses play in China's economic boom, Mr. Yang estimates that they employ five million people, and perhaps can account indirectly for the employment of another five million.
"That means about 30 million people are living off Taiwan companies," he said, counting children and other unemployed dependents.
Mr. Liu predicts a peaceful resolution to the crisis and says he is so eager for news about it that he reaches for the Taiwan newspapers delivered to his home as soon as he returns from work, irritating his wife with the way he ignores her.
"She doesn't like it," he said, "but I feel like I have to know what is happening. We can't influence politics. All we can do is sit off to the side and talk about it."
Mr. Yang, the businessmen's association chairman, shaking his head in frustration, added: "Everyone wants to stay unified, so why are we even talking about violence? One false move and there could be chaos. This society could come apart."
The tremendous economic growth in Shanghai and other coastal Chinese cities in recent years seems to offer a palpable alternative to such dark thoughts.
Christina Tsui, a housewife, came reluctantly from Taiwan to Shanghai because her husband was already here.
"Of course, I was afraid he'd get a mistress!" she said. After a year of adjustment, she has grown accustomed to living here, she said, in part because her family can maintain a higher standard of living.
"I have three children and four maids," she said. "With a driver and two tutors, that's 10 people I have to supervise. I feel like a general manager."
Mrs. Tsui said that although she and her friends had talked about the political situation a lot recently, she saw no reason why the life she was enjoying in Shanghai should be affected by it.
Simin Huang, a Taiwan restaurateur whose seventh-floor office sits atop a building with a restaurant of different cuisine on each floor, is likewise focusing on the upside. His building, for example, is worth five times what he paid for it four years ago.
"Everyone knows there can't possibly be any real problem," said Mr. Huang, reclining comfortably in a deep leather sofa in his spacious office. "There's too much at stake."
If other investors are hesitating to put any fresh money into China, he said, his company is proceeding with plans to open 400 fast-food outlets in Shanghai within two years.
"I am 100 percent confident," Mr. Huang said.
Of all Taiwan investors in China, he guessed, at least 80 percent are making money. "Among those who came early," he said, meaning three or more years ago, "I'd say 100 percent are making money."
If businessmen like Mr. Huang thrive on such optimism, ignoring the unpredictability of politics and concentrating on the benefits of making money, some transplants from Taiwan are more cautious.
Mr. Chiang, the steel factory manager, said that while business was proceeding well, he regularly encountered bureaucratic and management problems that he never saw in Taiwan. One of his concerns is that he feels he has to watch what he says in conversation with his staff or with local acquaintances.
"Talking about politics is fine as long as you all agree," he said. "As soon as we start to disagree, I know I'd better stop, and I change the subject."

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls For Tax Cuts In New Plan For Budget

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
President Clinton proposed a $1.64 trillion budget today embodying months-old proposals for middle-class tax cuts and slower growth in spending, and he sought to paint the Republican-controlled Congress as the impediment to balancing the Federal budget by 2002.
"We should enact a balanced budget and we should do it now -- not after the November election, not after the political season, not later, but now," Mr. Clinton said in presenting his budget for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. "The American people deserve nothing less. It is the right thing to do." 
 At the same time, Mr. Clinton invited Congressional leaders to the White House for a budget meeting on Wednesday, even though he has been deadlocked with them for months over tax and spending priorities for the current fiscal year, which is half over. The current budgets of nine Cabinet departments and scores of other agencies are still in dispute.
The Republicans promptly responded with withering fire against Mr. Clinton today, blaming him for the deadlock for rejecting their previous plans for balancing the budget, which had tax cuts twice as big as he wants and deeper spending cuts than he supports.
"We passed a balanced budget -- Clinton vetoed it," Speaker Newt Gingrich said. "Who's he kidding? We passed tax cuts -- Clinton vetoed it."
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, sounded a similar note, saying: "The good news about the budget is that at least the President is talking about it again. We've had nine different budget submissions in the last 12 months by the President of the United States. I think it's an American record, probably a world record."
Mr. Dole, who is virtually certain to face Mr. Clinton in the November Presidential election, did say that he would look forward to the meeting on Wednesday if the President was serious. And he offered a small olive branch aimed at resolving Congressional disputes over the pending line-item-veto bill, which Mr. Clinton has long favored and which the Republicans called for in their Contract with America.
Because some Republicans are reluctant to give Mr. Clinton the line-item veto, the power to strike individual items from spending bills, Mr. Dole proposed in a phone call with the President today that the effective date of the measure be delayed until next year. Mr. Clinton agreed.
"If that's the best we can get, that's the best we can get," said the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. "We thought the Contract on America applied to this session of Congress, but the President would like to have that power, and he's delighted that it looks more likely that he'll have it for a second term."
Budgets are always the tangible financial outlines of a politician's political priorities, but, more than most, Mr. Clinton's is an almost purely political exercise this year. It has about $100 billion in tax cuts for the middle class, proposes the closing of some corporate tax loopholes and vows to protect programs for education, the environment and the elderly.
The bulk of the proposals Mr. Clinton re-announced today have been the core of his domestic agenda since December 1994, when, after the Republican Congressional sweep, he revived his 1992 campaign promise of middle-class tax relief.
Virtually all those proposals -- new tax deductions for college education, a $500 tax credit for families with children and the like -- have lain dormant with Congress, though not, the White House believes, with the electorate, so Mr. Clinton amplified his views once again, on the eve of the general election campaign.
"After a lot of hard work," Vice President Al Gore said, "he and his team have managed to balance the budget without unbalancing our values." Mr. Clinton stood by Mr. Gore's side at a White House briefing that was chock-full of such sound bites. "This plan recognizes that Government cannot do everything, but that it must do some things," Mr. Gore added.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, spending would rise about 4 percent above the estimated $1.57 trillion the Government will spend this year. A handful of agencies would receive much more. At the Justice Department, spending would increase nearly 14 percent in an effort to counter drugs, violent crime, terrorism and illegal immigration.
But Republicans were underwhelmed, making it clear that they held out little hope for resolving disputes over the current year's budget, much less a quick agreement on next year's, or over the broader plan to cut taxes and spending and balance the budget over the next seven years.
"We're going to study it carefully," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee. "Maybe there's something we can work together on. But it's very, very difficult when the President gives a State of the Union address bragging about how he's going to make Government smaller, and in an election year it still grows."
Part of the Republicans' ire reflects the reality that Mr. Clinton has not accepted some of their major priorities, like a cut in the capital gains tax. In fact, he proposes to require investors selling stocks to compute their profits based on the average cost of the shares they hold in a specific company. That would keep them from holding down their taxes by claiming that they are selling the shares that originally cost them the most, which would minimize their gains.
In all, Mr. Clinton would also raise about $44 billion over seven years by eliminating what his budget describes as unwarranted tax benefits, most of them for corporations. His plan would restrict multinational corporations' ability to reduce their United States taxes with taxes paid to foreign governments.
But Mr. Clinton's proposal today also shows once again how far he has moved toward accepting many of the Republicans' other conditions, like their calls to balance the budget in seven years, rein in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid spending (although he would limit that less severely than the Republicans) and cut taxes.

HEADLINE: THE BALKAN PEACE: THE PENTAGON;
Pentagon Report Predicts Bosnia Will Fragment Without Vast Aid

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The Pentagon has offered its grimmest assessment of the prospects for peace in Bosnia to date, warning that without an enormous international aid program to rebuild its economy and political institutions, the country will probably fragment after the withdrawal of NATO peacekeeping troops late this year.
The assessment for the Senate Intelligence Committee was prepared by the Pentagon's senior intelligence analyst, Lieut. Gen. Patrick M. Hughes, and it could signal an effort by the Defense Department to distance itself from blame if the civil war resumes shortly after the NATO withdrawal. 
 General Hughes, the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, offered reassuring words in his report for American troops stationed in Bosnia, suggesting that NATO forces face no organized military threat. If the war resumes, he said, it will not be until after the American peacekeepers and their NATO allies have pulled out.
But the report, dated Feb. 22, offered no similar solace for the people of Bosnia. General Hughes said that the "prospects for the existence of a viable, unitary Bosnia beyond the life" of the NATO deployment are "dim" without a large international program to revive Bosnia's war-shattered economy.
If his assessment is accurate, the peace effort in Bosnia could well be doomed, since the civilian reconstruction effort there is barely under way and its economy and physical infrastructure -- roads, water and electricity lines, telephones -- are still in ruins. The last American soldiers are scheduled to withdraw from Bosnia in December.
General Hughes said that the strategic goals of the warring factions in the region "have not fundamentally changed" since the days of the civil war and that tensions among them would probably grow in the months leading up to the NATO pullout.
If that is true, the Clinton Administration might come under intense pressure from its NATO allies not to withdraw American troops by the end of December -- a deadline that the Administration insists it will hold to.
The Pentagon assessment also implicity questions basic elements of the American-brokered Dayton peace agreement, which laid out what critics in Congress called unrealistic deadlines for political and economic reconstruction in Bosnia and for the withdrawal of peacekeeping troops.
"There's only so much our soldiers can accomplish," said another senior Defense Department official, echoing the report's central findings. "The military forces agreed to keep the peace for a year, and that's what we're doing. But this peace will not hold without an effort to rebuild the country. That's not being done yet. And that's not our job."
The job of organizing the economic and political reconstruction of Bosnia has been left to a European delegation led by Carl Bildt, a former Swedish Prime Minister.
But Mr. Bildt has complained repeatedly in recent months that foreign governments have been slow to make available the billions of dollars needed for civilian reconstruction -- everything from building bridges to printing election ballots -- and that the political component of the peace effort is lagging far behind its military component.
In a meeting this month with donor countries, he pleaded that the donors "do more to honor the pledges we have made."
While questioning whether Bosnia was about to dissolve once again into civil war, General Hughes said in his report that "in the short term, we are optimistic" about the situation faced by the 18,400 American soldiers stationed there as part of the peacekeeping force.
"We believe that the former warring factions will continue to generally comply with the military aspects" of the peace accord, the report said. "We do not expect U.S. or allied forces to be confronted by organized military resistance."
The threat faced by the American forces would come instead from land mines "and from various forms of random, sporadic low-level violence," the report said. "This could include high-profile attacks by rogue elements or terrorists." So far only one American soldier has been killed in Bosnia, an Army sergeant who was killed in an explosion on Feb. 3 as he tried to defuse a land mine.
The report suggested that if the civil war resumes, it will flare up only after the NATO forces have pulled out, removing the buffer that has kept the factions at peace for most of the last four months.
"The overall strategic political goals of the former warring factions have not fundamentally changed," General Hughes said. "Without a concerted effort by the international community, including substantial progress in the civil sector to restore economic viability and to provide for conditions in which national (federation) political stability can be achieved, the prospects for the existence of a viable, unitary Bosnia beyond the life of IFOR are dim." The NATO forces in Bosnia are known as the implementation force, or IFOR.
General Hughes suggested that all of the fragile alliances created by the peace accord might collapse -- with tensions between the Bosnian Muslims and Bosnian Croats threatening their federation, with the Bosnian Croats working toward "de facto integration" with Croatia, and with elections and the resettlement of refugees "delayed or stymied."
He said that the Bosnian Serbs were likely to consolidate their hold on their own territory, seeking "some form of political confederation" with Serbia.
Questions about whether any peace in Bosnia would outlast the presence of NATO troops -- and whether American troops would be stuck there if it did not -- were at the heart of the debate in Congress that preceded votes to authorize the American military deployment. Senator Bob Dole, the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, demanded and won an Administration pledge to play a role in arming and training the Bosnian Government's army.
The assessment by the Defense Intelligence Agency is only slightly more pessimistic than remarks heard elsewhere in the Pentagon. Senior Defense Department officials have long warned that the peace would fail without a huge effort to rebuild Bosnia and to give the people some hope of economic and political stability after years of slaughter.
"Ultimately I think the bigger problem is not the military implementation of the peace agreement," Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the House National Security Committee this month. "We need to make sure we understand that it is equally important to the overall effort -- and also to the safety of the troops -- that we get on with the civilian functions that need to be performed."
"And when I say 'we,' I don't mean the military, but the nations that are involved in this effort," he added.
"The elections have to go forward, the refugees have to begin to return, reconstruction has to start, the infrastructure has to be rebuilt so that the people in the country can see an advantage to not fighting."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
USAir's terminal at La Guardia comes in second in a poll ranking airport concession programs.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
WITH short runways, inadequate parking space and its location in the heart of a busy city, New York's La Guardia Airport wins few accolades from passengers or pilots. But the USAir terminal at La Guardia tied for second place with Portland, Ore., International Airport in a recent poll ranking airport concession programs. USAir's operation at Pittsburgh International finished first.
In the poll, airport executives, concessionaires and consultants were asked to rank the top three airports in the country with the best retail services, including concept mix, physical layout, design and theme. All three winning airports are among the growing number that charge "street prices" in their retail stores. 
 The poll was conducted by World Airport Retail News, an aviation industry newsletter.
 
Giveaways and Discounts
Travelers appreciate discounts and getting something for nothing, so an increasing number of hotels and airlines are using such promotions to call attention to themselves.
Inter-Continental Hotels and Resorts, for example, is celebrating its 50th anniversary by giving away two solid gold bars, worth $12,500 each, to winners in a promotion running in 27 cities in the Americas, from Buenos Aires to Washington.
The sweepstakes runs through Oct. 15, 1996, and is open even to people who do not stay at an Inter-Continental. However, frequent guests will be entered automatically each time they stay. Inter-Continental, which is owned by the Saison Group of Japan, has 177 hotels in 67 countries.
Cathay Pacific is not giving away gold bars, but it is allowing members of American Airlines' AAdvantage frequent-flier program to bid on any of 100 first-class seats from North America to Hong Kong. Such flights usually cost 125,000 frequent fliers miles, but bidding at this auction starts at 40,000. The carrier has already received about 500 bids and expects another 500 by the time bidding ends on March 31.
 
American Airlines Update
AMR's American Airlines will begin daily nonstop service between Dallas-Fort Worth and Santiago, Chile, on Nov. 1. The new flights will be in addition to its daily nonstop service between Miami and Santiago. Gerard J. Arpey, an American vice president, said that Santiago had become a strong market for business and leisure travelers primarily because of the strength of the Chilean economy.
American already serves Sao Paulo, Brazil, with daily nonstop flights from Dallas-Fort Worth and has an application pending with the Department of Transportation for nonstop service between Lima, Peru, and Dallas-Fort Worth.
On Monday, American started a frequent-flier program for travelers who are away so often they do not always have time to arrange having their lawns tended, termites routed, carpets cleaned or home security systems installed. The program is in conjunction with Service Master -- which owns Trugreen-Chemlawn, Terminex, Merry Maids, Service Master Residential Services and American Home Shield -- and Pittston's Brinks Home Security.
The program costs $79 a year. Members get miles when they purchase listed services -- and will have access to one-stop shopping and 24-hour home advisers, along with a a 30-day Service Master guarantee. Moreover, dissatisfied members can have their membership fee refunded.
 
Hotel Update
Crown Plaza Hotels and Resorts, owned by Bass P.L.C., will offer triple airline miles plus free enrollment in its frequent-guest program to customers who present a competitor's frequent-guest card upon check-in, through May 22.
Hyatt Hotels is offering rooms at least $50 below its published rates at 19 hotels in California. Based on space availability, the rates are in effect March 29 through April 14.
 
A Taxing Reward
Here's some tax news that won't trouble your sleep: If your 1995 tax return lists a donation of at least $25,000 to the National Endowment for the Arts, Club Med will give you a free week at its Columbus Isle Village in the Bahamas. A donation of $50,000 or more on a joint return will earn two free trips. The purpose of the promotion is to highlight Club Med's collection of folk art and artifacts at the resort. To qualify, a copy of your 1995 tax return and proof of donations must be sent to Club Mediterranee in New York by May 1.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1336 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PRIMARIES;
Dole Continues to Roll Toward G.O.P. Nomination

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Wednesday, March 20

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole roared through the industrial Midwest Tuesday, piling up resounding primary victories in Illinois, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin that left him just a handful of delegates short of sealing the Republican Presidential nomination.
"I think it's safe to say now that I will be the nominee," Mr. Dole, shedding his usual caution, declared at a rally of mostly young supporters at a Washington hotel Tuesday night. Next week's primary in California is likely to put him over the top. 
 Mr. Dole pounded his only remaining rival, Patrick J. Buchanan, drawing about three times as many votes in Illinois and Ohio. The outcome was closer in Wisconsin and Michigan.
With 98 percent of the vote counted in Ohio, Mr. Dole led Mr. Buchanan 66 percent to 22 percent. In Illinois, the count was 65 percent to 23 percent, with 85 percent of the votes counted. In Michigan, with 90 percent of the votes in, the Senator led 52 percent to 34 percent. And in Wisconsin, with 89 percent reporting, Mr. Dole's lead was 53 percent to 34 percent.
Several news organizations declared Tuesday night that Mr. Dole's sweep of the Big Ten primaries had assured him of enough delegates to the Republican National Convention to win the nomination outright. But an independent count by The New York Times found that Mr. Dole, the majority leader, would have only 914 of the 996 delegates needed after Tuesday's results were in.
Mr. Dole, the senior Senator from Kansas, also stopped short of claiming the prize. His aides said they were eager to keep up whatever suspense they could before the California primary, when 165 delegates, the largest cache of any state, are at stake. "California, here I come!" the Senator said Tuesday night.
But Mr. Buchanan, the former commentator, was no more than an afterthought for Mr. Dole Tuesday night as he recited his triumphs over the last three Tuesdays and trained his attacks on President Clinton.
"March has been a great month," Mr. Dole declared to the cheering audience in Washington. "Republicans across America are now united behind their choice as the candidate they want to restore common-sense conservatism to the White House. That will happen on Nov. 5, 1996, and take effect January 1997." He vowed that there would be "fundamental change in my Administration, in a Dole Administration, after Clinton is long gone."
Even as Mr. Dole was looking toward a confrontation with the President, he expressed concern Tuesday night about Ross Perot's strongest hint to date that he would run as a third-party candidate. Mr. Perot said earlier Tuesday that if his supporters wanted him to run, he would do so and give his full commitment to the race.
In response, Mr. Dole said in an interview on the ABC News program "Nightline" that the prospect of a Perot candidacy "does concern me."
"He helps Bill Clinton," the Senator said. Mr. Perot won 19 percent of the vote in his 1992 Presidential bid.
Mr. Buchanan pointed to his showing in Michigan, where he was winning about a third of the vote, as he was in Wisconsin, as evidence that his candidacy should not be dismissed. "We basically won the campaign for Michigan," he said, noting that he had rebounded from extremely low levels in newspaper polls. Mr. Buchanan's advisers said their candidate at least deserved to be considered as a Vice Presidential prospect.
Already campaigning in California, Mr. Buchanan was still seeking to slow the Dole juggernaut. He contended that his outspoken positions against immigration might give him a "miracle in California."
The primaries Tuesday were essentially a desultory exercise. The only suspense was over how close Mr. Dole would come to crossing the 996 delegate mark to claim the prize that has eluded him twice before. It was quite a contrast with the situation only a month ago, when Mr. Buchanan humiliated the Senator in the New Hampshire primary and Mr. Dole fought to climb back into contention, declaring a battle for the heart and soul of the Republican Party.
Mr. Dole's success Tuesday continued a winning streak that began on March 2 in South Carolina. Since then, he has overwhelmed his opposition in every contest, from New England to the Rockies. Even before Tuesday voting, Mr. Dole seemed to have an insurmountable lead, having amassed 718 convention delegates. An additional 219 delegates were at stake on Tuesday.
Mr. Dole has a major edge over Mr. Buchanan in California's winner-take-all primary, polls there show. And in Tuesday's voting, Mr. Dole drew vigorous support from nearly every demographic group, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls. The surveys were conducted by The Associated Press and the four major television networks.
But one reason Mr. Buchanan attracted more support in Michigan and Wisconsin was that in those states he found a receptive audience for his attacks on foreign trade and complaints of economic problems.
Mr. Dole's barnstorming of the Midwest in the last few days was more a victory lap than actual campaigning. His aides said they had always expected him to triumph yesterday; the only question was how overwhelming his victories would be.
Still, there were signs of trouble ahead for Mr. Dole. At least 4 in 10 of the voters in Ohio, Michigan and Illinois said Mr. Dole did not have any new ideas, according to the voter surveys. In Illinois, more than one-third of those who backed Mr. Dole said they had done so even though he had no new ideas to offer.
Economic issues like jobs, taxes and the deficit were at the top of voters' concerns. In Michigan, for example, those issues were the leading concerns of 60 percent of voters. The next most important issue was abortion, but it was cited by only 11 percent of voters in the state.
In the surveys, voters did not shed much light on whether Mr. Dole should pick a running mate who supports or does not support abortion rights. About one-third of voters in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio said it did not matter whether the running mate favored abortion rights. Another fifth said Mr. Dole should select a running mate who supports legal abortion. But a sizable minority, roughly one-third, said Mr. Dole should choose a running mate who opposed legal abortion.
Midwestern Governors have been jockeying to be picked as Mr. Dole's running mate, but the voter surveys showed no consensus on who the choice should be, although Gen. Colin L. Powell was popular. In Michigan, voters chose Gov. John Engler over General Powell. But in Illinois, voters were divided between General Powell and their Governor, Jim Edgar. And in Ohio, General Powell ran about 10 points ahead of the Governor there, George V. Voinovich.
On Monday night, in Mr. Dole's final day of campaigning in the Middle West, he went out of his way to emphasize in a speech that he was heartened to have Governor Engler's endorsement, which did not come until late last week. Asked by a reporter if there was trouble between the two of them, Mr. Dole replied, "Unless you're trying to stir some up, I hope not."
Rather than engage his sole remaining rival, Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Dole used his Midwest tour as more of a warmup for the general election. He trained most of his attention on Mr. Clinton, challenging him to resume negotiations over a balanced budget, welfare overhaul and tax cuts.
In another indication that the primary phase is all but wrapped up, Dole aides said the Senator planned to travel to his hometown of Russell, Kan., on Monday to celebrate with family and friends.
Mr. Engler acknowledged that the primary in his state had been nothing more than a formality. "I don't think the voting is very important anymore," he said. "I'm not sure there's much to be learned. But the importance for the fall is crucial."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
So Chipper, So Smiley, So Upbeat, but Why?

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
Should Willy Loman rise from his lonely grave in the next few weeks and visit the Circle Repertory Theater, he would surely recognize the character being played there by Frank Whaley.
True, the Buster Poindexter pompadour might throw him for a second. But otherwise, Peter Hogancamp, the central figure in a broken-hearted, symbol-cluttered play by Charles Evered called "The Size of the World," is like Willy's younger self on Benzedrine: a frenetic, hopelessly hopeful soul who, even though it's the 1990's, has dragged out that tattered "smile and a shoeshine" philosophy for success. 
 Mr. Whaley's Peter is a Vesuvius of chipper, Dale Carnegie-style adages, delivered in tongue-twisting eruptions with the gestures of a high school debate captain. The lodger of Stan and Vivian Merkle (Louis Zorich and Rita Moreno), an older couple in Passaic, N.J., Peter has a nightmarish, cartoonish intensity that would be just right for a "Saturday Night Live" sketch, perhaps titled "The Dead Salesman Who Came to Dinner."
Mr. Evered, a 30-year-old playwright and screenwriter, is in absolute earnest, though. So is Peter, when he says, "I'm gonna run and talk so fast through this life that no one's ever gonna catch me." "The Size of the World," which has been staged by the Circle's artistic director, Austin Pendleton, may be packaged in shiny irony. But it's definitely not sending up the postwar American drama of disillusionment. Beneath its whimsical, absurdism-tinged surface beats a sentimental 1950's heart.
At two full acts, "World" has the feeling of a single conceit stretched well beyond the limits of its charm. Mr. Evered -- who shows a sure, if conventional, structural sense and an ability to sustain a poetic logic -- has talents. Knowing when to quit is not among them.
The play has been produced and acted with such obvious care and affection that initially you root for it, hoping that it's not going to take you where you think it's headed. And there's no question that the work is informed by a real core of anguish about human loneliness and thwarted connections. But it is also stymied by the good-student neatness of the symbolic correspondences it sets up. There's no room for the characters to breathe naturally.
"World" is less about plot than coy, meaningful imagery. In it, the quiet life the Merkles have known since their only son left home is disrupted when they rent a room to Peter, an unemployed professional public speaker.
A few things you should know about these people before you decide to meet them: Peter has lost his parents; the Merkles have, in effect, lost their son. Stanley is blind, although the coddling, homey Vivian says "it's better not to let him know" that others know this. Stanley is an amateur historian and rock collector; Peter is terrified by "the idea of caring about something in the past tense."
Vivian keeps a tape recording of their long-dead dog barking (so Stanley will believe it's still alive) and refers wistfully to "our dogwood," now only a stump beside which the family fish (named Champion) is buried. "Everything you say you have doesn't exist," notes Peter, who is slower to get the point than the audience.
"World" has been provided with an ideal set, a butter-yellow time warp of a kitchen, by Jeff Pajer. And the actors make a lot out of the single notes they have been given to sing. Mr. Whaley uses some arch, distancing mannerisms that seem to belong more to the performance than the character. But Ms. Moreno's regretful, silky maternalism and Mr. Zorich's defensive bluster are as affecting as the material allows.
Actually, the classic filial-parental triangle shown here, with its sad, inevitable pattern of needy clinging and breaking away, will always be relevant. And when Ms. Moreno delivers a soundless scream of anguish near the play's end, it is hard not to empathize. But like the prolix Peter, "World" twists itself into some mighty precious knots to state the self-evident.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Bermuda's new campaign tries to shed the resort's staid image.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
BERMUDA will switch off its award-winning "Bermuda shorts" campaign today in favor of a kickier campaign designed to shed its staid image and attract younger, first-time visitors.
DDB Needham New York, the Omnicom Group unit that created the "Bermuda shorts" concept in 1990, is also responsible for the new ads, which carry the tag line "Let yourself go." The campaign -- more visually striking and spirited than its predecessor -- is running in media geared to travelers ages 25 to 49; the budget is $12.2 million for the year starting April 1, up from $10.2 million for the corresponding period a year ago. 
 Another first: Bermuda, which Competitive Media Reporting says was the sixth-largest travel destination advertiser in 1995, is teaming up with American Express to promote itself by direct mail. All ads are geared to the United States market, which produces 83 percent of Bermuda's visitors.
Tourism is the lifeblood of Bermuda. Half of the island's gross domestic product is tourism-related, while one-third of the adult population is employed in tourism-related jobs. But tourism has declined during the last nine years, dropping from a peak of 631,314 visitor arrivals in 1987 to 589,855 in 1994 and then to 557,628 in 1995. Air arrivals from Bermuda's top four markets -- New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Washington -- fell almost 14 percent last year; last fall, for the first time, repeat visitors outnumbered first-time visitors.
Enter David Dodwell, 48, a Cornell University hotel school graduate and owner of the Reefs, a small, upscale resort in Southampton. A member of Parliament since 1993 and minister of tourism since August, he is the first tourism chief with travel expertise.
"We recognized the gradual decline in arrivals and decided we needed to change people's perceptions," Mr. Dodwell said in a telephone interview from Hamilton. "While DDB had won many awards for the 'Bermuda shorts' campaign, the call to action just wasn't there. We have to get back into the minds of people. We want them to feel Bermuda, crave Bermuda."
To that end, Mr. Dodwell commissioned DDB Needham to come up with a campaign that would increase the number of Americans arriving by air this year by 25,000, and another 25,000 next year.
Unlike the "Bermuda shorts" campaign, the new advertising is visually bold, more overtly humorous and irreverent. One print ad, with a man's and a woman's legs peeking out from under a beach umbrella, is captioned, "Of course our sand is pink, it's blushing." Another, with a man windsurfing, suggests that a visitor "Arrive as Clark Kent, leave as Superman."
The commercials, directed by Peter Kagan of Nike "Revolution" fame, are even more playful: one has a couple flying past Bermuda's sights on a moped, accompanied by Steppenwolf's "Born to be Wild," while another combines Louis Armstrong crooning "I'm in the Mood for Love" with photographic allusions to romance, shots of flowers blooming and waves breaking.
James Cammisa Jr., a Miami-based travel industry analyst, said that in many respects, the new campaign was "strategically very right."
He added: "There's a growing role of entertainment in travel. Beaches aren't enough any more. People are constrained for time and money, and they want to pack the most they can into a vacation."
The campaign will make Bermuda appear "more contemporary, active and vibrant compared to dated, old Caribbean islands," Mr. Cammisa said. But he warned that aiming it at a younger audience could be a mistake. The 25-to-44-year-old market will decline by 9 percent over the next 10 years, while the market for those over 45 will rise 26 percent, he said.
The previous DDB Needham campaign was called "Bermuda shorts" not for its focus on the famous Bermuda short pants but for the brevity of the ads and plays on words to convey Bermuda's charms.
Richard Lobel, group account director at DDB Needham, said his team was inspired in creating the new campaign by the highly successful and seductive campaign for Norwegian Cruise Line that carries the theme "It's different out here." That campaign was created by a sibling Omnicom shop, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco.
The Bermuda print ads will run through August in mostly regional editions of 24 magazines, including travel, food, golf and life-style publications where Bermuda has advertised before, as well as additional titles like Entertainment Weekly, Playbill, Sports Illustrated and Vanity Fair.
All other media purchases for the campaign will focus on East Coast markets and Chicago. DDB Needham is buying prime-time local television for the first time in three years; the commercials will appear on "Friends," "Seinfeld," "E.R." and the Academy Awards show, among other programs.
Radio spots and co-op newspaper advertising, done in conjunction with tour operators, will run through August. Bermuda will also advertise this summer on a billboard -- another new medium -- on the Long Island Expressway that will read: "It takes longer to get to the Hamptons. Bermuda, let yourself go."
As part of Bermuda's total marketing effort, which Mr. Dodwell estimates at $14 million, Rapp Collins Worldwide, the Omnicom direct marketing unit, and American Express will send information about Bermuda to 250,000 card holders in Chicago and nine East Coast markets; the mailings will be aimed solely at individuals who have never visited Bermuda.

HEADLINE: Russian Diplomacy Gets a Wily Spy and Survivor

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 20

 BODY:
A month after American-led forces defeated Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, Yevgeny M. Primakov, then a top adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, published a dashing account of his last-ditch efforts to broker a face-saving solution for Saddam Hussein in February 1991 and prevent the ground war.
The efforts of Mr. Primakov, now the Russian Foreign Minister, failed, but that did not damp his relish for desert adventure. A former Pravda correspondent in the Middle East, he sounded like a Soviet-era Lawrence of Arabia as he told in the pages of his old newspaper of his dangerous race to the Iraqi President's safe house in Baghdad, his camouflaged car backlit by falling American bombs. 
 Mr. Primakov, 66, does not look like an adventurer. With his bulky frame, somber face and thick, dark-rimmed glasses, he more resembles John Le Carre's bookish spymaster, George Smiley. In fact, Mr. Primakov proved a circumspect but wily chief of foreign intelligence for five years under President Boris N. Yeltsin before becoming Foreign Minister in January.
When he was first appointed, American diplomats were suspicious of his Soviet background, his diplomatic meddling in the Middle East, and his intelligence work. But as he prepares to meet with Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Moscow this week, Mr. Primakov's experience and pragmatism have so far managed to mollify Washington's worst fears.
"I was pleasantly surprised," Mr. Christopher said of their first encounter in Geneva last month. Another senior Western diplomat, who insisted on anonymity, said: "He's straightforward and professional and he is not rude. He makes his point, but he can also listen."
Even though he came into office echoing the pervailing nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric, Mr. Primakov has not yet indicated any significant shifts in Russian foreign policy. So far, his most visible contribution to Mr. Yeltsin has been domestic -- in replacing the unpopular Andrei V. Kozyrev, a liberal who was villified as too subservient to the West, Mr. Primakov has robbed the President's Communist-nationalist opposition of a favorite whipping boy.
The hostile Russian Parliament is not baying for Mr. Primakov's head. Even hard-line Communists describe him as a tough, experienced bureaucrat who won't sell out Russian interests.
From his first day in office, Mr. Primakov set himself up as the Un-Kozyrev. His predecessor, a genteel career diplomat who speaks fluent English and French, was accused of neglecting ties with former Soviet republics in favor of Europe and the United States.
Mr. Primakov's first overseas trip was to war-torn Tajikistan. Pushing for greater economic and political cooperation, he has since traveled to Kazakstan, Belarus and Ukraine. Most recently, he went to Poland -- to remind the new Government in Warsaw of Moscow's staunch opposition to NATO expansion.
Earlier this month, he criticized the West for expressing reservations about Moscow's attempts to increase integration between Russia and former republics. But this week he even more sharply attacked the Communist-led Parliament's vote to dissolve the treaty that dismantled the Soviet Union, a nonbinding resolution whose symbolism alarmed Ukraine and most other former Soviet republics.
Mr. Primakov, an Arabist who worked for various official research centers before being inducted into Leonid I. Brezhnev's circle of foreign policy advisers in the 1970's, is perhaps best known for his survival skills.
Recruited by Mr. Gorbachev to help carry out the policy of perestroika, or restructuring, he served the Soviet leader loyally, defending him against the failed coup of August 1991. But when power shifted to Mr. Yeltsin, so did Mr. Primakov. "He has no ideology," said a former colleague at the Russian intelligence service, the external branch of the former K.G.B. "He's not for or against anything. He's a genuine pragmatist."
Born in Kiev to a Jewish family, he was raised in Tbilisi, Georgia. In a bow to the state-sponsored anti-Semitism of the time, he changed his name as a student to Primakov before entering the prestigious Institute of Oriental Studies in Moscow. His Russian friends consider him a Georgian by character, if not birth; he is described as a warm, humorous man who is intensely loyal to old friends.
When he was asked by Mr. Yeltsin to head the foreign intelligence service, Mr. Primakov was viewed warily by many K.G.B. old-timers. Even though Mr. Primakov had strong ties to the K.G.B. since his days as a foreign correspondent, he was not seen by the old guard as a professional spy.
But Mr. Primakov proved an able administrator, valued by his subordinates less for his intelligence acumen than his bureaucratic finesse -- he could protect his turf from Kremlin interference when other departments could not. One K.G.B. officer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, recalled that during the October 1993 insurrection in Parliament, Mr. Primakov resisted intense pressure from the Kremlin to publicly support Mr. Yeltsin.
And he worked hard to maintain the foreign intelligence service's distance from the bungled, unpopular war in Chechnya. "Primakov kept us out of the Chechnya mess," the K.G.B. officer said. "Primakov stayed in his job for five years -- there have been five different heads of the internal service."
At the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Primakov has brought a few trusted aides over from the intelligence side, but he has not significantly reshuffled the staff and some diplomats there say that morale, which had sagged under Mr. Kozyrev's disorganized rule, has improved.
Mr. Primakov's early reviews in Russia have been so favorable that some analysts are already speculating that if Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, were to be elected President this summer, he might ask Mr. Primakov to stay on in the job.
"Let's not be hasty -- he worked for Gorbachev and Yeltsin," cautioned Anatoly I. Lukyanov, the former chairman of the Soviet Parliament who was jailed for supporting the coup against Mr. Gorbachev and now advises Mr. Zyuganov. "But he is smart and certainly artful -- the kind who can walk through a rainstorm and not get wet."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Anything vs. Whatever

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is Wednesday, Sept. 25, 1996, the night of the first Taco Bell Presidential Debate. The candidates are at their podiums on stage at Washington University in St. Louis. The moderator, Ricki Lake, shakes hands with President Clinton and Bob Dole and gets the show rolling.
Lake: Wow! This is exciting. The topic for this evening is "He's Trying to Steal My Job!" Now, according to the draw, Senator Dole -- 
 Clinton: I just want to tell you, Ricki, I love your show, especially those makeovers for fat girls. Speaking of things that are big as the broad side of a barn, the era of Big Government is over. This is the age of possibility. More Americans from all corners of the country and all walks of life should have more options to reach more kinds of personal and family and community fulfillment than they have ever had in all of human history. But if we're going to do this, we have to find a way to go into this very modern, new world still clinging to our old-fashioned values, because it's no accident that we're still around here after 220 years.
And let me just follow up on myself, Ricki. I think that Bob and I agree on many things. He's mainstream. I'm centrist. I got off track for awhile. But then Dick Morris helped me glom onto some Republican issues like a hair in a biscuit. I have gone a long way to try to meet Mr. Dole in agreement on a balanced budget and welfare reform, in my effort to give the American people a rebirth of bipartisan productive accomplishment. And it has been real interesting to watch and see whether the creative tension --
Dole: Gaghhhd!
Lake: Mr. President, you are way over! Mr. Dole, your opening statement.
Dole: Bob Dole is a doer, not a talk--
Clinton: Ricki, if I might just add, I think I know what Bob is trying to say. He believes that now is the time for us to look to the challenges of today and tomorrow, beyond the burdens of yesterday. Bob and I agree that we've got to get a government that works better and costs less. We agree that liberals need not apply for Federal judgeships. We agree that families are the foundation of American life. He's trying to say that we must all ask more of ourselves, we must expect more of each other, and we must enable all our people to make the most of their own lives with fundamental values, more educational opportunity, economic security, safer streets, in a safer world.
Dole: Stop lying about my vision!
Clinton: As I was saying, Ricki, Bob and I agree that parents need more control over what their children see and what they are taught. That is why I have signed the V-chip legislation, and why I invited Hollywood media moguls to come to the White House and pretend that they care about improving what our children see on television. We're fighting for the heart and soul of our country.
Lake: Mr. Dole, is your daughter dating a criminal or a space alien, or living as a boy?
Dole: We're the party of ideas. Not certain what they are. Not born in blue suit. Not good with little slogans or phrases. Tested and tested. Don't give up easily. Got around to buttonhooks a few years ago. Voluntary school prayer. No more Mapplethorpe. Bob Dole wouldn't cozy up to Castro. Bob Dole wants English as the official language, tax credits for this or that, better America for blacks, whites, whatever. Got to get back on track on moral issues, character, corruption, whatever. I've never raised the issue of Whitewater. Got Al D'Amato for that.
Clinton: I would like to say a word from the baby-boom generation to Senator Dole and to all our other senior citizens in this auditorium who fought so long ago in World War II: I salute your service and so do the American people.
Dole: Agghhh!
Lake: Time for closing statements, guys. President Clinton?
Clinton: Our country is, and always has been, a great and good nation. But the best is yet to come if we all do our part. God bless you, and God Bless the United States of America. Do I have to stop talking now?
Dole: Bob Dole is a real person. Bob Dole will do the right thing. That's what Bob Dole is about.
Lake: Tune in for the next debate in St. Petersburg, when the moderator will be Jerry Springer and the topic will be "Help! I'm Obsessed With My Pollster!"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Retail Sales Figures Send Treasuries Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday after a report on retail sales was weaker than expected.
After recent reports on employment and industrial production showed unexpected strength in the economy, yesterday's data helped ease concerns that the economy was growing too fast to allow the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates this spring. Bond prices rallied after the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, less than the rise of 1.1 percent that had been forecast. 
 "It's a relief rally," said John Ryding, an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "People had priced in the worst" before the retail sales report, he said.
Still, one report is unlikely to instill confidence in a market still shaken by a March 8 selloff that came after a report showed more than 700,000 jobs were created in February. Most market participants are looking for further clues to the direction of the economy and in the meantime do not expect the Federal Reserve to take any action when its policy-making committee meets on Tuesday.
The market gets one of the first reports on March economic growth today, when the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia releases a survey of regional manufacturing conditions.
"People will be looking very closely at it to see if the manufacturing sector is rebounding," Mr. Ryding of Bear, Stearns said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 yesterday, to 90 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.63 percent, from 6.71 percent on Tuesday. It was the biggest price gain in more than a week.
Prices of shorter-term maturities also rose, with the price of the two-year note gaining 8/32, pushing its yield down to 5.71 percent from 5.85 percent.
Bond prices briefly dipped after Republican leaders of Congress ended a one-hour meeting with President Clinton over plans to balance the budget, traders said.
"People were hoping the Republicans would use their leverage to get a budget deal," said Andrew Brenner, a senior bond trader at Nomura Securities International.
Disappointment over the failure of Congress and Mr. Clinton to agree on a budget plan has helped drive 30-year bond yields up about 75 basis points this year, said Bob Alley, who oversees $3 billion of fixed-income securities at AIM Investment Advisors in Houston. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the corporate debt market, Riverwood, an Atlanta-based maker of cardboard packages, sold $650 million of bonds in two parts to help pay for its buyout by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc., a New York leveraged buyout firm.
The company sold $250 million of 10-year notes at a yield of 10.25 percent and another $400 million of 12-year bonds at a yield of 10.875 percent. Those yields were at the low end of where the bonds were marketed.
In another sale of junk bond debt, EKCO Group Inc., a New Hampshire maker of housewares, sold $125 million of 10-year notes in a private sale, according to MCM Corporate Watch, which tracks sales of fixed-income and other securities.
In the municipal market, the Greater Detroit Resource Recovery Authority's sale of $423 million in revenue bonds felt the effect of last week's decision by Illinois to repeal a subsidy for several waste incinerators. Some investors said the repeal set a dangerous precedent for the market as a whole, saying it could be equated to an issuer walking away from its obligations.
"There hasn't been a lot of good news as of late about resource recovery plants," said John Mooney, who manages about $190 million in insured bonds for the SunAmerica Asset Management Corporation.
The bonds due in 2006 were priced to yield 5.35 percent, or 17 basis points more than what comparable insured bonds were yielding before the sale, according to Bloomberg Fair Value analytics.

HEADLINE: A Program to Revive Harlem

 BODY:
Harlem was once the center of life for the African-American middle class and a Mecca for artists, writers and musicians. But during the 1960's, middle-class flight and business closings left the district one of the most depressed in New York City. The city-funded effort that resurrected the South Bronx somehow passed Harlem by. Even so, recent years have seen a slow but steady influx of middle-class homeowners, drawn by affordable real estate and Harlem's proximity to both midtown and the suburbs.
Now the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, financed with Federal, state and local money, will try to spur a commercial renaissance with a $300 million development fund and $250 million in tax incentives, to be spent over 10 years. The amount is small given the immensity of the job. The empowerment zone will only succeed if officials target dollars where they will do the most good. 
 By express subway lines, Harlem is a mere two or three stops from Times Square, and its vintage prewar buildings should make it one of the most desirable locations in Manhattan. But Central Harlem and East Harlem have almost 6,000 abandoned apartments -- more than eight times as many as the East New York section of Brooklyn, which ranks just behind them on the city's abandonment list.
Even so, not-for-profit development groups, using both public and private dollars, have been fighting back. The North General Hospital project and Abyssinian Baptist Church have worked hard to reclaim their immediate areas from decay. The St. Charles Condominiums and Bradhurst development projects, both near historic Strivers Row, have also produced pockets of optimism amid the blight. The appetite for home ownership in Harlem generally seems to be outstripping supply.
The empowerment zone hopes to amplify these gains by attracting businesses and creating jobs. The city, state and Federal governments have committed $300,000 in cash, to be spent on small-business loans, training ventures and related activities. In addition, companies that move into the zone will receive a $3,000 tax benefit for each full-time job they create. Zone officials need to choose their targets carefully.
Both City Hall and the business community were skeptical of the zone, given Harlem's history of political infighting and loose spending of public dollars. In an effort to allay that skepticism, zone officials have hired as director Deborah Wright, the City Housing Commissioner. The Giuliani administration credits Ms. Wright with developing the city's new housing policy, which will save tens of millions in redevelopment costs by placing city-owned residential properties in private hands. The zone's board of directors, headed by Richard Parsons, President of Time Warner Inc., seems well suited to its task.
Empowerment zone officials will come under intense pressure to pack the payroll with political appointees -- and to spend money in far-fetched ways not at all related to economic development. But 10 years from now, the zone will be judged on how many businesses it spawned and how many jobs it created. Urban policy has already fallen into grave disrepute. Failure or mismanagement in Harlem would signal its death knell.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
