HEADLINE: John Engler, Welfare Maverick

 BODY:
Gov. John Engler of Michigan is running hard to become Bob Dole's running mate, largely on his record of driving down welfare rolls. Mr. Engler's policies deserve credit, though a robust state economy did much of the work. But the intriguing part of this story is that the best parts of his welfare policy might make Mr. Dole mightily uncomfortable. They mirror President Clinton's welfare bill, which Mr. Dole and his Republican colleagues ridiculed out of existence.
Under Mr. Engler's 1992 program, parents on welfare sign a "social contract," which commits them to spending at least 20 hours a week in training, work education or community service. The state, in turn, makes work possible by subsidizing child care and health coverage. It also makes work attractive by allowing enrollees to keep more of their earnings. Recipients who fail to live by their contract may lose some benefits. No parent who follows these rules is thrown off the rolls. 
 All this is remarkably like President Clinton's proposal, which embraced the idea of reciprocal responsibility by government and enrollees. Conversely, it is remarkably unlike Congress's plan -- which Mr. Engler helped design and Mr. Clinton vetoed. Congress would have imposed time limits on benefits whether the parent had followed state rules or not. Though Mr. Engler hotly opposed Congressional efforts to micromanage the states, he swallowed time limits, perhaps as a necessary concession to win the freedoms he craved. Back home, he has taken a more sensible approach. But time limits have since become the rage nationwide.
According to the Center on Law and Social Policy, a liberal research group, states are also becoming stingier. More states have cut benefits by at least 10 percent in the past year than in the previous 20 years. Gov. George Pataki of New York proposes to cut benefits by 25 percent. Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut cut 11 percent.
Under law, states must get Washington's approval to overhaul welfare rules. Before 1995, most states sought permission to impose work requirements. In recent months, the vast majority of states have been asking for time limits. Putting welfare recipients to work costs lots of money. Cutting off benefits after two years or so saves money.
The conservative turn after the 1994 elections gave governors, desperate to balance their budgets, political cover to cut welfare spending in the name of reform. A largely unnoticed brake on the "race to the gutter" has been the Administration's refusal to approve state proposals that do not provide some ongoing help for parents who follow state rules. The Congressional bill would have stripped the Administration of this power.
The trend toward time limits is ominous. Upward of 30 percent of welfare mothers are unemployable because of low skills, substance abuse or other handicaps. In Detroit, according to a recent study, the probability that a young, black high school dropout will find a decent-paying job is less than 10 percent. States that impose time limits will drive these women and their children into poverty. Only a few states, like Vermont, Utah and Michigan, promise backup jobs or continuing support in return for community service.
During Mr. Engler's term, Michigan has reduced its welfare rolls to their lowest levels in 20 years. One reason is that the percentage of welfare recipients who work doubled. But another was Mr. Engler's unsympathetic strategy for reducing the welfare caseload. For starters, he eliminated the state welfare program for childless adults, throwing thousands into homeless shelters. Further, he and the legislature seem reluctant to spend the money required to underwrite the positive aspects of his program -- the training, education and child care that enrollees will need once Michigan's roaring economy slows down.
Even so, Michigan remains among the few states that acknowledge the basic need to take care of welfare parents who do everything the state asks but still cannot find a decent-paying job. It reflects badly on Congressional Republicans that they are so far out of step with a Governor whose tough but imaginative policies have attracted the attention of their party's presumed Presidential nominee.

HEADLINE: Moderate Rise in Retail Sales Seen as More Evidence of Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
American shoppers pushed $201.1 billion across retail counters in February, a moderate eight-tenths of 1 percent monthly rise that economists called further evidence that the economy was expanding somewhat faster after skirting recession for much of the winter.
"The pace of growth is beginning to pick up," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. 
 Taken by itself, the Commerce Department report was inconclusive because of extremely harsh weather in January, a possible statistical overcompensation for February's leap day, and the fact that the initial estimate covers only about 15 percent of outlets in the full retail survey, analysts said.
But combined with other recent upbeat data on jobs, housing, industrial output and consumer confidence, the sales figures tend to support the notion of an economy picking up a bit of steam. Few, if any, specialists still expect the Federal Reserve to make another cut in short-term interest rates at its policy meeting on Tuesday, though some believe the central bank may see a need to ease monetary policy by its May 21 session.
The bond market rose after the sales figures were released, apparently because the figures show that when the automotive sector is excluded, retailers took in just four-tenths of 1 percent more revenue last month. That followed a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in January.
"The February bounce-back was slightly less than expected," said Mark P. Vitner, an economist at First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C. "But all the data seem to be pointing to at least a modest pickup in the economy. That makes it a slam dunk that the Fed's on hold."
Sales of nondurable goods, which account for 59 percent of the total sales figure, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month. That followed a two-tenths of 1 percent increase that merchants eked out in January despite the blizzard that hit the Northeast.
Analysts calculated, however, that leap year distorted the seasonal adjustment process enough to lop five-tenths of a percentage point off nondurables and three-tenths of a point off total sales.
"There's more mud in these numbers than at any time I can recall," Mr. Vitner said, noting that the General Motors strike would affect much of the March economic data and make it hard to judge underlying trends.
Sales of durable goods, those designed to last at least three years, jumped 1.4 percent last month, mainly reflecting a hefty 2 percent rise in car sales, spurred by incentive programs.
The other durable-goods categories showed gains of eight-tenths of 1 percent for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes, and three-tenths of 1 percent for those dealing in furniture and equipment for the home.
Among nondurables, department stores and others selling general merchandise gained 2.3 percent, apparel and accessory stores gained 1.2 percent and bars and restaurants and drug stores each gained three-tenths of 1 percent. Food stores had an eight-tenths of 1 percent decline following a surge of 1.1 percent in January, while gasoline service stations had unchanged sales, held back by a decline in the price of gasoline.
The Commerce Department revised modestly upward its results for both December and January. December now shows a seven-tenths of 1 percent gain (one-tenth higher than before) while January shows a one-tenth of 1 percent decline instead of a three-tenths of 1 percent decline.
The figures on retail sales, which account for one-third of economic activity, are adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, holidays and trading-day differences but not for price changes. An adjustment is made for leap year but private analysts said it was faulty, diminishing reported sales more than it should have.
The department said it would make its annual revision of sales estimates, covering the period from January 1993 to February 1996, next week.

HEADLINE: G.M. Strikers Fear Threat To Way of Life

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 20

 BODY:
The rest of the world knows the nation's largest auto maker as the General Motors Corporation, but residents of this quiet southeastern Ohio city have their own name: Generous Motors.
The nickname reflects a mixture of awe and envy at the wages and benefits that G.M. provides to its workers here. The 3,200 brake factory workers who have been on strike for 15 days are mostly high school graduates who lately have earned an average of $69,000 a year by working six- and seven-day weeks. 
 That is more than four times what recent high school graduates can earn here. With inflation-adjusted wages down by more than 20 percent for high school graduates over the last 20 years, G.M. wages sometimes raise eyebrows.
Larry Herron, a 45-year-old worker on the picket line here, recalled a bank teller who was appalled by his paycheck. "I said, 'Lady, you probably make $16,000 to $17,000, and I pay that much in taxes,' " Mr. Herron recounted.
In the minds of America's storied labor leaders, auto workers were supposed to be well paid. Rich corporations like G.M. were supposed to share the wealth with the men and women who toiled for the benefit of the company. It was a vision articulated by Walter Reuther, who led the United Automobile Workers union after World War II, and negotiated steadily richer pay and benefit formulas. Over the years, auto workers became he best-paid factory workers and solid citizens of the middle class.
U.A.W. members have the money to own their own homes and maybe a vacation home, too. They drive new cars and send their children to college.
But now, many of the workers here see their strike as a struggle to protect their gains. G.M., however, sees it as a fight cut labor costs to protect the well-being of the company and its stockholders.
Negotiations to settle the strike continued Tuesday night and through today. People close to the talks suggested that a deal might still come this week, possibly on Thursday, given that considerable progress had been made since both sides sent down fairly senior officials from Detroit last Friday.
One longtime auto industry labor relations observer said that the marathon bargaining sessions, together with the two sides' six-day-old blackout on public discussions of their differences, suggested that a deal might be imminent. "You just don't behave the way they're behaving unless you're close to a settlement," he said. "When you declare a blackout, you're really going for a settlement."
G.M. announced today that it had laid off another 9,250 workers, bringing the company's total to 175,800 layoffs since the strike began. While even G.M. does not know how many employees have been laid off by its suppliers, estimates run into the hundreds of thousands.
The Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, said today on the CBS program "This Morning" that Federal mediators were available, but he noted that both sides already seemed to be bargaining in good faith.
While waiting for a settlement, G.M. officials have been emphatic in contending that the company's long-term survival depends on holding down costs here. "At the end of the day, if we are not competitive, we will lose those high-paying jobs in the U.S.," said Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, in an interview last week. "In that scenario, everybody loses."
Union picketers see it differently. "It's about the future of the kids coming behind us," said Howard Lowe, a 49-year-old metal worker with graying hair who walked the picket line last weekend in a red windbreaker and gray trousers. "If we don't take a stand now, they're not going to have jobs."
G.M.'s efforts to bring costs under control now are complicated because the company posted record profits last year. But Wall Street investors have not been satisfied, fretting that the company still has not lowered its costs enough in order to stay profitable or at least break even in the next recession.
G.M. has made the same arguments this year that companies in many manufacturing industries have made over the last decade while driving down labor costs with layoffs and pay freezes. Few industries still offer the high wages and numerous benefits of the auto industry. G.M. officials estimate they pay about $20 an hour in wages, plus benefits, including a health plan that still allows workers to choose their own doctors and pay no expenses except routine office visits.
The high compensation for workers here is a legacy of the post-World War II days when everybody from Boston to Bangkok drove an American car. The main concern of the American auto industry then was in preserving labor peace so that the cars could keep rolling off the assembly lines and the profits could keep rolling in.
No car maker was more generous with its workers than G.M. Mr. Reuther used to say that when the workers wanted innovative work rules, they should bargain for them at the Ford Motor Company, which had thinner profit margins but executives unafraid to experiment. But for money, Mr. Reuther used to say, the union should go to G.M.
The union went to G.M. repeatedly, winning the removal of a cap on cost-of-living adjustments just before the high inflation of the 1970's, and winning ample pensions before the baby-boom generation began worrying about retirement.
Now G.M. is trying to draw the line here on its labor costs. With demand for cars and trucks strong recently, G.M. has been buying more brakes from nonunion outside suppliers and asking its workers to put in six- and seven-day weeks, paying them an average of close to $30,000 a year in overtime. The workers here have struck, demanding that brake orders not be given to outside companies and that G.M. hire more workers so that the next generation of Dayton residents can find good paying jobs here as well.
Yet some of the workers here do not want their children to follow them into the factory, despite the high pay. They cite the long hours and frequent injuries here, and the lack of alternatives for many who went from high school into the Army and then into the factory.
Warren M. Cooper, a 53-year-old maker of heating and ventilation ducts who is on strike, drives a 1984 black and silver Chevrolet pickup truck with 169,000 miles on it because he has spent his pay putting all three children through college.
And Mr. Herron, the metal worker, said that he had high hopes for his 14-year-old son. "I don't want him working in a factory," he said. "He's going to college, hopefully Ivy League -- he's a very bright boy."

HEADLINE: House Panel O.K.'s Bill Assuring Health Care in Job Switches

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
In a unanimous vote, the House Commerce Committee today approved a bill intended to guarantee health insurance coverage for millions of Americans who switch jobs or lose jobs each year.
The measure will be bundled together with legislation from three other House committees. The chief deputy whip for House Republicans, Representative Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said the full House would probably vote on the package next Thursday. 
 The Senate plans to vote on a bipartisan bill to increase access to health insurance next month. The Senate bill is sponsored by Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
The House package is more complex than the Senate measure, and it is likely to contain provisions that many Democrats detest like limits on damages in malpractice lawsuits and tax incentives for people to establish savings accounts for medical expenses, as an alternative to standard health insurance. But the Commerce Committee has no authority over these matters, so they were not included in its bill. As a result, Democrats had no reason to oppose it, and the vote was 38 to 0.
For years, House Republican leaders have championed medical savings accounts and restrictions on malpractice lawsuits. But the chairman of the Commerce Committee, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, said today that he would urge party leaders to let the full House vote on the bill approved today by his committee, without the provisions dealing with medical savings accounts, malpractice and other hotly debated issues.
Mr. Hastert, who is coordinating development of the health care package for House Republican leaders, said they had not decided whether to include malpractice legislation and medical savings accounts in the bill that goes to the House floor. "We want a bill that the President can sign and that we can get through the Senate," he declared.
Republicans say medical savings accounts encourage people to pay more attention to the price of health care because they realize that they are paying for it with their own money. Democrats say the accounts appeal mainly to people who are healthy or wealthy and will lead to an increase in premiums for people who remain in conventional plans.
Senators Kassebaum and Kennedy have said they will resist all amendments to their bill, which does not deal with either medical savings accounts or malpractice suits. Clinton Administration officials have made clear that they, too, would prefer Congress to omit those provisions.
The bill approved by the Commerce Committee, like the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill, would guarantee coverage for people moving from one employer-sponsored health plan to another. Thus, a person laid off in one city could not be turned down by an insurance company at a new job in another city because of a chronic medical problem.
Both bills would also guarantee coverage for people leaving an employer's group health plan and trying to obtain insurance on their own for themselves and their dependents.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he supported the bill because "half a loaf is better than none." But he added: "Some on the other side of the aisle seem committed to taking a couple of good wholesome slices of health insurance reform and slapping a lot of extraneous junk food on top, creating a health care hoagie of medical savings accounts, caps on medical malpractice awards and other unhealthy additives. These anchovies, olives and onions are sure to tickle the taste buds of a few very special interests, but cause heartburn for millions of consumers."
The Commerce Committee today rejected a Democratic proposal that would have required health plans providing maternity benefits to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care after childbirth. Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said some insurers were, in effect, forcing women to leave the hospital after just 24 hours.
But Republicans said Congress should not dictate the benefits to be provided under private health plans. "Insurance companies shouldn't be practicing medicine, and neither should Congress," said Representative Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CALIFORNIA;
Dole on Verge of Victory, But Autumn Is Uncertain

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 20

 BODY:
For the first time in more than three frustrating decades, California Republicans are poised to play a decisive role in choosing a Presidential nominee. More or less.
While some say Senator Bob Dole has already clinched the 996 delegates required for the nomination by sweeping Tuesday's Midwestern primaries, Mr. Dole has adhered to more conservative tallies, which show his campaign still several dozen votes short of the prize. As a result, the Kansas Senator says he will wait for the outcome of next Tuesday's California primary before formally claiming victory. 
 Polls here predict Mr. Dole will have little trouble thrashing his last serious rival, Patrick J. Buchanan, the former commentator.
By waiting for California to put him over the top next week, Mr. Dole will gain what many state Republicans say will be a strategic beat on the real battle for California: the contest next fall against President Clinton. Ken Khachigian, a Republican campaign consultant, said the best thing Mr. Dole could do would be stay in the state next week and do a victory lap, celebrating his California-borne candidacy.
But even as Mr. Dole stands on the verge of a resounding victory in the primary, some Republicans say they are edgy, recalling with some bitterness what happened in 1992, when George Bush conceded California to Mr. Clinton. The tactic not only cost Mr. Bush the state, but left Republican candidates across California to fend for themselves, without Mr. Bush's coattails or infusions of Presidential campaign cash.
With the nation's richest trove of electoral votes -- California counts 54 of the 270 needed to be elected -- the state already looms large in the calculations of Clinton campaign aides, who readily characterize the state as a "must win." Mr. Dole's aides say the Senator could be elected without carrying it, but they concede that disaster resulted when Mr. Bush decided not to contest it.
"It's possible, mathematically, as in some poly-sci class, to get elected President without California," said Gov. Pete Wilson, Mr. Dole's California campaign manager and briefly a Republican contender himself. "But practically, you shouldn't try it. Anyway, you never cede anything to your opponent that will hurt others lower down on your ticket and free him to use resources elsewhere. So you have to compete here."
Current California polls have Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Dole by almost 20 points, a daunting gap, even given that the election is still more than seven months off.
The President has visited California 23 times since taking office, something of a White House record, and he recently began broadcasting campaign advertisements in major media markets. At every opportunity, he has funneled into the state all manner of Federal money, from disaster aid to transportation projects.
Mr. Dole, by contrast, has spent little time in the state, leaving some state Republican leaders to grouse that he not only has endangered his own chances here in the fall but also the chances of Republican legislators and others who will be on the ballot with him. And, unlike Mr. Clinton, who has not had to compete in any primaries, Mr. Dole has no money left for any television ads, pending receipt of Federal funds for the post-convention part of the campaign.
Some top Republicans here worry that Mr. Dole may yet abandon California if the battle remains uphill, much as Mr. Bush did.
"A lot of us, all the way down to the courthouse level, still carry that abandoned-ticket scar tissue that Bush left us with in 1992," said State Assemblyman Jim Brulte, the former leader of the Republican caucus in the Assembly. "But beyond that is the fact that it costs a good $10 million of the $60 million that Presidential candidates get to run a competitive campaign in California, more than anywhere else. Now, if you decide not to compete, then you free up not just yourself but your opponent to spend that money somewhere else. It's a tough call."
Mr. Dole's national campaign manager, Scott Reed, insisted today that the Senator "absolutely" would not abandon California this fall. "We will not make the mistake Bush made in 1992," he said.
Whatever Mr. Dole's ultimate plans for California, for the moment he is headed here, arriving on Friday for a three-day swing during which he plans to emphasize Republican plans for halting illegal immigration, increasing foreign trade, controlling crime, creating jobs and eliminating affirmative action, all major concerns of California voters.
Mr. Khachigian, an old hand at running California and national political campaigns, says he expects the race to tighten steadily now that Mr. Dole is assured of the nomination. "Bob Dole can win California in November," he said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Buchanan, who won 26 percent of the vote here in 1992, continues to snipe at Mr. Dole.
Arriving in California on Tuesday with plans to remain a full week, Mr. Buchanan said his goal was not victory but a strong enough showing to give him and his followers a say in the San Diego convention this summer. Then, accusing Mr. Dole of being out of touch with the true desires of Republicans and calling Mr. Clinton soft on illegal immigration and protecting American jobs, he took off on a swing that will take him from the Mexican border, up through the Central Valley and on to the green hills of the north.
Without enough money for television advertising, he is working the hustings mainly by holding rallies and by appearing on every possible radio and television talk show.
Can he repeat his 1992 show of strength here?
Recent polls put his support below 20 percent, with indications that his demands for an end to abortion, free trade pacts and corporate downsizing are meeting some resistance in a state where most voters support abortion rights, where international trade undergirds 20 percent of the economy and where job formation is on the rise after extended layoffs.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CHALLENGER;
Buchanan Taking Aim At Dole On Free Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, March 20

 BODY:
Pointing to Ross Perot's potential candidacy and his own strong showing in two Midwestern primaries, Patrick J. Buchanan said today that he hoped to shatter the Republican Party's historic commitment to free trade, suggesting he may bedevil Senator Bob Dole on that issue as much as on abortion.
While strict opposition to abortion has been party policy for years, Mr. Buchanan is seeking to shift fundamentally the party's approach to trade and foreign relations. 
 "I don't believe long term the Republican Party has a real future if it continues down the road of internationalism, of globalism, of interventionism, of trade deals," Mr. Buchanan said at a news conference this morning in Irvine, Calif.
In the last two weeks, as Mr. Dole defeated him in state after state, Mr. Buchanan's threats to the party came to sound like whistling past the graveyard. But by campaigning against international trade agreements, Mr. Buchanan won more than one in three votes on Tuesday in Michigan and Wisconsin, certain to be battleground states in the general election.
Further, Mr. Perot, who has strongly hinted that he might run, is also an opponent of pacts like the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. His entry into the race would increase pressure on Mr. Dole to modify the party's stance.
Mr. Buchanan said that the November election "is shaping up as a replay of '92," and that Mr. Dole, like President George Bush four years ago, would lose voters to Mr. Perot if he did not better address their economic anxieties.
Multiplying Mr. Dole's worries, Mr. Buchanan and his aides today again markedly failed to discourage speculation about a possible third-party candidacy.
"I'm not saying yes or no to that," Mr. Buchanan told reporters this morning. "By the time we get to August, there could be third, fourth -- you could be talking about fifth parties."
Mr. Buchanan's sister and campaign chairwoman, Angela Bay Buchanan, said that she and her brother planned to meet with Buchanan organizers from around the country in Virginia next week to consider a third-party candidacy.
"There are some very strong feelings within our ranks about that," said Ms. Buchanan, who is believed to favor such a step.
She said that while Howard Phillips of the U.S. Taxpayers Party had offered Mr. Buchanan that organization's slot on many state ballots, "we've given him no indication we would do it."
Here in California, Mr. Buchanan has been emphasizing his opposition to illegal immigration. He came here this afternoon to view three parallel steel fences recently built along a muddy ditch on the border with Mexico. Mr. Buchanan said the fences, along a short stretch of the border, were deterring illegal immigrants.
"What I've said about a security fence -- triple-lined -- it works, it's not that extreme, so to speak," Mr. Buchanan said.
In response to a reporter's question, Mr. Buchanan said he had not formulated language on trade that he would like incorporated in the Republican platform. He said the party was deeply split over the issue.
"The Republican Party clearly now has a very powerful economic nationalist wing, which I lead," he said. "It has a very powerful internationalist GATT-Nafta wing, which funds a tremendous number of Republicans. How you pull that party together over the long haul is a very serious problem."
Earlier, in Irvine, Mr. Buchanan said that Mr. Dole would need his supporters to win critical states in November. "If Bob Dole cannot bring home the Buchanan voters in the Middle West, he can't win the Middle West," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Buchanan said he expected Mr. Dole to clinch the nomination in the next week. But Mr. Buchanan plans to keep campaigning long after that, he said, to maximize his influence within the party.
With money tight, Mr. Buchanan cannot afford to advertise here, so he is running a one-week campaign keyed to television news and talk radio shows. Ms. Buchanan, the campaign chairwoman, said, "What we'll start to do is hoard our money again and play in Pennsylvania," which holds its primary on April 23.

HEADLINE: Run-Up in Oil Price Halts; April Contract Falls $1.28

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Oil prices touched their highest levels in more than five years yesterday before falling sharply. Most analysts and traders said they expected that the recent surge in prices would end with spring's arrival, after one of the harshest winters on record.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract for West Texas intermediate crude oil, which expired yesterday, settled at $23.06 a barrel, down $1.28 for the day, after trading as high as $25.60. On Tuesday, the contract settled at $24.34 a barrel. Nearly two months ago, the spot price of oil hovered as low as $17 a barrel. 
 In large measure, the run-up in price, particularly over the last week or more, has been the result of an increase in demand by refiners, compounded by three months of freezing weather.
"Over the last six months, U.S. refiners have made a structural change in the way they manage their inventory levels, and have been able to operate with 7 percent to 9 percent less inventory than they have in the past," said Michael L. Mayer, a managing director and oil analyst at Schroder Wertheim in Burlingame, Calif. "The cold weather, not only here but in Western Europe as well, as forced those who need inventory to pay up for it."
Refiners -- beyond seeking to keep their inventories lean to free up working capital -- have been particularly vigilant against oversupply for the last month to six weeks as negotiations proceeded between Iraq and United Nations authorities over a possible resumption of Iraqi oil sales on an emergency basis. The Iraqi Government argues that the American-led embargo on the sale of its oil has caused its people critical shortages of food and medicine.
If Iraq were granted permission to sell on world markets, it is estimated that such sales would add 700,000 barrels a day to the available supply. The talks, however, broke off unsuccessfully at the end of last week.
"Refiners have been waiting for the Iraq news to come," said George Brown, a vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. "That has not materialized, and as a result, there has been a mad scramble to buy oil."
Another reason that inventories remain lean, currently reflected in the price of 12-month oil futures contracts, is that most traders and brokers expect prices to fall in coming weeks and months.
"Oil to be delivered a year from now is selling at $17 a barrel," noted one trader, who insisted on not being further identified. "No one wants to hold oil for future delivery because they think it is going to get cheaper."
For a day at least, that belief was reflected in the stock prices of major oil companies, many of which came under selling pressure yesterday.
Mr. Brown and others said they expected prices to soften this spring because global demand for oil tends to fall in the second quarter -- a period of modest consumption of heating oil and gasoline.
"Demand for oil will drop almost three million barrels a day in the spring from the winter," Mr. Mayer of Schroder Wertheim said. "If Iraqi oil came on stream on top of that, you would have a substantial amount of oil to deal with."
But others are not so sure about the outlook for American energy prices.
"Structural demand for oil falls by about three million barrels a day globally, but demand for West Texas intermediate goes up by more than a million barrels a day in the spring here in the United States," the oil trader said. "The betting is still that prices are going to decline. But organizations like the International Energy Agency have consistently underestimated growth in demand, and inventories have been reduced to levels that have become critical. God help us if there were any sort of blow-up somewhere in the world."
Philip K. Verleger, an economist at Charles River Associates, a Boston-based economic-consulting firm, said that "for the last nine months I have expected prices to fall, but inventories around the world haven't been building up." He added, "That suggests demand is still out there."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Modest Advances Amid Uncertainty on Germany

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against the mark and other major currencies yesterday because of conflicting signals over another cut in German interest rates.
The dollar was quoted at 1.4737 German marks, up from 1.4730 on Tuesday. The dollar also crept higher against the yen for the sixth day in a row amid tension between China and Taiwan and optimism that the dollar would have room to rise after Japan's fiscal year ends on March 31. The American currency rose to 106.35 yen, from 106.17 on Tuesday. 
 The dollar initially slipped against the mark after a bigger-than-expected jump in Germany's M-3 money supply, the Bundesbank's main inflation indicator, dented hopes for a German rate cut in the next month. Lower rates would be likely to hurt the mark because they would make German deposits less lucrative.
The German central bank has come under increasing pressure to lower rates as unemployment has surged to postwar highs in recent months. But the Bundesbank's sole mandate is to fight inflation, and the country's M-3 money supply grew at an annual rate of 12.6 percent in February, well above the bank's target range of 4 to 7 percent as well as most analysts' expectations.
Hopes for a rate cut, however, were somewhat revived yesterday after the release of a survey showing a drop in German business confidence last month.
The dollar was also helped in early New York trading by reports that President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders were meeting to discuss the budget, traders said, and from a rise in bonds. It pared those gains after the meeting lasted only an hour, leading some traders to conclude that the months-long budget impasse would continue.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5390, up from $1.5335.
In other late New York trading, compared with late Tuesday, the dollar was quoted at 1.1910 Swiss francs, up from 1.1887; 5.0475 French francs, up from 5.0345; 1,554 Italian lire, down from 1,556, and 1.3600 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3580.

HEADLINE: Digital Says It Won't Meet Forecasts, and a Sector Slumps

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Blaming slow sales of its personal computers, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that this quarter's earnings would fall below analyst expectations. The news sent Digital's shares tumbling nearly 17 percent, dragging down other computer issues and, in turn, the broader market.
The question for investors in Digital and other technology issues is whether the slowing sales of personal computers is a temporary or protracted trend. 
 In making the case that the slump is a passing phase, many analysts have cited the slow corporate adoption of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 operating system. In this view, sales will pick up in the second half of the year, after large companies complete their evaluations of Windows 95 and begin to buy the more powerful PC's that the system requires.
But Digital's warning for the third quarter, ending March 31, comes amid other recent signs of softness in the personal-computer market, including plunging prices for memory chips and less optimistic forecasts from the Compaq Computer Corporation and I.B.M. Earlier this week, Dataquest, a market research firm, released a report that concluded the home market for PC's is rapidly maturing; Dataquest forecast just 8 percent growth in 1996, down from 22 percent in 1995 and 42 percent in 1994.
Digital's shares dropped $11.25, to close at $56, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in the Hewlett-Packard Company dropped $3.625 to $97.625; those of I.B.M. fell $4.75, to $117; Compaq fell $2, to $38.125, and the Dell Computer Corporation fell $1.125 a share, to $32.50.
Related stocks also took a hit, with declines at the Intel Corporation, Micron Technology Inc. and Microsoft. The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 52 points in the session before rebounding to close at 5,655.42, down 14.09 points.
John Jones, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in San Francisco, recommended caution about the entire information-science sector, citing a broad shift in economic factors that does not bode well.
"We've had the wind at our back in this group for two years," he said. "We've seen now collectively, enough indications -- softness in certain markets, the PC market getting ugly, currency shifts, memory prices under pressure -- and yet the stocks until a few days ago were trading at two-year highs."
Mr. Jones has downgraded Digital, I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and several smaller companies, and sees no hurry to begin buying the stocks again. "Is this a long-term downturn or a speed bump in the road? I think it's a speed bump," he said. "The fundamentals of these companies are better than in years, but it doesn't mean their earnings aren't going to get hit. It's going to take a couple of quarters to settle out, so we think it's better to be cautious for a while."
Other analysts argued that while sales of personal computers had clearly slowed, there was little indication that work stations, servers and larger systems had followed suit. Driving down the share price of a diversified technology company like Hewlett-Packard or I.B.M. because of weakness in PC sales, they said, has created an opportunity.
"We're saying buy I.B.M. and H-P,"said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. But even he downgraded Digital Equipment to neutral. "I would return to the stock, but right now I don't think it's going to go anywhere," he explained.
Digital's problem is that PC's account for nearly 20 percent of the company's revenue; while sales of servers based on the company's Alpha chip are strong, they are not enough to compensate for such a big hit, Mr. Milunovich said. "My guess is the PC slowdown will cost them 25 to 30 cents a share and they just can't offset that with other business," he said.
But Stephen Smith, an analyst with Paine Webber, said the rest of Digital's businesses were performing well enough that investors should stay with the stock. "Everything else at D.E.C. is above plan; to get bitten in the leg by the PC business like this is a real tragedy," he said. "I think it's a major overreaction." He said Paine Webber has had a buy on Digital shares since they were at $18, and it was keeping that recommendation.
A positive indicator for Digital today was a Microsoft report that sales of its more powerful operating system, Windows NT, have accelerated. "Windows NT is really beginning to kick into high gear, and D.E.C. is aggressively serving that market," Mr. Smith said.
On the other hand, he said, Digital's advisory that price cuts have not stimulated corporate PC sales is worrisome -- and not just for Digital. "I'm concerned about I.B.M.'s exposure, Hewlett's exposure," he said. "It does not look to me like a D.E.C.-specific problem."
One reason for the divergence of views is that some indicators can be read in many ways. The steep drop in memory prices is widely believed to reflect excess inventories at PC manufacturers, created by the drop in demand. But cheaper memory lowers the manufacturing cost for computers, which should lead to lower prices, higher margins or both.
"Demand may be slowing on the PC side, but we can't see that there's any slowing on the work station side," said Doug van Dorsten, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "The upshot of all this is the tea leaves are a mess right now."

HEADLINE: Hospitality Is Their Business;
One Ethnic Group's Rooms-to-Riches Success Story

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
In the quarter-century that people of Indian ancestry have been emigrating to the United States in sizable numbers, they have carved out a steadily bigger share of the nation's hotel industry. Starting with no-name motels, they soon graduated to Days Inn, Econo Lodge, Rodeway and other economy franchises.
Today, with more than 12,000 properties, Indian-Americans own 46 percent of America's economy hotels and 26 percent of the nation's total 45,000 lodgings. 
 "We used to be isolated in a few states in the South," said Ravi Patel, whose Charlotte, N.C., company, Sree Inc., owns 20 hotels. "Now we're almost everywhere."
They are also moving up. A new generation is buying properties like Sheratons, Radissons and Hiltons, adding an upscale chapter to an immigrant success story.
The first wave of motel ownership was propelled by the Indian-Americans' strong family ties, close-knit communities and a willingness to invest years of sweat. This latest wave represents a break with tradition and a willingness to tackle bigger, more complex challenges. But the original community still provides the backing, as today's entrepreneurs pool the resources of extended families and borrow from fellow Indian-Americans, for whom a handshake is often sufficient collateral.
"These Indians are modern Horatio Algers," said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine University Institute for Public Policy in Malibu, Calif. "They're willing to start in marginal and sometimes risky areas that native-born Americans are not interested in going into, and working incredibly long hours."
Ramesh Gokal, who bought a 26-room hotel in North Carolina soon after coming to the United States in 1976, is now president of Knights Inn, a chain of about 160 franchised economy hotels. Children of the industry pioneers are establishing their own companies and using newly acquired knowledge of capital markets to build budding empires.
"My parents' generation did business by having x dollars, buying y goods and selling for z," said Karim Alibhai, the kinetic 32-year-old president and chief executive of Gencom American Hospitality, a family-owned hotel group in Houston. "At the roadside hotels they ran, the management philosophy was get guests in and out, and have the maids clean the rooms."
But these days, "you have to know administration, management and how to use Wall Street to invest and to grow," added Mr. Alibhai, who was born in Kenya and majored in economics at Rice University. (Many Indian-American hotelkeepers came to America by way of Africa, where their families had lived for several generations in many cases.)
In Mr. Alibhai's case, the big plans are not just talk. In September, he co-sponsored a $350 million initial public offering of a real estate investment trust, one of the largest in United States history. Paine Webber was the lead investment banker and Mr. Alibhai was initially the biggest individual shareholder.
Today Gencom affiliates, which began with a single Best Western that Mr. Alibhai's parents bought in 1979 after emigrating from Kenya, own all or part of 47 hotels in 13 states. Properties include the 759-room Radisson New Orleans, the 650-room Sheraton Astrodome in Houston as well as Marriotts, Hiltons and boutique hotels in Boston and San Antonio. Revenues are expected to exceed $200 million this year.
Like his parents, Mr. Alibhai said, he "worked the desk, drove the shuttle van to the airport and learned to fix the sewer plant." In the three years after finishing college in 1984, years in which the Houston hotel industry bled red ink, he still did odd jobs at the hotel, but spent most of his time learning the business.
"Operating during that recession was my M.B.A.," said Mr. Alibhai, a trim, tennis-playing executive whose office is in a sleek Houston high-rise. In 1987, with the economy looking up but hotel values still down, Mr. Alibhai began buying distressed properties, often jointly with other Indian-Americans.
"That's when the real learning process began," he said, "not just acquiring the properties but convincing lenders who had tightened their purse strings to finance me. I had to change their perception of Indians as being identified with low-end hotels."
In many ways, Mr. Alibhai's world of revenue streams, variable inflation rates for assessing potential purchases and structuring deals with investment bankers is alien to the generation of his 60-year-old father, Akber, who is in charge of purchasing for Gencom.
"The older generation is still very cautious about sharing information, like the cost of hotels," said Jay Patel of Colorado Springs, a 43-year-old native of Zimbabwe who is part owner of seven hotels in Colorado and California. "The younger generation is much more forthcoming."
There are other differences.
"When you come from India and Africa, your view of labor is very different," Mr. Alibhai said. "People are thankful just to have a job. That's their bonus. Here, employees also want to feel appreciated. I prefer this system." Most of Gencom's corporate employees are given stock or bonuses, he said.
In the early years, Indian-Americans had problems typical of many newcomers in trying to get financing and insurance. By their account, insurers in the early 1980's suddenly canceled property insurance to all Indian hotel owners, believing them to be part of an Indian conspiracy to buy properties and burn them down to collect insurance money.
"We were turned down by about 200 insurance companies, until we convinced underwriters that these immigrants were outstanding risks," said Ron Thomas, a vice president of United Insurance Agencies in Muncie, Ind., who is widely admired by Indian hotel owners for his early efforts on their behalf.
Discrimination also took other forms, including boasts by rivals that their properties were "American owned."
Much of the more blatant bias began to wane with the formation of an Indian hotel owners' association in 1989, vigorously supported by Henry R. Silverman, the chairman of HFS Inc., and Michael A. Leven, then president of Days Inn. Starting with about 100 members, the group now numbers more than 4,000 hotelkeepers.
"Indian franchisees have been the engine of growth for the entire economy-hotel sector," said Mr. Silverman, whose company's franchises include Days Inn, Knights Inn and Super 8. "They were willing to build with their own capital when no one else was willing to."
For all their success, though, Indian-Americans have stayed away from luxury hotels and five-star resorts, and often from full-service hotels, mainly because of their cost but also for cultural and religious reasons.
"Most Indian hotel owners here are Hindus from Gujarat state and don't do well with anything involving alcohol and meat," said Mr. Patel of Colorado Springs. (Most Hindus from the western state of Gujarat are vegetarians, according to the Indian Embassy in Washington, and most Gujarati women do not drink.)
But younger Indians feel differently. "They realize you can offer meat and alcohol to your guests, because it's all part of the hotel business," Mr. Patel added.
"Within the next five years you'll see a lot of us owning luxury properties, like Ritz-Carltons," said Tushar Patel, the 31-year-old president of Tarsadia Hotels in Costa Mesa, Calif. About half of Tarsadia's 13 properties -- including the 440-room Clarion Hotel at the San Francisco airport -- are full-service hotels, with restaurants and bars.
Tushar Patel, by the way, is not related to Jay Patel of Colorado Springs, unless distantly, or to most of the thousands of other Patels who own hotels in the United States. Almost all Patels, even those from Africa, trace their ancestry to Gujarat, where hospitality is highly regarded.
In the United States, many Indian immigrants turned to lodging because they could buy cheap motels, they could live rent free and the family could work the front desk, clean rooms, do laundry and make repairs.
When they stepped up to franchised properties, for as little as $20,000 plus 8 percent of revenues, the Indians acquired not only toll-free reservation systems and the benefit of bulk purchases, but an education about prices, payrolls and bookkeeping.
"We'll soon have eight hotels and we're looking to open a 200-room one soon, and it's no big deal," said S. Jay (you guessed it) Patel of Alpharetta, Ga. "Now we're experienced enough to know we can handle it."
His father, J. K. Patel, left a 20-year career with Barclays Bank in Kenya to come to America in 1978, spending six months looking for a business before buying a hotel in South Carolina. The elder Mr. Patel attributes the Indians' success in this country to "the way we were brought up."
Parents instilled the need for education and trust between families and among their own ethnic group. "In January I did a deal with an Indian partner in Dallas for two hotels," said Mr. Alibhai of Gencom. "We shook hands, and before the contracts were signed I wired him several million dollars."
Arvind Patel, who with his wife, Bhavna, owns a 39-room Days Inn in West Point, Miss., cites another factor -- the willingness of extended families and acquaintances to provide financial help.
"We work together as a team," said Arvind Patel, a native of Tanzania. "A lot of families give you $10,000, even $30,000, without charging you interest and without any collateral. They figure one day you may help them."
But like many Indians, these Patels are branching out and moving up, building an 81-room Wingate Inn and a 58-room Hampton Inn elsewhere in Mississippi. Meantime, both continue working a full shift each day behind the desk of their Days Inn, with their 12-year-old son and 10-year-old daughter pitching in on weekends.
"And if our help doesn't show up," Mrs. Patel said, "my husband and I still clean the rooms."
Many of the older Indian-owned motels were long ago refurbished, if only to measure up as franchises -- a method the Indians quickly saw as a route to financial independence. Some properties have been kept for the next generation, but most have been sold to a newer wave of Indian immigrants.
When Indian-Americans graduate from college, many have chosen to become doctors, engineers, lawyers and accountants. "But in most families at least one son or daughter will become hoteliers, because they realize it isn't the hard work it was for us," said J. K. Patel, the former Barclays banker. "The difference is, we used to man the desk ourselves. The new generation likes sitting in the office and delegating the work."

Some successful niche businesses serving the broad community carved out by recent immigrant groups in the United States:
 
Palestinians -- Run many mom-and-pop grocery stores in San Francisco, Detroit and elsewhere.
 
Koreans -- Already successful with small markets in big cities, they are opening bigger stores and dispersing to the suburbs and beyond, especially in Southern California.
 
Vietnamese -- Small store-front parlors for trimming and polishing fingernails, especially in the Los Angeles area.
 
Barbadians -- Short-haul trucking, especially in Brooklyn and Queens.
 
Chaldeans -- Iraqi Christians, who own many convienence/liquor stores in the Detroit and San Diego areas.
 
Chinese -- Started and remain at the center of the toy wholesale business in Los Angeles, and now employ many Vietnamese, Koreans and Hispanic people.
 
Cambodians and Vietnamese -- Donut shops, particularly scattered throughout Southern California. The suppliers to these shops are also Southeast Asians.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Product Liability Bill Clears Hurdle, Heads for Passage
The Senate took an important step toward limiting damages available to people who were are hurt by faulty products. By a vote of 60 to 40, the minimum necessary, the Senate cut off debate on the bill. A dozen Democrats voted with the majority, in a repudiation of President Clinton, who has promised a veto.
The Senate appears certain to pass the bill today and send it to the House, which is likely to approve it next week. [Page A1.]
 
Rockwell May Leave Military Field
Rockwell is considering the sale of its weapons businesses, people close to the discussions said. Such a sale would accelerate the rapid pace of change in an industry that, since the cold war, remains highly profitable for a shrinking number of manufacturers. Boeing and McDonnell Douglas were mentioned as companies Rockwell has approached. [D7.]
 
Retail Sales Suggest Strength
Retail sales grew eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, offering evidence that the economy was expanding somewhat faster after skirting recession for much of the winter. Because of special factors, the report was inconclusive, but combined with data on jobs, housing and other indicators, the figures point to an economy picking up steam. [D4.]
 
Stock Prices Retreat
Stock prices retreated with the Dow Jones industrials average losing 14.09 points, to close at 5,655.42. With technology issues weak, the Nasdaq composite index fell 10.68 points, closing at 1,101.82. [D10.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose, in response to the weaker-than-expected retail sales report. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 1, sending its yield down to 6.63 percent, from 6.71 percent on Tuesday. [D20.]
 
Oil Price Halts Sharp Rise
West Texas oil traded as high as $25.60 a barrel, the highest in more than five years, then dropped sharply to $23.06 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts attributed the run-up in recent days to heavy winter demand, a new system for gauging inventories, and fear of a supply glut from Iraq. They said they expected prices to decrease with spring's arrival. [D5.]
 
Wheat Futures Soar to Record Price
The expiring wheat contract soared on the Chicago Board of Trade, exceeding the previous record by far. Analysts said that a large commercial grain company, which they identified as Bunge, was caught short of grain and had to buy back futures it had sold. [D17.]
 
Monsanto Patents Synthetic Genes
Monsanto said that it had received a patent for the synthetic genes that it and other companies put in plants to cause them to produce their own insecticide. Monsanto, the leader in agricultural biotechnology, also said that it had sued Mycogen and Ciba-Geigy, which market corn containing the gene. [D17.]
 
Lehman Profit Doubles
Lehman Brothers' first-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $104 million, benefiting from revenue gains in underwriting and trading and a decline in expenses. [D16.]
 
C-TEC: Under the Wire on Taxes?
C-TEC said late on Tuesday that it might spin off one part of its telephone and cable TV operations and selling another. Vague in the extreme, C-TEC's news release might still qualify the company for a "Morris Trust" transaction, a popular way to avoid capital gains taxes when an acquirer wants only part of another company. The Clinton Administration wants to halt the practice. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
Banco do Brasil Loses $4.3 Billion
Banco do Brasil, Latin America's largest bank, lost $4.3 billion last year, more than its net worth. Rushing to the rescue, the Government said it would increase the capital of the state-controlled bank by $8 billion. [D4.]
 
Unfriendly Skies for Air Afrique?
Air Afrique proudly declares itself "the No. 1 Company in Black Africa," but its business appears to be hanging by a thread. Losses are climbing, and creditors are threatening to seize planes. [D4.]

HEADLINE: PATAKI IS SEEKING TO END REGULATION OF HOSPITAL RATES

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a broad plan today intended to lower health care costs by lifting most of the rules that control the fees charged by hospitals.
He also called for the state to make deep cuts in financing for medical education, a proposal that quickly ran into opposition in New York City, where programs that train doctors are one of the pillars of care in poor neighborhoods. 
 Mr. Pataki's aides said that by reducing money for medical education, the state should be able to cut by 30 percent the number of slots for medical residents in New York over three years. Such a move, they said, would help slim down a health care system that is bloated with extra doctors.
The Governor said that ending the state's decades-old practice of setting rates for services provided by hospitals would allow competition to push down costs and offer new incentives for people to seek cheaper treatment outside of hospitals.
"We are just quite confident that this will lead to a stronger and healthier health care system as we move into the next century," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference this morning.
The plan is the latest jolt to hospitals in New York City, which are already facing sharp cuts in Federal and state spending for Medicaid and Medicare. The city, which has one of the largest concentrations of hospitals in the nation, educates far more doctors than any other and relies heavily on government money to care for its poor.
Mr. Pataki's plan stirred a fierce response from some city hospital executives, who contended that the cuts might force hospitals to consolidate or close, hurting medical care in some areas. The proposal could also be a new source of tensions between the Governor and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, two Republicans who have often been at odds.
"This would obviously have a negative impact on the H.H.C. hospitals," said Maria Mitchell, who is Mr. Giuliani's top health adviser and is also chairwoman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the 11 municipal hospitals.
The Democrats who control the State Assembly also criticized the plan, saying it would give too much power to insurance companies and penalize consumers. Both houses of the Legislature must pass the proposal. It is intended to replace rules that expire on June 30.
Mr. Pataki expressed confidence that the plan could be passed before the deadline. But privately, leaders of both parties said that with the state's budget on hold because of the Federal budget impasse, it is more likely that the Legislature will extend the old rules for a few months and then tackle the proposal in the fall. Both parties generally agree, however, that the rules governing hospital fees must be revamped.
The Governor's plan would allow private insurance companies to negotiate rates for services with hospitals directly, a right that managed care companies already have. It would not affect the rates for Medicaid and Medicare, which would continue to be set by the state and Federal governments.
Of the $28 billion in hospital revenues annually in New York, $16 billion are covered by the current rules.
Under those rules, the state sets a standardized fee for every procedure that a hospital performs. The State Legislature has periodically passed bills mandating these rules, which the Health Department has then turned into a list of required charges that it sends to hospitals.
Health care experts said that nearly a dozen states moved toward regulating hospital rates in the 1970's to slow the steep increases in health care costs. But by the early 1990's, most of them had reversed field, as Mr. Pataki is proposing, deciding that deregulated systems governed by market forces would be more effective in controlling costs. New York and Maryland are the only states that still set hospital rates.
But deregulation has not always worked smoothly. Among the states that have deregulated their hospitals in recent years, both New Jersey and Massachusetts have had trouble providing enough money to pay for care of the poor.
Today, insurance companies and business groups praised Mr. Pataki. The New York State Conference of Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plans said the plan was a "laudable, pragmatic direction for New York's health care system that will help contain costs, enhance access to care and build on the quality of services delivered to citizens."
The exact amount of the cut in financing for medical education was difficult to determine from the Governor's proposal, but it could be several hundred million dollars. Nearly $3 billion is spent in New York on training doctors, including money from Medicare, Medicaid and a surcharge on the mandated rates that hospitals can charge.
Under the new system, the Medicare money would not be affected, but the state would allocate less from Medicaid for medical education. There would be a smaller surcharge, but hospitals would have to make up the difference through their own fees.
The Governor would also allow New York City to raise another $350 million for medical education at its hospitals through the city's own surcharge on health care.
"Let me stress that we are not looking to maintain the status quo with regard to medical education in New York State," said Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, the State Health Commissioner. "We are looking to scale down the graduate medical education program in New York to reflect the place that the country is at in terms of physician supply and to reflect the changing needs in New York."
Hospital executives said the new rules would put them at a disadvantage in negotiating with insurance companies. While they said they did not necessarily disagree with Mr. Pataki's proposal to deregulate health care, they called on him to find a better way to finance medical education and care for the poor.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 174 hospital and nursing homes in the New York City area, said the state should have some kind of tax on health insurance premiums so that such costs are not just borne by hospitals.
"The ability of hospitals to fight and get some of that money back, like economic gladiators -- it is a frightening thought," he said.

HEADLINE: NATO Urged to Keep Force In Bosnia After Pullout Date

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: TUZLA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 20

 BODY:
As warnings mount that the fragile Bosnian peace could collapse without the presence of NATO peacekeepers, international civilian and military authorities here have begun to press for keeping at least a reduced NATO force in Bosnia beyond the currently scheduled departure at the end of this year.
While the Clinton Administration continues to insist that all 20,000 American troops will be out of Bosnia only nine months from now, key officials here say the delicate tasks of resettling refugees and rebuilding the country are likely to fail without the security of outside peacekeepers. The NATO-led international force, known as IFOR, totals about 60,000 troops. 
 At American insistence -- and consistent with pledges President Clinton made to Congress when he sought support for the peacekeeping mission here -- the NATO forces are to leave at the end of the year. Both Britain and France have said that if the Americans go, the Europeans will pull out, too.
But many international officials in Bosnia say a total withdrawal could be disastrous. "We need something after IFOR, though not a 60,000-man force," said Carl Bildt, the international representative in charge of coordinating civilian efforts to put the peace agreement into effect.
"Refugee return is a two-year plan," Mr. Bildt said. "Reconstruction will take much longer than one year. Almost everything depends on a feeling of overall security for which some kind of military presence will be required."
The Pentagon itself, in an intelligence assessment drawn up last month, warned that without major new aid for economic and political rebuilding, Bosnia was likely to fragment and fall back into conflict after NATO forces pull out at year's end.
Mr. Bildt has already asked officials of the alliance in Brussels to begin thinking about what NATO could do after its one-year mandate here runs out. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and other allied foreign ministers will probably have to make a preliminary decision about what comes next when they meet in Berlin in June.
Some European officials have hinted that they might keep troops in Bosnia after the end of the year if the United States would keep troops nearby, providing logistical support. If so, that would give President Clinton a political break since he could withdraw Americans from the danger zone.
In an interview today, Maj. Gen. William L. Nash, the commander of the American sector for NATO forces in Bosnia, stressed the unwavering American determination to withdraw on schedule.
"The burden for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina is on the shoulders of those folks that live here," he said. "If they don't want peace, there ain't gonna be peace. If they want peace, one year is more than enough to get them started.
"The military part has gone pretty well. As people gain confidence, some sort of elections take place, and the international police force does its work, by next December things can be in a reassuring posture that will make withddrawal not the concern that it is now."
"Should there be a follow-on force?" General Nash asked. "I don't know."
Allied commanders here say the hardest part of the military implementation of the accords is almost over, with the forces of the warring parties disengaged from the old battle lines and many troops demobilizing.
If by mid-April, as called for under the peace plan, the sides have withdrawn their artillery, tank, and other heavy weapons forces to base areas designated by the NATO commander in Bosnia, Adm. Leighton W. Smith Jr., the allies can start thinking about when to begin withdrawal of the heaviest elements of their own forces.
"Everything has to stay until the Bosnian elections, which have to be held by the middle or the end of September," a high-ranking French official said in Paris. "After that, everybody leaves if the Americans do."
But according to Mr. Bildt and French commanders on the scene here, the threat that international force will be used has been the key to making the warring parties observe the agreements they all assented to in Dayton, Ohio, last November.
"There is some thought that we should wait until the Bosnian elections at the end of the summer before beginning the withdrawal, and some thought that we could begin before then," said Maj. Gen. Robert Rideau, the French commander of the NATO multinational division deploying 14,000 troops around Sarajevo.
"Nothing has been decided yet," he said, "but yes, it does seem that some force should remain in the future. Perhaps the Americans will be prepared to leave some troops at their staging area in Hungary." The United States now has more than 4,000 troops in Hungary supporting the Bosnian operation.
The implication of these and other statements by European officials is that if some Americans stayed, at least in the neighborhood if not in Bosnia itself, then some European forces would stay as well. Several thousand troops from Russia, Ukraine, Malaysia, Morocco, the Czech Republic, Poland, Morocco, and 10 other non-NATO countries are also participating with troops from 15 allied countries.
Mr. Bildt, like just about everybody else in Sarajevo, shakes his head when asked whether a residual peacekeeping force could come under United Nations command, like the ineffectual protection force that NATO replaced in December.
But a smaller, less heavily armed force than the one NATO deployed to be ready to impose peace on the belligerents is essential, in his view, to keep the peace in the future.
Other international officials agree. Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said recently that she could not imagine how to get two million refugees safely back to their homes, or resettled in other areas, over the next two years without the security provided by an effective international force.
Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Walker, a Briton who is Admiral Smith's principal deputy here, said that NATO military authorities had long assumed a need for a continuing force. "We made the assumption there probably would have to be a follow-on force, but that wasn't acceptable language at the time," he said at his headquarters here.
"I think the argument will go on for some time," he said. "NATO is trying to allow its member states to discuss the issues at the national level before trying to make a decision."
Mr. Bildt is particularly concerned about the need to remove millions of mines scattered around the country, and to resolve a dispute about boundaries in the critical Brcko area, the part of northern Bosnia that links the eastern and western Serb-controlled areas. The Dayton accords called on the parties to name arbitrators by June 14 and put their decision into effect by the end of the year.
"In Brcko all the issues that originated the conflict come together again," he said. "The area was 52 percent Muslim before the war, but Serb ethnic cleansing was brutal, and President Alija Izetbegovic is insisting that his boundary has to extend through Serb territory right to the Sava River. It's nowhere near being sorted out."
In addition, he and other officials point out, there is concern about the road that under the accords is to be built in a corridor through Bosnian Serb territory to the Muslim enclave of Gorazde in eastern Bosnia. The road is unlikely to be planned, let alone built, by the time the peacekeepers are now scheduled to leave, these officials said.
"I've told the alliance in Brussels that the issue has to be confronted within the near future," he said.

HEADLINE: Guns For Peace

BYLINE: By Muhamed Sacirbey; Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian ambassador to the United Nations, is special envoy for the implementation of the Dayton peace agreement.

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
The Dayton peace agreement ended the war in Bosnia, but it is only a small first step in securing a durable peace in the region. Economic redevelopment, the return of refugees and free and fair elections in Bosnia, combined with a movement in the region toward respect for law, are all critical to success. A new Pentagon report warns that more international aid must be forthcoming to speed rebuilding of the country and to lay the groundwork for economic and political stability. But equally important, the international community should support the United States in its pledge to provide the Bosnians with equipment and training to correct the military imbalances in the region.
Bosnia's leaders support regional arms control, as called for in the peace accord, and we will pursue seriously the arms limitation talks now taking place in Vienna. But those like the British, the French and the Russians, who favor a commitment to simple disarmament -- reducing Serb military strength while freezing Bosnian arsenals where they are -- fail to see that this policy is dangerously flawed. It will still prevent the Muslim-Croat Federation from gaining rough military parity with the Serbs. 
 This policy also clearly contradicts the Dayton agreement, which calls for the Bosnians' relative strength to be increased. It was the lack of parity that initially encouraged the Serb aggression against Bosnia in 1992. We lacked the weapons to defend ourselves.
The equip-and-train program should not solely be viewed as a plan to arm the Bosnian Government. Supplying the Bosnians with military aid and equipment would also give them the means and confidence to no longer rely on manpower strength to offset the overwhelming Serbian advantage in heavy weapons. Thus, perhaps 80 percent of the 200,000 Bosnian soldiers could be demobilized and returned to civilian life to help rebuild the country.
Finally, as a condition for the equip-and-train program, the Bosnian Army is working with the Bosnian Croat military forces to form an integrated chain of command, which will bolster the federation and further promote stability.
Are European leaders who support arms limitations yet oppose equipping and training the federation army willing to give Bosnia a guarantee of security? Judging by how well peacekeeping forces protected the "safe areas" of Srebrenica and Zepa, where an estimated 8,000 people were killed, such guarantees would not be trusted. The failure of the United Nations to protect these cities, while helping to defend the Bosnian-protected city of Gorazde, plainly demonstrated that the West only considered coming to the aid of the Bosnians when we were credible partners in our own self-defense.
It was not weapons alone that caused the war in Bosnia but too many weapons in the wrong hands and not enough in the hands of the victim. The Bosnian people are prepared to take on our share of the load, and demonstrate our ability to be a partner for the future and an accountable state committed to military balance and restraint. By equipping and training federation forces while reaching verifiable arms limitations in the region, the international community can send a compelling political and symbolic message of deterrence, and help prevent a new outbreak of fighting when NATO forces leave at the end of the year. That is, it can help achieve peace and stability, the ultimate goal of the Dayton agreement.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday by Muhamed Sacirbey, the Bosnian Ambassador to the United Nations, used the term "Muslim-Croat Federation," which he finds unacceptable. The article should have referred to the "Bosnian Federation."
