HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Keeping the Focus on Asia
Is the rarefied world of Asian art moving into the mainstream?
 It certainly looks that way. The Metropolitan Museum of Art's gigantic "Splendors of Imperial China: Treasures From the National Palace Museum, Taipei," which opened this week, is just the tip of an iceberg. Next week, Manhattan will be consumed with Asian art activities. The catalyst is the new International Asian Art Fair, which opens on March 30 and runs through April 2 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street. 
 The show was organized by Brian and Anna Haughton, the London-based show managers who brought the International Fine Art and Antiques Show to Manhattan six years ago. This new show will cover most categories of Asian art and antiques, from the 12th century B.C. to the present.
About 50 dealers are participating, "coming from as far away as Taiwan, Hong Kong, from all over Europe and the United States," Mrs. Haughton said. "It's such a huge subject, we're hoping the show will appeal to a lot of different people." While the Haughtons aren't expecting the crowds attracted to more general fairs, Mrs. Haughton said that "the people who come to these specialized events are passionately interested and therefore, hopefully, potential buyers."
Much as Sotheby's and Christie's time their Americana sales to coincide with the Winter Antiques Show held every January in Manhattan, because they know all the major collectors will be in town, the auction houses moved their Asian sales up a week this year so that they overlap the dates of the new Asian show. They hope that New York will become a center for sales of Asian art.
"With all the political turmoil going on in Asia, and with London in the doldrums, New York has become the sort of adopted home for Asian art," said Leon Wender, a private Manhattan dealer who specializes in Chinese paintings and will be showing at the fair. "This is certainly a calculated risk, but one worth taking."
The dealers aren't the only ones taking a risk. For the last several seasons, the auction market for Asian works has been quite patchy, in part because of a weak economy in Japan and the uncertainty over Hong Kong's political stability as it is returned to China. Both situations are believed to have made buyers more cautious.
Between Sotheby's and Christie's, about $25 million worth of Asian art will be auctioned next week. While both auction houses have a few important offerings, neither has any blockbuster single-owner collections up for sale.
Among the highlights at Christie's sale of Japanese art, on March 30, is a mid-17th-century hand scroll, one of the earliest surviving illustrations from the Taiheiki, or the Chronicle of Great Peace. Christie's estimates that the scroll, which depicts a famous struggle between ruling clans, will sell for $250,000 to $300,000. "This is one of 12 volumes of the earliest known set of these hand scrolls," said Sebastian Izzard, head of the department of Japanese works of art at Christie's in New York. "It came from a European collection." Mr. Izzard said he believed the scroll would appeal to a Japanese museum.
At Sotheby's, Korean art is one of the hottest areas. "Korea is a small country, and the demand far outstrips the supply," said Suzanne Mitchell, head of the department of Korean art at Sotheby's in New York. Among the top works that are to be sold at the Sotheby's sale of Korean art, on Wednesday, is a 19th-century, 10-panel screen depicting a royal banquet celebrating the 80th birthday of the Queen Mother Cho (Queen Sinjong). Sotheby's expects it to sell for $900,000 to $1.2 million. Another work that Ms. Mitchell expects to be especially popular is "10 Girls Drawing" (1961), a painting by the Korean artist Park Soo Keun, who died in 1965. Its price is estimated to be $300,000 to $350,000. "Park Soo Keun has an amazing following right now, in part because he brings out nostalgic feelings in Korean collectors," Ms. Mitchell said.
 
 
 
Growing in the Northwest
 While the Seattle area may be known as Microsoft country, it's never had a reputation as a center for contemporary art. But when the Henry Art Gallery, the museum of the University of Washington in Seattle, reopens a year from now, after a $17.5 million face lift, it hopes to provide the Northwest the kind of cultural center it has never had before.
"This is a rapidly growing area that is economically strong but museum poor," said Richard Andrews, the Henry Art Gallery's director. "Once the renovation and expansion is completed, we will have four times as much space, which will enable us to become a multi-faceted art center."
The museum's two-year renovation will increase its size to 46,000 square feet, from 10,000 square feet. "Right now, we have only one exhibition space, no storage and no loading dock," Mr. Andrews said. "And we have a collection of 18,000 objects that have never been on view."
Charles Gwathmey of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, the New York architect who designed the renovation and expansion of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan, has masterminded the Seattle design, which adds a three-story structure to the museum's 1927 Gothic-style building.
The university, which owns the building and the museum, pays its basic operating expenses. Mr. Andrews said 60 percent of the museum's budget comes from private sources, which finance the exhibitions and special programs. The museum is close to reaching its fund-raising goal of $23 million -- $21 million has been obtained -- for both the museum's new building and its endowment. Paul Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft, gave $5 million toward the new building.
 
 
 
Staying in the Neighborhood
 Robert Pincus-Witten has left the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue, where he was director for more than six years. But he's staying in the neighborhood: he's now exhibitions director of C & M Arts on East 78th Street, where he will put together the kind of historical exhibitions he was known for at Gagosian.

HEADLINE: Engineers Needn't Fear Worker Influx

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael S. Teitelbaum's cry of "Too Many Engineers, Too Few Jobs" (Op-Ed, March 19), on proposals rejected by Congress that would have held down increases in the number of skilled foreign workers allowed to immigrate to the United States, is an echo of the 1970's. 
 I cannot fault Mr. Teitelbaum's statistics on unemployment among engineers, but they are counter to the experience of my Ph.D. students, six of whom have found good jobs in industry in the last two years. In addition, all my Taiwanese students have returned home to find jobs. Students from India are attracted back home to an expanding economy.
As corporations cut research, the role of research universities in training engineers becomes more important. Some universities have seen decreases in their Ph.D. programs in response to anticipated funding cuts. Complex technology will require more engineers with advanced training, not fewer.
 
FRANCIS C. MOON
Ithaca, N.Y., March 19, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of engineering at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Buchanan and the Fish

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
So Patrick Buchanan will not be the Republican candidate for President this year. But he has become a steadily increasing political and moral liability to the Republican Party, to Americans who usually vote Republican and to Democrats thinking of doing so this November.
The burden was not created by Mr. Buchanan all by himself. He would have been a long time gone if he had not had the help of the Republican candidates and party leaders. 
 By selective silence they helped him build national standing and, save our souls, acceptability. They criticized his economics but refused to say why he had no place in political life, when they knew exactly why.
In the primary campaign, he showed himself as he has for years -- intelligent enough to exploit real problems troubling many Americans and superciliously ignored by the mainstream politicians, a rousing orator, and a bigot.
He tried on the stump to control revealing the hate in him during the campaign. But these types find that real hard. So he got what kicks were available at least cost -- slurs about Jews and Latinos meant to be understood beneath the light code-word covering, the ineradicable insult to blacks of promoting use of the Confederate flag, and the sick pride that gutter brawlers take in refusing to apologize for what they do.
But that's old Pat, the quintessential Washington insider hilariously playing a factory hand in overalls, the sidekick of politicians and journalists, the house anti-Jew whom even Jews among them tolerated and "stood by."
Poor chaps must have felt in an awkward situation. But not more awkward than the one William Buckley finds himself in. Some journalists recently said that Mr. Buckley had denounced Mr. Buchanan as an anti-Semite, in 1992, after I made the charge. In fact there were Jews who had taken their impression that a non-Jew was saying Mr. Buchanan was anti-Semitic as permission to say a few naughty-naughty words about him themselves.
Mr. Buckley has felt compelled to write a new column saying he had done no such thing. He is right.
Mr. Buckley points out that while he had written that it was impossible to defend Mr. Buchanan against charges that what he had done and said "amounted to anti-Semitism," he had also explained that Mr. Buchanan was "most probably" driven by an "iconoclastic temperament." You see? Mr. Buckley, my old friend, is irritated that lesser journalistic minds found the refinement "too complicated too handle." You can understand his annoyance.
But a few other noted writers are not finding it difficult to make themselves plain. George Will writes contemptuously of Mr. Buchanan's "eagerness" to use material denying the Holocaust. And in Time magazine Lance Morrow had a fine essay with the magnificently descriptive title: "Stinking to High Heaven."
It is the householder's hygienic duty to toss a fish out when it begins to stink. In the Buchanan matter, Republican leaders are the householders. But while many found fault with the fish's trade policy, most dealt with the fundamental, disqualifying issue of bigotry by looking pained and saying: "What fish?"
But in an open letter, Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, denounced Mr. Buchanan for denigrating women, bashing homosexuals, criminalizing immigrants, insulting African-Americans. I can hear the snickers of New Yorkers who would not give Mr. D'Amato credit if he pulled them out of a burning building: wasn't it easy for him because he led the Dole campaign in New York?
If it was so easy why don't more Dole backers do it -- or Mr. Dole himself? Will he really let Mr. Buchanan light a venom-fire at the San Diego Convention without renouncing him? Will they stand together, arms raised in unity? If so, where will we go to be sick? If not, shouldn't he start the casting-out of Mr. Buchanan before the Convention?
Every day that goes by without the Republican leadership breaking its silence about why American values disqualify Mr. Buchanan allows him to burrow more lastingly into American political life.
Am I shouting into the wind to ask Republicans to risk losing some votes of Buchanan backers by telling the truth about him? Probably, but better a hoarse throat than one more zippered mouth.

HEADLINE: Ruth Chinitz Uris, New York Philanthropist

 BODY:
Ruth Chinitz Uris, a New York philanthropist and chairwoman of the Uris Brothers Foundation, died on Tuesday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 86.
Mrs. Uris was the widow of Harold Uris, the developer, and she continued the couple's charitable work after his death in 1982. The beneficiaries have ranged from famous institutions that showed their appreciation by putting the Uris name on a school, a library or a hospital wing to low-income housing in the South Bronx. 
 Recipients of multimillion-dollar gifts from the foundation include the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Junior Museum and educational programs, the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, Cornell University, and Lenox Hill Hospital.
The foundation Mrs. Uris headed also gave grants to projects likely to better the life of a specific neighborhood and its homeless, unemployed and undereducated. She served for many years on the board of the Hudson Guild, a large settlement house in Chelsea.
She was born in Manhattan, the daughter of the restaurateurs Aaron and Rose Chinitz, and attended Smith College.
Mrs. Uris is survived by four daughters, Judith Haber of Germantown, N.Y., Susan Halpern of Manhattan, Dr. Linda Sanger of Cambridge, Mass., and Jane Bayard of Manhattan, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Bad Weather Is Blamed for Inventory Rise

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Business inventories jumped in January, the Commerce Department said today, but analysts said the surge reflected special factors and not a weakening economy. They similarly dismissed an increase in jobless claims.
Inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since a seven-tenths of 1 percent surge last October. At the same time, the Labor Department said that jobless claims shot up by 32,000 last week to the highest level in two months. 
 "It seems to be the weather and the strike," said Jeff K. Thredgold, an economist for Keycorp in Cleveland, who was referring to the blizzards in January and the 17-day strike against the General Motors Corporation, in which a tentative agreement was reached today.
For business in January, sales were down in all categories -- nine-tenths of 1 percent for manufacturers, six-tenths of 1 percent for wholesalers and one-tenth of 1 percent for retailers. Inventories rose as manufacturers and wholesalers had difficulty shipping their goods because of the severe weather, which also kept consumers from visiting stores and shopping malls, Mr. Thredgold said. "People either couldn't get out or chose not to fight the storms, so the stuff on the shelves didn't go anywhere," Mr. Thredgold said.
The G.M. strike was limited to two plants but eventually crippled 26 of G.M.'s 29 assembly plants and 18 parts plants and forced the auto maker to furlough 175,800 of its 250,000 hourly workers in the United States, Mexico and Canada. The strike also affected dozens of other parts plants and suppliers.
The Labor Department said the layoffs contributed to the 384,000 new jobless claims last week, but was unable to say how much. The weekly increase was the largest since a jump of 91,000 during the week that ended Jan. 20.
The Commerce Department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $982.65 billion in January, up from $977.26 billion in December, when they were off four-tenths of 1 percent for their first decline since March 1994.
Both manufacturers and wholesalers saw stockpiles rise seven-tenths of 1 percent, and retailers experienced a two-tenths of 1 percent gain.
Business sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $695.64 billion, after rising 1 percent in December. It was the first decline since a three-tenths of 1 percent drop in October and the largest since 1.1 percent last July.
The inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.41, up from 1.40 in December, meaning it would take 1.41 months to exhaust stockpiles at the January sales rate. The ratio was 1.42 in November.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Investory-Sales Ratio" shows total month-end business inventory divided by total monthly business sales from Aug. 1994 to Jan. 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Hint of Rate Cut by Germany Strengthens Dollar in Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday, bolstered by renewed hopes for lower German interest rates.
 The dollar opened New York trading higher on comments by the Bundesbank's chief economist, Otmar Issing, that the next move in German interest rates was likely to be down.
Comments by Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister, and Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, a Bundesbank official, later fueled further dollar buying, briefly pushing the dollar above 1.4800 marks, traders said. 
 Bundesbank officials "have another interest rate cut left in them, and that's helping to buoy the dollar," said Win Thin, international economist at Midland Bank.
The German central bank, which last lowered official interest rates in December, is under pressure to make further cuts to help restart the sputtering German economy and relieve high unemployment.
Lower German interest rates would benefit the dollar by making dollar-based stocks and bonds more attractive versus their German counterparts.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4785 marks, from 1.4737 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was quoted at 106.70 Japanese yen, up from 106.35 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5375, from $1.5390.
Mr. Kuhbacher of the Bundesbank said he still saw room for further cuts in German interest rates, despite a strong 12.6 percent annualized rise in German money supply in February.
The February data had dampened speculation about a near-term cut in German interest rates, traders said.
"People are putting a little less weight on the money supply data and putting more weight on the fact that German growth is slow," Mr. Thin said.
Comments yesterday by Mr. Waigel that German gross domestic product may have fallen again in the first quarter of 1996, reflecting sluggish economic growth, also supported the dollar, Mr. Thin said.
The dollar remained strong against the yen as a haven currency on continued friction between Taiwan and China, traders said.
Tomorrow Taiwan will hold its first presidential elections, which China is attempting to influence with military exercises and missile tests in the Taiwan Strait.
"With the election in Taiwan coming, people would rather sell yen and buy dollars," said Cynthia Johnson, vice president of foreign exchange at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday on a report that showed regional manufacturing activity slowing slightly. The report served to revive hopes that the nation's central bank could yet lower interest rates.
The Philadelphia Fed's regional survey found that business activity fell one-tenth of 1 percent in March, after a 3.8 percent gain in February. A component of the survey tallying prices paid fell in the month but much less so than in February. With the general signs of sluggishness, economists predict that the next national survey by purchasing managers is likely to decrease. 
 The 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to a price of 921/32 for a yield of 6.61 percent, down from 6.63 percent on Wednesday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that other statistics released yesterday did not answer questions about the course of economic activity. Initial claims for unemployment insurance rose sharply because of the General Motors strike and subsequent assembly line shutdowns, but since the increase in claims was less than expected, it prompted some analysts to suggest that labor market conditions possibly improved, excluding the G.M. effect.
"This theory of course cannot be tested at this time," he said, "but since the G.M. work stoppage has just apparently been settled, the uncertainty surrounding the initial claims statistics will gradually lessen over the next few weeks." For the week ended March 18, initial unemployment claims rose 32,000, to 384,000.
But there was nothing ambiguous about the March survey from the Philadelphia Fed, "which was both weaker than anticipated and weaker than February," Mr. Fine said. "Not surprisingly, this was led by a drop in new orders, and although the prices paid and prices received weren't quite as negative as they were a month ago, both price measurements were still subject to downward pressure."
"The Philly Fed index did not really change the market perception of the manufacturing sector; it was simply confirmation of the industrial sector's sluggishness," Mr. Fine said. He said the service and construction sectors accounted for 95 percent of February's huge payroll gain. The March jobs report, due out on April 5, will answer some questions, he said.
The payroll numbers are typically the most awaited economic data of any month, he said, "but this time around the anticipation may establish the all-time record and approach heart-attack proportions."
Bonds were given a small boost yesterday afternoon on news that a tentative accord was reached in the G.M. strike, with a union vote on today. While the strike was mainly about outsourcing, some market participants seem to think the United Automobile Workers was testing General Motors' resolve in case it picks that company as its negotiating target for industrywide contract talks in September. "Based on appearances at the moment, the union has found out that G.M. certainly has more resolve than they anticipated," Mr. Fine said. "The market apparently came to the same conclusion, given its sensitivity to wage pressure and inflation. That's why bonds prices started to rise shortly after the announcement in the afternoon."
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, commented that the market had finally reached the top of the range, a level not seen since the March 8 release of the employment data. "Traders are questioning where the next round of buying will come from," he said. "Since Friday will not bring any exciting data, the bias is to stay within the current price range and try a a breakout early next week."
He forecast that any testing of higher prices would bring out sellers among American investors. "For the most part," Mr. Burtnick said, "they remained long when the market fell off the cliff a few weeks ago, and wouldn't mind lightening their load before the end of this quarter."

HEADLINE: Minnesotans Split on Bill Requiring 'Living Wage'

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, March 20

 BODY:
In the hallways and tunnels of the Minnesota Capitol here, Mel Duncan spends his days lobbying for bills that he hopes will house the homeless, feed the hungry and ease the burden of workers who try to support their families on $4.25 an hour, the minimum wage.
Mr. Duncan, the executive director of the Minnesota Alliance for Progressive Action, a coalition of citizens' groups, does not often see eye-to-eye with anti-government conservatives like Patrick J. Buchanan. But these days, the two men and a growing number of Americans from right to left, from St. Paul to Baltimore to Los Angeles, agree on at least one issue: businesses that are getting richer every day, helped in part by corporate tax breaks and other benefits, have a responsibility to more than just the bottom line and should pay all of their workers a "living wage." 
 It is an idea that is spreading across the country like a fire on the prairie in these tense times of layoffs, declining wages and fear about tomorrow.
The flames are especially high and hot right now in Minnesota, even though the state has one of the lowest unemployment rates in the nation. On Tuesday, the State Senate passed legislation that requires businesses with more than 20 employees that receive at least $25,000 in state or local assistance to pay workers whose jobs were created because of the subsidy a minimum of $7.28 an hour in wages and benefits.
Part of the reason for the law, Mr. Duncan says, is that scrutiny is rarely focused on government aid to business, which he calls corporate welfare, and that corporations benefiting from this assistance should be required to give something back to the public.
"Look at all the spotlights we put on mothers and children on A.F.D.C.," said Mr. Duncan, referring to Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program. "We spent $116 million on A.F.D.C. in Minnesota, and $1.5 billion on corporate welfare, and we don't even have a flashlight shining on that."
State Senator John C. Hottinger, a Democrat who sponsored the legislation, said in an interview: "What this bill is really about is accountability and responsibility. If we're spending government money, taxpayers' dollars, we should get something in return." He added, "Unemployment is down in Minnesota but more and more people are having a hard time making it because so many of the new jobs are low paying."
The Republican leader of the State Senate, Dean E. Johnson, opposed the bill and rose to his feet in the Senate chambers on Tuesday to condemn the measure as "socialist."
Then State Senator Kevin Chandler, a Democrat, picked up his microphone and said that if businesses "come to us with their hands out" and receive government loans or grants, they must be held to the same standard that ordinary citizens are held to, "that is, they must be responsible." He continued, "All we're asking is that companies keep the social contract they used to have with their workers."
The bill, one of the first of its kind in the country to be so close to becoming state law, is expected to move to the State House of Representatives on Monday and could go into effect as early as Aug. 1 if passed and signed by Gov. Arne Carlson, a Republican.
But Mr. Carlson's deputy chief of staff, Cyndy Brucato, said in an interview that the Governor would veto the bill because it "substantially interferes with the marketplace" by mandating the higher minimum wage. "It impedes rather than promotes business growth," she said.
The Senate passed the bill, 39 to 22, despite the Governor's opposition, which echoes the concerns of the Minnesota Chamber of Commerce and other business groups that warn that the higher minimum wage would chase corporations out of the state, which is known for its lakes, clean cities, cold weather and warm business climate.
"We support accountability but mandating wages like this will have a chilling effect on business development," Judy Cook, president of the Minnesota Retail Merchants Association, said as she lobbied against the measure. "But this is an election year, and common sense is usually the first to go."
Peter Dreier, a professor of public policy at Occidental College in Los Angeles who was a special assistant to Raymond L. Flynn when he was Mayor of Boston, said that the bad-for-business talk was "bogus," and that coalitions of labor unions, church groups, advocates for the homeless and other citizens' groups were forming around living wage campaigns "in a way that is reminiscent of the 60's."
"It's a step in the right direction," he said. "It will help the economy because it will put money in people's pockets."
There are similar "living wage" campaigns in Los Angeles, Chicago, Baltimore, St. Louis and several other cities and states.
But organizers know they have a long way to go. The Minnesota bill's mandated wage is about $3 higher than the minimum wage. But it still just barely puts a family of four on the slippery slope of the Federal poverty line, a place where "nobody can really raise a family," Mr. Duncan said, adding that he preferred to call the measure a "poverty-level wage" rather than a "living wage."
It is unclear how many workers would be affected by the bill, but there are now about 120,000 workers in Minnesota earning the minimum wage. There are also several groups, like Acorn, here and across the country, that are conducting efforts to increase minimum wage levels for all workers, whether their companies receive government assistance or not.
In Minnesota, a coalition of labor unions, advocates for the homeless and other citizens' groups have been lobbying for the legislation for more than two years. Last year, the Minnesota Legislature enacted a watered-down version that did not mandate a wage scale, the most contentious element of "living wage" campaigns around the country.
Last November, St. Paul voters rejected a citywide ballot proposal linking higher wages and government business assistance. The St. Paul measure was broader than the bill the Senate passed on Tuesday and did not exempt small businesses from the higher wage obligation.
The House sponsor of the state bill, Karen Clark, a Democrat from Minneapolis, said she was confident that it would be passed by the House, which, like the Senate, is controlled by Democrats.
"We have the momentum now," Ms. Clark said after the Senate vote. "It's a good victory for working people and those who want to work."

HEADLINE: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE EXPATRIATES;
Thousands Head Home For the Vote

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 21

 BODY:
Ming-Chau (Mitch) Yang said goodbye to his pregnant wife and 2-year-old daughter today to join millions of other Taiwanese by casting his vote in Taiwan's first direct presidential election.
Mr. Yang is one of nearly 6,000 Taiwanese living in the United States who are flying back for Saturday's election, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington. In addition, several thousand more of the nearly 300,000 Taiwanese who live in the United States are going to Taiwan to witness the event without voting, community leaders estimate. 
 It was only in the 1980's that the people of Taiwan -- ruled for decades by Nationalist leaders who had fled the mainland as Communists took over -- had a free choice of parties in legislative elections, and Saturday will provide their first chance to vote directly for a President.
"I want to go back and talk to many people and convince them the best chance for Taiwan is independence," said Mr. Yang, explaining why he is spending nearly $2,000 and taking three days off work to vote.
"It's very expensive, but it's all worth it," said Mr. Yang, 36, an electrical engineer who is also working toward his M.B.A. at the University of Southern California. "I want to participate in making history."
Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, 73, who is expected to win the election, has been attacked by Beijing for what it says is his secret ambition to achieve Taiwan's independence from China. China has staged a series of missile tests and war games off Taiwan, apparently in the hope of weakening Mr. Lee by frightening voters from the polls or steering them toward other candidates.
Professor Chi Tsung, who specializes in East Asia and Chinese politics at Occidental College in Los Angeles, said he believed Beijing's attempts at intimidation have worked. Before China's military maneuvers, which began on March 8, tens of thousands had been expected to return to Taiwan to cast their vote. "The military exercises by the mainland has had a clear impact on the number of people deciding to go home," he said, adding that those who are returning are not politically homogeneous.
For example, Joe Chiu, president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Organization in Los Angeles, said that about 50 of his group's members flew to Taiwan to vote for President Lee.
Mr. Yang, on the other hand, planned to vote for Peng Ming-min, the candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party, which seeks complete independence for Taiwan from the mainland China. He said he was not worried about his safety, partly, he said, because he did not believe that China would invade Taiwan, but mostly because he is willing to sacrifice his life for Taiwan, to which he hopes to return someday to live with his family.
"If war should break out, I will join the army and defend Taiwan," he said. "I want to show my support for an independent Taiwan in any way I can."
Mr. Yang's wife, Frances, 29, who came to the United States about 13 years ago to attend school, said she would accompany her husband to Taiwan to vote if she were not eight months pregnant.
"I feel very angry toward China," said Mrs. Yang, who holds dual citizenship and will vote in the California primary this month. "I think their actions just show that they have no regard for people's choices and that they don't really know what democracy is. I hope the people of Taiwan stand up for themselves, for independence and democracy."

HEADLINE: Maybe a House Is Just a Home;
Skittish Prices Dull Real Estate's Investment Luster

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE, Md., March 21

 BODY:
In the 1980's, it was a gold mine. Now, the suburban brick colonial at 8304 Aqueduct Road here about 10 miles northwest of downtown Washington is just a house again.
The price trajectory of Ralph and Elizabeth Mittl's Rockville home -- soaring from $130,000 in 1980 to $283,000 in 1988 and $312,000 in 1991 before falling back to $291,000 when they bought it last December -- has a lot to do with the big changes in the way Americans, and baby boomers in particular, are trying to build financial security. 
 Not that long ago, the common prescription was simple: buy a house you could scarcely afford, borrow as much as possible, and wait to be rewarded for your extravagance. As a Merrill Lynch Realty flier of the day put it, "Put inflation to work for you!"
And it worked. That highly leveraged, tax-advantaged house -- financed at rates otherwise available only to blue-chip corporations -- almost invariably rocketed in value. Was making money in real estate easy, or what?
Today, of course, that's history -- at least in most parts of the country. Big gains are the rare exception these days and some sellers, in fact, wind up in the painful and embarrassing position of having to bring money to the closing, occasionally even more of their own cash than the buyer brings. As an investment, housing is no longer a sure thing.
This reversal in the real estate market is part of a decade-long shift from real assets to financial ones, with the stock market taking off last year in one of the biggest rallies on record.
Today, for the first time since the early 1970's, stock holdings have jumped well past the the value of home equity. In 1993, mutual fund and other stock market holdings of Americans edged ahead of equity -- the value of owner-occupied housing minus mortgage debt -- but last year stock market ownership climbed above $5.5 trillion, easily surpassing the estimated $4.3 trillion equity in the nation's homes, according to Federal Reserve data.
Part of that gain is price appreciation, but much is a reflection of the vastly increased money flowing into stocks. In 1980, for example, Americans purchased only $2.1 billion in mutual fund shares, the prime vehicle for middle-class stock ownership. Last year, mutual fund purchases were close to $200 billion.
"The color of money has changed," said Joseph G. Carson, senior vice president and chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Housing is not likely to ever regain the investment status it had back in the 1970's," Mr. Carson contended.
Mr. Mittl, a 31-year-old consultant with Price Waterhouse who had lived in a Washington apartment for four years before buying the house, is well aware of the change. "It's a place to live to us," he said, taking a break on a recent Sunday from installing a new brass lamp alongside the front walkway. "It's not really an investment."
Instead, Mr. Mittl said, he's been "pouring more" money into the stock market over the last year and a half, at least doubling the monthly amounts going into a half-dozen stock mutual funds he and his wife own. They bought another mutual fund to set aside money for the college education of their son, 11-month-old Matthew, and just opened an account for an unborn child, the son they expect this June.
Saying that stocks offer the best way to build assets, the Mittls also own a few individual stocks and use tax-advantaged retirement vehicles. "We both max our 401(k)'s, we both do I.R.A.'s," Mr. Mittl said.
Interviews with recent buyers and market professionals alike strongly support the view that families no longer regard housing as the soundest means for accumulating wealth and the foundation of a comfortable retirement.
"They can't count on that as their nest egg that's going to continue to grow at 6 to 8 percent," said Michael P. DeChant, head of a company here that appraises residential real estate. "That's out the window."
These days, said F. Ruth Dickie, who manages a Bethesda, Md., branch of Long & Foster, the Washington area's largest real estate agency, most buyers are not as willing to stretch to buy the biggest, most expensive house. "They know that if they put it in housing," she said, "that it's not going to do as well as in the stock market."
But the sobering lesson in real estate reality, rudely impressed on recent buyers and sellers, is not yet appreciated by many homeowners who have had no exposure to the market since 1989 or 1990, when prices roared to a peak in affluent Montgomery County, which includes Rockville and other prosperous suburbs just outside Washington. The 1990's have witnessed a persistent decline that only recently has begun to show signs of reversing. Median prices here soared from $78,750 in 1985 to $130,000 in 1990, but slipped to $122,500 in 1994 before eking out a modest gain to $125,000 last year.
"Our job is to tell them their baby's ugly," Mr. DeChant said. Homeowners, many of whom have lavished expensive improvements on on their houses, react angrily, he said, when told that their house is worth less than its value six years ago. Often, the news derails hopes of refinancing or taking out a large home equity loan. Longtime homeowners, of course, still enjoy a large equity stake, but those who bought a home after 1988 almost invariably have lost part of their down payment and sometimes owe more than their home is worth.
Most of the decline has been in the lot rather than the house. "The land is the more volatile element -- always has been," said Joseph Blalock, senior financial economist for America's Community Bankers, a trade association for savings and loans.
Shocking as it is, the reaction to falling home prices mainly reflects the mind-set of a generation of homeowners who came to regard the abnormal as the natural economic order. Ms. Dickie, the Long & Foster manager, knows better. She recalls her own days as a "high flying" agent when houses sold within a week or two at steadily escalating prices but recognizes that they are long gone.
Through financial history, "you'll find that houses track inflation," she said. "We're reverting to normal."
The real estate boom of the 1970's and 1980's was also fueled by the demographics of baby boomers reaching prime home-buying years. But today, as baby boomers are entering their 40's and 50's, they are pouring more money into financial assets, spurred by a new-found desire to save for retirement and to pay for their children's college education. A home can no longer be counted on to finance such needs.
In real estate, buyers are well aware of their bargaining leverage, making them extremely fussy. "People come and look so carefully now -- seven or eight times at the same house," said Susan Messitte, whose Chevy Chase residence has been on the market since last April despite three price reductions that have brought it down this month to $519,000 from an initial $599,000. The Messittes' first broker proposed listing at $630,000.
Another sign of the times is the growing number of agents who are leaving the field, with membership in the Montgomery County Association of Realtors down 30 percent from its high in 1989.
And it could get even bleaker, home builders and others in the industry contend, if some version of a flat tax ever became law and eliminated deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes.
Already, weak housing markets in some areas are contributing to making the country somewhat less mobile. According to the Census Bureau, 16.7 percent of the population moved between March 1993 and March 1994, down from 20.2 percent who moved in 1984-85. Long Island has one of the highest proportions of what the Government calls "stayers," said Robert Bonnette, a bureau statistician.
But despite the distress here and in other formerly white-hot markets, like Boston and Southern California, there are other areas, scattered through the Sun Belt, Midwest, Pacific Northwest and in Rocky Mountain boom towns like Boise, Idaho, and Salt Lake City where housing is doing well.
Indeed, home ownership in the fourth quarter of 1995 climbed to its highest point in 14 years. But that rebound mainly reflects improved affordability because of low interest rates and sluggish prices. Demographic projections have underestimated demand, particularly from immigrants, who tend to be avid home buyers.
So all is not lost for homeowners. A recent forecast by Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa., suggests that housing may not lag financially by as much in the second half of the 1990's as in the first half of the decade. And while it is likely to continue to trail stocks, the average single-family home, the firm predicts, should at least outperform Treasury bills.
"Long term, housing stacks up relatively well against financial assets -- and beats cash," said Mark Zandi, chief economist for Regional Financial.
Others note that homeowners developed exaggerated expectations in the era of inflation. Robert J. Shiller, professor of economics at Yale and a proprietor of Case Shiller Weiss Inc., a company based in Cambridge, Mass., which tracks home transactions, describes residential real estate as "kind of an amateurish market" subject to great volatility. Too many people, particularly on the East and West Coasts, assumed that houses could only increase in value forever.
"People had just wild expectations," Mr. Shiller said. "They used to think real estate was a terrific investment. Now people think stocks are a great investment. It's capricious."
And however traumatic it has been for many homeowners -- real estate being the core of net worth for the middle class -- disenchantment with houses as investment vehicles is probably good for the economy at large, most analysts agree.
"The United States is overinvested in housing," said James F. Smith, who teaches graduate finance at the University of North Carolina. "We now get more investment in other things -- meaning more productivity, higher corporate profits, higher employment and higher personal income. This is long overdue."

HEADLINE: Stock Market Closes Mixed, With Dow Falling by 28.54

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday, reflecting investor concern over a deteriorating economy. Although the key market indicators all closed lower, there were more advances than declines on the major exchanges.
"It was a down market, but it was not down with conviction," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist of Gruntal & Company. "The bigger-capitalization stocks were affected negatively more than the general market." 
 Thus, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.54 points, or one-half of a percentage point, to 5,628.88. Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.79 point, or 0.12 of a percentage point, to 649.19, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.03 points, or 0.18 of a percentage point, to 1,099.79.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange narrowly exceeded decliners, 1,237 to 1,134. A total of 365.8 million shares changed hands, down from 409.8 million shares on Wednesday and the lowest since 362.9 million shares were traded last Jan. 29.
In contrast to stocks' directionless performance, the bond market was up modestly in the wake of a report on regional manufacturing by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank that was more sluggish than expected. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 4/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.61 percent, from 6.63 percent on Wednesday.
"Stock prices are very close to the top," Mr. Battipaglia said. "The day's pullbacks were not statistically significant."
Once again, technology issues paced the decline. The weakness in computer stocks -- partly attributed to Digital Equipment's warning on Wednesday that quarterly earnings would be below expectations -- continued. Digital dropped 2 3/4, to 53 1/4; I.B.M. gave up 2 1/8, to 114 7/8, and Hewlett-Packard declined 2 7/8, to 94 3/4.
Software companies followed the same downward pattern. Microsoft closed at 100 3/4, down 3 7/8; Intuit closed at 47, down 1/4, and Netscape closed at 43 1/2, down 2 1/2.
Networking stocks sagged after some analysts voiced concern over sluggish demand for these products. Cabletron lost 5 1/4, to 69 3/4; 3Com fell 7/8, to 42 1/8, and Cisco Systems dropped 1 1/4, to 44 3/4.
As traders rotated out of the high-tech sectors yesterday, they moved into defensive groups with steady earnings, like pharmaceuticals. Eli Lilly increased 4 5/8, to 66 5/8; Pfizer gained 3 1/2, to 66 7/8, and Merck added 2 1/2, to 65 1/2. The American Stock Exchange's pharmaceuticals index climbed 8.52 points, or almost 3 percent, to 307.7.
Automotive stocks were generally firm, after General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union tentatively agreed to settle a 17-day strike. General Motors rose 1/8, to 53 5/8, and Chrysler advanced 7/8, to 63 3/8. But Ford Motor fell 1/8, to 33 7/8.
Stac Inc. rallied 1 1/8, to 10 1/8, after being upgraded by Smith Barney. Health Management soared 1 7/8, to 4 3/4, after saying that a restatement of earnings would show the company to be profitable in the 1995 fiscal year. And Dawson Production Services jumped 1 1/4, to 11 1/4, on its first day of trading.
However, Philip Morris, plagued by investors' concerns over smoker lawsuits, resumed its recent slide and declined 2 3/4, to 86 3/4. Amcol International, which said that first-quarter earnings would be far below Wall Street estimates, plunged 4, to 12 5/8. And Strawbridge & Clothier, which was downgraded by UBS Securities, dropped 3 1/4, to 21 1/2.

HEADLINE: Federal Agency Fines Company a Record $1.5 Million for Hiring Illegal Immigrants

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
Federal immigration authorities yesterday announced the largest fine ever levied against a company for hiring illegal immigrants -- $1.5 million against a Westchester cleaning business -- as part of a national effort to increase pressure on employers to comply with immigration laws.
A lawyer for the company, Colin Service Systems Inc., based in White Plains, said it had never knowingly hired illegal workers and would contest the fines. The company employs 4,200 people in seven states and had income of $67.5 million in 1994, according to immigration officials. 
 The company, which provides cleaning and maintenance services, said it dismissed more than 2,200 of its employees in 1992 after the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service examined the individuals' work documents and notified the company that it suspected the workers were illegal immigrants.
But Doris Meissner, the agency's commissioner, said the dismissals came only after the agency cited the company for more than 150 instances, dating to 1990, of "knowingly hiring illegal aliens and continuing to employ aliens after their work authorization had expired," and for 2,500 instances of failing to maintain proper employee records.
In addition to the fines sought by the immigration service, Ms. Meissner said prosecutors were seeking a grand jury to bring criminal charges against five of the company's managers. She did not give any more details on the grand jury investigation.
The fine brought against the company is part of the Clinton Administration's strategy to toughen enforcement of a 1986 law that prohibits any person or company from employing illegal workers. Administration officials say the effort will help dry up job opportunities for illegal workers here and their desire to immigrate.
Since last year, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has more than doubled the number of inspectors, to 700 nationally and to 60 in New York, devoted to workplace enforcement. And last month, the agency's New York office began detaining all workers arrested for being here illegally. Before, they had been released with an order to return for a deportation hearing, then often never showed up.
The agency is also clearly seeking to maximize publicity for its enforcement actions, magnifying their impact. This week, immigration agents arrested dozens of meat packing workers in Philadelphia, machine operators in Norwalk, Conn., and janitors at the State House in Trenton.
Last month, agents swept through restaurants in a suburb of Washington, arresting 83 people. And the immigration service says it has apprehended 700 illegal garment workers in New York over the last six months.
The agency's offensive comes at a time when Congress is considering stricter sanctions against employers who hire illegal workers and Presidential candidates are heatedly debating who has the best plan to slow illegal immigration.
Ms. Meissner acknowledged that 700 inspectors cannot begin to examine the hiring practices of every employer in the nation. Rather, she said, the agency is counting on random enforcement in industries that have particularly bad records of hiring illegal workers to encourage broader compliance with the law.
"Nobody questions that the people here in an illegal status work hard and that they contribute to the productivity of the economy," she said. But, she added, their presence in the work force "undermines labor standards and working conditions of all workers and sets up situations of exploitation of workers."
Since the law on sanctioning employers was adopted in 1986, the agency has had little money to enforce it, officials said, a situation that is only beginning to change. And the law has been difficult to enforce, in part because the Government has had a hard time proving that employers knowingly hired illegal immigrants.
Some immigration experts say it is hard to predict what impact the new approach will have, while others say it is more likely to push illegal immigrants further into the underground economy than deter them from coming to America in the first place.
The $1.5 million fine announced yesterday is the largest the agency has levied since 1992, when it fined a fruit packing company in Georgia $1.2 million.
Since 1989, the immigration service has collected less than half the fines it had notified companies it was seeking. Last year, for example, the agency levied $10.4 million in fines, and collected $4.1 million.
And officials at Colin Service Systems said that the agency unevenly enforced actions against its workers. The agency's current policy is to deport illegal workers. But in 1992, when the company dismissed more than 2,200 workers whom the agency suspected were illegal, immigration authorities made no attempt to apprehend them, company officials said.
"The I.N.S. didn't arrest any of them," said Aaron Marcu, a lawyer with Howard, Darby & Levin, which is representing the company. "They didn't ask for their addresses."
Immigration officials said their ability to arrest illegal workers was limited by the lack of detention space. The agency is now trying to expand that capacity, they said.
Of the 62 workers at Colin that the immigration service arrested from 1991 to 1994, the agency could only say with certainty that one had been deported, said Mark Thorn, an agency spokesman. Another 53 were placed in deportation proceedings and eight agreed to voluntarily leave the country.
On Wednesday, immigration agents arrested 24 workers employed by the Trenton Janitorial Supply Company after the workers arrived for the nightshift at the New Jersey State House and another state office building. The workers, mostly Central Americans, were ushered to a conference room and asked to produce work documentation. Those who did not have it were taken away in handcuffs.
The 10 women were released on their own recognizance. The 14 men were detained at a facility in Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: GENERAL MOTORS AND UNION AGREE TO END WALKOUT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 21

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union agreed today to end the biggest auto industry shutdown in a generation, a 16-day strike at two brake factories here that virtually halted G.M.'s operations across North America and caused the layoff of hundreds of thousands of workers.
The tentative agreement, which must be approved by striking workers here, calls for some additional hiring at the brake factories, up to several hundred jobs over the next two years if the operations here hold down costs, a person close to the negotiations said. The pact also contains a few new features allowing G.M. to continue buying some brakes and brake parts from independent, nonunion outside suppliers. This hotly contested practice, known as outsourcing, led to the strike which began here March 5. 
 But G.M. did not achieve its most important goal: new, nationwide rules allowing it to buy many more car and truck parts, not just brakes, from outside suppliers, the person close to the talks said. G.M. could still ask the U.A.W. to follow today's pact as a model in negotiations this summer on the union's nationwide contract with Detroit's Big Three automakers.
Both the company and the union officially declined to discuss any terms of the agreement that was hammered together here at the end of a two-day bargaining session. So it was not entirely clear to labor and auto experts today who won and who lost. But there were considerable concerns that G.M.'s gains fell short of the strike's cost to the company -- estimated at up to $1 billion in pretax profits. No deal covering the Dayton operation alone could justify the strike's cost, said Sean McAlinden, a University of Michigan automotive economist.
When Richard Shoemaker, the director of the U.A.W.'s G.M. division, came out the factory's beige steel doors to announce today's deal, he insisted that the accord addressed local issues and did not set precedents for the national negotiation. "Of course it doesn't set the stage for that; it puts the issues behind us in this dispute," he said, while refusing to discuss any details.
The accord will be voted on by local workers at a meeting Friday morning. Daniel Warrell, the manager of the two brake factories here, said that he planned to reopen the factories on Friday afternoon and begin producing brakes immediately. Industry experts said it could take up to a week to resume production at the 26 vehicle assembly operations that were closed by the strike. G.M. officials said that they would first refresh inventories at the plants that make the company's best-selling vehicles.
Today's deal ends the biggest work stoppage in the American auto industry since 1970, when the U.A.W. staged a general strike against G.M. in a dispute over a new national contract. By contrast, this strike was a local work dispute that shut the two factories that make virtually all of G.M.'s brakes. As the strike lengthened, shortages sprang up and closed all but three of G.M.'s 29 North American automotive assembly plants and dozens of parts factories, idling 177,375 workers.
In addition, layoffs at G.M.'s 1,600 suppliers and other businesses ran into the tens of thousands of employees. Several economic research firms estimated earlier this week that the strike had eliminated $5 billion to $7 billion worth of economic output, trimming the nation's economic growth rate in the first quarter by a third.
After making steady progress through the week in negotiations, G.M. and U.A.W. officials struck the critical compromises on Wednesday night, people close to the negotiations said. Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, flew down from Detroit this morning and sealed the deal by shaking hands across the bargaining table with Mr. Shoemaker, who also came down this morning, the person close to the negotiations said. Union officials celebrated afterward with a birthday cake for one of their negotiators.
Mr. Shoemaker had insisted on Mr. Pearce's presence as a guarantee that the corporation would stand behind today's deal, a person close to the talks said. The union local here went on strike accusing G.M. management of backing away from a 1994 deal to keep jobs here -- an accusation that G.M. has repeatedly denied.
The corporate guarantee of good faith by the local factory management was the last detail settled. Relations between local factory managers and local union officials have been acrimonious for several years.
G.M. had sought the ability to buy more parts from outside companies and a chance to influence this summer's negotiations on a new national labor contract. Today's deal did allow G.M. to continue its plans to begin buying some anti-lock brakes next year from a German-owned factory in South Carolina.
Close to 3,200 workers here from U.A.W. Local 696 went on strike. They demanded more safety equipment and training, the hiring of more workers so as to reduce the need for seven-day workweeks and an end to the company's plans to buy more parts from outside suppliers.
G.M. officials responded to the strike as a direct challenge to their ability to choose whether to buy parts from outside companies, and resisted the union's demands much more vigorously than they had during previous strikes at critical parts factories.
"If we can be competitive within our divisions that would be great -- if we can't then we need to look outside," Mr. Pearce said in an interview last week.
The strike drew national attention as a possible signal of a new militancy on the part of organized labor. Yet the issues involved were largely local and the U.A.W. made no effort to involve other unions. The Dayton dispute quickly shut down assembly plants because a decision in recent years by G.M. to save on storage and administrative costs by holding minimal inventories of parts and concentrating parts-making skills in a few factories.
The strike also coincided with the Republican Presidential primaries on Tuesday in Ohio and three other Midwestern states. And the strike touched on the same theme of job security that Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative political commentator, emphasized so strongly in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Union workers often portrayed their strike as an effort to assure that the children of Dayton could someday find good-paying jobs in the factory. G.M. pays up to $40,000 a year plus overtime that lately has raised pay to an average of $69,000. But today's deal to add more workers may not result in people being hired off the street, the person close to the negotiations said. The existing labor contract between G.M. and the U.A.W. gives hiring preference to unemployed U.A.W. workers elsewhere.
On Wall Street many investors saw the strike as evidence that G.M. would attack its problem of high-cost parts. Unlike its rivals, which buy most of their parts, G.M. makes most of its components at U.A.W. plants like the brake factories in Dayton. When the strike began, General Motors' stock closed at $52.25 a share; today it closed at $53.625 a share, up $1.375 a share over the course of the shutdown.
When the brake factories here reopen, Mr. Warrell, the plant manager, said the first brakes manufactured would go to plants G.M. wants to restart quickly. "We've got a start-up plan to flow product to the most important plants," he said.
While Mr. Warrell refused to identify these factories, G.M. is likely to start by sending brakes to its factory in Janesville, Wis., which makes the popular and highly profitable Chevrolet and GMC Suburban, Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon sport utility vehicles. G.M. has less than a month's supply of these vehicles, far below the two-month supply that the industry tries to maintain. The Janesville factory closed only on Monday, making it the last G.M. passenger car or light-truck factory to be closed in the United States.
The U.A.W. has traditionally negotiated a labor contract with whichever auto maker among Detroit's Big Three seemed most likely to make concessions, and then demand that the other two companies accept nearly identical terms. The union has chosen the Ford Motor Company for each of the last several contract negotiations, and Ford has used each occasion to negotiate terms that were advantageous to it but that also tended to hurt G.M.'s competitive position.
Most auto industry analysts have been predicting that the U.A.W. will choose the Chrysler Corporation this year, because the company is very profitable and was not a U.A.W. target for many years when it was financially ailing. Chrysler already buys a higher proportion of its parts from low-cost outside producers than Ford or G.M.
Executives at G.M. have been concerned that Chrysler may negotiate a pact freezing all further moves to buy parts from outside vendors. Such a deal might not hurt Chrysler but would hurt G.M., which plans to buy more such parts.

HEADLINE: TENSION IN TAIWAN: THE POLITICS;
War Games Play Well for Taiwan's Leader

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 21

 BODY:
"We hate China and we will fight to the death for Taiwan!"
Chang Ting-sen, an otherwise temperate-mannered professor of Chinese literature, shouted those words into the din of a packed stadium rally in Chiayi, a southern stronghold of Taiwan's pro-independence forces, and then smiled with satisfaction and yelled it again. 
 As the night sky crackled with fireworks and loudspeakers warmed up the crowd with a torrent of political bombast, he and 20,000 banner-waving Taiwanese packed the sports arena on Tuesday to cheer their candidate, Peng Ming-min, of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.
Like many in Taiwan, the crowd had been roused to indignation by the missile tests and war games China has carried out in an attempt to intimidate the 12 million voters of Taiwan, who on Saturday will hold their first direct presidential election.
But even many independence advocates conceded that they are not the real beneficiaries of the confrontation with China. No one has profited more than Lee Teng-hui, the incumbent and native-born Taiwanese leader, whose own vision of Taiwan's future with the mainland is ambiguous.
Fundamentally, this is President Lee's confrontation with Beijing, brought on by his pursuit of a distinct and independent image for the island of 21 million people. It has transformed the election into a referendum on who should lead Taiwan in its time of crisis. By all accounts, Mr. Lee will win the contest handily.
His critics say this is exactly what the 73-year-old President wanted, an international emergency that would insure his victory and mobilize the United States to strengthen its guarantee of Taiwan's security with a show of naval force and the sale of new weapons.
In whistle-stop appearances through the island and in rousing speeches with nationalistic themes, Mr. Lee, a prodigious campaigner, is siphoning off voters from the pro-independence camp, while holding on to an opposing constituency that simply craves stability, the status quo and a strong leader to face China.
He does so without ever betraying whether he favors reunification or some form of independence.
With the balloting about to begin, the pollsters here say that only his margin of victory is in doubt.
Just a year ago, Mr. Lee's political fortunes were in decline. The legislative majority of his governing Nationalist Party, which has been in power here since 1949, when Chiang Kai-shek appropriated the island as his exile home, was splintering under an assault of anti-corruption sentiment and reformist zeal.
But Mr. Lee's trip to the United States in June, a first for any Taiwan leader and made possible by a well-financed lobbying campaign in Congress, touched off a bellicose response from Beijing that still may not have reached its militaristic peak.
The Communist leaders in Beijing assume that Mr. Lee's image-building campaign is just another way to declare Taiwan's independence and undermine the "one China" principle by which China and Taiwan have lived since 1949.
 
Vagueness on Goals Is a Lee Strategy
But Mr. Lee is deliberately vague about his true colors, so much so that even close associates who have known him for many years are unwilling to venture a guess as to his overall objective.
Chang Tso-chang, president of the island's most influential newspaper, described Mr. Lee this way: "In his heart, he wants independence, but he has never been able to say it. And he is not willing to reunify with the mainland, but he also has never been able to say that."
Added the chairman of a major Taiwan corporation who has known Mr. Lee for many years: "I think Lee Teng-hui shows many different faces to many different people. That's why people are confused by his statements."
Still others see an innate pragmatism in Mr. Lee and a wily political instinct to keep the Communist mainland guessing and at arm's length, while searching for more "living space" for Taiwan in regional and international affairs.
Most Taiwanese today are willing to support such a strategy until some form of greater Chinese democracy emerges in which Taiwan could be confederated. Until then, few people in Taiwan are willing to put themselves in Beijing's hands, as Hong Kong's residents must do in 1997 when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
Mr. Peng, the candidate of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, put it more bluntly at this week's rally in Chaiyi. "Lots of people in China are trying to escape their own country," he said. "Why would we want to be a part of China? If you choose reunification, you are out of your mind."
This campaign is taking place in the midst of the worst political and military crisis here since 1958, when Mao Zedong's threat to send troops across the Taiwan Strait to reclaim China's long-separated province was blocked by the United States Seventh Fleet.
 
China and U.S. Exchange Demands
Now, with two American carrier battle groups steaming protectively in the western Pacific, one near Taiwan and the other expected to arrive this weekend, the crisis has led to harsh exchanges between Washington and Beijing.
Chinese Government spokesmen accuse the United States almost daily of "gross interference" in China's internal affairs, first for sending warships to the region and second for selling, most recently, Stinger missiles and other advanced, defensive weapons to Mr. Lee's 400,000-member armed forces.
In the final days of the campaign, the polemics have only increased with Chinese admonitions that American warships stay out of the Taiwan Strait and Washington's assertion of right of passage through the international waterway.
The Communist leadership in Beijing appears to expect that its display of military fireworks this month will reduce Mr. Lee's margin of victory or sober him to the threat China could mount against the island's economy. That, Beijing may believe, would render Mr. Lee more pliant in negotiations to open direct trade and transportation links across the strait, which China sees as the first step toward reunification.
But experience has shown that Mr. Lee, as a tactician, is not to be underestimated.
"Taiwan has created an economic miracle, and we have built a democracy without bloodshed," Mr. Lee told more than 600 foreign journalists who have arrived to cover what he characterized as democracy in the "shadow of war."
Mr. Lee has shrewdly said his victory would represent a mandate from voters to deal with Beijing from a position of strength. It appears he will get it.
"He has asked the Taiwanese to give him a mandate, to support him in this crisis," said Tim Ting, chief consultant to the polling company, Gallup Taiwan. "I believe he wanted a confrontation with the mainland because it has internationalized the problem of Taiwan. He is getting CNN live coverage, and he is drawing world attention to the threat of Chinese nationalism, while also building up Taiwanese nationalism."
In the field of four candidates, Mr. Ting added, it has been clear for some months that Mr. Lee has a lock on 40 to 50 percent of the vote, well ahead of any challenger.
But Mr. Lee's strategy is not without risks, and there are signs of stress fractures everywhere.
First, there was the sudden deployment this week of a phalanx of security men armed with M-16 rifles to protect all four presidential candidates after reports of an assassination plot detected by the National Security Bureau.
The details were sketchy, but Mr. Peng, the Democratic Progressive candidate, said he had been told that the plot involved a team of mainland Chinese infiltrators who were paid $5 million to kill one or more of the candidates. Government officials confirmed that a plot had been detected, but there was no allegation that Beijing was behind it.
Then, there was the Government intervention in Taiwan's stock market, where central bankers thus far have pumped more than $3 billion to give the appearance of stability in this crucial week before the voting.
Mr. Lee has also sought to calm financial markets with hints that he will seek a new accommodation with the mainland to insure that the $25 billion to $30 billion in Taiwan investment on the mainland is protected.
Still, most of the island's business leaders are panicky over a drop in orders for Taiwan's exports and the flight of capital out of the country.
As a native-born Taiwanese, educated in Japan and the United States, Mr. Lee shows little affinity for the mainland or the mainlanders in his party. The mainlanders are often disparaged here as "wai sheng," or foreign-born, intruders who took over the island when Chiang Kai-shek fled the Communist victory and who, for many years, used martial law rule to suppress indigenous democratic stirrings and to build a corrupt party machine, which today is still accused of vote buying and "money politics."
 
Unpredictability Confounds Critics
With his 6-foot-plus frame, striking silver hair and a disarming, Cheshire cat smile, Mr. Lee continues to confound his critics with unpredictable political tactics. He has promised that he could make another landmark trip after the election to a capital that "no one could imagine."
"The people like Lee Teng-hui because he is a strong leader and he stands up for them in the face of China's dictators," said Chen Shui-bian, the popular mayor of Taipei who is a rising star in the pro-independence camp, but who concedes a grudging admiration for Mr. Lee's political style.
Aside from the fact that Mr. Lee sits atop a party machinery that controls the island's television networks and billions of dollars in assets, his greatest advantage is his own formidable campaigning skills arrayed against an opposition that is seriously diluted.
His appeal straddles the colliding politics of reunification versus independence, infuriating some in both groups.
"Mr. Lee Teng-hui directs and acts the play himself and leads the two sides to the edge of war," said one critic, Lin Yang-kang, the candidate of the New Party. Mr. Lin, 69, is among several stalwarts of the governing Nationalist Party who have given up party posts and privileges to work for Mr. Lee's defeat.
Mr. Lin and his running-mate, Hau Pei-tsun, 77, who were both deputy chairmen of the governing Nationalist Party and once close advisers to Mr. Lee, opened their presidential campaign this winter, accusing Mr. Lee of betraying the Nationalist cause, which is to work for the reunification with the mainland.
The Lin campaign now calls for "peace" with the mainland, but ever since the missiles were launched at target sites near Taiwan's ports this month, their approach has been portrayed by Mr. Lee as surrender to "terror."
In the south, where the independence movement was born, Mr. Lee has never uttered a commitment to declaring independence from the mainland. He does not have to. Taiwan's independence forces believe that he is with them.
He speaks the slang of the southern ports and factory towns, riding bull-horn trucks with local candidates and setting off firecrackers to please the deities of local temples.
"There is no question that he is a native of Taiwan and he thinks like us," says Parris H. Chang, a pro-independence legislator, "and there is nothing in his blood or his system that makes him want reunification."

NATIONALIST PARTY
President Lee Teng-hui, 73, has served as President and chairman of the party since 1988, when Chiang Ching-kuo, son of Chiang Kai-shek, died in office while Mr. Lee was serving as Vice President. His running mate, Lien Chan, has served previously as Foreign Minister and Prime Minister.
 
DEMOCRATIC PROGRESSIVE PARTY
Peng Ming-min, 72, a founder of Taiwan's dissident movement. He was jailed in the 1960's and then escaped abroad, where he studied law in Canada and France and then joined the faculty at Wright State University in Ohio. In 1992 he returned to Taiwan to help build the pro-independence party. His running mate is Hsieh Chang-ting, a legislator and former Taipei city councilman.
 
NEW PARTY
Lin Yang-kang, 69, a vice chairman of the Nationalist Party until December. He and his running mate, Hau Pei-tsun, issued an open letter to the party accusing Mr. Lee of "trying to ruin the party and betray the country" in abandoning the party's traditional support for reunification. They were ejected from the party, but their bid to unseat Mr. Lee attracted the support of Taiwan's New Party, which split from the Nationalist Party in 1993.
 
INDEPENDENT
Chen Li-an, 59, educated at M.I.T. and New York University in mathematics and engineering, he taught at the City University of New York during the late 1960's. After returning to Taiwan, he served in senior Nationalist Party posts, including secretary general of the party's central committee. A former Defense Minister, Mr. Chen also rebelled against Mr. Lee's leadership this winter and formed a presidential campaign with Wang Ching-feng, a lawyer. (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

General Motors and Union Agree to End 16-Day Strike
Negotiators for G.M. and the United Automobile Workers agreed to end the industry's biggest work stoppage in a generation. One person close to the talks said the accord called for some additional hiring at two brake factories, and would give G.M. some flexibility to farm out work to nonunion suppliers.
But U.A.W. members, like the two shown at left, did not give G.M. broad national rules on when it could buy parts outside the company. [Page A1.]
 
Archer-Daniels Shifting Board
Four Archer-Daniels-Midland managers will step down from the agricultural giant's board to make room for an outside majority. A corporate governance committee said the current chummy board had not taken a Federal investigation seriously enough. [D2.]
 
Business Inventories Jump
Business inventories jumped in January, but analysts said that special factors were responsible, and not a weakening economy. They similarly dismissed an increase in jobless claims in the latest week. [D2.]
 
Another Step to Farm Overhaul
A House-Senate panel agreed to overhaul farm programs, ending New Deal policies that pay farmers of certain crops when market prices fall, and replacing them with flat payments that would decline over seven years. The legislation would also end most Government controls over the planting decisions of America's 1.5 million farmers. [A1.]
 
I.B.M. to Hire 3,000 AT&T Workers
I.B.M. agreed to hire as many as 3,000 AT&T workers in exchange for a multibillion-dollar contract with Lucent Technologies, the soon-to-be-independent arm of AT&T. [D7.]
 
Stock Indexes Drift Lower
Stocks closed mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 28.54 points, to 5,628.88. Broader indexes also slipped, but over all, more stocks rose than fell. The technology sector continued to weaken. [D6.]
 
Citicorp Joins Bidding at Masco
Citicorp said it wanted to invest in Masco's furniture business with other partners. Masco said it expected to raise more than $1 billion from the sale. [D6.]
 
Neighbors Assess a Swindle
Edward J. Reiners, who owned the local video store in Somers, N.Y., also swindled eight financial institutions of $323 million, according to Federal prosecutors. The news has left his neighbors agog. [B1.]
 
Signet's loan exceeded its usual limits, showing, experts said, how banks sometimes stretch disciplines to make a profit. [D2.]
 
Top Fund Managers Leave Hancock
Two of the nation's best-performing equity mutual fund managers are leaving the John Hancock Funds, in a demonstration of how top managers can write their own ticket. [D6.]
 
Higher Costs for Chemical Bank
Chemical Banking and Chase said the one-time costs of merging would be $1.9 billion, or $400 million more than first announced. [D3.]

Marketers Paying Top Dollar for Oscar
When ABC broadcasts the 68th annual Academy Awards ceremony next Monday, 11 blue-chip marketers including Coca-Cola, Eastman Kodak, General Motors and Revlon will pay the network a record average of $795,000 for each 30-second commercial run nationally -- an amount exceeded only by what the networks charge for Super Bowl ads. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
British Beef Is Refused
France and Belgium stopped importing British beef after London linked 10 fatalities to mad-cow disease. [A8.]

The S.E.C. approved tighter safeguards over money-market funds that invest in tax-exempt municipal securities. [D6.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; National Desk
