HEADLINE: POLITICS: VOICES;
California Voters Seem Wary of Dole

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: COLTON, Calif., March 21

 BODY:
Patricia Schnall, Eric Segura and Mark Ruckman all voted against Bill Clinton four years ago, offering their support instead to George Bush or Ross Perot. They are all Republicans or self-described independent voters who long ago gave up on the Democratic Party. They live in this teeming region east of Los Angeles, which these days is monitored closely for signs of shifts in both California's electoral dynamics and economic fortunes.
Mrs. Schnall, Mr. Segura and Mr. Ruckman have another trait in common, too: They intend to vote against the Republican Party's presumptive Presidential nominee, Bob Dole, and are even considering a vote for the candidate they vigorously opposed just four years ago, Mr. Clinton. 
 Recoiling at the mention of Mr. Dole's name, Mr. Segura, a 33-year-old factory scheduler who is a registered Republican and lives in nearby Ontario, said: "I don't want that guy near the White House. He has a lot of old values that don't work anymore. He's like my Dad -- he means well, but he's too out of touch."
President Clinton, added Mr. Segura, who is preparing to cast his first vote for a Democratic Presidential candidate this year, "hasn't hurt me personally."
Republicans will go through the motions of a Presidential primary here in California next Tuesday. But the serious political attention has already turned eight months up the road, to the contest in November between Mr. Clinton and, presumably, Mr. Dole. And in this mountainous and smoggy stretch of California -- San Bernardino and Riverside Counties, which make up the sprawling Inland Empire, starting just beyond the Los Angeles line and stretching east into the Mojave Desert -- the news for Mr. Dole is not good.
Two days of conversations with scores of voters here suggest that the Kansas Senator's supporters are neither plentiful nor particularly enthusiastic. They are motivated by antipathy to Mr. Clinton rather than loyalty to Mr. Dole. That is particularly true among people who said they voted for Mr. Perot four years ago -- and it seems likely that they will drift back to him if the Texas billionaire decides to run again.
Moreover, among self-described independent voters and some Republicans, there is a wariness about Mr. Dole that suggests the dimensions of the task he faces as he tries to defeat Mr. Clinton in a state that is the bedrock of the President's re-election strategy. They are wondering if Mr. Dole is, at 72, too old, too politically entrenched or too uninspired to bring about the kind of change that many people in this economically battered part of the state say they hope for from Washington.
"He's just a dyed-in-the-wool politician," said Dolores LaJoie, 54, a retail manager from Rialto who until this year considered herself an unwavering Republican. "Dole has just been around so long that I think people just see him as an inside person. People say to him, 'I need,' and he says: 'Yeah. You're going to get it.' "
The conversations with voters here -- from Montclair to Ontario to this small community 60 miles east of Los Angeles, at the side of Interstate 10 -- confirm and amplify polls that have been conducted across California. A poll published in The Los Angeles Times on Tuesday found Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Dole 58 percent to 37 percent. The findings from the interviews, though anecdotal, reflect the opinion of political analysts and help explain the growing speculation in political circles that Senator Dole might in the end cede this state's 54 electoral votes to the President.
And the fact that Mr. Dole is experiencing early difficulties in communities like this suggests problems that go beyond California, a state that Mr. Clinton courted even before he was sworn in as President. For Mr. Dole, it signals difficulties in other critical states with similar communities of independent-minded voters struggling through economic difficult times, from Michigan to Ohio to Illinois.
To be sure, it is eight months until the election, and Mr. Dole is politically on the short end of a stick here. He has neither campaigned nor advertised significantly in California.
But that said, Mr. Dole is well known and does not appear to have a particularly sympathetic base to build on. Indeed, even his attempts over the last two months to flesh out his public image by reminding voters of the crippling war injuries he suffered in World War II may not be having the effect Mr. Dole and his advisers have intended.
"This is tacky to say, I guess, but I'm tired of him going through that bit that he has a lame arm," said Jane Shirkey, a retired oil company worker from Houston who lives in Riverside.
"I know that's terrible," she continued. "I'm sorry. I'm sorry about that. But good grief. That was 50-odd years ago. Get over it."
Mrs. Shirkey, a registered Republican who voted for Ronald Reagan in the 1980's, supported Mr. Clinton four years ago and intends to again.
In the interviews, voters repeatedly raised, without prompting, questions about Mr. Dole's age and his physical stamina and mental acuity. Republicans and Democrats alike said that his choice of a running mate would be particularly important this time around. "What is he 71, 72?" asked Fred Yankee, a security guard outside a store here in Colton. Mr. Dole is 72.
"People always say, 'Look at Reagan,' " said Mr. Yankee, shaking his head. Mr. Yankee, a registered Republican who voted for Mr. Perot four years ago, added that Mr. Dole's choice of a running mate would be a "key thing" in helping him to decide whether to abandon the Republican Party this year.
Mr. Dole also appears, at least at this early stage of the campaign, to be hampered by his association with Washington, particularly among voters who said they voted for Mr. Perot in 1992. Mr. Ruckman, a sales executive who voted for Mr. Reagan in the 1980's and Mr. Perot last year, said he did not like Mr. Dole because "to me, he's a finagler."
The Senator was repeatedly accused of not having articulated a rationale for his Presidency or of being too conservative.
Joe Breunig, a 24-year-old hotel desk clerk who is a registered Republican and who voted for Mr. Bush four years ago, said he was wary of a candidate he now considered to be "too ultraconservative."
Mrs. Schnall, 42, a physical therapist from Claremont who is registered as an independent and who supported Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush, said she was now inclined to vote for Mr. Clinton. "I don't know what it is," she said of Mr. Dole. "I just don't like him. For one thing, he doesn't talk about issues. He's very vague."
Ric Zbinden, 37, an unemployed salesman and registered Republican who also voted for Mr. Bush, said Mr. Dole struck him as uninspired and unsure why he was running for President.
"Dole has to do something to prove to me that he is in touch," Mr. Zbinden said. "If he doesn't do something to show me he's definitely interested in this -- that makes me believe he's got it. I don't think he's too old. I just don't think he's all there."
Mr. Clinton appears slightly more popular here than in recent years, and it is reflected in The Los Angeles Tomes poll, where 56 percent of the respondents said they approved of his job performance.
"He's the lesser of two evils at this point," said Julia Luna, a kindergarten teacher and registered Democrat. "I think he would have accomplished more if he had more cooperation from the Republicans."
There is, to be sure, some support for Mr. Dole. Bill Lloyd, a 67-year-old retired business manager who lives in Ontario, said: "I will vote for Dole. He hasn't really showed me a lot of things. But here again, as far as I know, Dole is pretty honest."
Still, the main thing Mr. Dole seems to have going for him these days is a dislike of the President. When Mrs. LaJoie was asked if she could see any way she would vote for Mr. Dole over Mr. Clinton, she paused for a long moment, staring across the hot parking lot in Riverside, until her 14-year-old daughter, Jennifer, piped up with an answer.
"He's better than Clinton," Jennifer said.
"I don't know if that's the case," her mother responded. "At this point, there really isn't a candidate I care for."

HEADLINE: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"It's a Slow-Growth Economy, Stupid" (Week in Review, March 17) correctly characterizes the inanity of economic campaign rhetoric. The Federal Government has fewer tools to create real economic growth than politicians will admit. What growth does occur happens because of the diligence, determination and smarts of individual business leaders, entrepreneurs and workers. 
 You miss an important point, though, while reminiscing about the 4 percent growth of the 1960's. The implicit argument that higher growth rates in the gross national product would mean real income growth, better job security and all the things it meant in the 1960's is specious in the global economy.
It is possible that this nation could return to 4 percent growth rates and yet continue to experience mass layoffs and job insecurity as labor is displaced by automation and thrown into competition with the low-wage, unregulated economies of the Southern Hemisphere and Pacific Rim.
Indeed, the nostalgic "consensus" notions of our national economists -- anachronistic measurements like gross national product, trade balances, productivity, efficiency and economic growth itself -- are becoming irrelevant to explaining the economic reality of most Americans.
As national wealth becomes maldistributed, these measures only reflect the economic fate of a small part of Americans at the top whose incomes will be correlated to national growth measures.
The paradox of gross national product growth for some and declining living standards for most has emerged as the most salient feature of the global economy. The more pressing debate is not in defining "acceptable" growth rates but in defining the acceptable distribution of national growth among economic classes.
 
TIMOTHY P. LAW
Elkins Park, Pa., March 19, 1996

HEADLINE: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain;
Profit Obsession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Executive Defends Downsizing" (Business Day, March 19): 
 Chrysler Corporation's chief executive, Robert J. Eaton, deserves the Marie Antoinette award for his callous remarks defending corporate downsizing and his attack on the news media that have reported on this phenomenon.
What troubles me is Mr. Eaton's questionable business sense. He says that "companies that focus on making money become more competitive." Companies that focus on making money become obsessed with quarter-to-quarter performance to the detriment of long-term planning; lack product innovation (research and development do not "make money"); engage in questionable marketing strategies (customer service is less important than making money) and create other problems that have become the legacy of bad management and a contributing cause to downsizing. Mr. Eaton's guide ought to be, "Companies that focus on their customers become more competitive." His customers are getting cake.
 
COLLIN G. MATTON
Fairfield, Conn., March 19, 1996
 
The writer is an adjunct associate professor of business policy at Pace University.

HEADLINE: Even if Economy Grows, Only a Few Will Gain;
Management's Duty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Executive Defends Downsizing" (Business Day, March 19): Robert J. Eaton, chief executive of Chrysler Corporation, is on the mark. 
 The global economy and our own economy benefit from taking these hard decisions. Enlightened policies that provide a fair, merit-based, safe, exciting, educational work environment are all that an employee, blue-collar or management, should expect and all that a shareholder-accountable employer should be obligated to provide.
Management has not only the right but also the duty to deploy assets in pursuit of profitability and shareholder value generation. Often this means redeploying labor and middle management from one endeavor to another. Often it means redeploying capital.
When management fails to fulfill this requirement, competitiveness inevitably suffers, and in the end entire enterprises -- capital, labor and management -- will be sacrificed.
 
ROBERT WHITBY
Winter Park, Fla., March 20, 1996
 
The writer is a management consultant.

LENGTH: 216 words

HEADLINE: Engineers Needn't Fear Worker Influx

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael S. Teitelbaum (Op-Ed, March 19) contributes to the witch-hunt call to curtail the limited legal immigration of skilled foreign workers who fill technical positions. 
 To be eligible for employment in the United States, a skilled foreign worker and the prospective employer-sponsor must submit applications and support documents to the Department of Labor and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which have safeguards that must be met before a foreign worker may secure nonimmigrant status.
An employer must pay the foreign worker a designated "prevailing wage" for the position as determined by the Labor Department. That wage is generally higher than the free-market rate for the position.
In addition, the sponsor company must prove that there are no qualified United States candidates for the job, advertise it in a widely circulated newspaper and post it internally so that employees may also apply. If a United States candidate meets the minimum requirements, he or she is considered acceptable by the Labor Department and the application for the foreign worker is rejected, precluding the company from proceeding to filing an application with the I.N.S.
 
DIANE M. PORGES
New York, March 20, 1996
 
The writer is an immigration lawyer.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Team Owners Approve Revenue-Sharing Plan

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, March 21

 BODY:
In what could be considered a do-over, baseball club owners overwhelmingly adopted a second new revenue-sharing plan today, hoping it could serve as a catalyst for a new collective-bargaining agreement with the players.
The two-year plan, termed interim pending agreement on a new labor contract, would transfer about $39 million from 13 high-revenue clubs to 13 low-revenue clubs this year. 
 Union approval is needed to trigger the transfer from rich to poor of a greater share of local revenue -- ticket sales, concessions, advertising, local radio, television and cable. Union opposition killed a plan the owners adopted in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 26 months ago.
The owners' labor policy committee hoped that the combination of the plan, redrawn along lines that management officials believed the union preferred, and a new proposal that negotiators presented to union representatives tonight would go a long way toward settling the nearly two-year dispute.
Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, acknowledged that both the revenue-sharing plan and the proposal contained elements that the union had not seen in previous plans. But his only other comment on the two-prong effort was only that "we will study them."
A management person familiar with the new proposal said it eliminates the adjustable tax system that would have tied payroll levels to the percentage of industry revenue, raises the thresholds at which a luxury payroll tax would be triggered and reduces the length of the agreement from seven to six years.
The proposal, in the first year, retains a 2.5 percent tax each player would pay on his salary, but reduces the tax rate in the second year from 5 percent to 3.5 percent. The salary tax was an idea the players initiated in one of their previous proposals. In the third year, the owners raised the luxury tax threshold from $44 million to $46 million and lowered the tax rate from 50 percent to 40 percent. The threshold would rise automatically in each succeeding year by 7 percent to a high of 56.3 million in 2001, the last year of the contract.
Although the owners' revenue-sharing plan was labeled interim, Randy Levine, the owners' chief labor executive, said his goal was to make this the first year of an overall revenue-sharing plan that would be part of a new labor agreement.
Fred Wilpon of the Mets cast the only "no" vote in the 26-1-1 outcome. Peter Angelos of Baltimore abstained.
Wilpon declined to comment, but a person who attended the meeting said that Wilpon had said that he understood the need for the plan and hoped it would be help get a labor agreement, but that the labor deal should come before a revenue-sharing agreement.
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, who has become a master at mustering one-sided positive votes among the owners, made a bid to change possible "no" votes by modifying the plan that was presented to the owners at their last meeting, two months ago in Los Angeles.
The key change reduced the amounts that the hardest-hit clubs would pay. Based on economic projections for the coming season, the Yankees, No. 1 among contributing clubs, would pay about $5.8 million instead of the nearly $7.5 million projected under the Los Angeles plan. The Orioles would pay about $5.3 million, instead of $6.85 million.
The Kansas City Royals would be the biggest beneficiary, getting nearly $5 million, up from about $4.5 million. Under the redrawn plan, wealthy clubs would pay less, middle-revenue clubs would remain where they would have been and poorer clubs would get slightly more.
The money redistributed this year would represent 60 percent of the amount that the owners ultimately want to move to low-revenue clubs.
Under a complex formula involving two choices of payment, each club would put a percentage of its local revenue into a pool. Each club would then receive 1/28 of 85 percent of the pool. The remaining 15 percent would be disbursed to the 13 low-revenue clubs.

HEADLINE: World Bank Blocks U.S. Builders' Bids

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The World Bank said today that because the United States had fallen behind on contributions, American contractors would be prevented from bidding on about $2.1 billion worth of contracts financed by other nations.
The ban was approved at a meeting this week in Tokyo by more than 30 nations, including the United States, that donate to the International Development Association, World Bank officials said. 
 Lionel C. Johnson, who represented the United States Treasury at the Tokyo meeting, said the development association's lending would not be interrupted. "Other countries felt it necessary to put on those restrictions, for political reasons back home," Mr. Johnson declared.
The International Development Association, an agency of the World Bank, makes loans at less than 1 percent interest to 78 of the world's poorest countries, many in Africa. The money is used to build essential facilities like schools, clinics and water projects.

HEADLINE: Who Benefits by New Jersey Income Tax Cut?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New Jersey's Tax Cuts Have Worked' (Op-Ed, March 16), by Timothy J. Goodspeed and Peter D. Salins, is political camouflage to help Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in her quest for the Republican Vice-Presidential nod. 
 Considering that the full 30 percent income tax cut did not take effect until this January, it is too early to assess the impact Governor Whitman's fiscal policies will have at the local level.
Cutting income taxes will make less money available for property tax relief.
More than 100 school districts were excluded from Mr. Goodspeed's and Mr. Salins's analysis of how decreasing state aid affects property taxes. The richest 7 percent of the state's taxpayers will pocket 41 percent of the income tax cut savings. But property tax increases are strangling the middle class.
The Governor promised that the income tax cuts would create 450,000 jobs. Not only have the jobs not materialized, but New Jersey's economy has been rocked by corporate layoffs and its unemployment rate is the second highest among industrialized states.
 
JOSEPH V. DORIA JR.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Soar on Low Stocks; Soybeans Rise and Copper Drops

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures soared on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, a move that helped advance other energy futures as investors bid up prices on concern about tight supplies going into the spring driving season.
In other commodity markets, soybeans futures rose sharply, while copper futures plunged as supplies rose. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 1.41 points, to 252.08, nearing a seven-year high. 
 With supplies at a 19-year low, light sweet crude oil for May delivery rose 90 cents, to $21.95 a barrel. April heating oil rose 1.32 cents, to 62.65 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline rose 1.46 cents, to 65.49 cents a gallon. April natural gas rose 12.3 cents, to $2.863 for 1,000 cubic feet.
"The crude looks like it's pretty much off to the races yet again," Tim Evans, an oil analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group in New York, said. "The April contract rose into the $24-$25 range and the logic is the May contract at $22 looks cheap in comparison, considering the supply situation has not eased."
Crude stocks now stand at 299.7 million barrels, 8 percent below levels a year earlier. Gasoline and heating oil stocks have also been tight this winter.
Soybeans futures prices rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported in part by rumors that the British Government was considering a soybean meal substitute for traditional cattle feed in an attempt to control the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad-cow disease, which has caused a growing number of countries to ban British beef imports. Such a move would greatly strengthen American imports. May soybeans rose 8.75 cents, to $7.3050 a bushel.
With warehouse stocks of copper rising, futures plunged to a three-week low on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential Securities, said copper was still poised to rally. "I still believe we will see it move up to the $1.20-$1.23 levels; it may take a little while longer," she said.
May high-grade copper fell 1.75 cents, to $1.15 a pound, the lowest since Feb. 28.

HEADLINE: Jury Rules Against Hospital For Negligent Care of Baby

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
A jury has ordered the New York City hospitals agency to pay $23.3 million to a boy who suffers from brain damage and extensive paralysis because of complications after his birth in 1988.
The verdict in favor of the boy, Jermaine Eccleston, of Brooklyn, was returned late Wednesday against the Health and Hospitals Corporation in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn after a two-week trial before Justice Nicholas A. Clemente. The City Corporation Counsel's office said it is considering an appeal. 
 After deliberating for two days, the jury of three men and three women agreed with Thomas A. Moore, the lawyer for the boy and his mother, that the Kings County Hospital Center was negligent in treating the child after his difficult birth on May 25, 1988.
Mr. Moore said doctors should have known that Jermaine needed careful monitoring because his mother, Claudette Eccleston, had suffered from pregnancy-related diabetes. In addition, Mr. Moore said, Jermaine was born three weeks prematurely in a delivery so difficult that the baby's shoulder was broken.
"This high-risk infant was placed in the regular nursery and examined exclusively by inexperienced trainee physicians," Mr. Moore said after the verdict. "His care was rendered by doctors who had neither the background nor experience to provide the care this infant needed."
When Jermaine was 3 days old, he was placed in a regular nursery, where his heart and breathing stopped, Mr. Moore said. His condition was not discovered immediately, and when it was, resuscitation was delayed because the proper equipment was not handy, the lawyer maintained.
Jermaine is alert and understands the world around him but cannot speak. He has only limited use of his arms and legs and attends a special school, Mr. Moore said.
Eugene Borenstein, chief of the Corporation Counsel's tort division, said the city would ask Justice Clemente to reduce the amount of the award and, depending on the justice's decision, would consider appealing its size or the findings of negligence.
While the verdict is one of the larger ones against a city agency in recent years, it does not approach the biggest verdict returned against the hospitals agency. That verdict, $73 million in connection with a botched delivery, was returned several years ago but was reduced considerably on appeal.
Of the $23.3 million awarded Wednesday, $7 million is for Jermaine's pain and suffering, Mr. Moore said. The remaining $16.3 million is for Jermaine's care until he reaches age 55 and is based on expected inflation.
Assuming that the verdict stands, Mr. Borenstein said the city would not actually pay $23.3 million out of its coffers but would buy an annuity for much less than that for payments to Jermaine in the years ahead.

HEADLINE: Economic Data Show Big Jump In Job Creation in New Jersey

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 22

 BODY:
New Jersey gained a significant number of new jobs last month, and the state's unemployment rate declined slightly, according to economic data released today.
The gain of 29,700 new jobs in February eased concerns among some economists that the loss of 26,500 jobs in January was a signal of a sudden downturn in the economy. State officials had attributed the huge job loss to the severe weather in January. 
 The state's unemployment rate declined from 6.6 percent to 6.5 percent, the new data showed, but continued to lag a full percentage point behind the national average.
Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors and a professor of economics at Rutgers University, said the new economic data released today showed that the state's economy would continue to grow moderately in the coming year. "What the February numbers demonstrate is that the economy did not fall off the shelf," Mr. Seneca said. "That is very welcome news."
But he added that while New Jersey would benefit from signs that the nation's economy was improving, the state still faced the prospect of more job losses through corporate downsizing. More than 7,000 jobs alone at AT&T will be eliminated this year. "Downsizing will remain with us," he said.
With 3,200 new jobs created this year, State Department of Labor officials said that the pace of job growth so far was about equal to the monthly increases recorded during the last quarter of 1995. Most of the new jobs were in the service and business services industry, which included temporary help and employment agencies.
"The unemployment rate and the employment numbers indicate that New Jersey's economy has recovered from the effects of the January blizzard," said Labor Commissioner Peter J. Calderone. "It is important to note that even with the setbacks due to severe weather and corporate downsizings we are continuing to create jobs."
But Democrats in the State Legislature noted that the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average. Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hudson County who is the assistant Senate minority leader, said, "The Whitman administration may feel the state has recovered from the January blizzard, but the tens of thousands of downsized New Jersey workers won't fall for the snow job that her tax cuts have fixed for the economy."

HEADLINE: Gay Marriage, an Oxymoron

BYLINE: By Lisa Schiffren; Lisa Schiffren was a speechwriter for Vice President Dan Quayle.

 BODY:
As study after study and victim after victim testify to the social devastation of the sexual revolution, easy divorce and out-of-wedlock motherhood, marriage is fashionable again. And parenthood has transformed many baby boomers into advocates of bourgeois norms.
Indeed, we have come so far that the surprise issue of the political season is whether homosexual "marriage" should be legalized. The Hawaii courts will likely rule that gay marriage is legal, and other states will be required to accept those marriages as valid. 
 Considering what a momentous change this would be -- a radical redefinition of society's most fundamental institution -- there has been almost no real debate. This is because the premise is unimaginable to many, and the forces of political correctness have descended on the discussion, raising the cost of opposition. But one may feel the same affection for one's homosexual friends and relatives as for any other, and be genuinely pleased for the happiness they derive from relationships, while opposing gay marriage for principled reasons.
"Same-sex marriage" is inherently incompatible with our culture's understanding of the institution. Marriage is essentially a lifelong compact between a man and woman committed to sexual exclusivity and the creation and nurture of offspring. For most Americans, the marital union -- as distinguished from other sexual relationships and legal and economic partnerships -- is imbued with an aspect of holiness. Though many of us are uncomfortable using religious language to discuss social and political issues, Judeo-Christian morality informs our view of family life.
Though it is not polite to mention it, what the Judeo-Christian tradition has to say about homosexual unions could not be clearer. In a diverse, open society such as ours, tolerance of homosexuality is a necessity. But for many, its practice depends on a trick of cognitive dissonance that allows people to believe in the Judeo-Christian moral order while accepting, often with genuine regard, the different lives of homosexual acquaintances. That is why, though homosexuals may believe that they are merely seeking a small expansion of the definition of marriage, the majority of Americans perceive this change as a radical deconstruction of the institution.
Some make the conservative argument that making marriage a civil right will bring stability, an end to promiscuity and a sense of fairness to gay men and women. But they miss the point. Society cares about stability in heterosexual unions because it is critical for raising healthy children and transmitting the values that are the basis of our culture.
Whether homosexual relationships endure is of little concern to society. That is also true of most childless marriages, harsh as it is to say. Society has wisely chosen not to differentiate between marriages, because it would require meddling into the motives and desires of everyone who applies for a license.
In traditional marriage, the tie that really binds for life is shared responsibility for the children. (A small fraction of gay couples may choose to raise children together, but such children are offspring of one partner and an outside contributor.) What will keep gay marriages together when individuals tire of each other?
Similarly, the argument that legal marriage will check promiscuity by gay males raises the question of how a "piece of paper" will do what the threat of AIDS has not. Lesbians seem to have little problem with monogamy, or the rest of what constitutes "domestication," despite the absence of official status.
Finally, there is the so-called fairness argument. The Government gives tax benefits, inheritance rights and employee benefits only to the married. Again, these financial benefits exist to help couples raise children. Tax reform is an effective way to remove distinctions among earners.
If the American people are interested in a radical experiment with same-sex marriages, then subjecting it to the political process is the right route. For a court in Hawaii to assume that it has the power to radically redefine marriage is a stunning abuse of power. To present homosexual marriage as a fait accompli, without national debate, is a serious political error. A society struggling to recover from 30 years of weakened norms and broken families is not likely to respond gently to having an institution central to most people's lives altered.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Slightly vs. Yen But Retreats Against the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar showed slight gains against the Japanese yen and was lower against the German mark yesterday after large institutional investors and European corporations sold the dollar to take profits.
The dollar was supported against the yen by buyers seeking a safe haven ahead of the elections today in Taiwan, traders said. 
 "No one wants to be short of dollars because they don't know what will happen on the weekend," said Norihiko Ogihara, vice president at Mitsui Trust and Banking.
The dollar opened lower in New York trading, retreating from overnight highs above 1.4800 marks and 107 yen, as American hedge funds and other institutional investors sold dollars.
But buying by Japanese companies and others later helped the dollar regain some ground against the yen, traders said.
"The dollar is still firm against the yen," Mr. Ogihara said. "Even after huge profit-taking orders this morning, some investors in Japan still want to buy dollars."
In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 106.86 yen, up from 106.70 on Thursday.. The dollar settled at 1.4761 German marks, down from 1.4785.
The dollar gained against the British pound after several countries banned imports of British beef over worries about the so-called mad-cow disease that is being investigated in Britain.
Eight European countries, including Germany and France, banned the meat, arousing concerns that the disease will hobble Britain's $3 billion beef industry and damage the nation's trade performance.
In New York trading, the British pound fell to $1.5350, from $1.5375 on Thursday.
In addition to the Taiwan election, the currency market is also awaiting results of German elections for state assemblies tomorrow.
Traders said the mark could be bolstered in the long run if Germany's main opposition party, the Social Democrats, did well.
The party is campaigning for a delay in the European economic and monetary union. A strong showing by the Social Democrats could bolster the belief that Europe's efforts to create a single currency are losing steam, and that could increase demand for marks, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Forecast for Taiwan Remains Upbeat

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 22

 BODY:
Marinus van Gessel, an American, has been here for 21 years, running a small but thriving import company, and business has never been better.
But increasingly aggressive war games by the Chinese and growing vituperation from Beijing's leaders and uncertainty over Taiwan's first presidential election have stirred anxieties over the future. 
 "I was sweating bullets for a while," Mr. van Gessel said. "Now that a large part of our Seventh Fleet is parked offshore, I feel a lot better. And it's not just for the Taiwanese but for the Americans as well."
Even so, Mr. van Gessel's business -- importing specialty foods like cheeses, Western fish and fine lettuce -- puts his finger on the pulse of foreign activity in Taiwan, and the beat has been a bit fainter in recent days.
There has been no visible alarm on Taipei's streets over China's threats, but beneath the calm, some economic cracks have appeared. Most people, though, see any uncertainty as short-lived and say that in the long run Taiwan's economic might will be unscathed.
 "In my case," he said, "I delayed a shipment coming in. Some people are canceling meetings. Hotel occupancy is down a bit. At some promotions, the band didn't show up. The last two days and the next two days are going to be slow. With all this excitement, people are not going to be doing special things."
In the last 10 days, China has fired ballistic missiles off the northern and southern tips of Taiwan and staged two live-fire war games near islands controlled by Taiwan, all in a declared effort to scare Taiwan's leaders away from visions of independence. China claims Taiwan as a rebel province, but on Wednesday President Lee Tung-hui, who has repeatedly disavowed any desire for independence, continued to describe Taiwan as a "sovereign state."
Mr. Lee, who is widely expected to win the country's first presidential election on Saturday, enraged Beijing last summer when he visited Cornell University, where he received a doctorate in agricultural economics. China denounced his visit as part of his effort to "split" Taiwan from the mainland.
Today, the Government released data that showed exports for the first half of March down 9.9 percent over the period last year; the reason it cited: a sudden caution by shippers.
The stock market, which has seesawed throughout the crisis, has been buoyed by Government intervention over the last week but is still down some 25 percent for the year -- not, analysts say, because of worries about China, but because of a general sense that stocks are overvalued. In a market dominated not by institutional but by individual investors, those small investors have been selling out, analysts say.
For their part, foreign investors regard the tensions between Taiwan and China as transitory, the economy as fundamentally sound and the prospects for investment as good.
"Broadly speaking," said Christian Murck, the country manager for Chemical Bank here and the president of the American Chamber of Commerce, "in a medium- to long-term point of view, the economic fundamentals and the investment climate are very good here. We expect to see continued investment."
Indeed, Taiwan has proved to be one of Asia's most formidable economies, both in terms of size and for having shed its reliance on the United States and focused on Southeast Asia. In fact, Taiwan is now the world's 14th-largest trader, has the world's third-busiest container port, in Kaohsiung, and has emerged as a big provider of capital throughout the region.
It is the largest foreign investor in Vietnam, has invested between $13 billion and $25 billion (depending on who's counting) in China, and has emerged as a big consumer market for Western goods. For Chrysler, for instance, Taiwan is the largest market outside North America, and Citibank makes more money from its credit card business here than in all of Europe, according to the American Chamber of Commerce.
"Foreign companies that are doing business here share a common premise that over the long term there will be stability across the strait and, secondly, that the astonishing process of economic integration will continue," Mr. Murck said. "Eventually there will be direct transport links and an integrated China market."
Yet even in the current climate of uncertainty, Mr. Murck said he knew of no companies that had shelved investment plans here.
"Decisions on investment are being made on medium- and long-term economic considerations," he said. "Most people think that the Chinese pressure will continue in some degree after the election. Obviously, if the situation goes on for a long time and the situation deteriorates, there will have to be a re-evaluation."
Some Americans here even see unexpected benefits from the escalation of tensions. "If anything, it will work in Taiwan's favor," said Warren Gerig, the country manager for United Airlines, "because it will show Americans what Taiwan is all about." At last count, more than 600 foreign reporters had arrived to cover Saturday's election.
"We don't see this as disruptive," Mr. Gerig continued. "We see it as what it is, saber-rattling, to intimidate the people here before the election. It's totally backfired."
In his industry, Mr. Gerig said that Taiwan would continue to be a big regional market, and that the region would continue to boom for 20 years. "The only thing that can stop it," he said, "is if there is some sort of military escapade by some country."
Mr. van Gessel, the importer, said the only way to ease tensions permanently was through closer economic ties, which he said would be possible once the election was over. "Most people here think things are blowing over," he said. "China and Taiwan need to get back to business. From a long-term view, there's a lot of opportunity here. Both sides need each other."

NEW YORK
 
Killer's Neighbors Saw Trouble
 
Even when he was young, his neighbors knew that Richard Sacchi Jr. was trouble, someone they best stay away from. As he got older, his brooding and bullying personality led to stays in a school for disturbed youngsters, a psychiatric center, a White Plains homeless shelter and an alcohol rehabilitation center. And he had been arrested at least five times. Neighbors of Mr. Sacchi suggested that had someone taken harsher action against him much earlier, the shootings of two police officers Thursday night might not have happened. [Page 1.]
 
The gunman was to start a 30-day jail term next month for stalking his estranged wife, and was apparently despondent at the failure of his marriage and may have snapped, friends and family said. [26.]
 
Officer Michael Frey, described as everyone's friend, enjoyed the friendly house calls on his job. [26.]

Pension Plan Dispute Resolved
 
State officials announced that they had reached an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service, averting the possibility of costly litigation or additional funding requirements for the state's public employee pension system. The state will not have to come up with an additional $1 billion to restore money that was transferred out of the pension systems and into the state's coffers in 1992 and 1994. [27.]
 
Residency Rule Suspended
 
A judge temporarily barred Essex County from dismissing workers who did not live in the county, even though he found that the county's 18-year-old residency requirement had been properly adopted. [27.]
 
Police Salaries at Issue
 
As the Port Authority tries to control spending, it points to the $20,000 average difference in annual pay between city police officers and its own officers. The agency is focusing on police salaries in its negotiations with police unions. [27.]
 
Job Growth Heartens Analysts
 
New Jersey gained a significant number of new jobs last month, and the state's unemployment rate declined slightly, according to economic data. The gain of 29,700 new jobs in February eased concerns among some economists that the loss of 26,500 jobs in January was a signal of a sudden downturn in the economy. [27.]

HEADLINE: Bond Buyers Snatch Up Disney Notes

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company sold $2.6 billion in debt yesterday, the largest bond offering ever by a top-grade company.
Demand for the Disney bonds was so strong that the size of the offering was sharply increased twice in the last two days. Disney had originally planned to sell $1.5 billion of bonds but increased the sale to $2 billion on Thursday and to $2.6 billion yesterday. The sale drew buyers away from the Treasury market, where prices were lower in light trading. 
 Disney is "a name people would love to have in their portfolio," said Tom Davidson, a bond salesman for BA Securities Inc. "A name that doesn't come to market often."
The strong demand confirmed Disney's high standing on Wall Street. Despite taking on a huge amount of debt for its $19 billion acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC, analysts and money managers remain enamored of the company's cash flow. Disney's balance sheet, many analysts say, is much stronger than those of other media companies like Time Warner Inc. or the News Corporation.
Disney's stock also rose yesterday, closing at $64.875, up 37.5 cents on the day.
The Disney debt offering was split equally between 5-year and 10-year notes and was priced through the joint lead managers Merrill Lynch International and CS First Boston Ltd. Disney plans to use the proceeds to help finance the cash portion of the Capital Cities/ABC acquisition. Disney initially raised the cash for the Capital Cities deal last week, selling $8.6 billion of commercial paper, with the intention to refinance about half of the commercial paper with longer-term debt. Yesterday's bond offering was the first installment of the refinancing.
The sale was larger than the previous biggest investment-grade offering of $1.2 billion of I.B.M. bonds in 1993, according to the Securities Data Company of Newark, a market research firm. But both offerings are dwarfed by the $4.1 billion in junk bonds -- or bonds with ratings below investment grade -- issued by RJR Holdings as part of its leveraged buyout in 1989.
The 5-year Disney notes were priced at par to yield 6.375 percent, or 35 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than a comparable 5-year Treasury note. The 10-year Disney notes were priced at at 99.855 to yield 6.77 percent, or about 47 basis points more than a comparable 10-year Treasury note.
The bonds were sold simultaneously in the United States, Europe and Asia. The securities are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by both Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps Credit Rating. Those ratings are several notches above speculative grade, meaning they carry some risk for investors but not a great amount.
While some traders said the prices of the Disney securities were a bit expensive, they were still impressed by the demand.
But that demand was apparently not as strong in Europe as it was in the United States and Asia. According to calculations by Bloomberg Fair Market, the Disney five-year notes were selling in Europe at a yield of about 6.36 percent, or 11 basis points below yields of 6.47 percent for a comparable security that pays interest in Eurodollars, or dollars held by European banks.
In the Treasury market, prices were lower in light trading.
"No economic data, and Tuesday's pending Federal Open Market Committee meeting kept many positions close to home," said Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data of Boston, referring to Federal Reserve's chief interest rate panel.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 8/32 , to 9123/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.64 percent, from 6.61 percent on Thursday.
Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research in Boston, said that with little or no fundamental data to give it direction, yesterday's trading in Treasury futures was technically driven. Few investors sought to hold long positions ahead of the weekend.
The June contract closed yesterday at 11128//32 . Yesterday's expiration of April Treasury bond options, she said, did not add any volatility to the session.

HEADLINE: The General Motors Strike

 BODY:
Although the 18-day strike at two General Motors plants in Dayton, Ohio, ended Friday, the issues that provoked it will resurface this summer when the time comes for the United Automobile Workers to renegotiate its contracts with the Big Three auto makers. The practice of "outsourcing," which allows a manufacturer to buy component parts from outside contractors, is seen by the U.A.W. as a grave threat to its members. By buying from companies that pay lower wages, either in the United States or abroad, a manufacturer can save millions. G.M. makes more of its own parts than either Ford or Chrysler, but it believes that increased outsourcing is vital to its competitiveness.
Big employers like G.M. feel that to be competitive they need to cut their staffs to the bare bones. When demand goes up, it is cheaper to require overtime from a leaner work force than to add employees. When even overtime will not keep up with demand, the manufacturers want to be able to turn to outside suppliers. 
 The U.A.W. called the strike when G.M. awarded a contract to Robert Bosch GmbH, a German company that has a non-unionized plant in South Carolina, to supply anti-lock brakes. The U.A.W. said the company broke a 1994 agreement to consult with the union before giving any more work to outside suppliers. The U.A.W. described the strike as a local action, but both sides felt that any concessions made in Dayton could set precedents for the national negotiations this summer.
Union officials are unmoved by G.M.'s concerns about competitiveness, pointing to the company's record profits last year. G.M. management contends that enhanced competitiveness will create more jobs, but union leaders are skeptical, since large corporations have continued to cut payrolls even when profits are up.
With this strike, the union has proved that as long as G.M. continues to manufacture inside the United States, it is going to have to put labor concerns into its economic calculations. Its practice of maintaining only a "just-in-time" inventory meant that G.M. was vulnerable to a well-aimed strike in one plant that brought the whole North American operation to a standstill.
The Dayton settlement was not a clear-cut victory for either side. G.M. did win the right to contract some work out at its Dayton plants. The union won some promises of additional jobs and the promise to honor the union's right to be consulted on work the company wants to place elsewhere.
But all sides agree that this was only a warm-up for the main contract negotiations later in the year. Dayton poses a question that will hang over the entire industry and its workers in the months ahead. In its negotiations with the Big Three this summer, the U.A.W. is likely to target Chrysler, which is now the biggest outsourcer. Industry analysts figure that Chrysler is most likely to agree to a freeze on outsourcing, , setting a precedent that G.M. would then be under pressure to follow.

HEADLINE: Stock Market Revives a Bit, With Dow Rising by 9.76

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices advanced yesterday for the first time since Monday, after investors weighed the week's Government statistics and concluded that the economy was expanding moderately.
Volatility has contracted, with the range between the highs and lows of major indicators narrowing from the swings of early March. For the third consecutive day, turnover dropped below the three-month average. 
 "I thought it was August," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Smith Barney. "There was not much movement during the day, and some brokers wondered if the market had closed."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.76 points, to 5,636.64, marking a gain of 51.67 points for the week. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks increased 1.43 points, to 650.62, while the Nasdaq composite index added 2.43 points, to 1,102.22.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange topped declines by 1,328 to 966. Slightly under 330 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, down from the 365.8 million shares traded on Thursday.
Bond prices shifted lower, also on thin volume. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond fell 8/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.64 percent, from 6.61 percent on Thursday.
Banking stocks rose amid optimism that borrowing costs would not show any appreciable advance. Citicorp increased 1/2, to 79 1/8; BankAmerica was up 1 5/8, to 75 3/4, and Nationsbank climbed 1 1/4, to 75 1/4. The Keefe, Bruyette & Woods bank index jumped 3.94 points, to 428.03.
Household-products issues benefited from indications that there would be slow economic growth this year. Procter & Gamble closed at 87 7/8, up 3/4; Colgate-Palmolive closed at 80 5/8, up 5/8, and Avon Products closed at 87 1/8, up 3/8.
Electrical equipment companies moved higher, led by General Electric, which was awarded a $2.3 billion, 10-year contract from British Airways to overhaul engines. G.E. advanced 1, to 78 3/8; Emerson Electric rose 1 1/4, to 81 3/4, and Westinghouse Electric increased 1/8, to 19.
But automotive stocks turned downward as analysts weighed the effects of the estimated $850 million cost to General Motors of the just-ended United Automobile Workers strike. G.M. eased 1/4, to 53 3/8; Ford dropped 1/4, to 33 5/8, and Chrysler declined 5/8, to 62 3/4.
Drug stocks, in contrast to their performance on Thursday, were lower. Eli Lilly closed at 64 7/8, off 1 3/4; Merck closed at 63 1/2, off 2, and American Home Products closed at 101 1/4, off 1.
Paper stocks were also depressed as institutions moved funds to other sectors. Georgia-Pacific lost 3/4, to 67 1/4; Champion International dropped 1 1/8, to 44 7/8; Westvaco fell 3/8, to 30 1/4, and Boise Cascade declined 3/8, to 41.
Exide, which yesterday denied rumors that it was being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, gave up 4 1/4, to 26 1/4. Adobe Systems, which reported lower earnings for its fiscal first quarter, fell 2 7/8, to 31 3/8. And Broken Hill Proprietary, which reported lower-than-expected profits, plummeted 2 1/8, to 55 5/8.
Airgas rose 2 3/8, to 41, after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split. Broderbund Software advanced 1, to 38 7/8, after reporting better-than-expected earnings from operations. And Nike increased 2 3/8, to 82 5/8, after being upgraded by Dean Witter Reynolds.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Workers Return to G.M., But Issues Are Unresolved
Workers began returning to two General Motors plants, ending their 17-day strike without resolving critical issues between the company and the United Automobile Workers union. While a few local disputes were resolved, the national issues are sure to come up again this summer when the U.A.W.'s three-year national contract expires. 
 G.M. and the U.A.W. agreed to no changes in either the national contract or local agreements on the chief issue, the extent to which G.M. can farm out parts production to nonunion companies, a practice known as outsourcing. [Page 1.]
 
Alitalia Sees Need for Bailout
Alitalia, its debt having doubled in the past year to $2.2 billion, needs a bailout this spring to pay salaries, Domenico Cempella, the executive appointed last month to save Italy's ailing national carrier, said. He did not say when the state holding company that controls Alitalia would seek permission from the European Union to provide fresh capital. [36.]
 
U.S. Sues Big Mining Companies
The Justice Department filed suit demanding that several big mining companies, including Asarco, Hecla Mining, Sunshine Mining and Coeur d'Alene Mines, pay for environmental damage across a huge swath of Idaho where toxic wastes from mining and smelting wastes have polluted lakes, streams, groundwater and wetlands over the course of a century. Government officials said the damages might run into hundreds of millions of dollars. [11.]
 
President of Moody's Resigns
In a surprise move, John A. Bohn resigned as president of Moody's Investors Service, one of the top credit rating agencies. No successor has been named. Moody's parent company, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, is being split into three new companies, and Moody's is facing increasing competition from Standard & Poor's bigger rating service. [37.]
 
Judge Urges Companies to Settle
Chancellor William Allen of the Delaware Chancery Court urged Time Warner and U S West to settle their legal dispute before he rules on it in June. "The law is unclear. The facts are unclear," he said, citing contradictory evidence in the 8-day trial, making any ruling subject to an appeal. U S West sued, seeking to block Time Warner's planned $7.5 billion acquisition of Turner Broadcasting. [47.]
 
Romania Blocks Foreign Banks
The Romanian central bank stripped two more large foreign banks, Chemical Banking of New York and ABN-Amro of the Netherlands, of their licenses to trade currencies on the fledgling foreign-exchange market, leaving only Romanian banks in the market. [36.]
 
Dow Industrials Up for Week
Stock prices advanced as investors concluded that the economy was expanding moderately. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.76 points, to 5,636.64, marking a gain of 51.67 points for the week, and the Nasdaq composite index added 2.43 points, to 1,102.22. Volatility has contracted, with the range between the highs and lows of major indicators narrowing from early March. [38.]
 
Oil Futures Prices Soar
With crude oil supplies tight, futures prices soared. Light crude oil for May delivery was up 90 cents, to $21.95 a barrel. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 1.41 points, to 252.08, nearing a seven-year high. [34.]
 
Argentines Gloat Over Beef Sales
Argentina was almost euphoric over the prospect that its beef exports could rise sharply this year, as the ban against British beef spread through Europe and to other parts of the world because of mad-cow disease. [36.]
 
Germany and Italy joined the ban on imports of British beef. The ban plunged Britain's $6.2 billion beef industry into a crisis. [3.]
 
A Legal Setback in Implant Case
In a stunning blow to the lawyers handling hundreds of thousands of injury claims against Dow Corning, the judge overseeing the company's bankruptcy proceedings ordered that the lawyers negotiating on behalf of women who say they were injured by silicone breast implants be replaced with a new negotiating committee, made up of the women themselves. [7.]

HEADLINE: White House Snubs China Over Military Maneuvers

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The Administration signaled its displeasure with China on two fronts today, calling off a long-awaited visit to Washington by China's Defense Minister and informally extending the freeze on new financing of American business deals in China.
The two actions are meant to signal Washington's displeasure over China's war games in the Strait of Taiwan, which the Administration charges are intended to intimidate voters before the presidential election on Saturday. 
 On a broader scale, the measures are the latest manifestation of the downward spiral of relations between China and the United States over a range of issues, including pirating of American movies and music, Beijing's poor performance on human rights and sales of cruise missiles to Iran and weapons technology to Pakistan.
Senior Administration officials said today that the United States and China had failed to resolve the dispute over the sale of sensitive nuclear-related technology to Pakistan, which led to the freeze on United States financing.
Complicating the picture is the fact that China is surfacing as a campaign issue. Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, are threatening to try to withhold China's most-favored-nation trading status this spring. That would put Mr. Clinton, who charged George Bush four years ago with "coddling" China but who now favors renewing those benefits, in the embarrassing position of appearing to be soft on China.
Secretary of Defense William J. Perry abruptly decided to cancel the visit of his Chinese counterpart, Chi Haotian, after China insisted Mr. Chi be given red-carpet treatment, including a meeting with President Clinton at the White House.
"A large-scale official visit is not appropriate in the current climate," Mr. Perry said in a brief statement that did not refer directly to Taiwan.
In addition, a growing number of Republican lawmakers were critical of the invitation to Mr. Chi, who was a key general during the repression of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
The visit, scheduled for the first week in April, had tentatively included visits to Sandia National Laboratory in Albuquerque, N.M., where nuclear-weapons research is conducted; the United States Space Command headquarters in Colorado, and an aircraft carrier at the Norfolk Naval Base. Mr. Perry had planned to escort Mr. Chi to the United States military installations.
Mr. Chi's trip was originally scheduled as a way to reciprocate for Mr. Perry's visit to China in 1994 and to deepen military-to-military ties between the two countries. It would have involved a 19-gun salute at the Pentagon, which some Republicans on Capitol Hill said would have made excellent television footage for use against Mr. Clinton in the campaign.
As the strains between the two countries deepened over China's military exercises, it made no sense to go forward with the visit, a senior Pentagon official said in an interview today.
"We tried to feel out the Chinese about whether we could squeeze it down to a straight business trip," the official said. "They wanted it to look like visiting royalty."
James R. Sasser, the American Ambassador to China, asked the Chinese to consider a less formal meeting between Mr. Perry and Mr. Chi in Hawaii or another location in the coming weeks and expressed hope that a formal meeting in Washington could take place in the summer.
 But the Chinese Government said the cancellation was its decision, not Mr. Perry's, explaining that it was acting in retaliation for Washington's show of support for Taiwan.
Last fall, the Chinese declined an invitation to President Jiang Zemin for a working meeting with Mr. Clinton in Washington because it was not a full-fledged state visit with a formal state dinner and a 21-gun salute.
But in a sign that the overall high-level dialogue will continue, the State Department said today that Secretary of State Warren Christopher intended to proceed with his scheduled meeting with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, in Europe next month.
At the White House today, the spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, suggested for the first time that the Administration intended to ask the Export-Import Bank to continue to defer financing for American companies who want to export to China.
"We are still reviewing the issues and are involved at the moment in bilateral dialogue with the People's Republic on the nature of the transaction that triggered our concern in the first place," he said. "We would hope that the Ex-Im Bank would continue to keep applications on hold."
He later amplified his remarks in a telephone interview, saying, "The existing freeze remains in place while we continue to assess the proliferation issues."
Last month, the United States requested a 30-day freeze on financing for new American deals, pending the outcome of talks over the technology sale to Pakistan. The freeze runs out this weekend, but the bank is not scheduled to take up any new financing applications next week.
Talks in Beijing between Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Robert Einhorn and Chinese officials have failed to resolve the dispute, a senior Administration official said. The Administration had asked China to limit future shipments of nuclear-related technology and equipment to Pakistan, suggesting that in return it could waive some economic sanctions under consideration.
Mr. Einhorn is to report back to the State Department next week, and the Administration will decide whether to make a formal request to extend the financing freeze or to impose other punitive sanctions on China, as required under law.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONVENTION;
Parallel Agonizing Over Immigration

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
Just as the Presidential primaries have often made the Republicans look like two opposing parties struggling within one body, this glittering seaside city on the Mexican border, where the Republicans will hold their convention in August, often feels like two deeply conflicting communities, one of anger, one of hope.
Gilbert A. Partida certainly knows about the hope. Mr. Partida, 33, moved here in 1987 right out of law school, set up the first Mexican trade practice at a big law firm and then three years ago became the first Hispanic president of the Greater San Diego Chamber of Commerce. He has led the chamber from near bankruptcy to buoyant growth, partly by opening to the Mexican-American community and building ties with Tijuana, a neighbor that, though 20 minutes from downtown, was long ignored. 
 And yet, Mr. Partida said, he is all too familiar with the anger. Eighteen months ago, during an emotional battle over a California state initiative to ban public benefits to illegal immigrants, Mr. Partida said he was assaulted by loads of hate mail, much of it racist, for leading the chamber in opposition to the measure.
Mr. Partida said such hostility was a dying vestige of the old San Diego, but it is clearly more complicated than that. San Diego's voters supported the initiative on immigrants, known as Proposition 187, by a lopsided margin of 67.4 percent, compared with 59 percent statewide. The measure's chief supporter was California's Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, a former Mayor of San Diego and a favorite son here.
"Every sector of the economy here is heavily dependent on immigrants," said Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego. "They all draw heavily on this labor pool, and most of it is illegal. It underwrites an affluent life style. But the anti-immigrant line is very popular because of all the anger. People really want to have it both ways."
The Republicans, too, are divided in their views on immigrants, trade and Mexico. Senator Bob Dole, traditionally a proponent of free trade, has thrashed Patrick J. Buchanan in the primaries so far. But Mr. Buchanan's acerbic insistence on all but stopping the flow of goods, investment and people across the Mexican border has forced the party and Senator Dole to take a harder line on immigrants.
For San Diego, this comes at an awkward time. The city wants to appear open and optimistic when the convention begins, not angry.
As one local businessman put it, "When Pat Buchanan gets up in the morning and marches down to the border to shake his fist at all those Mexicans, who do you think is going to be making the bed at his hotel? It's the people he says are destroying our society."
This city's business and civic leaders are struggling to put that conflict behind them, but so far with only modest success.
"Historically, you talked about integration across the border and you were almost shot," Mr. Partida said. "This represents a shock to a community that was very isolationist. People are finally starting to see Mexico differently, but there's still a real disconnect between impressions and reality, and there's so much fear."
Susan Golding, the city's Mayor and a proponent of the more open attitude toward Mexico, conceded that it is an uphill battle.
"There are still people in San Diego who would prefer this to be an elegant cul-de-sac, if it could still be elegant," said Ms. Golding, a Republican. "I just don't think that's possible."
With 1.2 million residents, San Diego is the sixth-largest city in the country, and it has long been a Republican bastion. For decades, it was effectively a company town, and the company was the Pentagon. The Navy maintains several huge operations here and numerous aerospace and military factories are in the area.
This was no accident. Early this century, the Chamber of Commerce raised money to buy the land for the Navy. Mr. Partida said recent research into the chamber's minutes showed that the business community had pursued the Navy in part because, at the time, it was regarded as the whitest of the services. Today, San Diego has the largest military payroll, uniformed and civilian, in the country: $3.7 billion a year.
For years, Mexico and Tijuana had little place in the comfortable life that San Diego had created, except as the home of bars and brothels. "Sailors went to Tijuana," said Mayor Golding, who recalled that when she arrived here 20 years ago and suggested a visit south, a friend told her in effect that nice girls did not do such things.
And although tens of thousands of Mexicans came to San Diego to work at manual and agricultural jobs, they were often treated with disdain, many here say.
"I was not prepared for what I found when I started the office here eight years ago," said Claudia Smith, the lead lawyer in San Diego for California Rural Legal Assistance, which represents immigrants. "Even today, the anti-immigrant feelings are raw and much stronger here than anywhere else in the state."
Times began to change a few years ago. The aerospace and military factories were hit hard by the steep, post-cold war decline in Pentagon procurement. Aerospace jobs have plummeted from a peak of 27,800 in 1989 to about 9,000 now. Although the Navy bases will remain, business leaders realized they had to look elsewhere for growth.
"We started to focus on economic integration with Mexico all of a sudden because we had to," Mr. Partida said.
San Diego set up a sister city relationship with Tijuana in 1993. Greater attention was paid to the growth of the maquiladoras, the factories built in Tijuana that were allowed to move parts and finished goods across the border duty free. Often, two plants would be built, one in San Diego to do the more complex work, and one in Tijuana to do the assembly, using the cheaper wages of Mexican workers.
With that opening, the San Diego-Tijuana area has become the largest manufacturer of television sets in the world, many made by companies like Sony, Samsung and Matsushita. Many American companies have also built plants in Tijuana, part of a thriving high-technology sector here.
San Ysidro, one of several crossings here, is the busiest overland border post in the world. San Diego Dialogue, an organization affiliated with the University of California at San Diego, estimates that about 40,000 people legally cross the border for work each day, about 10,000 of whom are American citizens who choose to live in Tijuana. The group also says that Mexicans spend more than $2 billion a year in San Diego's stores.
A recent survey by the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies has found that 51 percent of the labor in the high-technology sector is foreign born, 95 percent of agricultural labor, 63 percent of construction workers and 87 percent hotel workers.
Even the world of sports has changed. Under new ownership, the San Diego Padres baseball team started marketing heavily to Hispanic residents and in Tijuana over the past year. The Padres will play three regular season games this year, against the New York Mets, in Mexico -- a first for the league.
Nevertheless, a battle of perceptions still rages.
"I think they're naive and headed for great disappointment," Roger Hedgecock, a former Mayor of San Diego and now a popular local talk show host, said of those who want a closer relationship with Mexico. "This illegal immigration is a runaway train and we don't know all the consequences. They're coming in in a tidal wave."
Mr. Hedgecock and others argue that immigrants are swamping the welfare system and causing widespread crime. But figures supporting the view are hard to come by.
Violent crime has dropped 24 percent in three years. Only about 10 percent of the 4,892 inmates in San Diego's jails are illegal immigrants.
People here complain that Mexicans are stealing American jobs, but the city's unemployment rate, 6 percent, is significantly lower than the state average of 7.7 percent. The county government is among the leanest in the state, with spending per capita about half the level of Los Angeles County, suggesting that the welfare system is under control.
The number of people caught trying to enter San Diego illegally from Mexico has risen sharply. From Oct. 1, 1995, to March 17, the Border patrol apprehended 237,286 people, a steep increase from 175,891 in the comparable period a year earlier.
But Mark Moody, a spokesman for the Border Patrol, said the jump reflected better policing rather than more people trying to slip in.
The conflicting views have left some people apprehensive about which San Diego will be on display.
"With people here just starting to see Mexico as an opportunity rather than a negative, the last thing we want is a convention directed toward extremist themes," Mr. Partida said. "We want to people to see the new San Diego."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Immigrants like Jesus E. Garcia, who came from Ensenada, Mexico, 30 years ago, are at the heart of a furious debate in San Diego. Mr. Garcia repaired fishing nets with the city's downtown skyline in the background. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Colombia's Beleaguered Chief Hints at Calling Early Election

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 22

 BODY:
 President Ernesto Samper, who has spent much of his presidency fending off accusations that Cali drug dealers financed his campaign, opened the way today for his resignation by raising the prospect of early elections, perhaps before the end of the year.
In a speech made as he signed a law lifting judicial secrecy from the proceedings of the Congressional Committee of Accusations, which is hearing evidence against him, the President broached several possible "political options to overcome the crisis." They included a Government of national unity, shortening his term as President or submitting his mandate to a popular referendum. 
 The prospect of early elections, like the President's proposal for a national referendum, first raised several months ago, does not appear to be meeting with widespread support. Some saw it simply as a delaying tactic, in part because the President raised it as the last in a series of proposals, preceded by vague suggestions of campaign-finance reform and judicial reform.
"As President of Colombia, my priority is to find an exit to the crisis that is affecting us," Mr. Samper said. "We have to resume a sense of normalcy."
But if Mr. Samper does decide to step down, it is clear he will not go quietly. Tonight, his attorney, Luis Guillermo Nieto, charged that the President's two main accusers, his campaign manager and treasurer, had raised money from Cali drug dealers in the name of the Samper campaign but had depositng millions of dollars in their personal bank accounts. Earlier this week, the President lashed out at the chief prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso, saying he should go after drug dealers instead of Government ministers. Mr. Valdivieso is investigating three members of the President's cabinet.
Mr. Samper did not suggest specific dates in his speech, but radio and press reports said he was planning to propose elections for some time between November and next March. But Mr. Samper has said he will not take any steps until Congress concludes its investigation.
In just the last month, the President has suffered several setbacks, starting on March 1 with the United States decision to declare Colombia uncooperative in the fight against drug trafficking -- an assessment that was directly tied to Washington's insistence that Mr. Samper had accepted more than $6 million in campaign contributions from drug traffickers.
Then, last week, three ministers who have been close allies of the President throughout his travails came under investigation for possible violations of campaign financing rules in Mr. Samper's election campaign and for a subsequent cover-up, which that includes accusations of the widespread use of bribery to force Mr. Valdivieso out of office.
The three could, in short order, find themselves behind bars. They are Horacio Serpa, the Interior Minister, who has been the President's most loyal and indefatigable supporter; Mr. Samper's Communications Director and childhood friend, Juan Manuel Turbay, and his Foreign Minister, Rodrigo Pardo, who had been held in high esteem here and abroad.
With each setback, the President's determination to stay in office appears to be diminishing. The man who went from saying, "Here I am and here I'll stay" a few months ago, to suggesting in individual interviews and through associates that he was seeking a "dignified exit," now appears to be acknowledging that he is unlikely to finish his term, which is to end in 1998.
This week the President met with major figures throughout the country "to hear their opinions and advance some initiatives." They included Mr. Valdivieso; three former Presidents, including Cesar Gaviria, the chairman of the Organization of American States; Liberal and Conservative Party leaders; Vice President Humberto de la Calle, and the writer Gabriel Garcia Marquez.
The President, who was given a standing ovation by business executives and trade ministers from 34 countries when he opened a meeting on trade strategies in Cartagena on Wednesday night, nevertheless has reportedly been criticized by Colombian business leaders for a decline in the country's economic fortunes in the month since decertification.

HEADLINE: Essex County's Residency Rule Faces Setback

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 22

 BODY:
A judge dealt a setback today to an attempt by the Essex County Executive to require employees of the county to live within its borders.
The judge, Alvin Weiss, of Superior Court, temporarily barred the county from dismissing workers who do not live in the county, even though he found that the county's 17-year-old residency requirement had been properly adopted. 
 The judge did not set a date for a hearing on a permanent injunction.
In addition, Judge Weiss found that the requirement should not apply to people who work for the county prosecutor and sheriff because those offices hire and dismiss their own employees.
The county executive, James W. Treffinger, announced earlier this year that he would enforce the dormant 1978 law in the hopes of improving the county's ailing economy.
"The $44 million in salaries paid to nonresident county employees comes from the hard-earned salaries of our Essex taxpayers," Mr. Treffinger said, "and they deserve to see that money pumped back into their own communities." . He set a deadline of July for the 750 county employees affected by the requirement to move into Essex or lose their jobs.
Eleven public employee unions representing 4,000 employees in occupations like corrections officers, clerical workers, supervisors, hospital workers and investigators challenged Mr. Treffinger in court.
After the ruling today, David H. Weiner, chairman of the Essex County Joint Labor Council, which represents all the unions that filed lawsuits, said, "The judge struck a blow against tyrannical misuse of authority by Mr. Treffinger."
Late today, Mr. Treffinger issued a statement indicating that he might consider an earlier offer made by unions to begin the residency requirement this year.
"If the ultimate result of this process proves to be that, at the very least, all persons hired by Essex County government after Jan. 1, 1996, must be Essex County residents, then I will feel that I have done my duty and served our Essex County taxpayers," Mr. Treffinger said.
But Steven Weissman, a lawyer representing four unions, said he had not heard from Mr. Treffinger.
Of the 444 employees on the prosecutor's staff, 180 live outside the county, said John S. Redden, the deputy first assistant prosecutor. "I shudder at the thought of how badly we would have been affected," he said.
Sheriff Armando B. Fontoura said 70 of his 480 employees live outside Essex County. Mr. Treffinger's plan "would have had a devastating impact on law enforcement," Sheriff Fontoura said.
In their legal arguments, the unions had contended that workers had been told by their bosses that they were permitted to live out of the county and had relied on that information in buying homes and settling their families.
But Michael Griffinger, the lawyer representing Essex County, looked at it differently.
"Some county employees chose not to obey the resolution because somebody winked at them," Mr. Griffinger said. "That will be an issue that will have to come up before the judge."
