HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN WESTCHESTER: THE GUNMAN;
Spasm of Gunfire Brought a Man's Troubled Life to a Dismal End

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
With a prayer for forgiveness scrawled on the wall and his funeral clothes neatly laid out, a troubled young man with an arsenal of weapons was found dead in his Westchester County home at dawn yesterday, ending a terrifying, 14-hour siege in which he turned a quiet suburb into a battleground, murdered a police officer by ambush and then killed his grandmother, his dog and himself.
While no one was sure what precipitated the killings, officials noted yesterday that the gunman had pleaded guilty in Manhattan last month to charges of stalking and harassing his estranged wife and was to begin a 30-day jail term in April. Friends and family said he was apparently despondent at the failure of his marriage and the prospect of jail, and may have snapped. 
 By 6 A.M. yesterday, when police sharpshooters moved into his sprawling tan home at 17 Morgan Street in Eastchester, five miles north of New York City, and crept upstairs to the back bedroom that had become his final refuge, the suspect, 26-year-old Richard Sacchi, may have been dead all night.
The police acknowledged that hundreds of heavily armed officers with armored and robot vehicles, helicopters and an army of support personnel and equipment had probably laid siege to a dead man through a bizarre night of heavy metal music blaring from his house and searchlights playing over its facade in a frightened, evacuated neighborhood.
They said Mr. Sacchi, after spraying his street with 50 shots from rifles and shotguns for an hour, had ceased firing about 4 P.M. In retrospect, and after examining the scene for clues, officials said Mr. Sacchi had apparently killed his 88-year-old grandmother by mistake, and then himself deliberately, in the hour after he killed Officer Michael Frey.
The 29-year-old Eastchester officer had been the first to respond to what the police yesterday said was evidently an ambush the gunman himself set up with a call summoning the police to his home just before 3 P.M. Thursday. The moment Officer Frey drew up, alone in his cruiser, high-powered bullets crashed through his window, struck him in the chest and killed him.
Fourteen hours later, Mr. Sacchi -- whose unhappy life was a chronicle of mental problems, violence, petty crimes, reform schools, jails, unemployment and tumultuous relationships, including a recently broken marriage -- was found lying on his back on a bloodsoaked bed beside a 12-gauge shotgun and the 30.06 rifle that he had apparently used to blast a hole in his stomach and abdomen.
It was a gruesome, eerie scene. On a hanger, the gunman had left out a black shirt and a grayish black suit, with a note that said, "clothes for me funiral." His white terrier, shot to death, lay nearby. Six rifles and shotguns were found in various rooms.
On the wall above his body, he had scribbled last words in pencil: "Jesus, forgive me for my sins. I will see you in eternity." And, "My dad is the best dad in the world." Richard Sacchi Sr. had arrived home from work only to find himself pinned down with seven officers by his son's gunfire from an upstairs window.
Lying at the bottom of the steps, the gunman's grandmother, Catherine M. Sacchi, was found dead with a gaping wound of the torso. Investigators said she had apparently been shot through a door, perhaps mistaken by her grandson for an approaching police officer, and had tumbled backward down the steps.
In a denouement laden with strange paradoxes, family acquaintances recalled yesterday that the gunman's grandmother had been an almost lifelong friend of Viola Morrissey, the 83-year-old mother of Officer Richard Morrissey, 45, the other officer who was shot. He suffered a graze wound of the head and was pinned down for hours by the gunfire and its aftermath.
Even in the light of day yesterday, it was difficult to say where the origins of the nightmare began. Mr. Sacchi had been troubled all his life, a bully in school, an adolescent out of control, who was sent to a school for disturbed youths, a psychiatric center, an alcohol rehabilitation program and lived for a time at a homeless shelter.
His parents were divorced, his mother moved away and he continued living with his father and grandmother in the big house that she owned in Eastchester. Since 1987, he had been arrested and convicted five times -- for criminal trespass, menacing and third-degree robbery.
He married Denise Marie Wiggins in 1992 and for a time was happy. He loved hunting and fishing, collecting rifles and shotguns. They worked together for a housecleaning service. But Mr. Sacchi was said to have abused his wife and the marriage fell apart last year.
She took a boyfriend, and Mr. Sacchi became violently jealous. She got an order of protection and he was arrested with a shotgun and pleaded guilty on Feb. 23 to a charge of aggravated harassment. A judge sentenced him to 30 days in jail beginning April 12.
Reconstructing the events of Mr. Sacchi's final day, officials said that the failure of his marriage and the prospect of jail may have caused him to snap. The Eastchester Police Chief, James Maher, said that Mr. Sacchi had called acquaintances and relatives on Thursday and "indicated that he would not be around too much longer."
At 2:55 P.M., he called the Eastchester police number, not 911. "He said there's a suspicious person in front of 17 Morgan Street," his own address, Chief Maher said. He said Mr. Sacchi was apparently setting up an ambush. The gunman took up a firing position in an upstairs living room, moving to a front window overlooking the lawn and street of middle-class homes. He had to wait only a few minutes.
Officer Frey responded, driving up alone in his patrol car and parking at the curb. There was no hint that a deadly situation confronted him, the Chief said.
Without warning or provocation, Chief Maher said, five copper-jacketed bullets from a high-powered 30.06 deer rifle crashed through the window of the cruiser and struck Officer Frey, who was wearing a bullet-resistant vest that covered his front and back, but left a gap on his right side -- where the fatal bullet entered his chest. He was the first officer ever killed in the line of duty in Eastchester.
Chief Maher said a female neighbor saw the the bleeding officer slumped at the wheel. She went to Mr. Sacchi's door to get help -- and then noticed the barrel of the gun out the window above, and quickly retreated and called the police.
Officer Dominick Santoianni, a 20-year veteran, arrived next and immediately came under fire and took cover. Officer Morrissey arrived with the next wave of officers and was wounded as he tried to approach the house. He took cover behind a patrol car. Reinforcements poured in and were pinned down by gunfire, as was the rifleman's father.
"He was very helpful," Chief Maher said of the father, who provided information about his son, his mother -- who was presumed then to be a hostage -- and on the layout of the house. Scores of officers from other communities joined the siege, but it was not until New York City police officers arrived with a tanklike armored car that the authorities were able to rescue those who were pinned and retrieve Officer Frey's body.
The police fired numerous bullets into the house, but officials said they did not believe Mr. Sacchi or his grandmother were hit.
As the gunfire subsided, the police settled into what seemed an all-night standoff. Efforts to reach the gunman by phone and bullhorn drew no responses. For most of the night, heavy metal rock wailed from the darkened house. Just before midnight, a police robot with a video camera found Mrs. Sacchi's body, and a team of officers went in and carried the victim out.
The robot -- a waist-high marvel that goes 5 miles an hour and climbs stairs -- was sent back in. It searched everywhere, but failed to maneuver into the back bedroom. German shepherds went in to sniff for signs of life. They found none. With time on their side, the police waited all night before moving in.
They found Mr. Sacchi face up on his bed in the gray dawn, his funeral suit laid out beside him, his last prayer scrawled on the wall, his midsection blown away.

HEADLINE: Who Benefits by New Jersey Income Tax Cut?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Timothy J. Goodspeed and Peter D. Salins (Op-Ed, March 16), in their praise of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's tax policies, overlook the 60,000 state workers who have been subjected to four-year contracts with two-year wage freezes that mean 5 percent effective wage cuts. 
 We have seen our health benefits gutted and our pensions and retirement health care attacked. My contacts with state workers suggest a level of anger that may not be measurable in immediate dollars but will come home to haunt the taxpayers.
 
RICHARD W. FRANKE
Upper Montclair, N.J., March 20, 1996
 
The writer is an executive board member, Local 1904, American Federation of Teachers.

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN AT G.M. LEAVES BIG ISSUES STILL UNRESOLVED

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, March 22

 BODY:
Workers began returning to two General Motors brake factories this afternoon, ending their 17-day strike with local disputes resolved but not critical national issues between the company and the United Automobile Workers.
The national issues are sure to come up again this summer when negotiations begin before the expiration on Sept. 14 of the U.A.W.'s three-year national contract. But for now, both sides have paid a stiff price for a strike that paid off mostly for the local workers. G.M. lost considerable production, and by the end of the strike, 177,775 U.A.W. members were laid off. 
 G.M. and the U.A.W. made no changes in the national contract or local agreements on the extent to which G.M. could farm out parts production to nonunion companies, a practice known as outsourcing. This was the most important battleground in the strike for G.M. and the national leadership of the union.
The union let G.M. proceed with plans to buy some anti-lock brake systems and other parts from outside companies. But G.M. agreed to hire more workers here and promised to continue making many other brake parts here. G.M. also agreed to pay $1,700 to each local worker in compensation for buying parts from outside companies in violation of the U.A.W.'s national contract.
Both sides claimed victory in the agreement, which was reached on Thursday and approved this morning by close to 3,200 striking brake factory workers. The workers began returning to their jobs and G.M. officials said the company would reopen 26 shuttered assembly plants by the middle of next week and rehire the laid-off G.M. workers.
For his part, James M. Hagedon Jr., a G.M. spokesman, said that the company had preserved its ability to buy parts from outside companies. "We have the flexibility we've always had," he said.
Richard Shoemaker, the director of the U.A.W.'s G.M. department, said the agreement provided job security for current workers, some new jobs for Dayton residents and improvements in unsafe working conditions.
"Once again, the U.A.W. has proven that when working people stand together in defense of their rights and their livelihoods, and to demand a better future for their families and their communities, we will win," he said.
G.M. finally settled the strike several days after closing its last and most profitable factory in the United States, a plant in Janesville, Wis., that makes sport utility vehicles.
In the national contracts this summer, G.M. is likely to find itself at a disadvantage because the U.A.W. will probably seek a deal first with the Chrysler Corporation and then demand that the Ford Motor Company and G.M. accept an identical arrangement.
Chrysler already buys most of its parts from outside companies and may prove willing to cut a deal that puts a freeze on any further outsourcing, in exchange for other concessions. Any freeze on outsourcing would prove a big problem for G.M., which makes more of its own parts than any other large auto maker in the world.
One of the most unusual features of the strike here has been the very visible participation of Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman. Mr. Pearce is a combative lawyer who used to be G.M.'s general counsel and is now a strong candidate to someday succeed John F. Smith Jr. as G.M.'s chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Pearce made his reputation several years ago when he unearthed evidence that an NBC television program on safety defects in G.M. pickup trucks had used model rockets to make sure that a truck exploded during a videotaped collision.
Mr. Pearce, with the support of G.M.'s board, took a much more aggressive approach to the strike talks than Big Three labor negotiators had in the past. He gave interviews contending that G.M.'s survival was at stake if the company could not become more competitive by holding down its auto parts costs.
He also had G.M. ask state governments nationwide to deny unemployment benefits to U.A.W. workers, contending that the union was engaging in a national strike disguised as a local action.
Auto industry experts said today that Mr. Pearce's hardball tactics prolonged the strike. But Mr. Pearce's willingness to challenge the unemployment benefits may also make the U.A.W. think twice before starting large strikes in the future.
With the U.A.W. strike fund already depleted by an unsuccessful strike against Caterpillar Inc. last year, and with national contract negotiations approaching, Mr. Pearce's maneuver of challenging unemployment benefits represented a real financial threat to the U.A.W.
But Mr. Pearce found an equally pugnacious opponent in Joe Hasenjager, the president of U.A.W. Local 696, which represents the brake factory workers here. While Mr. Pearce could put financial pressure on the national leadership of the U.A.W., he had less leverage with Mr. Hasenjager, at the local level.
Once on strike, Mr. Hasenjager refused to lead his men back to work without numerous guarantees of jobs. Mr. Pearce and Mr. Shoemaker ended up having to fly to Dayton on Thursday and personally guarantee the jobs to Mr. Hasenjager -- a rare step for the second-ranking executive at a company with close to 800,000 workers globally.
Mr. Hasenjager has been the president of the union local here since 1987 and his father was president of the same local here in the early 1950's. He is running for re-election as president of the union local and is widely expected to win.
In interviews over the last 10 days, many members were vague about the details of the dispute and said they were on strike partly because they trusted Mr. Hasenjager's view that a strike was necessary.
The result, people close to both sides of the negotiation said today, was a final strike settlement that accommodated the local union's concerns without resolving broader tensions between G.M. and the U.A.W.
 
How Each Side Fared
 
The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union released yesterday some of the details of the agreement that settled a brake factory strike in Dayton, Ohio. Here are the agreement's key provisions, reached Thursday:
 
WHAT THE U.A.W. WON
 
Hiring. The U.A.W. says G.M. will hire 417 workers, most of them in 1996 and 1997. G.M. says some workers will retire or leave, so overall employment will rise by only 47 workers.
Less unwanted overtime. The U.A.W. says weekly overtime for a worker will fall to 8 hours from 16 hours.
Money. G.M. will pay $1,700 to each worker as compensation for company violations of the U.A.W. national labor contract's rules on purchases from outside companies.
Safety equipment and training. The U.A.W. says G.M. will spend $6.5 million. G.M. says it planned spend more anyway.
Information. The U.A.W. says G.M.'s car and truck assembly division will provide a list of future brake needs, to help the U.A.W. and the factory bid to build them. G.M. refuses to comment.
Technology. The U.A.W. says G.M. will invest to keep the factories up-to-date. G.M. says it planned to do so anyway.
 
WHAT G.M. WON
 
Buying parts outside. The right to keep recent contractors to buy some anti-lock brakes and other parts from outside companies.
End of the strike. the ability to resume production at 26 assembly plants across North America.
 
WHAT EACH SIDE CLAIMS IT WON
 
Future outsourcing . No changes were made. The U.A.W. says it prevented G.M. from gaining new freedom to give future contracts to outside companies. But G.M says it protected existing flexibility.
 
(Sources: General Motors, United Automobile Workers)

HEADLINE: The Grunge American NovelA New York Times Magazine Profile

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI

 BODY:
NERVOUSNESS AND DREAD frequently chase David Foster Wallace, and when they catch him, as they have now, he writhes and twitches and prattles at a breakneck clip, his incessant quips running the gamut from marvelous to mundane. ''Do you have my saliva?'' he asks a companion in his cab, reflecting on the way his jitters have drained all moisture from his mouth. ''Somebody took my saliva, because I don't have it.''
 The Sunday-night traffic is negligible and the taxi's route is a fairly straight shot down Broadway from Wallace's hotel in midtown Manhattan to a club downtown where he will kick off a 10-city book tour. But the trip seems to take an awfully long time, perhaps because it represents such a pivotal passage -- as close as anything else to a dividing line between what Wallace was and what he is becoming, between modest literary recognition and immodest literary fame.
 ''I'm sort of nervous,'' he says as the cab creeps ever closer to its destination. ''I have no saliva.'' 
 The taxi pulls up to a dark building that could easily pass for abandoned. K.G.B. is a smoky, shadowy club with a Muscovite motif and a weekly reading series, largely for avant-garde writers. Wallace steps inside to find a narrow staircase mobbed with people. They are merely the spillover. The real crowd waits in a room at the top.
 Wallace's lips almost curl into a smile, then beat a hasty retreat. He wants this, he doesn't want this, he is still sifting through his feelings. He is also trying to find precisely the right face to put on them, because he knows that the way he plays this scene and similar ones could color his whole career.
 He pushes up the stairs, through the tangle of bodies, and somehow, inch by crushing inch, makes his way to the front of the room, where a lectern stands before about 125 people. After a short wait and a fawning introduction by the club's co-owner, he opens a copy of his sprawling 1,079-page novel, ''Infinite Jest,'' and begins to read three snippets.
 For the first, concerning a bungled burglary by two drug addicts, his voice is halting and the crowd's laughter is tentative. During the second, about a bizarre fitness guru, both his confidence and the crowd's response grow strong. And by the end of the third, about the use of video telephones in the near future, he sounds positively exultant, and the audience answers him with sustained applause. Bathed in that delicious noise, Wallace looks beatific.
 Nervousness? Dread? For this moment, at least, they seem distant memories, banished by the heady thrill of it all.
 a DECADE AGO, IT WAS MCINERNEY. DECADES earlier, Mailer. Right now, it is Wallace, the first young novelist in several years to pique such intense curiosity.
 He is a 34-year-old writer with the ardor, arrogance or sheer audacity to produce a book so bulky that, as he jokes, customers at Barnes & Noble may need help carrying their purchases to their cars. ''Infinite Jest'' is not only massive but also forbidding, and more than a few of the hardy souls who set out to scale it will neither make it to the summit nor care to.
 Set mostly at a tennis academy and a drug rehabilitation center in the not-too-distant future, ''Infinite Jest'' tells a jumble of tales that often seem loosely related, if at all. Front and center is the story of the three Incandenza brothers -- a promiscuous football punter, a brainy tennis prodigy and a dwarf -- and the long shadow cast over them by their father, who committed suicide. Off to the side are a band of terrorists in wheelchairs who are on the hunt for a copy of a movie, the eponymous ''Infinite Jest,'' said to be so entertaining it puts anyone who watches it into a permanent, blissed-out stupor. And way down below, struggling to the surface for air, is Don Gately, an old drug addict with a new religion.
 All of these strenuously eccentric characters inhabit a narrative that proceeds in a distinctly nonlinear fashion, lurching from abrupt, trumpetlike blasts of information to sentences so long only a supercomputer could diagram them. Wallace is to literature what Robin Williams or perhaps Jim Carrey is to live comedy: a creator so manically energetic and amused with himself that he often follows his riffs out into the stratosphere, where he orbits all alone. ''Infinite Jest'' is best read with a dictionary and maybe even a pharmacology textbook at hand, for it employs an often arcane vocabulary (''strabismic,'' ''erumpent'') and makes reference to a bulging medicine chest of psychoactive drugs. Some are explicated in the 96 pages of footnotes that Wallace has appended to his tome.
 The critics -- or most of them, anyway -- are smitten. ''Next year's book awards have been decided,'' began a review in New York magazine by Walter Kirn. ''The plaques and citations can now be put in escrow.'' The normally saturnine Sven Birkerts, writing in The Atlantic Monthly, proclaimed that ''Infinite Jest'' had ''internalized some of the decentering energies that computer technologies have released into our midst.'' Will Blythe, of Esquire, after grousing about the novel's heft and hype, came right out and declared that ''it shows signs, in fact, of being a genuine work of genius.'' Even those critics with qualms about the novel's loquacity and opacity gave it high marks in the end. Michiko Kakutani, who reviewed ''Infinite Jest'' for The Times, was highly dubious, but ultimately anointed Wallace ''a writer of virtuosic talents who can seemingly do anything.''
 The critics aren't the only ones angling to prove that they get it. Wallace's contemporaries have shown up at his public appearances in force. When he read at K.G.B., Elizabeth Wurtzel, the author of ''Prozac Nation,'' claimed a spot near the front of the room. The following night, at another jampacked reading, this time at Tower Books in the Village, Ethan Hawke lurked in the back. And at the official book party two nights later at an East Village club, M. G. Lord, the author of ''Forever Barbie,'' can be seen chatting up another novelist of the moment, A. M. Homes. Between puffs of their cigarettes, many people whisper what Wallace says he does not want to hear: he is the current ''it'' boy of contemporary fiction.
 For a long stretch Wallace retreats to an office above the club's kitchen to decompress. There are moments when the full measure of his success hits him and he feels what he describes as ''unalloyed happiness.'' But there are moments, too, when he feels besieged, disoriented and even a bit terrified.
 ''Something is slightly off about this whole thing,'' he says on the eve of his tour, as he sits on a sofa in his house in Bloomington, Ill. The smaller of his two dogs, a black Labrador retriever mix named Jeeves, keeps trying to climb into his lap and lick his lips, a gesture not unrelated to the fact that Wallace is eating a bologna sandwich. ''They pretend they're kissing you,'' Wallace says of his dogs, ''but they're really mining your mouth for food.''
 He is as suspicious of the attention coming his way as he is of Jeeves's motives. ''I keep getting the feeling that all of this is about some initial surge of excitement, and now it's created excitement about the excitement,'' he says. Elated as he is about his achievement and eager as he is to promote the book, he maintains that the hoopla almost makes him want to become a recluse.
 This assertion plays in part like a canny pose of tactful modesty and in part like a nod to such literary idols as J. D. Salinger and Thomas Pynchon, whose work Wallace's resembles. But Wallace's friends say that his desire for privacy is genuine. They cite his decision to live far away from the publishing hubbub, in the flat farmland of the Middle West, and to teach at Illinois State University, a school without ivy. Jonathan Franzen, a fellow novelist and confidant, says Wallace is like many serious writers who, by necessity, spend most of their time alone. ''You tend to develop the personality that corresponds to that solitude,'' Franzen says.
 This helps explain why sudden fame is often more awkward for a serious writer than for a serious actor, who does his work in public and is accustomed to being the subject, rather than the agent, of observation. An actor can mug his way through a fairly long string of parties and fashion shows before he is accused of overexposure and ridiculed; a writer hits that threshold sooner. ''Then his subsequent work isn't looked at directly, but through the glare of all that publicity,'' says the editor Gary Fisketjon, whose stable of writers at Knopf includes Jay McInerney. The more a writer indulges the news media, Fisketjon observes, the more vulnerable he is to deflation. ''It raises the stakes on everything he does in the future.''
 Wallace has a virtually innate awareness of this danger. ''When I won't do things like appear on network television, it's not because I have a lot of integrity,'' he says. ''Part of it is that I feel I'm going to turn off exactly the people whose approval I'm most hungry for.'' While he is not greedy about money, he explains, ''I'm real greedy about respect.''
 In one sense, the success of Wallace and ''Infinite Jest'' are a complete surprise. No one knows who and what will hit the jackpot at a given moment, and publishers constantly squander large cash advances and aggressive publicity campaigns on books that land quickly in the remainder bin. ''It really depends on so many things that are impossible for you to align by yourself,'' says Bret Easton Ellis, who has had more than a decade, and plenty of disappointments, since the publication of ''Less Than Zero'' to reflect on the process. ''It's the mood of the public, the times -- all these intangibles.''
 But in another sense, what is happening to Wallace was predictable and painstakingly engineered. When Michael Pietsch, the book's editor, convinced his colleagues at Little, Brown and Company to fork over a figure estimated at $90,000 to buy ''Infinite Jest'' as a work in progress, he argued that Wallace had developed a significant cult following with his first two books, ''The Broom of the System'' and ''Girl With Curious Hair,'' and was due for a breakthrough.
 Pietsch also apprehended several other realities that have influenced Wallace's success. Many years had passed since the so-called Brat Pack of the mid- to late 1980's -- McInerney, Ellis and Tama Janowitz -- turned putatively serious literature into a fashion statement, and it was long past time for a new Wunderkind to do something similar. More to the point, the members of so-called Generation X had yet to claim definitively a maverick, idiosyncratic literary voice all their own. Wallace's work spoke both to this generation's shtick and to its soul.
 ''Infinite Jest'' is sardonic, jaded and steeped in references to all strata of popular culture, from high to low. It exhibits both a savvy grasp of the cyberfrontiers on the horizon and a deep, abiding distrust of them. It is mildly subversive, occasionally ribald and sporadically crude. Think David Letterman with a postgraduate degree and diction, and you get at least some idea of the sensibility. ''This has become a very hip book to read,'' says Alice K. Turner, the fiction editor at Playboy, who encouraged Wallace early in his career. ''We've had a lot of skimpy fare for a long time.''
 Indeed, executives at Little, Brown quickly realized that the sheer length of ''Infinite Jest'' could work in their favor, and although Wallace was asked to cut about 300 pages from his initial draft, he was still allowed to exceed 1,000 pages, which meant that the book would be priced at $30. ''We decided to play it as importance -- that the size lent a certain weight to the book, that there was a certain undeniability about it,'' says Amy Rhodes, head of marketing for the company. Her strategy revolved around a kind of dare: are you reader enough for this book?
 To create that elusive, ephemeral entity known as buzz, the company compiled a list of 4,000 booksellers, industry insiders and media types and sent out a staggered series of six postcards that cryptically heralded the release of an at-first-unspecified book that gives ''infinite pleasure'' with ''infinite style.'' And when blurbs to that effect became available from other authors and critics, Little, Brown put them on postcards and dispatched another series of three. Says Paul Slovak, senior vice president of publicity for Viking Penguin, ''The promotional campaign has been brilliant.''
 And Wallace -- wittingly or unwittingly -- has served it well, projecting the perfect measure of aloofness, particularly in his appearance, which flouts conventional vanity in a manner that doth protest perhaps a bit too much. He often wears a bandanna wrapped tightly around his head, as if to avoid combing his shoulder-length hair and to coddle his febrile mind. His wire-rimmed glasses, stubble of beard and hole-ridden sweaters lend him the aspect of a doctoral candidate so deep in thought that he cannot afford the time or energy for grooming. Yet he runs regularly to stay fit, and his bathroom contains special tooth polish to combat the effects of the tobacco he chews. There's also a special acne medication to keep his skin unblemished.
 He hates that his publicity tour involves so many photography sessions. ''Whenever the picture comes out, it's absolutely appalling to me,'' he says. ''I just so wish that wasn't what I looked like. I've just figured it out: I'm not going to look at them anymore.''
 DO YOU GUYS KNOW 'THE CHARLIE ROSE Show'?'' Wallace asks two of his faculty friends at Illinois State, a married couple many years older than he, when he visits their house to say goodbye before his three-week tour. ''Would you think it was whorish if somebody went on it?''
 ''No, no,'' says Charles Harris, a professor of English. ''It's on late at night, and it goes into things at length. Are you going on it?''
 ''I did have a no-TV pledge,'' Wallace sighs.
 ''Until they asked?'' jokes Harris's wife, Victoria.
 After considerable introspection, Wallace nixes ''Charlie Rose,'' just as he turned down the ''Today'' show before it. In the interviews he does grant, Wallace draws sharp boundaries about what he will discuss and begs assurances about how it will be presented. ''If you quote that,'' he will qualify something he has just said, ''I'd really like you to quote that I acknowledge it sounds banal and cliched.''
 Friends say there are powerful currents of ambition and competitiveness in Wallace that can be traced back to his childhood in Urbana, Ill., and his career as a junior tennis player of some local prominence. Wallace's father, a philosophy professor at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign, and his mother, an English teacher at a community college, ferried him to tournaments throughout the Middle West.
 At Amherst College in Massachusetts, however, it was the life of the mind that he pursued, and with a similar vengeance. His major was philosophy. He recalls that during his sophomore year a professor told him he was a genius: ''It was the happiest moment in my life. I felt like I would never have to go to the bathroom again -- that I'd transcended it.''
 Mark Costello, a classmate, says Wallace was pegged by professors there as someone who could become an important philosopher. So when Wallace turned his intellectual energies toward fiction writing, it was a decision fraught with ambivalence and fear. ''He was a guy under tremendous internal pressure,'' Costello says. ''I think it was important to him to get a little external confirmation that he hadn't made an absurd choice.''
 His senior thesis at Amherst became the first rough chunk of ''The Broom of the System,'' his 467-page Pynchonesque debut novel; shortly after he graduated and went on to what he derisively calls a ''master of flatulent arts'' program in creative writing at the University of Arizona, he had a contract with Viking Penguin, which published ''Broom'' in 1987. That same year he won a prestigious $25,000 Whiting Writers' Award. Two years later Norton published ''Girl With Curious Hair,'' a collection of short fiction.
 But Wallace was tormented and miserable. Was he really brilliant, as some people told him? Or was he a fake, as he sometimes felt? By this point he was drinking heavily, taking drugs and sleeping around, self-destructive behavior that he figured was consistent with the life style that a cool, serious writer was supposed to have. Wallace is intentionally vague on this period of his life, and what he divulges sometimes contradicts the recollections of friends. He says he never formally entered a recovery program; Alice Turner says he did. He mentions a single suicide scare and subsequent stay in a psychiatric ward; friends allude to more than one.
 There is agreement, however, that he halted his downward spiral around 1990 and began to cultivate a saner, stabler existence. He eventually took a job as an associate professor at Illinois State in Normal and bought a middle-class house on a road that winds past fields of feed corn and a slaughterhouse. He adopted Jeeves and another black Lab mix, the Drone.
 For a while, a woman lived there, too, but she is gone now, her departure marked by the absence of any furniture in the living room. ''I hate that room,'' Wallace says. ''I always walk fast through that room to get to other rooms.'' His relationships, he confesses, have been many and short-lived. Before moving back to Illinois, he became involved for a time with the writer Mary Karr, author of ''The Liar's Club,'' and had her name tattooed on his upper arm. He blames himself for the brevity of his attachments. ''I'm massively selfish about my work, and I don't seem to be able to be very polite or considerate about other people's feelings,'' he says.
 His friendships appear to be more durable, and he finds them in unexpected places. Back in Illinois, he began to attend Sunday services at various churches around town -- there is something about religious faith, which was missing from his rearing by two atheists, that entices and calms him -- and he formed his closest social relationship with an older, married couple, Doug and Erin Poag. They met at a Mennonite house of worship.
 The Friday night before the Sunday start of his book tour finds Wallace watching ''The X-Files'' with the Poags in their living room. They are eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and Italian heroes on trays.
 The Poags mention that another of Wallace's favorite shows is ''Baywatch,'' and his face reddens. ''There are very complicated esthetic reasons why I watch it,'' he protests. ''It's why I used to watch 'The Love Boat' -- it was soothing, like a narcotic. You knew all problems would be resolved in 15 minutes and many lush platitudes would be exchanged.''
 wALLACE ACTUALLY BRINGS ERIN POAG ALONG to his readings in New York. The trip was a Christmas present to her from both Wallace and her family, but it clearly serves Wallace as well, reminding him of his other life outside the limelight.
 It will be difficult to balance the two existences. Although Wallace had initially decided not to read reviews of ''Infinite Jest,'' telling his agent to save them for some later date, he made a special trip to the campus library to find one of the first ones. He even donned sunglasses, ''because I'm an idiot who imagines that people have nothing better to do than sit around and watch me read my reviews.''
 Five days into his tour Wallace says that what he finds scariest about the whirlwind is his ability to tune out the aspects that make him uncomfortable and to let himself be borne along on its velvety currents. By the time he reached his 12th photo shoot, he says, he had learned to travel far away from the moment in his mind: ''I have actually gotten to revisit, in my head, all the museums I've ever gone to.''
 Very soon, he says, he will go home and get back to work. He will even change his telephone number. But there's a subtle note of worry in his voice. At some level, he knows how hard it will be to stop the ringing, and how hard it will be to resist it.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 24, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3344 words

HEADLINE: The Grunge American Novel

BYLINE: By Frank Bruni; Frank Bruni is a reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
ERVOUSNESS AND DREAD frequently chase David Foster Wallace, and when they catch him, as they have now, he writhes and twitches and prattles at a breakneck clip, his incessant quips running the gamut from marvelous to mundane. "Do you have my saliva?" he asks a companion in his cab, reflecting on the way his jitters have drained all moisture from his mouth. "Somebody took my saliva, because I don't have it."
The Sunday-night traffic is negligible and the taxi's route is a fairly straight shot down Broadway from Wallace's hotel in midtown Manhattan to a club downtown where he will kick off a 10-city book tour. But the trip seems to take an awfully long time, perhaps because it represents such a pivotal passage -- as close as anything else to a dividing line between what Wallace was and what he is becoming, between modest literary recognition and immodest literary fame. 
 "I'm sort of nervous," he says as the cab creeps ever closer to its destination. "I have no saliva."
The taxi pulls up to a dark building that could easily pass for abandoned. K.G.B. is a smoky, shadowy club with a Muscovite motif and a weekly reading series, largely for avant-garde writers. Wallace steps inside to find a narrow staircase mobbed with people. They are merely the spillover. The real crowd waits in a room at the top.
Wallace's lips almost curl into a smile, then beat a hasty retreat. He wants this, he doesn't want this, he is still sifting through his feelings. He is also trying to find precisely the right face to put on them, because he knows that the way he plays this scene and similar ones could color his whole career.
He pushes up the stairs, through the tangle of bodies, and somehow, inch by crushing inch, makes his way to the front of the room, where a lectern stands before about 125 people. After a short wait and a fawning introduction by the club's co-owner, he opens a copy of his sprawling 1,079-page novel, "Infinite Jest," and begins to read three snippets.
For the first, concerning a bungled burglary by two drug addicts, his voice is halting and the crowd's laughter is tentative. During the second, about a bizarre fitness guru, both his confidence and the crowd's response grow strong. And by the end of the third, about the use of video telephones in the near future, he sounds positively exultant, and the audience answers him with sustained applause. Bathed in that delicious noise, Wallace looks beatific.
Nervousness? Dread? For this moment, at least, they seem distant memories, banished by the heady thrill of it all.
A DECADE AGO, IT WAS MCINERNEY. DECADES earlier, Mailer. Right now, it is Wallace, the first young novelist in several years to pique such intense curiosity.
He is a 34-year-old writer with the ardor, arrogance or sheer audacity to produce a book so bulky that, as he jokes, customers at Barnes & Noble may need help carrying their purchases to their cars. "Infinite Jest" is not only massive but also forbidding, and more than a few of the hardy souls who set out to scale it will neither make it to the summit nor care to.
Set mostly at a tennis academy and a drug rehabilitation center in the not-too-distant future, "Infinite Jest" tells a jumble of tales that often seem loosely related, if at all. Front and center is the story of the three Incandenza brothers -- a promiscuous football punter, a brainy tennis prodigy and a dwarf -- and the long shadow cast over them by their father, who committed suicide. Off to the side are a band of terrorists in wheelchairs who are on the hunt for a copy of a movie, the eponymous "Infinite Jest," said to be so entertaining it puts anyone who watches it into a permanent, blissed-out stupor. And way down below, struggling to the surface for air, is Don Gately, an old drug addict with a new religion.
All of these strenuously eccentric characters inhabit a narrative that proceeds in a distinctly nonlinear fashion, lurching from abrupt, trumpetlike blasts of information to sentences so long only a supercomputer could diagram them. Wallace is to literature what Robin Williams or perhaps Jim Carrey is to live comedy: a creator so manically energetic and amused with himself that he often follows his riffs out into the stratosphere, where he orbits all alone. "Infinite Jest" is best read with a dictionary and maybe even a pharmacology textbook at hand, for it employs an often arcane vocabulary ("strabismic," "erumpent") and makes reference to a bulging medicine chest of psychoactive drugs. Some are explicated in the 96 pages of footnotes that Wallace has appended to his tome.
The critics -- or most of them, anyway -- are smitten. "Next year's book awards have been decided," began a review in New York magazine by Walter Kirn. "The plaques and citations can now be put in escrow." The normally saturnine Sven Birkerts, writing in The Atlantic Monthly, proclaimed that "Infinite Jest" had "internalized some of the decentering energies that computer technologies have released into our midst." Will Blythe, of Esquire, after grousing about the novel's heft and hype, came right out and declared that "it shows signs, in fact, of being a genuine work of genius." Even those critics with qualms about the novel's loquacity and opacity gave it high marks in the end. Michiko Kakutani, who reviewed "Infinite Jest" for The Times, was highly dubious, but ultimately anointed Wallace "a writer of virtuosic talents who can seemingly do anything."
The critics aren't the only ones angling to prove that they get it. Wallace's contemporaries have shown up at his public appearances in force. When he read at K.G.B., Elizabeth Wurtzel, the author of "Prozac Nation," claimed a spot near the front of the room. The following night, at another jampacked reading, this time at Tower Books in the Village, Ethan Hawke lurked in the back. And at the official book party two nights later at an East Village club, M. G. Lord, the author of "Forever Barbie," can be seen chatting up another novelist of the moment, A. M. Homes. Between puffs of their cigarettes, many people whisper what Wallace says he does not want to hear: he is the current "it" boy of contemporary fiction.
For a long stretch Wallace retreats to an office above the club's kitchen to decompress. There are moments when the full measure of his success hits him and he feels what he describes as "unalloyed happiness." But there are moments, too, when he feels besieged, disoriented and even a bit terrified.
"Something is slightly off about this whole thing," he says on the eve of his tour, as he sits on a sofa in his house in Bloomington, Ill. The smaller of his two dogs, a black Labrador retriever mix named Jeeves, keeps trying to climb into his lap and lick his lips, a gesture not unrelated to the fact that Wallace is eating a bologna sandwich. "They pretend they're kissing you," Wallace says of his dogs, "but they're really mining your mouth for food."
He is as suspicious of the attention coming his way as he is of Jeeves's motives. "I keep getting the feeling that all of this is about some initial surge of excitement, and now it's created excitement about the excitement," he says. Elated as he is about his achievement and eager as he is to promote the book, he maintains that the hoopla almost makes him want to become a recluse.
This assertion plays in part like a canny pose of tactful modesty and in part like a nod to such literary idols as J. D. Salinger and Thomas Pynchon, whose work Wallace's resembles. But Wallace's friends say that his desire for privacy is genuine. They cite his decision to live far away from the publishing hubbub, in the flat farmland of the Middle West, and to teach at Illinois State University, a school without ivy. Jonathan Franzen, a fellow novelist and confidant, says Wallace is like many serious writers who, by necessity, spend most of their time alone. "You tend to develop the personality that corresponds to that solitude," Franzen says.
This helps explain why sudden fame is often more awkward for a serious writer than for a serious actor, who does his work in public and is accustomed to being the subject, rather than the agent, of observation. An actor can mug his way through a fairly long string of parties and fashion shows before he is accused of overexposure and ridiculed; a writer hits that threshold sooner. "Then his subsequent work isn't looked at directly, but through the glare of all that publicity," says the editor Gary Fisketjon, whose stable of writers at Knopf includes Jay McInerney. The more a writer indulges the news media, Fisketjon observes, the more vulnerable he is to deflation. "It raises the stakes on everything he does in the future."
Wallace has a virtually innate awareness of this danger. "When I won't do things like appear on network television, it's not because I have a lot of integrity," he says. "Part of it is that I feel I'm going to turn off exactly the people whose approval I'm most hungry for." While he is not greedy about money, he explains, "I'm real greedy about respect."
In one sense, the success of Wallace and "Infinite Jest" are a complete surprise. No one knows who and what will hit the jackpot at a given moment, and publishers constantly squander large cash advances and aggressive publicity campaigns on books that land quickly in the remainder bin. "It really depends on so many things that are impossible for you to align by yourself," says Bret Easton Ellis, who has had more than a decade, and plenty of disappointments, since the publication of "Less Than Zero" to reflect on the process. "It's the mood of the public, the times -- all these intangibles."
But in another sense, what is happening to Wallace was predictable and painstakingly engineered. When Michael Pietsch, the book's editor, convinced his colleagues at Little, Brown and Company to fork over a figure estimated at $90,000 to buy "Infinite Jest" as a work in progress, he argued that Wallace had developed a significant cult following with his first two books, "The Broom of the System" and "Girl With Curious Hair," and was due for a breakthrough.
Pietsch also apprehended several other realities that have influenced Wallace's success. Many years had passed since the so-called Brat Pack of the mid- to late 1980's -- McInerney, Ellis and Tama Janowitz -- turned putatively serious literature into a fashion statement, and it was long past time for a new Wunderkind to do something similar. More to the point, the members of so-called Generation X had yet to claim definitively a maverick, idiosyncratic literary voice all their own. Wallace's work spoke both to this generation's shtick and to its soul.
"Infinite Jest" is sardonic, jaded and steeped in references to all strata of popular culture, from high to low. It exhibits both a savvy grasp of the cyberfrontiers on the horizon and a deep, abiding distrust of them. It is mildly subversive, occasionally ribald and sporadically crude. Think David Letterman with a postgraduate degree and diction, and you get at least some idea of the sensibility. "This has become a very hip book to read," says Alice K. Turner, the fiction editor at Playboy, who encouraged Wallace early in his career. "We've had a lot of skimpy fare for a long time."
Indeed, executives at Little, Brown quickly realized that the sheer length of "Infinite Jest" could work in their favor, and although Wallace was asked to cut about 300 pages from his initial draft, he was still allowed to exceed 1,000 pages, which meant that the book would be priced at $30. "We decided to play it as importance -- that the size lent a certain weight to the book, that there was a certain undeniability about it," says Amy Rhodes, head of marketing for the company. Her strategy revolved around a kind of dare: are you reader enough for this book?
To create that elusive, ephemeral entity known as buzz, the company compiled a list of 4,000 booksellers, industry insiders and media types and sent out a staggered series of six postcards that cryptically heralded the release of an at-first-unspecified book that gives "infinite pleasure" with "infinite style." And when blurbs to that effect became available from other authors and critics, Little, Brown put them on postcards and dispatched another series of three. Says Paul Slovak, senior vice president of publicity for Viking Penguin, "The promotional campaign has been brilliant."
And Wallace -- wittingly or unwittingly -- has served it well, projecting the perfect measure of aloofness, particularly in his appearance, which flouts conventional vanity in a manner that doth protest perhaps a bit too much. He often wears a bandanna wrapped tightly around his head, as if to avoid combing his shoulder-length hair and to coddle his febrile mind. His wire-rimmed glasses, stubble of beard and hole-ridden sweaters lend him the aspect of a doctoral candidate so deep in thought that he cannot afford the time or energy for grooming. Yet he runs regularly to stay fit, and his bathroom contains special tooth polish to combat the effects of the tobacco he chews. There's also a special acne medication to keep his skin unblemished.
He hates that his publicity tour involves so many photography sessions. "Whenever the picture comes out, it's absolutely appalling to me," he says. "I just so wish that wasn't what I looked like. I've just figured it out: I'm not going to look at them anymore."
"DO YOU GUYS KNOW 'THE CHARLIE ROSE Show'?" Wallace asks two of his faculty friends at Illinois State, a married couple many years older than he, when he visits their house to say goodbye before his three-week tour. "Would you think it was whorish if somebody went on it?"
"No, no," says Charles Harris, a professor of English. "It's on late at night, and it goes into things at length. Are you going on it?"
"I did have a no-TV pledge," Wallace sighs.
"Until they asked?" jokes Harris's wife, Victoria.
After considerable introspection, Wallace nixes "Charlie Rose," just as he turned down the "Today" show before it. In the interviews he does grant, Wallace draws sharp boundaries about what he will discuss and begs assurances about how it will be presented. "If you quote that," he will qualify something he has just said, "I'd really like you to quote that I acknowledge it sounds banal and cliched."
Friends say there are powerful currents of ambition and competitiveness in Wallace that can be traced back to his childhood in Urbana, Ill., and his career as a junior tennis player of some local prominence. Wallace's father, a philosophy professor at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign, and his mother, an English teacher at a community college, ferried him to tournaments throughout the Middle West.
At Amherst College in Massachusetts, however, it was the life of the mind that he pursued, and with a similar vengeance. His major was philosophy. He recalls that during his sophomore year a professor told him he was a genius: "It was the happiest moment in my life. I felt like I would never have to go to the bathroom again -- that I'd transcended it."
Mark Costello, a classmate, says Wallace was pegged by professors there as someone who could become an important philosopher. So when Wallace turned his intellectual energies toward fiction writing, it was a decision fraught with ambivalence and fear. "He was a guy under tremendous internal pressure," Costello says. "I think it was important to him to get a little external confirmation that he hadn't made an absurd choice."
His senior thesis at Amherst became the first rough chunk of "The Broom of the System," his 467-page Pynchonesque debut novel; shortly after he graduated and went on to what he derisively calls a "master of flatulent arts" program in creative writing at the University of Arizona, he had a contract with Viking Penguin, which published "Broom" in 1987. That same year he won a prestigious $25,000 Whiting Writers' Award. Two years later Norton published "Girl With Curious Hair," a collection of short fiction.
But Wallace was tormented and miserable. Was he really brilliant, as some people told him? Or was he a fake, as he sometimes felt? By this point he was drinking heavily, taking drugs and sleeping around, self-destructive behavior that he figured was consistent with the life style that a cool, serious writer was supposed to have. Wallace is intentionally vague on this period of his life, and what he divulges sometimes contradicts the recollections of friends. He says he never formally entered a recovery program; Alice Turner says he did. He mentions a single suicide scare and subsequent stay in a psychiatric ward; friends allude to more than one.
There is agreement, however, that he halted his downward spiral around 1990 and began to cultivate a saner, stabler existence. He eventually took a job as an associate professor at Illinois State in Normal and bought a middle-class house on a road that winds past fields of feed corn and a slaughterhouse. He adopted Jeeves and another black Lab mix, the Drone.
For a while, a woman lived there, too, but she is gone now, her departure marked by the absence of any furniture in the living room. "I hate that room," Wallace says. "I always walk fast through that room to get to other rooms." His relationships, he confesses, have been many and short-lived. Before moving back to Illinois, he became involved for a time with the writer Mary Karr, author of "The Liar's Club," and had her name tattooed on his upper arm. He blames himself for the brevity of his attachments. "I'm massively selfish about my work, and I don't seem to be able to be very polite or considerate about other people's feelings," he says.
His friendships appear to be more durable, and he finds them in unexpected places. Back in Illinois, he began to attend Sunday services at various churches around town -- there is something about religious faith, which was missing from his rearing by two atheists, that entices and calms him -- and he formed his closest social relationship with an older, married couple, Doug and Erin Poag. They met at a Mennonite house of worship.
The Friday night before the Sunday start of his book tour finds Wallace watching "The X-Files" with the Poags in their living room. They are eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and Italian heroes on trays.
The Poags mention that another of Wallace's favorite shows is "Baywatch," and his face reddens. "There are very complicated esthetic reasons why I watch it," he protests. "It's why I used to watch 'The Love Boat' -- it was soothing, like a narcotic. You knew all problems would be resolved in 15 minutes and many lush platitudes would be exchanged."
WALLACE ACTUALLY BRINGS ERIN POAG ALONG to his readings in New York. The trip was a Christmas present to her from both Wallace and her family, but it clearly serves Wallace as well, reminding him of his other life outside the limelight.
It will be difficult to balance the two existences. Although Wallace had initially decided not to read reviews of "Infinite Jest," telling his agent to save them for some later date, he made a special trip to the campus library to find one of the first ones. He even donned sunglasses, "because I'm an idiot who imagines that people have nothing better to do than sit around and watch me read my reviews."
Five days into his tour Wallace says that what he finds scariest about the whirlwind is his ability to tune out the aspects that make him uncomfortable and to let himself be borne along on its velvety currents. By the time he reached his 12th photo shoot, he says, he had learned to travel far away from the moment in his mind: "I have actually gotten to revisit, in my head, all the museums I've ever gone to."
Very soon, he says, he will go home and get back to work. He will even change his telephone number. But there's a subtle note of worry in his voice. At some level, he knows how hard it will be to stop the ringing, and how hard it will be to resist it.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 24, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
A Tawdry TV Pageant

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
IS THERE AN adolescent in America who did not know, weeks before its premiere, that "N.Y.P.D. Blue" -- yes, blue -- set out to stretch the boundaries of permissible sex on broadcast television? Is there any parent who doesn't know that "E.R." depicts anguished hospital scenes and gory medical procedures that might frighten a child? Does anyone need a ratings chart to discern the porno promise of a typical hour with Sally Jessy Raphael entitled "Mom, I'm a Teen Prostitute"?
Why, then, does President Clinton put any stock in a new law requiring a V-chip in television sets to enable parents to lock out undesirable programs? And why did the media moguls acquiesce so quickly in a scheme they had vowed to fight all the way to the Supreme Court? Suddenly and dutifully, they accepted President Clinton's election-year summons to the White House and promised, by next year, to invent a ratings system to measure and proclaim the intensity of sex and violence in their programs. "They're handing the TV remote control back to America's parents," Clinton exulted. 
 Don't believe it. The television industry has not lacked for means to reveal the content of its programs or to cancel the trashy ones. It has been no more reluctant to advertise violence and smut than to produce them. Contrary to the headlines, the President and the broadcasters are colluding to give only an appearance of doing something for "family values."
In the process, they have dealt a serious blow to the cause of improving the quality of children's television. And, not so incidentally, they have virtually wrecked all hopes of compelling, or even persuading, the networks to give political candidates free air time in the last weeks of an election campaign.
DOING SOMETHING FOR TV-hooked kids and TVdependent candidates is the last remaining item on the agenda of those who think broadcasters owe society a good amount of "public service." A leader of that effort is Reed Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who thinks that a few hours of desirable programming is the least that Government should ask in return for the industry's free use of the airwaves. He believes that broadcasters, like other spectrum users, should pay for their channels both in cash and time. The President, the Congress and the industry, however, seem eager to settle for mere gestures. This pageant of media pretense has played out with remarkable speed. In December, Congress finished writing the most comprehensive telecommunications law in half a century to stimulate phone and cable competition. It mandates the V-chip and tries to outlaw pornography on the Internet, but otherwise provides for the gradual elimination of virtually all Government supervision of prices, services, profits and operations. The bill was held up in the Senate, however, when Bob Dole, the majority leader, protested its continuing "give-away" of spectrum space to broadcasters. He relented on Feb. 1 only on the promise that the spectrum issue would be revisited later this year.
State of play: The most likely Republican candidate for President threatens to tax industry profits with spectrum fees.
Hundt, meanwhile, held F.C.C. hearings to emphasize the public's stake not only in the spectrum but also in the five or six additional channels each television station would acquire in the coming era of digital transmissions. The value of that additional spectrum space was said to be at least $40 billion, maybe double that. So besides urging auction or rental of that space, many witnesses suggested trading it for public-service programming.
State of play: Industry senses an urgent need to outflank the forces gathering around the liberal Hundt and the conservative Dole.
Enter Bill Clinton, discoursing on the State of the Union's "values": "I challenge the broadcast industry" to rate its programs -- with something resembling the movies' G, PG-13, R and NC-17 -- "and I invite the leaders of major media" to discuss "concrete ways to improve what our children see on television."
State of play: President begs the industry to help him seize the "family values" issue from the Republicans and implies he could help seize the spectrum issue from Hundt and Dole.
The entertainment industry is seized with a change of heart and promises a ratings system by next January. Its moguls bask in the President's praise. They promise nothing about better children's programs and he, revealingly, says nothing about the public's stake in the spectrum.
State of play: Clinton, having once signed the spectrum's "give-away" without complaint, stands ready to be the only Presidential nominee who would sign again.
The White House meeting isolated Dole just when his campaign needed broadcasters' good will the most. It also blunted Hundt's pitch to have broadcasters pay for some of their spectrum space with three hours a week of educational children's programs and free air time for candidates. It cheerfully ignored the public's hypocrisy in complaining about the depravity of programs that it rushes to watch and about negative political ads to which it obviously responds.
So instead of using its muscle to promote instructive new programs, the Government is settling for ratings and labels that no one seriously expects will change anything. Years will pass before the V-chip is in many homes. And, whatever the ratings system, what will be a warning to one viewer will be a come-hither for another.
AH, BUT DIDN'T RUPERT Murdoch come to that White House meeting promising Clinton and his opponent an hour of free time on Fox stations? Didn't he ask the other networks to help liberate candidates from the high cost of TV commercials -- that "cancer in our political system"? Yes, indeed. Murdoch was said by his aides to prefer giving air time valued at $2 million to making the cash contributions politicians keep asking for.
Murdoch also prefers thus to ward off complaints that Fox makes no sustained effort to cover political, economic or foreign news. Since CBS, ABC and NBC look upon their news divisions as a costly and significant public service, they had good reason to dismiss Murdoch's challenge as "grandstanding." But now the good idea of replacing the clash of costly and violent political ads with a calm presentation of the candidates and their views has also been tainted, defined on excellent authority as just another cynical ploy.
Outcome of the play: Broadcasting is freed from most regulation. More valuable spectrum is given, or "lent," to all stations free of charge. The public's concern is assuaged with a few pious program ratings, and television as we know it, tawdry television, is made safe from even reasonable obligations.

HEADLINE: Visions and Revisions

BYLINE: By Michael Kazin; Michael Kazin's most recent book is "The Populist Persuasion: An American History." He is currently teaching history at the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands.

 BODY:

William Appleman Williams
The Tragedy of Empire.
By Paul M. Buhle and Edward Rice-Maximin.
318 pp. New York:
Routledge. Cloth, $65. Paper, $16.95.
A SURPRISING paradox lurks within the history of the American left. A sizable number of radicals have been motivated, at least in part, by rather traditional beliefs. The revolutionary socialist Eugene V. Debs was a devout Christian, while the militant labor organizer Mother Jones dismissed woman suffrage as a cause for "parlor parasites." The Roman Catholic anarchist Dorothy Day glanced fondly back at the pious peasant villages of the Middle Ages. Many leftists, hostile to what modern corporations and efficiency-minded thinkers call progress, have dreamed of egalitarian communities organized around an old-fashioned ethic of cooperation. 
 Another who combined radicalism with a sense of tradition was William Appleman Williams. Among budding New Leftists in the 1960's, no historian was more influential than he was. In two passionately written volumes published while he was a professor at the University of Wisconsin, Madison ("The Tragedy of American Diplomacy" and "Contours of American History"), Williams argued that the United States had, from its birth, been a nation addicted to imperial expansion. From the conquest of Indian lands to the botched intervention in Indochina, he identified a ferocious impulse to spread individualist ideas and unceasing economic growth.
This sweeping, critical interpretation broke sharply with the upbeat view of the nation's past that held sway in most universities at the end of the 50's. Revisionism, Williams-style, gave young radicals the confidence to denounce the argument, made by many liberals at the time, that the bloody debacle in Vietnam was a minor "mistake" in an otherwise laudable diplomatic record. No real change could occur at home, New Leftists warned, until the roots of empire -- economic and ideological -- had been uncovered and destroyed. Of course, Williams's perspective enraged many liberal cold war historians; some, like Arthur Schlesinger Jr., accused him of misreading key documents and promoting a new isolationism that made the Soviet Union seem innocent of any international wrong.
Yet "William Appleman Williams: The Tragedy of Empire," a fluid and insightful biography by two independent scholars, makes it clear that the intellectual godfather of revisionist history was always animated by a profoundly conservative vision. Born in 1921, Williams grew up in the small but prosperous locale of Atlantic, Iowa -- where extremes of wealth and poverty were as rare as loyal Democrats. When he went off to military school on a sports scholarship and then on to the Naval Academy, he left his old hometown for good. But throughout his life, Williams believed that the only alternative to restless imperial striving was to decentralize political power and distribute it to contented, homogeneous communities. In tune with utopian and environmentalist thinkers, he viewed marketplace thinking as the "great heresy of human history," and he endorsed the virtues of the small and bounded life. At the height of his renown in the late 60's, he left the academic limelight of Madison for a rural town in Oregon and a post at an undistinguished college.
Williams did not view all past American leaders as equally culpable in the rush to empire. Among his prime villains were some of the nation's most revered icons -- Jefferson, Lincoln, Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt. He accused these men of having waged territorial and commercial expansion with a missionary zeal, of attempting to save people who had no inclination to save themselves. Although his grasp of narrative and quotation was impressive, Williams did betray, as Paul M. Buhle and Edward Rice-Maximin note, "an almost obsessive determination to overturn the accepted hagiography of American heroes, including many of the traditional favorites of liberals and radicals."
Williams's alternative pantheon included such unlikely figures as John Quincy Adams and Herbert Hoover. Hoover, he wrote, was "the last great conservative to honor the bedrock principle of self-determination," as well as a shrewd critic of Roosevelt's international maneuvers in the years preceding World War II. These qualities mattered far more to Williams than did Hoover's admiration of big business and hatred of the New Deal.
Such iconoclasm -- what his biographers call "horse sense and moral pleading" -- appealed to New Left intellectuals, even if they didn't agree with every twist of Williams's logic or his quirky choice of a usable past. His central idea that American diplomacy was a tragedy of hubristic designs made the past seem a continuous drama of clashing world views that required probing interpretation by activist scholars. Devoted former students like Walter LaFeber, Thomas McCormick and Lloyd Gardner rewrote the history of United States foreign policy -- extending, refining and qualifying the ideas of their mentor but never departing from his basic critique.
Even though Mr. Buhle and Mr. Rice-Maximin appropriately focus on Williams's writings and politics, they do not scant his personal life, much of which was painful. When he was 8, his father, a military pilot, was killed in a plane crash. Two of his three marriages ended badly, with unhappy children predictably struggling in the wake. And after leaving the University of Wisconsin, he began to drink heavily. Williams had made his intellectual mark by 1961, when he was only 40, and he produced little that was original from then until his death in 1990. His biographers, themselves former students of his at Wisconsin, describe these travails in melancholy, affectionate, always sensitive terms. Warm supporters of Williams's general perspective, they clearly wish he had grown more, both as a thinker and as a man.
With his one big idea about America's imperial affliction, Williams occupied a small but distinguished intellectual precinct. Like his fellow historians Christopher Lasch and Eugene Genovese, he flailed liberal individualism with eloquence and wit and had a nostalgic affinity for communitarian values and modest achievement. In 1957, he wrote that the United States was "neither the last best hope of the world nor the agent of civilization destined to destroy the barbarians," adding, "We have much to offer, but also much to learn." Perhaps that was his best legacy -- as preacher of humility to Americans possessed of more power than wisdom.
