HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Lindenhurst, L.I.;
An Involved Village on Great South Bay

BYLINE: By VIVIEN KELLERMAN 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of the Village of Lindenhurst, a South Shore Long Island community 70 minutes from Manhattan, believe in fighting to preserve their neighborhoods.
When burglaries and vandalism aroused one neighborhood residents organized a volunteer night-time crime patrol. When a chain-link fence owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority began to fall apart, another group of residents banded together to get the fence, and its blighting effect, removed. 
 Other groups work to clean the streets, to plant trees and to get laws on the books to go after people who would destroy the community.
"The civics really challenge people who don't maintain a decent environment," said Gary Biggs, of the Southwest Civic Association. "Our problem is we may expect too much. Many of us know what Lindenhurst was in the 60's and 70's, and we want it to be that way again."
With its well-tended neighborhoods (some with houses on the water), its own marina, village parks, access to major roads, an active community center, and good shopping Lindenhurst considers itself a good bet for first-time home buyers.
Jo Ann Boettcher, an agent with Prudential Long Island Realty in Lindenhurst, said that single-family homes in the village range in price from $85,000 to $285,000, with a median of $128,000.
Neighborhoods are made up of developments of Cape Cods, split-levels, high-ranches and colonials mostly built after World War II. But some on Great South Bay were originally summer cottages that date back to the 20's.
A typical listing would be a 35-year old three-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath ranch with a finished basement and one-car attached garage. The house, on an 80- by 202-foot lot, is being offered for $148,990. Taxes are $5,548.
There are no condominiums or co-ops in the village, but legal rental apartments in single-family homes are available. One-bedroom units go for about $650 a month, two-bedrooms for about $750.
Ms. Boettcher said that many of the people she sells to have grown up in Lindenhurst. Among them are Jane and Tom Hennessey, who have lived in the village nearly all their lives. Mr. Hennessey is a corrections officer who commutes to Riverhead about an hour east of Lindenhurst. Mrs. Hennessey is an emergency medical technician in Queens, about an hour west.
When the couple, who have four children ranging in age from 3 to 20, decided they wanted a larger home, they thought about moving out of Lindenhurst, primarily, said Mr. Hennessey, because he wanted more land. In the end, they decided to stay in the village.
Last April, the couple moved into a 30-year old, 5-bedroom, 2-bath colonial with an oversized two-car garage. The house, for which they paid $147,000, sits on a 75- by 100-foot lot.
"The commute is fair for both of us," said Mr. Hennessey. "But we also have a lot of family and friends here. Many have also lived here all their lives. That's a lot of history. When it came right down to it, we couldn't leave."
ALL of the Hennessey children have gone through or are in public schools in Lindenhurst, which has seven kindergarten-to-fifth-grade elementary schools, one 6th-to-8th-grade middle school and one high school, with a total enrollment of 6,659.
Margaret McKenna, the acting superintendent, said that 78 percent of last June's high school graduates went on to higher education.
Last year, to encourage even more students to go to college, the district took part in a program with Dowling College in Oakdale, enabling high school seniors to earn as much as a first year's worth of credits in special classes.
Students pay $50 a credit for classes in the high school taught by teachers that have been certified by the college. The program differs from advanced-placement courses in that the student actually works with the Dowling curriculum and uses the same books.
This year, said Ms. McKenna, 18 students are enrolled in the program, all taking a full year of college credits. She added that all credits earned by the 17 enrolled last year had been accepted at the colleges of their choice.
Ms. McKenna said that the district had an all-day kindergarten program and an alternative high school designed to prevent students from dropping out. Sixty-five high-risk students are enrolled in the program, in which class sizes are smaller than normal and job training and placement in jobs in the community are offered.
Ms. McKenna said that the high school also had a graffiti-removal program. And despite the fact that the district is on an austerity budget, she said, it has managed to update its entire heating system in an attempt to improve air quality, which became an issue three years ago when spores and mold showed up in two of the elementary schools.
"Maintenence is an issue we've worked very hard on," said Ms. McKenna.
The district also has a gifted-and-talented program for grades 3 to 6; 175 pupils meet one day a week in one of the elementary schools.
Seven hundred prekindergarten-to-8th-grade students are enrolled in the school of the Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic parish, which is celebrating 125 years in Lindenhurst. The original buildings have been demolished, but part of the school dates back 1941.
Most shopping in Lindenhurst is along Wellwood Avenue, which has about 60 stores. John McDermott, the president of the Chamber of Commerce, said that about 10 percent of the stores were vacant.
In 1994, Waldbaum's built a new 60,000 square foot store in an area off Wellwood Avenue. The supermarket houses several smaller businesses including a bank, dry cleaner's and a photo shop.
Along Montauk Highway, another business area, there are mostly marine-related business, reflecting the fact that Lindenhurst is on the water.
Mr. McDermott said the chamber, which had been inactive for some time, regrouped in 1990 in response to problems with minor vandalism. It now has 55 members who are working together and with the police to protect the shopping area.
ABOUT seven minutes either east or west of Lindenhurst are two shopping malls. Sunrise Mall, with 150 stores including Sears, J.C. Penney, Stern's and Macy's, and the 830,000-square-foot South Shore Mall, which has a Macy's and a J.C. Penney.
There are several parks in Lindenhurst, including the nine-acre Village Park, which has a pond, ballfields, three tennis courts, and a playground. Shore Road Park has 12 acres, with ballfields for soccer, football and baseball. Lincoln Park comprises five acres of undeveloped wetland. There is also a public dock for fishing.
Shawn Cullinane, the administrator of the village, said that there was a 47-slip municipal marina at the dock with fees ranging from $450 to $650 a season. An additional 200 village slips, for smaller boats, are available at a nearby canal for $250 to $450. When a slip becomes vacant, (no more than a couple a year, Mr. Cullinane said) the next occupant is chosen by lot from the waiting list.
The Lindenhurst Community Center serves the elderly alone from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. five days a week and offers them free door-to-door transportation. In the evening, the center is used by civic groups.
The village also runs an annual Oktoberfest, which is held the first Sunday in October. The one-day event, featuring a beer garden and including vendors, rides and food, attracts about 10,000 people, Mr. Cullinane said.
The Old Village Hall Museum, which houses local artifacts, is run by the Lindenhurst Historical Society. It is open Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays 2 to 4 P.M. from June 1 to Sept. 30 and Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 2 to 4 P.M. Oct. 1 to May 31. Admission is free. Built in 1914, the building, originally a residence, served as a dry goods store and then as the village hall until 1953.
The 1901 Restored Depot and Freight House at the Irmisch Historical Park is open Monday through Friday from 2 to 4 P.M. in July and August. On exhibit, among other things, are a history of the restoration, old trunks, crates and uniforms. Admission is free.
THE area that became Lindenhurst was purchased by English settlers from the Secatogue Indians in 1657. For more than 200 years they and their descendants farmed the land. But in 1867 the South Side Rail Road, an antecedent of the Long Island Rail Road, laid a single track from New York City to Babylon and opened the area to development.
Thomas Welwood and his wife, Abby, of Brooklyn, began purchasing land in 1861 and by 1870 had bought so much that the railroad's timetable listed a Welwood Station.
Welwood joined with Charles D. Schleier, a Brooklyn German newspaper editor, to build a place where German immigrants could live and work. They formed a company to develop the "City of Breslau," which was dedicated on June 6, 1870. It had a population of about 200
In 1889, hard times, unemployment and clouded land titles tainted the community's name and led to a movement to change it to Lindenhurst, a nod to linden trees planted by the German immigrants.
The first attempt was voted down, but two years later the name was changed. In 1923, Lindenhurst was incorporated. Development began in earnest after World War II and today, Mr. Cullinane said, its 27,000 population makes it the fourth largest incorporated village in New York State.

CRIME PATROLS: Last summer, when burglaries and vandalism began to afflict her neighborhood, Betty Dean, a 30-year Lindenhurst resident, decided to do something about it. So she organized the Triangle Civic Association for the 500-home Triangle neighborhood. In October block captains were designated and volunteer weekend car patrols began at the end of the month from 8 P.M. to 2 A.M. The first night, a patrol car spotted some youths stealing porch furniture and ran them off. The volunteers, who keep in touch by newsletter, radio the police in case of real trouble, said Ms. Dean.

LENGTH: 2526 words

HEADLINE: The Three Tenors Juggernaut

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
THE IDEA WAS BIG, and fittingly it came from the big man himself, Luciano Pavarotti. It came to him at a big event, the 1994 sellout "Three Tenors" concert at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, an extravaganza beamed to 1.3 billion television viewers worldwide, four years after the trio's smash debut in the ruins of ancient Rome, which generated the largest-selling classical recording of all time.
Backstage at the stadium, behind the mock rain forest, with its four-story waterfalls and pseudo-classical pillars, Mr. Pavarotti turned to his partners, Jose Carreras and Placido Domingo, and said (as he later rendered it in his fluid if slightly stilted English): "Why not doing this around the world?" 
 And so it has come to pass. In June, the tenors will embark on a ballyhooed four-continent circuit of some of the world's largest outdoor arenas -- "Three Tenors III," in effect. Already it is growing to colossal proportions in a triumph of marketing and song. The original five stops -- including one American appearance, at Giants Stadium on July 20 -- have ballooned to at least nine, counting newly booked concerts in Goteborg, Sweden, and Dusseldorf, Germany, and a New Year's Eve gala yet to be announced. There are also plans for a concert at the World Cup soccer championship in Paris in 1998.
Although the onslaught is still almost three months off, the heart of the event, the marketing, is already churning at full tilt. Crews around the world have been working for months readying and tuning instruments of commerce and technology that render the musical instruments almost incidental. The "Three Tenors" phenomenon has become an indomitable force.
But music aside, as skeptics say it is, could these bookings overexpose an act that has already been beamed to half the world's population -- and recently became a running gag on "Seinfeld"? It is a risk the tenors are willing to take.
"If it's too much, we don't do any more," said Mr. Pavarotti in a recent conversation from Barbados, where he was vacationing. "But for the moment, it's better we do while we are still here."
The repertory should hold few surprises, he said: "More or less the same as last time." So get ready again for the likes of "Granada," "La donna e mobile," "Vesti la giubba," a medley of "My Way," "Moon River" and "Singin' in the Rain," and Mr. Pavarotti's signature crowd-pleaser, "Nessun dorma" from "Turandot."
If it's not high operatic art, it's aimed unashamedly at a vast, adoring and financially supportive audience. From the moment the three kick off their tour in Tokyo on June 29, records -- the Guinness kind -- are likely to go flying.
The tour is costing the promoter, Matthias Hoffmann of Mannheim, Germany, about $100 million (including an insurance bill of $1.5 million to cover refunds in case of cancellation). If all 500,000 seats are sold at an average price of $240 each, ticket revenues would reach $120 million, not counting merchandizing tie-ins, pay-per-view and other television rights.
For their appearances, Maestros Carreras, Domingo and Pavarotti stand to make close to $10 million each: about $500,000 per concert in fees and a like amount in licensing income. James Levine, who is replacing Zubin Mehta as conductor, will get a flat $500,000 per concert.
"Good money, eh?" Mr. Pavarotti said. "By God, it's good money!"
Whew! Was classical music ever like this? No and yes.
 
Hoopla Old and New
Barnum and Beyond: A Tale of Hoffmann
The numbers are certainly groundbreaking. In their first two concerts, the tenors reached a combined television audience of about two billion people. Audio and video recordings have sold 23 million copies, to become far and away the best-selling classical recordings of all time (more or less matching what Michael Jackson achieved with a single album, "Dangerous," in 1991).
Clearly, even for tenors -- who have historically won adulation for their acrobatics on the high C's -- the three have achieved an enviable crossover: opera singers adored like rock stars, classical icons clasped to the collective bosom of millions of fans who have never stepped inside an opera house. But although modern technology has spectacularly magnified the effect, the phenomenon itself is hardly unique.
"I wonder if P. T. Barnum would have anything to learn from today's marketing," said Morris Dickstein, a cultural historian at the Graduate School of the City University of New York. Barnum, the shameless showman, repackaged the soprano Jenny Lind as a popular attraction and booked her around the tent circuit that served as the mass entertainment of the 19th century.
"Classical music has always brought us a few superstars, usually in opera," said Mr. Dickstein. Certainly, the tenor Enrico Caruso, who lived from 1873 to 1921, was a cult figure who inspired widespread fan hysteria in his prime. "I'm sure that when he made his first recordings for RCA Victor," Mr. Dickstein said, "people thought he was betraying opera."
Even the three tenors' propensity to mix arias with pop repertory has venerable precedents, Mr. Dickstein added. The early operatic tradition was much more open to opera lite, including operetta and Neapolitan songs. Wagner, he explained, helped steer opera toward serious, unified productions. Verdi, on the other hand, might have fancied "The Three Tenors."
"Americans have a long history of adoration of the virtuoso," said the cultural historian Ann Douglas, author of "Terrible Honesty: Mongrel Manhattan in the 1920's." At times, she said, the fixations have verged on the campy, as when Caruso was lured to the vaudeville stage to appear with Al Jolson.
"It's as if we say, 'The great artists are ours; we can rough them up, have fun with them,' " she said. At times, she added, the three tenors "seem on the edge of satirizing themselves."
Tibor Rudas, Mr. Pavarotti's Hungarian-born promoter, disdains the carping of music and social critics. "We didn't realize in Rome that we created the Beatles for the senior citizens," he said. "It's something the people have been waiting for for a long time. Only nobody knew they were waiting for it."
Michael Sampliner, the New York director of Hoffmann Concerts, agrees: "You could say the three tenors have created their own form of alternative music."
Mr. Hoffmann does not begrudge the tenors their hefty fees. "If Janet Jackson can sign a deal for $80 million," he said, "the three tenors are totally, totally underpaid."
Whatever the ultimate musical judgments, the marketing blitz seems clearly aimed at fomenting a global tenor mania.
Behind the latest hoopla is a modern-day tale of Hoffmann -- Matthias Hoffmann, that is, promoter of Mr. Carreras and Mr. Domingo. By persistence or default, Mr. Hoffmann assumed the presenter's role from Mr. Rudas, a Las Vegas-trained impresario who put on the Los Angeles concert during the last World Cup festivities.
Mr. Hoffmann, a 45-year-old entrepreneur who dropped out of Mannheim University in 1970 to present a rock festival that became known as the German Woodstock, said that Mr. Pavarotti worried initially that no promoter would be crazy enough to take on an international tour of such proportions. Whereupon Mr. Carreras and Mr. Domingo responded more or less in unison, "Oh, we have one, and he's crazy and waits for nothing more than to do a 'Three Tenors' concert." Mr. Pavarotti said he was at first dubious about putting the tour in the hands of any promoter other than his own, but he realized that his colleagues' promoter deserved a chance.
Mr. Hoffmann said that he had offered to make Mr. Rudas a joint presenter of the tour -- sharing both risk and potential profits -- but that Mr. Rudas declined. Instead, Mr. Rudas sold Mr. Hoffmann his Los Angeles production to insure the quality of amplified sound and lighting at the concerts for around $500,000. "I would have been prepared to present it; yes, I would have, but I'm a very fair man," Mr. Rudas said from his office in Pacific Grove, Calif. "It was quite a fair request."
 
The 1990 Concert
A Rotten Deal Is Still a Deal
Feelings are still sensitive from the experience of the first "Three Tenors" concert in Rome. That event, timed to the 1990 World Cup finals and staged in the Baths of Caracalla before 8,000 spectators, was presented by an Italian concert manager, Mario Dradi of Bologna. The tenors, who had already turned away some 50 offers to sing together, agreed this time, they explained, as a way of celebrating the soccer championship and hailing Mr. Carreras's comeback after a near-fatal bout with leukemia. Indeed, all three donated their portions of ticket revenues to charity.
Mr. Dradi, who declined to be interviewed, sold recording rights to Decca/ London for a large fixed fee, which provided for no royalties to the artists. "We wanted to pay a royalty and share the risks," Roland Kommerell, Decca's president, said recently from his office in London. But Mr. Dradi rejected the offer in favor of a one-time payment that Mr. Kommerell described as "a horrendous mountain of risk" for the label. When, to almost everyone's amazement, the concert and the record emerged as a sensation, Decca reaped the profits.
"We got nothing," said Mr. Pavarotti, who has an exclusive recording contract with Decca. A deal was a deal, he maintained, and he had no complaints. But Mr. Domingo was furious and has ostracized Decca ever since. "Placido suspects us of paying Pavarotti a royalty," Mr. Kommerell said. He denied it and shrugged off the fracas. "We pushed the frontiers quite far," he said. "Now it's like the real-estate business."
 
The 1994 Concert
'Tibor Rudas Is an Old Fox'
The tenors were not about to make the same mistake four years later. This time, Mr. Rudas was the presenter. Born in Budapest in 1926, he studied voice and toured Europe singing in variety shows before establishing a dance studio in Australia. He took his "French style revues" to Las Vegas in 1963 and expanded into casino entertainment, including classical performances, in Atlantic City. In 1982, Mr. Rudas hooked up with Mr. Pavarotti, presenting him first in a tent in Atlantic City, then in recitals and arenas around the world.
Shrewdly, Mr. Rudas made the concerts attractive to television. "These TV shows brought him more and more to the crowd and away from the opera," Mr. Rudas recalled. "I just proved that he has another audience." Actually, Mr. Pavarotti had already been introduced to movie audiences in 1982 as a lovable Lothario in the film "Yes, Giorgio."
When the World Cup matches came to the United States for the first time in 1994, Mr. Rudas contracted with soccer authorities to provide the closing entertainment. With the arena locked up and Mr. Pavarotti in his stable, he was in position for his coup: the return of "The Three Tenors."
Mr. Rudas was still shy two tenors, but their promoter, Mr. Hoffmann, recognized that he had been outmaneuvered and could do little but allow his counterpart to put up the money and collect the profits. "Tibor Rudas is an old fox," he said admiringly.
Mr. Hoffmann's beginnings as a concert promoter did not go back as far as Mr. Rudas's, and his rise was more precipitous. Born in 1951 to two music teachers, he left the economics program at Mannheim University at 19 to organize what became the British Rock Meetings in Speyer, open-air concerts that drew crowds of 100,000 to hear Pink Floyd, Deep Purple and the Doors.
By the 80's, he had founded his own concert bureau in Mannheim. He met Mr. Carreras in the mid-80's and, drawing on his experiences as a rock promoter, booked him as a V.I.P., arranging for limousines, bodyguards and other trappings of celebrity, and taking out full-page ads in newspapers to announce his appearances.
"Half a year later," Mr. Hoffmann said, "Jose Carreras was a famous person in Germany." Word spread to Mr. Domingo, who also became a client. Then Mr. Carreras took ill, battling cancer. But after his striking recovery, he returned to the Hoffmann fold.
"My accomplishments as a promoter and the incredible international success I have the privilege of enjoying with the 'Three Tenors' is sheerly a result of these two men entrusting me with their remarkable talent and allowing me to work on their behalf," Mr. Hoffmann said. He put his company's annual gross at $130 million.
Still, in 1990, he, like Mr. Rudas, was reduced to watching, amazed, as his clients catapulted to new fame as part of a trio in Rome. He was not resentful, he insisted. "I said I will have a huge benefit out of this. It was a changing of the classical concert business. I was happy, happy, happy."
Yet when Los Angeles beckoned four years later, he was too slow off the mark. "Let's face it," he said. "Rudas did his homework. He was the first to go to the football people in Los Angeles and say, 'Give me the rights.' I was not tough enough. But I was sure that when this is done and there should be another 'Three Tenors,' I must be the one."
The tenors, too, had learned their lesson. This time, they were paid about $1 million each plus royalties. The concert was recorded by Warner and telecast to more than 100 countries. Not surprisingly, given its runaway commercial as well as popular success, Mr. Pavarotti quickly rallied his partners for the world tour.
 
1996 and After
Pulling Aces From a Sleeve
Finally, it was Mr. Hoffmann's turn. But he was sobered to learn that Mr. Rudas's 1994 contracts with Warner barred lucrative recording or international telecasting rights until 1998.
The tenors, for their part, were dismayed to learn that Mr. Mehta's bookings left him unavailable to conduct, and they talked of postponing the tour. "Postpone it?" Mr. Hoffmann responded. After he had gotten all three together? Soon they all endorsed Mr. Levine.
Mr. Hoffmann had other aces up his sleeve. Arguing that a "Three Tenors" concert would bring a commercial windfall wherever it might alight, he played off arena against arena, angling for the best terms and winning rent-free stadium space in three European cities.
The Giants Stadium concert, moreover, will be carried to a potential audience of hundreds of thousands on pay-per-view television at $30 per viewing. Domestic telecasts in the other countries visited are also planned. Additional commercial opportunities include sales of programs and souvenirs and payments from sponsors and "media partners."
Working around crowded opera and recital calendars, Mr. Hoffmann and the tenors agreed last fall on a five-city tour with stops this summer in Tokyo, London, New York and Munich and next March in Melbourne. A sixth was wedged in this July in Vienna.
But in recent weeks the schedule has grown more hectic, with the added concerts in Goteborg and Dusseldorf, and another under discussion for Johannesburg. A concert is planned for New Year's Eve in an undisclosed city.
After 1997, Mr. Rudas said, it will be his turn again. "We have already obliged them, so from then on, we would be controlling the rest."
Mr. Hoffmann isn't so sure. "Never change a winning team," he said.

HEADLINE: A Successful Company Is Acquired. Will It Remain on L.I.?

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG 

 BODY:
EMPLOYEES at Fiber Options, Inc., first sensed something amiss last fall when strangers began parading through their Bohemia headquarters. Rumors began circulating in the executive suite and in the factory where fiber optic transmission systems undergo final assembly.
Then, at the company's Christmas party, Robert DeLia Sr., the founder and president, made an announcement. Mr. DeLia had indeed put Fiber Options on the block, and it was being acquired by the Sentrol Lifesafety Corporation of Tualatin, Ore. 
 Immediately, employees began questioning whether their jobs were at risk. "I was a little concerned at first about how things would change," Rodney Cormier, a test manager, said. "I was concerned about being asked to relocate."
At the party and in the months since, Mr. DeLia has tried to calm these fears. According to Mr. DeLia, Sentrol is committed to keeping Fiber Options on Long Island for "a reasonable amount of time."
"I don't know if it's going to be for the next 50 years, the next 20 years, but I know it's at least two to three years," he said. He acknowledged, however, that Sentrol "has made no guarantees about 'forever.' "
The uncertainty over the long-term outlook reverberates far beyond Fiber Options' modest offices and low profile. Albeit a small company, with 70 employees, itrepresents a vital piece of the Island's manufacturing potential. And it is not the only company that has been acquired by a large off-Island giant. The acquisitions raise questions about whether these companies can or will remain on the Island and be competitive in their industries.
These questions, and others, come at a time when several attempts are being made to rebuild the manufacturing segment of the Island's economy. Manufacturing jobs on the Island fell to 114,400 at the end of 1995, from a peak of 170,500 in 1988. While the Island unexpectedly added 18,600 jobs overall last year, the net job loss in manufacturing continued -- at 3,200, slightly less than a year earlier.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the New York State Department of Economic Development, said there was always a concern when an out-of-state corporate acquirer enters the picture. "You never know if it's buying the company for its production facility or if it's buying the technology and will run out with it," he said.
Barry Greenspan, acting regional director of the department's Long Island office, agrees. "It absolutely is a red flag," he said.
Since 1990, at least 14 mid-sized to large high-technology companies on Long Island have been acquired, according to state officials. Of these, eight plants have closed or moved -- to North Carolina, Puerto Rico, Florida, and New Jersey, among other places. Six companies have remained here.
Fiber Options, because of its small size, is not counted in these statistics, although it is one of the fastest growing private companies on the Island.
The Grumman Corporation's acquisition by Northrop, based in Los Angeles, in 1994 eventually reduced the work force of what was once the Island's largest corporate employer from a high of 23,000 in 1987 to 3,700 today.
Other smaller-scale acquisitions also have taken their toll. When Pass & Seymour/Legrand bought Slater Electric, a manufacturer of electrical wiring devices, its 300 employees breathed easy for a while. But in 1994 the $2 billion French company, with North American headquarters in Syracuse, closed the Glen Cove operation and moved to near Greensboro, N.C. Only 25 employees were asked to move south; the remainder got pink slips.
Edward Braxton, vice president of operations, said the company left because "the total operating cost on Long Island is the highest of just about anywhere in the U.S." He noted, for example, that the company now pays 4.5 cents per kilowatt hour for electricity, compared with 11 cents on the Island, and that was after the Long Island Lighting Company granted a rebate. Mr. Braxton said the state made "feeble" attempts to provide incentives to remain on the Island.
Jeffrey Bass, chairman of the Long Island Venture Group, said local companies -- high-technology or not -- would not "in theory" be more prone than out-of-state companies to be acquired and relocate. "But when a company is confronted with maintaining a competitive advantage, then we might have a slight disadvantage because of the cost structure of the Island's economy," he said.
Richard Kalenka, managing partner of the high-technology practice in the Long Island office of Price Waterhouse, said a decision to relocate after an acquisition often depends on the industry, possible integration with other operations, and a company's dependence on the Island's skilled work force and research centers. "Many times what a company is buying is management," he said. "If the management wants to stay put, the company generally stays put.".
Robert DeLia Sr., 48, has spent his professional career on Long Island. He had started two real estate companies and, in 1974, he co-founded Communitronics, a manufacturer of radio communications. He sold his share in Communitronics just before its acquisition by a Vermont company; it subsequently relocated.
In 1988, after working for a competing fiber optics company, Mr. DeLia founded Fiber Options to manufacture and market communications equipment for the transmission of video, audio and data signals over fiber optic cable networks.
From the beginning, Fiber Options grew rapidly, by at least 30 percent annually. In 1992, a Boston company invested an undisclosed amount for a 30 percent stake. Last year, Fiber Options' revenues were $13 million.
The company has built its reputation on customer service. It contracts out about 90 percent of its manufacturing to Long Island companies to try to maintain fixed manufacturing costs and avoid cyclical employment. It does final assembly in-house. Last year, the company set up a subsidiary in Britain.
Mr. DeLia said that the company would have sustained steady growth on its own over the next few years but that he wanted a management team and strategic expertise to protect Fiber Options' position in the industry.
"To grow bigger and faster, it would take a lot more resources than we have," he said, adding: "We did not need money as much as horsepower."
In January 1995, Mr. DeLia hired an investment broker to pursue an acquirer. Among his top criteria was remaining on Long Island. "From day one, point blank, I told anyone I spoke to that we are not moving," he said, citing a personal desire and a commitment to long-time personnel. He said he rejected some higher priced deals for that reason. "I was not going to come out of this with a nice fat wallet and let the people that helped me get here go on the unemployment line," Mr. DeLia said.
Sentrol, a privately-held subsidiary of the $500 million Berwind Industries Inc. of Nashville, Tenn., and a manufacturer of security, alarm, and fire detection systems acquired Fiber Options on Jan. 12. Mr. DeLia said only that the purchase price was in the "millions of dollars."
Kenneth Boyda, Sentrol's chief executive, declined requests for an interview. A spokeswoman, Meg Kenagy, said Fiber Options will continue to operate independently, and there are no plans to move the company off Long Island.
"I don't know what will happen in 10 years," she said. "That's where it is today."
Mr. DeLia said he felt comfortable with Sentrol's acquisition history, noting, "The best I can tell, they've left things alone at other companies." Ms. Kenagy said that not all of its acquired companies have remained in place, but she did not give details.
She confirmed that Sentrol was looking at shifting Fiber Options' outside contracting off Long Island -- about $1 million in annual business -- to its North Carolina operation, while keeping final assembly on the Island.
Mr. DeLia said that the company benefits from good service and minimal shipping costs by outside contractors on the Island. He said that Sentrol's "input to me was it depends on cost. If you can build it on Long Island for less, obviously, why change it?" He added: "They did say that if the time ever came if we wanted to pull it off, they would do it in a way to phase it out."
Fiber Options' growth has not gone unnoticed by development officials in other states. Even before it was ranked on Inc. magazine's list of the 500 fastest-growing private companies last year, Fiber Options received solicitations at least once a month. Mr. DeLia said he had not considered leaving Long Island because "I never wanted to disrupt what we've had here; it's working."
Besides, he said, Fiber Options does not face competitive pressures like high-volume manufacturers. Its final assembly is in custom work, not mass production. It needs a skilled work force. And profit margins are not tight. He said: "If we were in a very, very competitive situation, my guess is it would be too expensive here."
To reassure employees following the acquisition, Sentrol executives were hosts at a champagne reception and made a presentation, including slides of its plant in Hickory, N.C. Sentrol executives have visited corporate headquarters since, looking for ways to help Fiber Options manufacture more cost-effectively and soliciting employee ideas.
Mr. DeLia said that he was excited about future growth prospects. With the new support, he said he foresees more aggressive international expansion and possible acquisitions in similar industries. Thirty percent annual growth should continue, along with more opportunities for skilled workers.
Fiber Options' employees now participate in Sentrol's profit-sharing plan. About a dozen existing employment contracts have been maintained, although the Sentrol spokeswoman would not comment on whether these agreements will be renewed. Mr. DeLia himself has a two-year contract. "Employees know I'm here now so that gives them a level of comfort," he said.
Mr. Cormier, who has been with Fiber Options seven years, said his initial fears about job security have been put to rest. "I'm sure there are employees who are concerned, but they're probably feeling much more comfortable now than the day they were told," he said.
Cathy Barbour, the company's production supervisor, held off buying a new car when rumors spread about a possible take-over. She recently went for it, figuring her job will be secure at least for the duration of the loan. "I have no idea what the future will hold," she said.
Concerns about whether acquisitions will diminish employment on the Island coincide with fears that some leading technology companies are, independent of a takeover, weighing moving elsewhere.
According to a Price Waterhouse study of Long Island technology companies released last May, 60 percent of the nearly 300 respondents said they had seriously considered relocating in the previous 12 months. Fifty-two percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with Long Island, and 48 percent expected to add jobs.
Another survey found that 10 percent of a cross-section of businesses plan to relocate this year, down from 17 percent the year before. Reasons included selling the business, as well as costs and incentives from other states. The survey was conducted by Dowling College's School of Business and Albrecht, Viggiano, Zureck & Company, a Hauppauge accounting firm.
The threat of any further erosion in employment comes as local officials are trying to rebuild the Island's manufacturing base. Project Long Island, initiated by the Long Island Association, hopes to generate programs to create long-term jobs in selected manufacturing industries.
In the past four years, the Long Island Research Institute has helped create six new high-technology companies here, and has given technical and other assistance to about 30 others. One company, Moltech, a manufacturer of lithium batteries, has relocated, to Tucson, Ariz. The state plans to develop more business development incubators, in addition to the one at the State University at Stony Brook.
Mr. Gargano said the state economic development department also was forming an advisory board of Long Island businessmen to work closely with the regional office to identify companies considering relocation. "The problem is we don't always know," he said. "We'd like to intervene as early as possible," he said, because "It's much more difficult when the decision has been made to move out."
State officials, for example, are talking with the St. Louis-based parent of Hazeltine Corporation to try to head off the possible loss of 800 jobs if the military contractor is sold.
Mr. Gargano said he was just as concerned about the potential job losses of smaller companies, noting: "One job is important."
The state had not contacted Fiber Options prior to or immediately after its acquisition.
Mr. Gargano pointed out that unlike in past years a number of companies that have been acquired recently are staying on Long Island, which in some cases could result in expanded operations here. "We're not as concerned as we used to be," he said.
He said that state efforts toward reducing taxes and unnecessary regulations, and incentives are helping stem the tide. Of the five acquired companies that have remained on Long Island since 1994, three received cash or other incentives.
Gary Huth, regional labor market analyst at the New York State Department of Labor, said it bodes well that most of the manufacturing left on Long Island is highly skilled. "Most of the purging has been done in those industries where you gain significant savings in labor costs by moving," he said.
Bennett X-Ray Technologies is among the high-technology companies that have stayed put after an acquisition. The manufacturer of advanced radiography and mammography products was acquired last September for $43 million by Trex Medical Corporation, a newly created subsidiary of the ThermoTrex Corporation of San Diego. The agreement included a commitment to remain at Bennett's Copiague operation at least for the term of its 10-year lease.
In January, Cal Kleinman, who had negotiated the deal and was Bennett's president, abruptly left the company without explanation. Despite that, Hal Kirshner, president of Trex Medical, said, "The plan never was to move. It still holds true as long as we continue to grow profitably."
Walter Schneider, who replaced Mr. Kleinman and is vice president and general manager, said Bennett was dependent on its solid, high-technology work force on the Island. "There's a success on Long Island, a work ethnic and closeness between management and employees. It would be foolish to change that," he said. Bennett recently spent $750,000 to renovate and expand and plans to add 100 jobs in the next two years.
Meanwhile, local officials expect more acquisitions in the future, especially if efforts at developing Long Island high-technology companies prove successful.
According to Philip Palmedo, president of the Long Island Research Institute, the difficulty lies in that most of the Island's high-technology companies are small. "Once these companies are allowed to grow, they will be the acquirers. Now that they're small being acquired is a risk," he said.
While this raises the odds of a relocation, Mr. Palmedo said, "I'm not sure we could do too much about it except to make the companies productive and happy here."

HEADLINE: An Audio Manufacturer Remembers Its Roots

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG 

 BODY:
THE HMG Digital Technologies Corporation of Hauppauge was what its founder calls "a textbook case of a company under pressure to economically justify staying on Long Island."
When the 700-employee company, which copies audiocassettes, videocassettes and compact disks, merged with Allied Film Laboratory Inc. of Detroit in January 1995, "it became even more pointed," said the founder, George N. Fishman, who started 15 years ago as a record manufacturer. "We merged with people that had other locations and land to expand on." 
 The new company, the Allied Digital Technologies Corporation of Detroit, had to decide whether to move or continue and expand operations on Long Island.
Mr. Fishman, co-chairman of the new Allied, said he felt a loyalty to the region and his experienced employees. He approached the state's Empire State Development Corporation and the Town of Islip Industrial Development Agency.
"I told them if they want to be competitive and keep us here, I'd need accommodations," he recalled. He obtained $750,000 in cash and a low-rate mortgage. In exchange, Allied made a commitment to add 60 jobs.
The company has proceeded with a 55,000-square-foot expansion, from a 90,000-square-foot plant in Hauppauge.
In April the company transferred the HMG video division to Allied Film's videocassette plant in Clinton, Tenn. "The cost of production was perceived to be less," Mr. Fishman said.
Among Long Island employees, 20 moved to Clinton, 50 were laid off, and 100 transferred to the compact disk division.
Despite the move, Mr. Fishman said, local officials agreed to the economic assistance because "there would have been a much larger erosion otherwise."
As it turned out, Allied, which had $161 million in sales last year, made what Mr. Fishman called an "economic error," one that cost $1.5 million in sales. In four months video production returned to Hauppauge. Even with economies of scale and somewhat lower labor costs, "it didn't work, because we lost the efficiency of our labor force," Mr. Fishman said, adding:
"It's productivity that counts. Our people are so tuned to this that their efficiency more than made up for the efficiency of combining the two units."

HEADLINE: Coastal Geologist Questions Plan for Restoration of Barrier Beach

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
WHEN Federal and New York State officials reached final agreement recently on a $30 million project to restore the storm-battered western end of the Westhampton barrier island, property owners applauded.
But one coastal geologist said the new project was a mistake, and another said it involved an experimental erosion control method that may have unexpected results. 
 The project is part of a settlement a $200 million Federal lawsuit brought by the property owners against the Army, the state and Suffolk County. It involved erosion damage blamed on a never-completed groin field the Army constructed in 1966 and extended in 1970.
Coastal experts for the Army, the state and property owners said they were convinced the project would stabilize the barrier island west of the groins. The Army said work would begin in June.
But a Duke University professor of geology, Dr. Orrin Pilkey, said the Army and the state were acting irresponsibly by going ahead with a project he said was doomed to failure.
"If ever there was a futile effort, this is it," said Dr. Pilkey, the director of a program for the study of developed shorelines at Duke. "The Westhampton area is smashed by every storm, it's extremely vulnerable and the rate of erosion is extremely high. They are trying to hold the shoreline out where it no longer wants to be.
"I would stake whatever reputation I have on this; it's not going to work," Dr. Pilkey said.
The project, which also entails 30 years of periodic beach replenishment at an estimated cost of more than $100 million, addresses one of the most widely known and vexing shoreline erosion problems in the coastal United States. It may also mark the start of an era of increased public spending for erosion control on Long Island's South Shore.
The Federal Government will pay 70 percent of the cost. New York will pay 21 percent and Suffolk County will pay 9 percent.
The project involves the tapering of the two westernmost groins in a 15-groin field. A new groin will also be constructed between the two tapered groins. The area between the 11th and 15th groin will be filled with sand pumped from offshore.
Beaches west of the groin field will be rebuilt and backed by a 13-foot-high dune. Property owners will be permitted to rebuild on the inland side of the dune, but the new beach will be public. Five access points on Dune Road, the road that runs along the barrier island, are also included in the plan. In the past, private property blocked beach access.
The state will hold a conservation easement from the seaward toe of the dune 25 feet inland.
Project engineers said tapering the groins and filling the four westernmost compartments with sand would help restore the predominant east-to-west movement of sand along the shoreline.
The groins -- massive stone fingers stretching from the beach into the surf -- are blamed for trapping sand that would otherwise replenish the eroded shoreline to the west of the groin system. Wide, sandy beaches within the groin field are a stark contrast to the flattened, narrow strip of barrier island to the field's west.
"The tapering is to help relieve the very severe anomaly that the groin field represents," said William W. Daley, the chief of the erosion management program for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. "We are convinced that this project will work and that time will show us it worked."
Mr. Daley said he was "not aware" of the high rate of natural erosion Dr. Pilkey referred to. "Dr. Pilkey is certainly allowed his opinion in this," he said. "He has staked his reputation on things in the past and been wrong."
Aram Terchunian, a coastal geologist and a consultant to property owners and municipalities, said the project "combines the best engineering and science we have, and I believe it will work."
"Dr. Pilkey hasn't been here in a long time," he said. "He should visit before he makes such strong statements."
But another coastal expert, Jay Tanski of the New York Sea Grant program, called the tapering of groins "a rather unique approach" that could bring surprises.
"It hasn't been tried anywhere else so in a sense its experimental," he said. "When you start dismantling structures in the water, there is a certain amount of uncertainty about what will happen. The groins are not just piles of rocks. They were very carefully engineered, and the groin field operates as a system."
Mr. Tanski said that changing the field's configuration could alter sand transport patterns in unexpected ways. "Of course the key is going to be careful monitoring of how the shoreline responds," he said.
Mr. Terchunian, who said he participated in the original design for the project in 1986, called it a "a textbook example of groin-field tapering."
"I share Jay's opinion that there are certain unknowns," Mr. Terchunian said. "We are dealing with the Atlantic Ocean, and there are no absolutes, but the cost of doing nothing exceeds the risk of us making mistakes by a hundred times."
Mr. Terchunian estimated that 90 to 95 percent of sand placed on the beach west of the groin field remained in place. He said this refuted contentions about a rapid erosion rate.
He referred to an $8 million emergency project by the Army to close a half-mile breach in the barrier island caused by a December 1992 storm and widened by a storm in March 1993.
About 200 summer houses west of the groins were destroyed by the breach and earlier storms. About 65 houses remain in the area, which is now incorporated as the Village of West Hampton Dunes. It has about 560 seasonal residents.
The village Mayor, Gary Vegliante, said the court settlement allowed property owners -- including some who lost most or all of their property to erosion -- to rebuild within an envelope no more than 75 feet in depth from Dune Road on the inland side of the new dune. "I'll bet every one of the houses will be rebuilt," he said. He said property owners would be eligible for Federal flood insurance.
Mr. Vegliante said the settlement was "a model for coastal management that protects the rights of private property owners while affording public access."
If the settlement became a model, Dr. Pilkey said, "then we will have to shut down the Defense Department to pay for these things."
"The absurd thing is, it's going to let these people build in what is probably the most storm-vulnerable area in the United States," he said of the settlement.
"What should we have done, just left it so Orrin Pilkey and his friends could walk on the beach?" Mr. Vegliante said. "He's an elitist and an exclusionist, and he has no data."
John J. O'Connell, the lawyer for the property owners, said the project would create a highly protected area west of the groin field and stimulate property values. He said Suffolk County was now one of the largest landowners because of tax defaults and would benefit from the higher values if the properties were resold.
"People who want to build near the ocean are going to go where they have the greatest protection," he said. "Now that this project has been announced, the market is beginning to heat up."
"As a result of this litigation, there is a recent recognition of the enormous inherent value of the barrier islands to the economy economy," Mr. O'Connell said. The governments, he said "have come to realize their value, and to admit responsibility for the fragility of a large part of the South Shore."
"The lawsuit yapping at their heels gave them the impetus to act on their good intentions," he said.
Paul Sabatino, the counsel to the Suffolk County Legislature, said the county would have to appropriate its 9 percent share of the project cost. "It was a good settlement," he said. "In the end, it was a bunch of reasonable people trying to solve and erosion problem, as opposed to trying to hit the jackpot with a multimillion-dollar lawsuit."
Dr. Pilkey said he was skeptical of a project that resulted from the settlement of a lawsuit. "Everybody has got the lawyers off their necks and they're breathing a sigh of relief, but it's very irresponsible," he said.
Mr. Daley of the State Department of Environmental Conservation said he believed the project would have been done even had there been no lawsuit.
The work at Westhampton is termed by the Army to be an interim project. The Army is currently completing plans for another interim project on Fire Island, where erosion has accelerated in recent years in many areas.
Under current plans, the Army will eventually undertake a massive coastal reformulation project along the South Shore of Long Island from Fire Island to Montauk. But the start of the omnibus project is probably at least 10 years away, officials said.
The Suffolk County Department of Parks said that a public beach at the western end of the barrier island, Cupsogue Park, would open for the summer season.

HEADLINE: A Sports Proposal for Pilgrim Site

BYLINE: By LINDA TAGLIAFERRO 

 BODY:
FOR 20 years the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood has been the subject of many redevelopment proposals: a regional incinerator, a juvenile detention center and a state prison. Community opposition was instrumental in defeating those plans.
Whether the latest, a proposal for a sports complex similar to the Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, will gain acceptance remains to be seen. 
 The cost for the sports project is estimated at $290 million, to be supplied by private developers.
Weyman Jones, whom the state appointed as chairman of a 12-member panel to seek out local reactions, said, "I see it as my job to produce a plan that is acceptable to the community and to avoid a repetition of the waste of time, money and effort in the past."
The panel held a hearing in January in Islip Town Hall and another is planned before the panel makes its recommendations. Gov. George E. Pataki has the power of final approval.
Pilgrim State was built in the 1930's, and by the 50's it was home to 16,000 mental patients. With the advent of drug therapy and the trend to deinstitutionalization in the 1970's, the number of patients began to decline steadily, to its present 750. Although the site has 84 buildings, many are unusable.
The Pilgrim Center sports proposal was created by the Empire State Development Corporation, formerly the Urban Development Corporation. The center would be built around what would remain of the psychiatric hospital.
The centerpiece would be the Sportsplex, which would radiate outward from the existing central water tower and encompass an area larger than the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
The redevelopment would include offices and 500 housing units.
The Sportsplex would include indoor and outdoor recreational activities like ice skating, swimming, rock climbing, tennis, gymnastics, general fitness, in-line skating and basketball and other court games.
Another sector would include a nine-hole golf course and playing fields, and the third would feature housing around a public green.
A preliminary report estimates that the complex would create 2,900 permanent jobs, as well as 1,800 during the construction.
The officials forecast that the project, which does not have a price tag, would generate $296 million a year for the Long Island economy during the construction phase and $421 million a year after that.
Nearby communities have raised concerns. A co-founder of the Pine Barrens Society, John Turner, said the area had oak brush plains that provided a habitat for rare or declining species like the buckmoth, the prairie wobbler and the pine wobbler.
"Because of this," Mr. Turner said, "the oak brush plains have gotten the attention of ecologists. It has also gotten the attention of people concerned about water quality, because in the western end of Suffolk County, where there has been so much development, not only does the Pilgrim property and the adjoining Edgewood Preserve provide respite, but they also recharge large volumes of clean water to the underlying aquifers."
In the late 80's, Mr. Turner said, the State Legislature amended the Environmental Conservation Law to designate a series of Special Ground Water Protection Areas. "The largest of these was the pine barrens," he said. "But another was the Edgewood-Pilgrim State site."
He added that his society was working closely with the State Environmental Conservation Department to join part of the Pilgrim site and Edgewood preserve.
Although his group does not oppose the sports plan, Mr. Turner said, "it will be a challenge for the applicant to square the proposal with the recommendations in the water-protection report."
James Tripp of the Environmental Defense Fund said the proposal indicated that the site was in a protection district, "but it says nothing further about it."
The president of the Brentwood Civic Association, Frank Signor, said his group favored the proposal, adding, "The Brentwood School District has been substantially cut in state aid, and we look forward to this project as a way to help the school district raise funds."
His only reservation, he said, is that the complex might generate heavy traffic.
A member of the citizens' panel, Laura Mansi, said, "All along I've been saying that we have to look at what else already exists in the area."
She noted that a Price Club warehouse store had opened in the area, that the Commack Multiplex movie theater was nearby and that Suffolk Community College was planning a conference center for the area.
"All of these are in the same immediate area," she said. "So there will be major traffic impacts."
A representative of the Town of Huntington, George Hoffman, said that he and other officials had been surprised by the extent of the proposal. "We also did not expect a sports-complex proposal," Mr. Hoffman said. "There is still going to be a psychiatric population that needs to be serviced, and we are not sure that a sports-complex development would be a good match for the existing psychiatric facility."
Mr. Hoffman said he was also concerned about proposed major road improvements. "This is very expensive," he said. "We certainly don't want to put a burden on our taxpayers to provide for this.
"We recognize that a project of this scope creates jobs and economic development, but there has to be a balance between economic development and the environmental quality of life for the community. We're not sure that the draft plan actually fulfills this, and we would like to see further modifications."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Water tower at former Pilgrim State Hospital would be on logo of proposed sports complex. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Live Animal Use Spurs Protests

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
LIVE animal experiments that some doctors call essential and others say are useless are stirring protests at New York Medical College here.
After experiments using dogs were conducted in a first-year physiology course last month, several students, including one who took the course last year, contacted People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. This led another advocacy group, Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, which is based in Washington, to sponsor advertisements condemning the college for using the dogs, which were later killed. 
 The students declined to be interviewed or give their names, but several doctors connected with the college said the experiments were no longer justified in teaching human physiology.
"In addition to being cruel, they are useless," said Dr. Don M. Sloan, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology, who is a member of Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine. "Lower animals don't have the same metabolism humans do. We have a different adrenaline flow, different thyroids and different mechanisms that guide us. Our brains are different and special."
Dr. Marjorie Cramer, a plastic surgeon at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan and a clinical assistant professor at the college, said she believed the experiments were detrimental to students. "I remember being just horrified," she said of her own experiments on cats as a medical student. "I think it interfered with my ability to learn."
New York Medical College is among 77 of 125 medical schools in the United States that still use live animals, mainly dogs and pigs, in teaching undergraduate courses in physiology, pharmacology and other subjects.
Thirty other schools have discontinued the practice since 1982. Stan Ammons, a staff associate with the Association of American Medical Schools, said the trend away from animal laboratories was continuing.
The reasons more often involve economics and curriculum changes than ethics, he said. At New York Medical College, the dog laboratory is conducted once a year and students are not required to participate.
Dogs are anesthetized, and surgical experiments, which include drugs, are conducted to show the functioning of their cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
Dr. Gabor Kaley, chairman of the physiology department here, said the students, many of whom grew up with dogs as pets, were well prepared to take part in the laboratory.
"We talk to them first, and explain why it is important," he said. We try to desensitize them." He said no students had chosen to abstain this year from the experiments, which he called an "absolutely necessary" part of the curriculum. "All consider this the highlight of the course in the first year," he said. "You're dealing with living tissue."
But Dr. Sloan, who practices in Manhattan and is also a sex therapist, said the experiments were outmoded in an age of sophisticated computers and techniques like high-resolution ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging, which can produce accurate simulations of the human body.
"It's not only not necessary to use animals," he said, "it is detrimental." He described a procedure to treat glaucoma, which was successfully tested on rabbits but caused blindness in humans. "You can't apply the same principles," he said. "The college is holding on to old ways."
Dr. Ralph Dell, chairman of the animal care and use committee at Columbia University's schools of medicine, nursing and public health, said animals had become too expensive to use in teaching undergraduates.
Instead, students observed demonstrations of cardiac catheterizations and other procedures on patients, as instructors explained what was taking place.
Dr. Dell said, however, that he had found animal laboratories very useful when he was a medical student. "I support New York Medical College in their efforts," he said. "If they have the money for it, that's absolutely fantastic."
Research animals are expensive not only because their treatment and upkeep must conform to Federal and state regulations but also because 14 states, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, prohibit pounds or shelters from providing animals for use in teaching or research.
Dr. Robert F. Case, a veterinarian in charge of enforcing animal welfare laws for the State Health Department, described an industry of licensed dealers who can provide the only legal supply of dogs and cats to medical schools and research laboratories.
The breeders raise mongrel puppies for teaching purposes and purebred dogs, usually beagles, for use in research, while other dealers obtain unwanted animals from their owners, who are required to have raised them from birth. All dealers must be registered with the United States Department of Agriculture.
Dr. Case visits sites unannounced to inspect the living conditions of animals and oversee the humane use of anesthesia. He said purpose-bred mongrels between the age of 6 and 8 months sold for $370 each, while dogs over 8 months sold for $525 each. Purebred beagles, which are most often used for research, cost between $325 and $385 each.
Second-hand dealers, who buy from the original owners, charge by weight rather than age; their prices range from $174 to $194 for dogs.
Room and board for dogs, which are usually kept for several weeks before experiments take place, as well as staff members to take care of them, also drive up the animal's cost to medical schools.
Dr. Kaley said about 20 dogs had been used in last month's laboratory class here. Dogs are preferred over rodents, for example, because "you need a larger animal to be similar to the human," he said.
Other medical schools have taken a different approach. The physiology course attended by 80 percent of undergraduates at Harvard Medical School, for example, was redesigned last year to emphasize human, rather than other mammalian, physiology. "We wanted the students in that course to study more closely the human body and its responses to physiology and stresses," said Dr. Bruce R. Zetter, a professor of surgery who directs the course. "We felt it was most important to understand the integrated workings of the body, and since they're going to be physicians, we wanted that to be the human body."
Dr. Zetter said the decision to stop using dogs and rats in the course, a practice that began at Harvard 35 years ago, was made for educational reasons. "We asked how in thinking about physiology in the 1990's we could design a course that emphasizes humans and teaches about the heart," he said, "and we came up with about 20 different ways." These include observing cardiac surgery and taking part in a new exercise laboratory, he said.
The other 20 percent of Harvard's undergraduate medical students attend a physiology course involving animal experiments taught in the school's Health Sciences and Technology Division, a joint program with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Officials at New York Medical College said the animal laboratories and use of dogs would continue.
"We firmly and strongly believe that what we are doing is necessary to the education of our future doctors," said Ellen F. Carr, vice president of communications.
Dr. Kaley called supporters of Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, who include 3,500 doctors and 65,000 other people, single-minded fanatics with a "crazy pseudo-philosophy that animals have rights or are as good as people."
He added: "There is only one side to this story. They are 100 percent wrong."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Don M. Sloan, associate professor at New York Medical College in Valhalla, who opposes live animal experiments. (Roberta Hershenson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Scientists Discover All Kinds of Friends

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
GOV. JOHN G. ROWLAND has been stung by beekeepers. And by farmers, horticultural-business owners, environmentalists, foresters, public health officials and householders who do their own landscaping.
All were among the hundreds of people at two recent public hearings who testified against the Governor's $4.5 million budget proposal to eliminate the state's Agricultural Experiment Station. Last week, legislative leaders conceded the proposal was dead. 
 Mr. Rowland -- citing soil, water, fertilizer and pesticide tests -- had said the station's services benefited only a small portion of the state's population. He also argued that the station's essential services (like certifying state-produced plants for export or shipment out of state), research on Lyme disease and other tick-borne diseases, as well as research on tree and plant blights and diseases, could be taken over by other agencies or institutions.
The Governor questioned the role of the state in undertaking the diverse research that has made the Agricultural Experiment Station -- with its 38 scientists, six-acre campus in New Haven, 73-acre research farm in Hamden and laboratory and research farm in Windsor -- world famous.
Among the station's achievements are the development of hybrid corn (a vital food source throughout the world), the discovery of Vitamin A and the development of the first tests to detect Lyme disease.
This is about making state government more efficient, said Nuala Forde, a spokeswoman for Mr. Rowland.
This is about the Governor being a city person who doesn't have a clue about the economic value of the state's agricultural and horticultural businesses, said State Representative John D. Mordasky, a Democrat of Stafford Springs and one of two farmers in the General Assembly.
Agriculture, and its related industries, is a growing sector of the state's economy that employs about 9,300 state residents and annually contributes $844 million to the state economy, according to a recent report done by UConn's Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics.
If the Governor has the opportunity to see the station's work, said John Lyman 3d, he would be able to see how efficiently essential services are provided to state businesses, businesses that generate millions of dollars for the state's economy and employ thousands of state residents.
Mr. Lyman is a Republican selected by Mr. Rowland to serve on the experiment station's board of control and the vice president of farm operations at Lyman Orchards in Middlefield. (The board of control includes the Governor, two of his appointees, the Commissioner of the State Department of Agriculture, and representatives from the University of Connecticut, Wesleyan and Yale.)
"The Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station is about value rendered to the citizens of Connecticut," said Larry Carville, executive director of the Connecticut Nurserymen's Association. The state's $600 million horticultural and nursery industry has more than 2,500 full- time employees, and 2,000 seasonal workers, said Mr. Carville. The experiment station is essential to the industry, he said.
Only 15 percent of White Flower Farm's products are sold in Connecticut, the rest is sold out of state or internationally, said Elliot Wadsworth, owner of the Litchfield-based business. Inspectors from the station certify Connecticut-grown products for shipment out of state and for international markets, he said.
Scientists at the station developed a beautiful and hardy new strain of mountain laurel, the state flower, which has become a very popular ornamental plant, said Mike Johnson, owner of Summer Hill Nursery Inc. in Madison.
A third-generation fruit grower from Ledyard, Richard Holmberg, recalled that during his gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Rowland had said that he and the state government wanted to be partners with business and to generate new jobs together. Mr. Holmberg described the Experiment Station as "a partner in New Haven for three generations, a partner and a friend that has never let me down."
"If the state of Connecticut really wants to be my partner," Mr. Holmberg said, "don't eliminate my most valuable asset."
The station's success in tick-borne disease is something that definitely couldn't be transplanted, said Louis Magnarelli, the state's entomologist and the assistant director of the Experiment Station.
The station's work with Lyme disease began in 1975 when a cluster of 30 juvenile arthritis cases was noted among children and young teen-agers in Lyme and Old Lyme. Station scientists were some of the first to recognize that the disease was tick-borne.
Dr. Magnarelli and Dr. John Anderson, the current director of the station, have done extensive research on the ecology of Lyme disease and other tick-borne disease. In 1989, station scientists discovered that tick-borne babesiosis, was present in Connecticut. Last summer, Dr. Magnarelli identified H.G.E., a potentially fatal tick-borne disease, as being entrenched in the state.
Station scientists have developed tests to diagnose such diseases, and Dr. Magnarelli is currently investigating whether a single tick bite can transmit more than one disease. He is also searching for diagnostic methods that can detect more than one tick-borne disease infecting a person simultaneously.
Station scientists are able to do this kind of work and achieve this kind of success, Dr. Magnarelli said, because they have been studying these pathogens for 20 years. Eliminating the Agricultural Experiment Station would wreck this research, he said, and destroy the experience and knowledge of tick-borne disease gained by station scientists.
At the March 11 hearing, about 70 state residents wearing green ribbons spoke in support of the Agricultural Experiment Station at the legislative office building in Hartford.
They talked about the work of station scientists in developing the first organic fungicide, the station's progress in protecting the state's hemlock trees from the woolly adelgid, and the station's work in producing clean compost from municipal sewage sludge.
"I definitely hear you," said State Senator Catherine W. Cook, a Republican of Groton and chairwoman of the Environment Committee.
Senator Cook said Republicans did not support elimination of the station, but many in the General Assembly did support charging user fees for laboratory tests and services.
Each year, station employees answer about 25,000 question from the public, and analyze about 10,000 soil samples from farms, lawns and gardens. They also do tests for disease on tens of thousands of ticks sent in by residents who have removed the insects from themselves or pets.
Dr. Anderson said that only about $100,000 to $200,000 could be generated by fees and that fewer residents would be likely to use the station's services under a fee system.
State legislators also want the station to seek out royalties from its research as well as support from private foundations and the Federal Government.
Following the hearing, the state's Deputy Budget Director, Donald W. Downes, conceded there weren't enough votes in the General Assembly to eliminate the Agricultural Experiment Station.
