HEADLINE: At UConn, How It Was With Harry at the Helm

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
HARRY HARTLEY is a pump-your-hand kind of guy. He walks around campus in a UConn sweatsuit, nor does he mind when a man in a pick-up truck dispenses with the formality usually offered a university president and shouts, "Hey Harry -- howsit goin'?"
"Fine," he calls back, chuckles. 
 As he walks, it keeps happening -- these hey's and hi's from all over. Then, suddenly, Dr. Hartley sprints away, toward a crowd he has spied in front of the UConn Co-op.
It is a group of high school students and their parents taking a tour of the university. Dr. Hartley steps right in, introduces himself as the president of the University of Connnecticut and quickly engages the prospective students, especially a couple of quiet ones standing on the fringe.
"Where are you from?" he asks.
"New Canaan," a young woman answers.
"Ahh, Fairfield County," Dr. Hartley says. "Is that part of New York or Connecticut? I always forget."
At first, they don't quite know what to make of this joke-cracking man, but then the corners of their lips turn up. Parents' shoulders relax.
Alena Cybart, the UConn senior giving the tour, says this happens all the time. "He's very accessible," she said. "You see him at a lecture or an event or a game and he's so approachable. I'd have to think that's rare."
On Sept. 1, after almost six years as head of the state's largest public university, Dr. Hartley will step down. He plans to take a year to travel and then return to the classroom. Why?
"People keep wondering what the big mystery is, why I'm leaving," he said. "Six years is a long time for a state university president. There are political factors, stress, budget shortfalls, so many competing constituents."
Among students, he has become one of the most beloved presidents in recent history. Politicians genuinely like him. He has, according to numerous op/ed pieces lamenting his retirement in newspapers across the state, helped to raise UConn's profile across the country.
But he has also ruffled the feathers of some traditional academicians with his man-on-the-street affability and what they see as an undue emphasis on sports.
"When it comes down to dealing with difficult, substantive academic issues, he simply doesn't engage himself," said Antonio Romano, a former dean of liberal arts and sciences and a professor emeritus of molecular and cell biology. "He does not want to hear problems."
"If he wasn't so besotted with his gym rat image, he wouldn't have been bad," added Julius Elias, also former dean of liberal arts and sciences and a professor emeritus.
Dr. Hartley replies that his commitment to academics is not to be doubted and that his enthusiasm for sports is simply to be expected. "Most of the top 10 schools you see in basketball rankings are also first-rate academic institutions -- Duke, Stanford, University of North Carolina," he added. "Academic success and athletic success are absolutely compatible."
Dr. Hartley is by all accounts likeable and has a multitude of supporters. Peter L. Halvorson, a professor of geography and a member of the executive committee of the University Senate, said "I think something Harry has done quite well as president was to lay on our doorstep UConn 2000. That was a tremendously important achievement."
Dr. Halvorson said faculty at any university hopes for a balanced view of academic and athletic programs and UConn is no different. "There is a sizable contingent of people here concerned about that balance, feeling it needs to be adjusted," he said.
But Dr. Hartley stands by his own academic achievements, and those of others that have occurred during his tenure at UConn. "I was a professor for 24 years," he said. "I achieved the distinguished rank of university professor -- the only president so named."
As for sports, he said, "I don't set society's priorities. Society in Connecticut set its sights on our basketball teams. One hundred thousand people turned out for a parade in their honor."
If the same happened for a debating team or a physics club, Dr. Hartley said, he'd be there banging the drum just as loudly.
Dr. Romano, for one, begs to differ. Last April, on the day the UConn women's basketball team returned to campus following their National Championship win, it was also UConn Scholars' Day, when the university honors its highest achievers in academics.
Dr. Romano said that while Dr. Hartley was on hand for all the basketball team's hoopla, he did not stop in to speak at the Scholars' Day, which he said speaks volumes about Dr. Hartley's priorities.
"Absolutely false," said Peter McFadden, executive assistant to the UConn President. "Harry Hartley was at the event." He also was at several others that day. Dr. Hartley very much believes what Peter Flawn, president emeritus of the University of Texas at Austin, said in his book, "Primer for University Presidents," Mr. Fadden said: "You show up at everything. You do not stay at anything."
Last May, Dr. Romano went head to head with Dr. Hartley after the university president approved tenure for a professor who had been denied throughout the ranks. Feeling that Dr. Hartley had "destroyed the integrity" of the tenure process, Dr. Romano retired rather than continue to work with him.
Dr. Romano and Dr. Elias said that under Dr. Hartley's tenure, graduate and PhD. programs have slipped in ranking.
Dr. Hartley acknowledged that some graduate program rankings have dropped, but said one of the key areas in need of improvement is graduate study in the area of liberal arts and sciences -- which he shot back to Drs. Elias and Romano as happening "during their watch."
He said the structure of the president's office changed last year with the hiring of Mark A. Emmert as chancellor, a position that has long been recommended. Dr. Emmert will focus primarily on academic issues and one of his first priorities, said Dr. Hartley, is to revamp the graduate and PhD. programs.
To the complaint that sports matter more to him than academics, Dr. Hartley said he was charged by the board of trustees to strengthen the school's athletics. "But it was not done at the expense of academics," he said. "During my presidency, the faculty's Federal research funding increased from $77 million in 1990 to $109 million." As he noted, UConn set up an economic partnership with the state, for research and development.
William Servedio, department head of sport, leisure and exercise sciences, said Dr. Hartley "was the best president to get us through very tough times."
"I don't think a lot of people realize how far he got our university, academically, with so little," he said.
"Harry's been visible at the sports games because that's where the cameras are but I've seen him at student government functions, United Way events, all kinds of student academic activities, Special Olympics," he said. "He's everywhere."
Adds Regina Barreca, associate professor of English, "I applaud what he did. He had an agenda and he accomplished it. He got the name of the university out there," she said. "A university president can never please everyone. It's a terrible job. If I were going to be a president on call seven days a week, answering to everyone . . . I'd do it at Chemical Bank where I'd make gobs and gobs of money."
A college presidency was hardly at the top of the dream list when Harry Hartley was a boy. He was going to be a stockbroker. He was born in Aliquippa, Pa., the same town that brought us Pistol Pete Maravich and Mike Ditka. "We were right outside of Pittsburgh, a steel mill town," Dr. Hartley said. "I like my blue collar roots."
His parents were both teachers but he didn't lean that way. He studied economics at Geneva College and later at the University of Pittsburgh. After a stint in the National Guard, he found work as a substitute teacher. He also found his calling. He went on for his Ph D. in educational administration at Penn State, worked for SUNY-Buffalo and then moved to Greenwich Village to become an associate dean at New York University.
He also wrote a book on time management and fiscal management, "Educational Planning-Programming-Budgeting," and dropped into Storrs on a book tour. In 1972 he was named dean of the school of education at UConn, where he taught and later became vice president for finance and administration.
"I loved Greenwich Village but when I came to UConn, I came home," he said. "I bought my first house, a dog. I put down roots."
He was named interim president for a month in 1987, then, three years later, when the Board of Trustees had concluded a national search, it went with the "local fellow," naming Dr. Hartley UConn's 12th president.
"It was what the board and the faculty wanted -- someone who was one of us," Dr. Halvorson said.
During his tenure, Dr. Hartley orchestrated efforts to put together UConn 2000 -- a sweeping plan that allows the university to issue bonds and spend $1 billion to address physical plant problems throughout the campus. He called its passage by the legislature his "finest moment," resulting from a "family effort" on the part of university officials, faculty and legislators.
But he also faced many a budget battle and faculty layoffs and has grown weary, he said, in the face of more operating budget woes on the horizon. "We have the same funding in 1996 that we had in 1989," he said, noting that Connecticut is near the bottom of the list in terms of state spending on higher education.
If UConn 2000 is his crowning achievement, the increasing cost of tuition and fees and the possibility that "the sons and daughters of Connecticut may not be able to afford UConn" is his biggest fear.
Dr. Hartley said he's also most proud of the strides made in the area of diversity during his presidency. He instituted a 100 Years of Women Celebration in 1991 and oversaw the creation of the Asian-American Cultural Center, the Asian-American Studies Institute and Puerto Rican and Latino Studies. The percentage of minority freshmen rose from 5.2 percent in 1990 to 18.9 percent in 1995.
"He's constantly putting issues having to do with culture and gender on the front burner," said Irene Quong Conlon, director of the office of diversity and equity.
While he worries over the financial picture for the university and his students, Dr. Hartley finds this generation of students to be one of the most motivated he's seen in years, realistic about the competition they face in the job market and genuinely concerned about other people.
"They also like to have fun and I like that," he said. "That's what I love about the job. I like being an ambassador for UConn and these people, a living logo."
He wears his National Championship Husky ring with pride. His office is hung with framed photographs of himself with President Bill Clinton, who was on campus last year, and Michael Bolton and Rebecca Lobo.
A search is underway for his successor and cards and notes from Senators, alumni, faculty and students crowd his windowsill. Despite the hubub and the usually hectic schedule, he manages to dart out of his office, to one the places he loves best -- the horse barn.
There in one of the stables is UC Harry H, a chesnut, 15 hands tall, 975 pounds strong. As Dr. Hartley explained it, "Each spring when the foals are born, visiting school children can write down the names they'd like for the horse and among all the names, the barn staff picks one."
One year, a child scribbled "Harry" and a lightbulb went off in John Bennett's head. "I thought, 'Let's name him for Harry Hartley,' " said Mr. Bennett, manager of the barn. "It was perfect."
Dr. Hartley said, "Nobody told me about it for months, but when I found out I was delighted. I love this guy."
The UConn president has become a fixture in this part of campus. He even was at the helm with UC Harry H. and a makeshift sleigh with Santa on board for for a snowless holiday event a couple years back when 400 children and their parents gathered at Christmastime.
"We stuck a sign on the back that said 'Student Driver' so no one got their toes run over," Mr. Bennett said and Dr. Hartley burst into laughter.
"You did? I didn't know that," the president said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harry Hartley, soon to step down as president of UConn, has a word with his namesake horse. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2029 words

HEADLINE: Corporate Giving, Falling Behind as the Needs Grow

BYLINE: By DIANE SENTEMENTES SIERPINA 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S biggest money givers -- its businesses -- are having a hard time meeting demand. The state's largest corporations did give away millions of dollars in 1995, but the pot may be shrinking as the needs keep growing.
Corporate grant makers say they are proud their budgets have remained largely stable in the past few years, but they say continuing cutbacks by Washington and by Hartford will mean even more requests than the thousands they already receive each year. 
 "We understand everybody needs money," said Carmella Piacentini, contributions manager for the Olin Corporation in Norwalk, which has a $2 million budget for philanthropy. "But we are not going to be everything for everyone. There's not enough money to go around."
"I think we do a pretty good job," added Zelda Jacobs, who manages corporate contributions for the Perkin Elmer Corporation in Norwalk, "but, God knows, we could do better."
Robert Bothwell, president of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthrophy based in Washington, D.C., is warning corporate grant makers to "barricade their doors." There will be an onslaught of requests for assistance coming soon, he said. It has happened before, with a weak economy and government cutbacks causing requests to companies to soar. "And it will happen again," Mr. Bothwell said.
Gail Promboin, assistant director of the Aetna Foundation in Hartford, has already seen a rise in requests. "Not only are the needs increasing," she said, "but they break your heart more." Aetna dispersed nearly $4 million in Connecticut from a $9 million national budget last year; most, she said, went to Hartford-area nonprofit agencies for children's health and educational opportunities for minorities and women.
But Mr. Bothwell says America's businesses aren't doing enough. National figures show that corporate giving has risen just 11 percent since 1987, while corporate profits over the same period increased by 84 percent. Companies used to donate an average 1.8 percent of domestic pretax income annually to charity, he said. In 1994, that figure dropped to 0.9 percent, according to the latest figures from the Conference Board, a research group based in New York. Audris Tillman, a research analyst with the board, described a dip below 1 percent as "cause for concern."
To Mr. Bothwell, the low figures mean businesses are shortchanging their social service communities nationally by $4 billion a year. "In the last six years, corporate giving has plateaued at $6 billion, hovered there and essentially gone nowhere," he said. "It is a very serious contraction."
On the bright side, said Ms. Tillman, the 383 companies that participated in the Conference Board's annual survey indicated their budgets for contributions would increase an average 3 percent in 1995 and another 5 percent in 1996. (Figures for 1995 will not be available until the fall.)
The concern about business community giving hasn't escaped the attention of SACIA (Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association), the Business Council of Fairfield County, said its president, Christopher Bruhl. The council expects to sponsor a conference for chief executives this fall to address changing philanthropic demands. "Business as usual can't do it anymore," he said. "Corporate giving needs to be re-examined. There hasn't been a broad national look at this in at least a decade."
Mr. Bruhl said corporate giving today is "more objective-driven and not need-driven." That is, companies are more motivated to give grants to specific sectors of their communities for a bigger impact rather than for the public relations rewards they sought in the 1980's, he said.
The education field is the big winner, as companies recognize the need to redefine basic skills for the future work force and to offer long-term learning opportunities for the current one. William Pitt, whose business is real estate, recently gave Sacred Heart University $3 million, to be used for a new health and recreation center.
Corporate grant makers around the state say that they have encouraged more employee volunteerism and offered matching funds to employees' charities. Some provide more services like classes and conferences, supplies and equipment, rather than cash. All have chosen to focus their grants in specific areas like education, foster care, health, culture, economic development and the environment. All, too, say they have written guidelines for giving that make it easier to say no to many other requests for donations.
Although many corporations do not disclose the size of their annual budgets for contributions, unless they are in the form of a legal foundation or trust, an informal survey of grant makers places the range at anywhere from $10,000 to $70 million, including United Way, matching gift and employee donations.
Many of the budgets -- the General Electric Corporation's estimated $70 million, for example -- encompass offices and divisions worldwide. Others are national in scope. It's difficult even for the professionals to compare apples with apples when considering the wide variety of budgets, the grant makers say.
In general, these grant makers say, budgets are set each year by the chief executive officer, board of directors or a committee of senior managers. Typically larger and multi-year donations are set; smaller donations that coincide with the company's grants agenda are made at the discretion of a manager. Only 10 percent to 15 percent of the annual budget is usually available for new requests.
The strength and size of a corporate contributions budget often reflects the attitude of the company's chief executive officer.
Linda Zemo, contributions manager at the Champion International Corporation in Stamford, says she knows this firsthand. Despite several lean years for the paper manufacturer, there are two things the retiring chief executive officer, Andrew Sigler, never did, she said: "fire people or reduce contributions, and that's very admirable."
Champion, which has a $7 million annual contributions budget, is widely recognized for its support of the Stamford Center for the Arts, lending of corporate executives to the city government and a five-year commitment to improve the middle schools in Stamford and three other American cities where its mills are situated.
Sometimes the favorite charities of the company's senior management get preferred treatment, so it behooves the nonprofits to get these managers on their boards of directors, grant makers said.
Although some firms have made it a full-time responsibility, corporate contributions often is only a part of a manager's duties, making it difficult to visit or monitor the agencies supported.
Many managers for the major corporations belong to regional contributions committees based in Stamford, Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford, which meet regularly to exchange information.
Corporate budgets and expenditures are not discussed, but grant makers often learn which company is supporting which projects and programs and they try to avoid duplication.
"We have to maintain a watch on our shareholders' dollar," said Kathy Buccy, director of contributions and educational programs for the SNET Corporation in New Haven. "We're under additional pressure to reassess our giving every year and focus on trying to provide more where we think we can make a difference."
SNET provides more in telecommunications tools and training sessions for educators than in cash, she said. Each year since 1988 the company has connected 25 new schools to the Internet through its Links to Learning program. Because of its work force reduction, it also had the bittersweet pleasure of opening its warehouse three times so nonprofit agencies could pick out office furniture and computers.
With industry money so tight, Ms. Buccy suggests charities with similar missions collaborate more on their projects and not make duplicative requests for contributions. Other managers suggested that agencies do more homework and learn about a corporation's policies before making their proposals.
Jane Polin, program manager for the $30 million G.E. Fund at G.E.'s Fairfield headquarters, an estimated $3 million of which is spent in Connecticut annually, said her company created the first matching-gift program in the nation during the 1940's and is always trying to be innovative with its funds.
Among other things, she said, the company conducts training conferences for the managers of social service agencies so they can do their jobs better. "We don't just give them fish," she said, "we teach them how to do the fishing."
G.E. also encourages current and retired employees to become dues-paying volunteers in its Elfun Society, which has 2,500 members in its three Connecticut chapters. Jack Batty, the paid director of the Connecticut chapters, said members provide tutoring, mentoring, time, talent and labor for various programs. Mr. Batty said other Connecticut firms have contacted him about starting similar programs.
The president of the Coordinating Council for Foundations in Hartford, Nancy Roberts, said that the area has received "very generous" support from its business community. But mergers and layoffs in the military, insurance and banking industries have apparently cut dollar totals.
Since 1992, Ms. Roberts said, contributions from 16 corporations surveyed by the council has decreased $1.9 million to $16 million, most of the shrinkage showing up in the banking and insurance sectors.
One major Hartford-based provider has been the United Technologies Corporation, whose contributions budget increased nearly 16 percent for 1996 to $12.8 million, $4 million of which is to be spent in Connecticut.
The company's contributions administrator, Leah Bailey, said that neither cash gifts nor volunteer hours have dropped. "The more we ask people to help out, the more they continue to sign up," she said. Last year, an estimated 4,000 employees volunteered to help at the Special Olympics World Games in New Haven.
Support for education account for 46 percent of the budget, and most grants are spread over many years. "We tend to be in there for the long haul," said Ken Green, director of contributions, who receives up to 40 new requests a day. Smaller projects, particularly in the arts, also are supported. Last year, United Technologies awarded the Mark Twain House in Hartford a two-year, $250,000 grant to renovate the home and create new programs.
At the end of 1995, with some discretionary funds left in the budget, the company bought $2,500 worth of cribs, bedding and furniture for six homeless shelters -- then delivered them unannounced. The company also presented each shelter with a $2,500 check. "That was one of the highlights of the entire year," said Mr. Green. "On a personal level, it was extremely gratifying." Unsolicited donations are the best, the UTC staff agreed.
Managers of contribution programs love their jobs.
"It makes it easier to get up in the morning," said Ms. Promboin of Aetna.
"Obviously, you feel like Santa Claus," added Ms. Jacobs of Perkin Elmer, whose company is recognized for its support of foster care and science/technology education. "I know it's through the largesse of the company, but my name is on the check and I'm the vehicle through which the money comes."
Richard Manz, assistant treasurer for the General Reinsurance Corporation in Stamford, who spends most of his day crunching numbers, said he gets the greatest pleasure visiting the organizations his company supports, particularly in the areas of health research and education. "No matter how much we give, it's great to make people happy," he said.
What he doesn't want to get from the agencies are fattening lunches or free tickets in appreciation. "That tells me they're using our money to wine and dine people," he said.
Who benefits most from business donations?
Mr. Bruhl of SACIA says its the companies themselves. "The corporations are completely dependent on the quality of their communities," he said.
"That's why they give and that's why they should give."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At United Technologies, employee volunteer efforts back up corporate dollar donations. In his Hartford office, Earl Flowers tutors Pao Keola. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THEATER FINANCING;
Post-War Survivors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Dinitia Smith's article "Curtain Calls With No Help From Uncle Sam" [March 3] generates more than respect for struggling theater artists. It also illuminates the drive in creative people who transcend economics and technology to keep their art alive. 
 A little history pre-dating those pocket theaters, not in Paris but here in New York City, seems timely. It was the late 1940's and early 50's. WPA support for the arts was over. World War II lingered in its aftereffects. And in the basements of libraries all over the city, Equity Library Theaters were flourishing on $50 grants from John Golden. I produced Chekhov's "Cherry Orchard" and Gorky's "Lower Depths" in a space the size of a handkerchief. We did Moliere with a line of dancers restricted to moving two feet in either direction. Our repertory included great plays of the Greeks as well as those of Odets and O'Casey.
 
ROSILYN WILDER
New York

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Paper Threat

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

POP INTERNATIONALISM
By Paul Krugman.
221 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The MIT Press. $22.50.
Now that the cold war is over, the terms of global competition have shifted from ideology to economics. And while this is arguably a more civilized form of competition, the combatants are just as dedicated and the stakes are just as high. On the one hand, the United States must fend off economic challenges from Japan and the European Community. On the other, it must find ways to compete with third world countries that gobble up our capital and technology while flooding our markets with goods produced by low-cost labor. 
 You've heard all this a hundred times before. Business analysts, labor leaders, prominent academics -- even the Rhodes scholar Bill Clinton -- apparently find it persuasive. There is just one catch: it is unadulterated nonsense that anyone who got a passing grade in Economics 101 should be able to refute. Why, then, has it become the conventional wisdom for so many?
That is the subject that loosely binds "Pop Internationalism," Paul Krugman's new book of essays. Like most other writers' collections of previously published work, it suffers occasionally from repetition and datedness. It is hard, for example, to recall why people were so obsessed with the professional qualifications of Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's surprise choice to head his Council of Economic Advisers. Still, everything Mr. Krugman has to say is smart, important and even fun to read.
Paul Krugman is no household name, but probably should be. A former professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who recently migrated to Stanford University, he is one of a handful of very bright, relatively young (age 42) economists who do everything well, and he was expected to represent the economics establishment in the big leagues of liberal policy wonkery. Indeed, his analysis of widening income inequality was used with great success by the Clinton campaign in 1992. But for reasons that reflect badly on the White House -- mostly Mr. Krugman's unwillingness to kowtow to the mushier-minded Friends of Bill -- he didn't make it into the Clinton inner circle.
The consolation is that Mr. Krugman now feels free to say whatever is on his mind. And much of it is not pretty. "Something really strange was going on," he writes of the President-elect's economic summit in Little Rock, Ark., in December 1992. "It was as if a high-profile conference had been convened that was billed as a gathering of the world's leading experts on human psychology -- and up there on the podium, giving the lead address, was John Bradshaw, telling me how to get in touch with my inner child."
The thesis of "Pop Internationalism" is that untutored views about international economics, mostly derived from the experiences of businessmen, soldiers and diplomats, are dead wrong. Corporations do compete for survival with other corporations: those that fail to please consumers, keep down costs or stay on the cutting edge of technology eventually disappear. "Countries, on the other hand, do not go out of business," Mr. Krugman writes. "They may be happy or unhappy with their economic performance, but they have no well-defined bottom line."
More to the point, the foreigners' gain is rarely our loss. When the Japanese build a better computer screen or the Brazilians mass-produce cheap shoes, American consumers enjoy the fruits of their innovation. Individual jobs held by Americans may end up in Osaka or So Paulo, but total employment in the American economy, Mr. Krugman reminds us, is largely determined by credit and monetary policy. Thus while the mix of jobs changes, there is no particular reason to believe that the losers outnumber the winners.
The grain of truth to the "trade as war" metaphor is in the exceptions to the rules -- exceptions that Mr. Krugman himself wrote about in the 1980's. Take the example of commercial aircraft. If there is room for only one low-cost manufacturer in the world market, a country that gets there first by subsidizing its industry or discouraging imports may reap the rewards of an effective monopoly. But potential gains from what has come to be known as strategic trade policy, Mr. Krugman notes, are elusive. All too often, the winners turn out to be losers: remember the race to be first in high-definition television?
One way or another, a country's gain at the expense of others must show up in improvement in its terms of trade -- how much more we get in imports in exchange for what we sell in exports. And by this objective measure, Mr. Krugman explains, the battle among global titans has amounted to shadow boxing. America's imports are a bit more expensive than in the 1960's. But the impact on American living standards has been trivial, a virtually unmeasurable ripple in the stormy seas of productivity change.
The puzzle, of course, is how so many influential people can be so wrong. One explanation, Mr. Krugman says, is that the global-competition bogyman is a wonderful diversion for politicians facing serious economic problems without obvious solutions. Another is that all sorts of people who know better go along with the fiction because it encourages virtuous behavior at home. It is easier, for example, to rally the nation around deficit reduction or investment in education by waving the flag than by arguing that a particular policy will increase the annual rate of economic growth from 2.1 percent to 2.3 percent.
But Mr. Krugman reserves his serious scorn for some of his most prominent colleagues. Lester Thurow, a very sophisticated economist, wrote a best seller entitled "Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe and America." "Would Thurow have sold a tenth as many books," Mr. Krugman wonders, if the subtitle had been "The coming struggle in which each big economy will succeed or fail based on its own efforts, pretty much independently of how well the others do"?
"Pop Internationalism" probably won't improve the sophistication of the public debate over Nafta or GATT, or encourage Japan to sell us more of those great products at bargain prices. But at least it is there to be read by those eager to get beyond the slogans that too often pass for economic wisdom.

HEADLINE: Dress Rehearsal For G.M. Closing

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
THREE decades and what seems like a lifetime ago, Otto Rivera, a lanky youth from the Bronx, drove to his first day of work here in a sporty, light blue 1963 Chevrolet Bel Aire. Since those first years working on the assembly line at General Motors, there have been promotions, a wife and family, a home in the suburbs and a series of newer model cars. Life was everything Mr. Rivera had hoped for, until his 47th birthday this year.
Now the shop chairman for the United Automobile Workers is facing unemployment because the automaker will close the plant once the current model year ends this summer. The shutdown is part of an accelerated consolidation and idling of 22 selected factories in the United States and Canada. So far, 13 plants have been closed or sold. 
 Many of the 2,000 members of Local 664 at the plant here have been offered similar jobs at other factories, and although Mr. Rivera said he was not ready to retire, he has decided not to go.
Perhaps it is a matter of his age, he said, but he has put down roots here since he first began assembling speedometers when he was 18, and he does not want to start anew. Working at this hulking factory along the Hudson River, where Chevrolet Lumina Minvans, Oldsmobile Silhouettes and Pontiac Trans Sports are assembled, has been the only job he has known.
"I thought I would be here forever," he said. "I never dreamed things would come down to this."
As Mr. Rivera must now prepare for life after General Motors, so must the village of North Tarrytown along with the shopkeepers on Beekman Avenue who depend on the trade generated by the plant.
But the departure of General Motors is not a surprise to any of these groups -- the workers, the governmental units dependent on payments in lieu of taxes that the company makes to them or the merchants. Plans to close the assembly plant were announced four years ago, when 3,450 workers were employed here. At first, the shutdown was set for 1995, but an extra year's reprieve was later granted because the minivans were selling well.
Even though there has been ample time to adjust and to make plans, the reality of the impending shutdown was accentuated on March 14 when the plant was forced to stop production because of a shortage of brake parts -- the result of a strike at the Delphi Chassis plant in Dayton, Ohio.
That strike, which followed a long-simmering dispute over General Motors' decision to buy components from outside suppliers, resulted in production stoppages at 26 other North American plants and idled more than 166,550 workers by the middle of last week.
Sympathy for the strikers notwithstanding, Mr. Rivera said that for workers here the layoffs have added insult to injury. "We already knew D-Day was coming," he said, "just not this soon."
Union workers here earn as much as $840 a week, compared with maximum unemployment benefits of $300 a week. Those benefits were in doubt for awhile because the automaker had said it would fight workers' efforts to obtain unemployment benefits, but last Wednesday the New York State Department of Labor rejected the argument that the shutdown was the result of a strike and not the company's fault.
Once the plant closes for good, General Motors' severance package should help ease the pain for workers like Mr. Rivera. The company is offering permanent, full-time employees a $60,000 severance payment and $16,000 in vouchers and cash toward a new car, according to the New York State Department of Labor. The automaker will also give them $1,000 a month for two years while they look for a new job.
"G.M. has a heart," said Charles Licari, a spokesman for the automaker's North American operations in Warren, Mich. "No one is going to be left out on the street."
A transition center has been set up for workers, and many have been offered work in Doraville, Ga., where the minivans are now being built.
The severance package notwithstanding, the outlook is extremely poor for workers who do not accept transfer offers, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the state's Department of Labor. Referring to the work force at the plant here, Mr. Surdey said, "Once these 2,000 jobs are gone, there are only about 400 jobs of that kind left in the transportation equipment industry in New York." Re-employment prospects for welders and assembly-line workers are especially grim, although electricians may be able to transfer skills, Mr. Surdey said.
Meanwhile, at Village Hall, Mayor Sean Treacy was also weighing options for the future. While Mr. Rivera considers retraining alternatives, Mr. Treacy is negotiating a departure package with the automaker and leading a task force studying how best to use the waterfront property once it becomes vacant.
General Motors had filed, but has subsequently dropped, a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan seeking an injunction against North Tarrytown's Environmental Protection and Abandoned Industrial Property Reclamation Law, the first ordinance of its kind in the state and one of the first in the country.
In effect, the local law holds General Motors -- or any other large company leaving town -- responsible for cleaning up after itself. The ordinance is intended to prevent problems that have occurred in other waterfront communities like Hastings-on-Hudson, where large companies moved away and left behind hazardous waste.
With the threat of a lawsuit out of the way, the village is demanding that General Motors either sell the 97-acre site to an appropriate user within three years or start demolishing the buildings.
In addition, the Mayor has requested that the automaker continue to make payments in lieu of taxes for another two years, worth $5 million to the village, the school district and the town of Mount Pleasant.
The village is also seeking an option to buy 1.3 acres of the General Motors property to obtain a permanent easement for the Greenway Belt to connect Sleepy Hollow Landing here with Kingsland Park and Rockefeller State Park.
"We've agreed on the major points," Mr. Treacy said. "We're just hammering out the details."
A task force appointed four years ago by former Gov. Mario E. Cuomo to study reuse options for the property recently hired the consulting concern of Arthur Andersen & Company in Manhattan.
The company's preliminary study suggested these alternatives: housing for the elderly and others; a tourist center, including boutiques, outlets, restaurants and craft studios; a recreational center, including a sports complex, marina and public promenade, or a business complex with a hotel and office space.
But Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the county's Planning Department and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's representative on the task force, said the group was taking a cautious approach.
"We need plans that will fly in the marketplace," she said, "not something that just looks good on paper."
Meanwhile, merchants were also taking a hard look at the future, and many said they were worried about whether there would be enough customers to support their businesses once the automaker left. In the last 10 days, since the most recent layoffs, business has dropped off precipitously for many situated near the assembly plant.
"It's like a sad dress rehearsal for the real thing," said Christopher Rezza, co-owner of Greene County Importing, which makes pasta products and runs a delicatessen for walk-in customers. "We're sitting around playing cards."
Other merchants, however, were more optimistic. Margaret O'Brien, owner of the Catering Deli, said she opened her shop four years ago "knowing full well the plant was going to close."
She added: "Tourism has begun to boom along the Hudson River, and the village is all fixed up and ready for it. There are new storefronts, new trees, new sidewalks. We're going to change with the times."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 'Reviving Lower Manhattan';
Uptown at Columbia, A Panel on Downtown

 BODY:
Its cavernous streets and skyscrapers -- both historic and glassily new -- are "the glory of the place," according to the architect Robert A. M. Stern, who will be presiding over a forum Friday to discuss the future of Lower Manhattan.
The free symposium, called "Reviving Lower Manhattan: Preserving the Past to Insure the Future," will start at 1 P.M. at Wood Auditorium in Avery Hall at Columbia University, where Mr. Stern heads the historic preservation program of the School of Architecture. 
 With guests like Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, the symposium will target hot issues for the downtown financial area: rezoning and redeveloping some of the archaic office buildings as apartments.
But it will also feature other preservationists and architectural historians, including Richard Plunz and Andrew S. Dolkart. "We're trying to make it an intersection between the world of academe, the world of practice and the world of politics," said Mr. Stern, who helped to launch the symposium, which is based on a report on Lower Manhattan prepared by preservation students.
With what forum participants say is 20 million square feet of vacant office space, and streets that become a ghostland after 6 P.M., there is a "need to try to diversify Lower Manhattan's economy so it's more of a 24-hour place," said Richard L. Schaffer, a panelist, who was Planning Commission chairman under Mayor David N. Dinkins. "How do you keep the appeal of the place, the irregular old 17th-century Dutch streets and the early 20th-century skyscrapers, when you bring in the restaurants?"
"The issues are all up for review," said Richard Kaplan, another panelist and co-chairman of the J. M. Kaplan Fund, which has recently launched a series of tours of lower Manhattan. "The area had the first skyscraper, the first subways, the first zoning, the immigrants, the first Indians, the first Presidential inauguration and the first $100 million woman investor. It's going to take a while for Lower Manhattan to turn into SoHo or TriBeCa, but the seeds are being planted now."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Redeveloping the State's Industrially Polluted Sites

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IN passing a new law that provides tax abatements to developers who clean up industrially polluted sites, the state has taken another step forward in spurring the redevelopment of such sites and, in the process, stoking the economy.
The new law mirrors a national trend of offering incentives and steering development to such sites. Indeed, earlier this month when President Clinton made a campaign stop in Bergen County, including a visit to a contaminated tract in Wallington, he talked of a $2 billion proposal to grant Federal tax breaks to businesses that clean up sites in poor neighborhoods. 
 The state's Environmental Opportunity Zone Act became effective Jan. 10. The measure permits municipalities to offer up to a 10-year tax abatement to reclaim abandoned or underutilized industrial tracts they designate as such a zone -- most of them in cities.
The abatement defrays the cost of cleaning such sites, which state law requires be rid of any contaminants before they are redeveloped. Brownfields, as these sites are known, are less polluted than a toxic-waste dump, but need a more extensive cleanup than undeveloped suburban or rural sites.
An Environmental Opportunity Zone can consist of one site or several that a community wants to revive for industrial or commercial use to help shore up an economic base weakened by the loss of industry. Last year New Jersey had 492,500 manufacturing jobs, down from 506,000 jobs in 1994 and from a peak of more than 900,000 in 1969, state data show. Estimates by the state's Council of Economic Advisers are that there will be a 2 percent decline in such jobs in this year.
"The law attempts to combine a cleaner environment with a more productive economy," said State Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger, a Westfield Republican who was its sponsor. "The two are not mutually exclusive."
Mr. Bagger said the law seeks to preserve open space and redirect jobs into cities while bolstering the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan. A central tenet of the plan is to encourage growth in cities.
Of New Jersey's 22,000 known or suspected contaminated sites 7,000 are being cleaned or investigated, and they could be helped by the new law, said Richard J. Gimello, assistant commissioner of the Division of Site Remediation at the Department of Environmental Protection.
Though many developers, municipal leaders and industry experts are still assessing the new law, they say another tool to recyle old industrial sites is welcome.
"The abatement could help neutralize some of the financial disincentives that go along with developing these sites in older cities," said Ira Whitman, who heads an environmental consulting firm bearing his name in East Brunswick.
Thomas Consiglio, a partner at Resource Realty, an industrial brokerage in Edison added: "It will not make or break a deal. Developers still must be comfortable with the environmental risk and how to address it."
BASICALLY, the law borrows a page from the state's existing tax-abatement program, but with a significant twist.
Businesses that clean up and redevelop Environmental Opportunity Zone properties can receive the up-to-10-year tax abatement on the new project as it is being built, permitting a 100 percent abatement on real estate taxes for the first year, phasing out to zero abatement in the 10th.
The difference is that the developer's payments during the tax-abatement period would be based on the assessment of the unrenovated property, "to offset the cost of the remediation," said Mr. Bagger. The abatement applies only to sites revived for commercial and industrial use. And it runs only until the developer recoups the cleanup cost, but cannot exceed the 10-year cap, Mr. Bagger said.
While the existing program provides for a tax abatement of up to 15 years, it is based on taxes attributable to the new construction or to the project's projected income.
Under the new law a developer, for its part, must complete the cleanup according to a state approved work plan. Doing so garners other benefits: Zone sites undergo an expedited approval process and their developers are not required to post a bond at the start of the remediation.
In addition, at least 5 percent of the $25 million left in the $55 million state fund set up in 1993 to help developers and municipalities finance cleanups has been reserved for such properties.
Participation in the tax-abatement program is voluntary and relies on the establishment of public-private partnerships.
Karen Waldron, manager of Trenton's six-year-old brownfields project, said that "we're interested in anything that can help draw developers into the city, and this law could be another piece to the puzzle."
"It can't hurt," she added.
Trenton has identified 50 plus brownfield sites and is working to reclaim them. It is also the only city in the state to receive a $200,000 grant under the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's 1993 Brownfields Economic Redevelopment Initiative, which gives such grants to communities to identify sites, determine how much pollution they contain and promote them to developers.
Lawrence D'Andrea, brownfield coordinator at the E.P.A regional office in Manhattan, said that so far 40 communities had received $200,000 grants each and that the last 10 of the 50 allotted to the program would be awarded this June.
"Developers must feel comfortable they will get a return on their investment," he said. "This law is a way to do that."
Ms. Waldron said Trenton initially was investigating three sites to market to developers for re-use and will explore the "possibility of applying the new law" to help achieve that. Among the sites is the former four-acre Champale brewery on Lamberton Street, across from the city's new minor league baseball stadium.
SOME observers say that the law is limited since it does not apply to the re-use of such properties for housing. And others say implementing the law may be difficult at a time when municipalities are struggling with how to diversify their tax base without increasing the burden to homeowners.
Assemblyman Bagger countered that "the idea is to recycle sites that are producing little or no tax revenue, so there is no immediate loss and a definite long-term gain."
Newark, which is facing a property-tax re-evaluation after 39 years, has such a struggle. But it also has identified 130 brownfields that it ultimately would like to bring back to useful life. To that end it is applying for one of the last 10 E.P.A grants, said Joel Freiser, project development officer at the semi-autonomous Newark Economic Development Authority.
"Notwithstanding the pending re-evaluation, I think Newark should also try to use the new law because it offers resources and tools that before now were unavailable," said Mr. Freiser.
New Jersey made it a bit easier to develop such sites in 1993 when it made changes to the state law governing their cleanup. Essentially, the 1993 law, the Industrial Sites Recovery Act, set up different procedures for residential and nonresidential cleanups. It also permits alternative methods including fences and impermeable caps to stop waters from seeping out instead of requiring their removal.
In addition, it has provided other redevelopment incentives, including the creation of the $55 million fund to assist with cleanups.
Yet, the cost of cleaning up such sites and the potential liability risks they still carry remain hurdles. While the law he sponsored provides incentives that will help defray the cost, said Mr. Bagger, it is not "a magic wand and more needs to be done" on the liability side. A provision of the original bill that would have given innocent purchasers of Environmental Opportunity Zone properties immunity from liability for past environmental conditions was deleted.
Mr. Bagger said he would introduce a bill this legislative session to address the liability issue, adding that several others were already in the hopper. "This law combined with closing the liability loophole would give New Jersey a significant brownfields redevelopment policy," he said.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Housing Programs Strained as Cutbacks Take Hold

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
SINCE 1983 Denise Crowell and her two school-aged sons have lived in a two-bedroom apartment at 2665 Decatur Avenue in the Bronx. Her housing has not changed in 12 years, but her living conditions have vastly improved. And her rent has declined.
The building was taken over by the city in 1985, when conditions were dire. Eventually building improvements were made. Ms. Crowell received a Section 8 rent certificate, relieving her of most of the burden of paying rent from her modest welfare allowance. Three years ago the building passed to tenant ownership, under the management of the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation, a nonprofit operator. 
 "It took two years to get the Section 8 certificate," said Ms. Crowell, who hopes to complete her college education when her two sons, now 17 and 12, can support themselves. "Before that I was really scuffling to pay the rent."
The stability that the system of Federal rent payments have brought to Ms. Crowell's life is complemented on a broader scale by the stability it has brought to buildings in lower-income neighborhoods.
Thousands of tenants, whether on public assistance or not, lack the income to pay rent sufficient to maintain decent building conditions. Vouchers or certificates pay the difference between what tenants can pay (figured at 30 percent of their income) and what buildings require to offer decent housing (sometimes called the economic rent).
Tenants who are issued vouchers or certificates use them to go out and find their own housing, in buildings where owners will accept voucher tenants. But sometimes they are made available for tenants in place, as at 2665 Decatur Avenue, to support the economic rent required after rehabilitation.
But Congressional cutbacks are now taking hold. Since summer, new commitments have been frozen, and the 1995 financing of new commitments was actually rescinded. With $16 billion in Federal contracts under these programs expiring by the year 2000, the long-term approach to sustaining housing where these subsidies are already in use is a key national issue. Solutions are unlikely in this Presidential year.
In New York City, Federal rent payments have become a key component of the maintenance of the rental housing stock, especially in high-density, lower-income communities. Another component is the use of privately raised tax-credit financing to supplement city or state capital contributions.
Since the certificates or vouchers go to tenants rather than buildings, their rent contributions form varying percentages of the total rents in different buildings, and often less than 20 percent.
The work of the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation in the West Bronx shows how housing improvement activity in low-income districts relies upon the Federal rent program . The corporation manages 55 buildings with 1,250 apartments in an area just north and south of Fordham Road.
"Probably 40 percent of our tenants are on some form of public assistance and almost all our tenants have income under $25,000 a year," said John M. Reilly, executive director of the corporation. "Some of those tenants on welfare just eke by."
BUT over-all the housing is well maintained because vouchers or certificates are available for about 20 percent of the tenants. A handful of buildings Fordham Bedford manages are still city-owned and in the rehabilitation pipeline.
"In time we're going to find it harder and harder to find tenants able to pay the rent we have to charge," Mr. Reilly said. His concern is that if the Government starts supplying funds to the state in block grants, as is sometimes suggested in the debate in Washington over the administration of social programs, "Will these tenants already getting assistance continue to get it?"
At 2352 Walton Avenue, Diane Hoard is a tenant who has hung on for years during decline under private ownership and stabilization in city hands. Now the 25-unit building has been rehabilitated; she contributed $250 from public assistance for her apartment and a Federal subsidy will pay the rest of the $508 rent when the building transfers next month to nonprofit ownership.
She is raising her granddaughter, Stephanie Mercado, after having raised four children who are now adults with little help from the mother, who lives elsewhere. She says she is thrilled to have the new management of the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation. "It makes us feel good that someone out there is listening to us when something goes wrong," she said.
The rent-up of the moderately rehabilitated vacant apartments is still under way. The very-low-income tenants in place already have their commitment for rent certificates, assuring economic rents for their 15 apartments.
But the lack of new Federal commitments has held up city-assisted rehabilitations of 30,000 apartments planned in 1994 through 1996, said Deborah C. Wright, Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development. About 9,000 certificates are needed for tenants who are to move into these apartments.
Over-all the housing agency has about 11,000 tenant-based certificates or vouchers in use under various rehabilitation programs. And 3,200 more that were issued by the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal are also in use in the city.
But the principal issuer of housing vouchers and certificates in the city is the Housing Authority. Since the program began in 1976 it has issued them to 71,000 households, officials said. Tenants who get them show up in all sorts of buildings. Housing Authority officials say that 15,700 vouchers or certificates are in use in rent-stabilized postwar apartments; 17,900 are in one- to five-family buildings; 26,600 in older rental buildings and the rest are scattered throughout the publicly assisted housing stock.
On average, tenants with vouchers pay only $138 a month of their own money as rent; the average true rent for the apartment is $628 a month.
FOR the entire country, 305,000 vouchers and 1.8 million Section 8 certificates are outstanding. The cost to the Government is about $6.5 billion a year in tenant-based subsidies alone, or $4,950 an apartment a year. But in the budget-cutting atmosphere in Congress, there have been no new commitments in the last two years.
"The appropriations are being eaten up by renewals, and no new families are coming in," said W. Donald Campbell, a Washington housing consultant.
Among the programs now threatened are the city's efforts to rehouse homeless people who have spent months in city shelters.
"Going forward, we won't be able to set aside empty apartments for the homeless unless we can find a new source of subsidy," said Marc Jahr, program director for the Local Initiatives Support Corporation (LISC), which gets the private capital for many low-income rehabilitations.
In projects assisted by LISC, 30 percent of the tenants come from the city's shelter system and usually derive all their income from public assistance.
Already the financial planning for projects in development reflects the decline in Federal subsidies. In the early days of the city's rehabilitation programs, tax-credit financing could be used to lower the city's cost of construction. Now the money raised through LISC is being used to support operating reserves. The city carries the full cost of rehabilitation.
Amid the cutbacks in financing for low-income housing, at least one major project managed to get in under the wire. State commitments to the rehabilitation of the former Morrisania Hospital on East 168th Street in the Bronx into a development called Urban Horizons -- sufficiently generous to make rent certificates or vouchers unnecessary -- were made in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's administration. They have been honored by the Pataki administration.
Construction has therefore begun on a project that represents the effort to provide "more than housing." Besides 132 apartments, Urban Horizons will have space for day care, health care and job training. At a community kitchen, home-based mothers will be able to run a catering business.
This $23 million project is getting $6.3 million in 1 percent financing from the state's Housing Trust Fund; $4.5 million from the state's Department of Social Services and $11 million in tax-credit financing, of which $3 million is for operating reserves. The developer is the Women's Housing & Economic Development Corporation, a Manhattan-based nonprofit company whose executive director is Nancy Biberman. The architect for the project is Becker & Becker Associates of New Canaan, Conn.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rendering of rebuilt Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx. (Becker & Becker Associates, New Canaan, Conn.); Diane Hoard and her granddaughter in their apartment. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (95%); CONNECTICUT, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Pine Barrens Landowners Say Rights Are Denied

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
ALL Joseph F. Gazza wants, he says, is a way to use property he owns in the Central Pine Barrens or a way of selling it at a fair price.
His 222 acres lie within the 52,500-acre core of a protected 100,000-acre watershed area in eastern Suffolk known as the Central Pine Barrens, which was established by the Long Island Pine Barrens Protection Act of 1993. Virtually all development in the core has been stopped under the law. 
 Only 12,000 acres of vacant land in the core are still privately owned. The rest of the land either already is publicly owned or otherwise protected or already developed. Controlled development can continue on the 47,600 acres abutting the core, which has been designated a compatible growth area.
Earlier this month, Mr. Gazza, a Quogue lawyer who is one of 3,200 owners of vacant land in the core, was told by state officials that his hardship application had been denied and that he could not build any houses on the 9.8 acres he owns fronting the Riverhead-Moriches Road in Remsenburg.
The same day, his application to plant beach grass on 6.5 acres he owns on Westhampton-Riverhead Road in Westhampton also was denied on the ground that the property's natural vegetation would be disturbed.
"I have now written state officials a letter to which they have not yet responded, that they either let me use my land, or that they buy it, or find me a buyer for my transfer of development rights," Mr. Gazza said. "If they don't, I will then have been deprived of the full use of my property and I will then have a case with which to go to court."
Mr. Gazza said he was using the Remsenburg and Westhampton properties, which front on highways in developed areas, "as key test pieces to see what the Pine Barrens people are going to do with property owners with similar situations."
His frustrations are shared by many other owners who feel their property rights have been taken away, while they continue to pay full taxes and payments on any mortgages they owe.
About 500 owners have formed Civil Property Rights Associates, which plans to file a lawsuit in Federal Court challenging the constitutionality of the 1993 statute.
"They are creating a preserve on the backs of people who own the land," said John J. O'Connell, a Manhattan lawyer who represents the group. "If this preserve was created for the benefit of all the people of Long Island and New York State, then all the people should pay for the land they are trying to acquire."
The fair way would be for the state to pass a bond issue and purchase the property from the owners at fair market value, Mr. O'Connell said, adding; "At the moment, if they are lucky they get a pittance. And if they are unlucky, nothing happens while they continue to pay their taxes."
THE 100,000-acre Central Pine Barrens tract extends generally from Route 25A south to Sunrise Highway starting at Exit 63 of the Long Island Expressway and ending just west of the Shinnecock Canal. About 60 percent of the area is in Brookhaven, 30 percent is in Southampton and 10 percent is in Riverhead.
State officials point out that owners in the core area have several ways to use or dispose of their land.
Development permits can be granted under a hardship provision of the law. Land that had development approvals prior to the statute can still be developed. A land acquisition program is under way, financed in part by state allocations and in part by a special quarter-penny sales tax first adopted by Suffolk County in 1987 and in force until 2000.
Finally, a key component of the plan is a development-rights transfer mechanism known as the Pine Barrens Credit Program, which allows owners to receive credits for their property in return for granting conservation easements. The allocation is based on the property's size and zoning. Credits can be used to increase density on land outside the core area.
Landowners must apply to receive a letter of interpretation of how many credits they could receive for their land. The determination can be appealed. About 24 applications have been filed and 12 determinations have been made. The proposed allocations range from 40.43 credits to 0.10 credits, but 7 of the 12 are less than one credit. A full credit is needed to increase density by one unit above what is otherwise allowed outside the core area.
Although the goal is outright purchase of 75 percent of the 12,000 privately owned acres, the credit program, which is expected to affect only 3,000 acres, is important because "it attempts to maintain some of the growth that would have occurred," said Raymond P. Corwin, executive director of the Central Pine Barrens Joint Planning and Policy Commission.
To that end, the commission, which administers a comprehensive land-use plan adopted under the statute, recently created a credit clearinghouse, which has received $5 million from the state to purchase credits from landowners. The clearinghouse may will then sell the credits to developers.
Credits may also be sold privately by landowners on the open market in negotiated deals, but the clearinghouse will only pay a fixed amount, which has not yet been determined.
Special receiving zones have been established where credits can be used as of right. In other areas, builders would have to seek a variance to use them. Critics argue that communities in receiving zones are going to be unduly burdened by higher density.
Builders support the program. "It accomplishes two things," said Edwin M. Schwenk, the executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute. "It saves the taxpayer money and it helps economic development."
But owners say that these proposals to compensate them are deceptive. For one, they note, there are not enough public funds available to acquire their land, so that purchase offers, which they also feel are largely unfair, could be years away while they must continue to pay full taxes on land they cannot use.
SINCE 1993, the state and county have bought 2,156 acres, generally paying $7,500 to $10,000 an acre. The state has so far appropriated $20 million; the county has spent $12.4 million and has pledged $12 million more through the year 2000, when the quarter-penny tax expires.
But, said Henry R. Dittmer, vice president of Civil Property Rights Associates, $250 million is needed to buy the remaining 12,000 privately owned acres in the core area at a fair-market value.
Owners also fear that if they give up their development rights in return for credits, the credits will be almost valueless. Expectations are that builders will pay less than $10,000 a credit. Because of the core's five-acre zoning, residential property holders will be allotted one credit for every 5.5 acres they own.
"They are placing values on land that are ridiculously low," said Walter H. Olsen of Flanders, the president of Civil Property Rights Associates. "The thing we are fighting for and the only thing we will settle for is fair market value for the properties involved."
But some builders say that owners have exaggerated notions of what their land is worth. Because of market conditions and zoning restrictions "much of the land in the Pine Barrens is not worth very much," said Donald M. Eversoll, a Commack builder.
"The principal issue raised by the Pine Barrens Act is whether the state can say to a property owner, 'You no longer have the use of your land, and the way you will be reimbursed for your loss is a Pine Barrens credit,' " said William W. Esseks, a Riverhead lawyer.
He is representing the W.J.F. Realty Corporation and Reed Rubin of Manhattan in a case against the county and the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, which has been brought in State Supreme Court in Riverhead. W.J.F. owns 278 industrially zoned acres in Southampton.
"If the state comes in and takes your house, wouldn't you want want just compensation, even if it's over a water source?" Mr. Esseks said.
"The Federal and state constitutions say the state can take property but not without due process, which means compensation -- meaning money," he said. "The state assumes here that due process means transfer of development rights. We don't think that's true, and this case will determine that."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Southbridge, Mass.;
Future Brightens for Depressed Massachusetts Town

BYLINE: By MICKY BACA 

DATELINE: SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
MORE than a decade after its major employer took most of its operations and jobs elsewhere, this small community in south-central Massachusetts is still trying to work its way back to full recovery. With help from the Department of Defense, it is now taking a major step forward.
The American Optical Corporation was once the lifeblood of a sprawling mill complex here and the largest manufacturer of eyeglasses in the world. But it has steadily reduced its local work force from 4,000 in the 70's to just a little over 200 today. While the company, which was founded in 1869, still owns the 150-acre, 1.3-million-square-foot, 14-building complex it now operates in just 200,000 square feet of what is now known as the Southbridge Business Center. 
 Now the Department of Defense is about to establish a finance and accounting training school in the 370,000-square-foot building that was formerly American Optical headquarters. Congress approved $88.8 million for the project in January and President Clinton endorsed it in February.
The measure authorizes $19.6 million for training and the rest for a 20-year lease with American Optical, according to John Raines, director of the Defense Business Management University, an agency of the Department of Defense.
Robert Miller, senior vice president of Franklin Realty Advisers, which is handling the development of the Southbridge Business Center for American Optical, said the company and the Defense Department were about to begin negotiating a lease agreement.
The training of finance and accounting personnel, now done piecemeal in offices throughout the country, will be consolidated at the school here. It will have 20 to 30 classrooms and 326 residential rooms where some 8,100 trainees a year are expected to live during their training. Mr. Raines said that 5,000 more people a year outside of Southbridge will get instruction through teleconferencing using satellite technology or through traveling teachers.
While the school is only expected to employ 450 to 500 people, community and company officials say it will generate spin-off businesses and a renewed interest in Southbridge.
"To get people back into the complex is the very best chance we have," said Southbridge Town Manager Florence Chandler, who helped lead a community campaign to bring the training school to her town. "This is a company town. Everybody relied on them for employment. I think the pendulum is about to swing back in Southbridge."
FOR Southbridge, a community of 17,000 that is considered the birthplace of the optical industry in the United States, landing the Defense Department center was a civic triumph.
In 1993, the town was one of three finalists in line for a much larger facility, an accounting center employing 4,000 people. But the late Les Aspin, who was then Secretary of Defense, decided that rather than concentrating the operation in one city he would spread it over five large cities, according to Ms. Chandler. "It was quite a shock," Ms. Chandler said. "It was like being handed a medal for crossing the finish line and then being told the race was canceled."
After an extensive civic campaign and a push by the local Congressional delegation, Southbridge was chosen for the smaller training center last May. The project had been wending its way through Congressional channels since then, stalled in part by partisan wrangling over the Federal budget.
American Optical now hopes to begin renovations and 100,000 square feet of additions to the century-old brick headquarters building to accommodate the Defense Department project by late summer, according to Mr. Miller. The company will use privately marketed bonds to finance the construction, which is expected to take some 18 months, said John van Dyke, American Optical's senior vice president and chief financial officer.
There is other activity at the Southbridge Business Center as well. A newly formed nonprofit fiber-optics organization called the Center for Advanced Fiberoptic Applications recently set up an office in 3,000 square feet. The group was set up by regional private fiber-optic companies, Massachusetts Electric Company and the University of Massachusetts to do applied research for fiber optics.
Mr. Miller said the center was expected to "create a new company or two every six months" and should attract people from all over the country. He envisions the business center -- which he says is now half full with about a dozen tenants other than American Optical -- as incubation space for such new ventures.
Ironically, Mr. Miller said, it was American optical scientists who were the first in the 1950's to discover fiber optics, but it did not emerge as a major focus for the company.
American Optical has been a subsidiary of M & R Industries of Greenwich, Conn., since 1982, when it was purchased from Warner Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, which had owned it since 1967. Before that it was a family-owned company, run by descendants of George Washington Wells, who incorporated the company in 1869. Wells worked with a jeweler named William Beecher, who began making spectacles here in 1833. Before that, most spectacles were imported from Europe.
BY the turn of the century, Southbridge had become home to the largest optical plant in the world. Most of the town's residents worked at the plant, walking there from the triple-decker housing that still dominates its downtown. It was a place of solid employment opportunities and business prosperity. Today, however, said Charlene Gravel, the town's Community Development Director, Southbridge is ranked 326th of the state's 351 municipalities in per capita income.
American Optical is still a major manufacturer of optical products, employing 1,200 people in Mexico, France, the United Kingdom, Singapore and Canada, according to Mr. van Dyke. In 1982, when M & R Industries bought it, American Optical was still the area's largest employer, with 2,500 workers. According to Mr. van Dyke, M & R Industries began consolidating the company's Southbridge operations to make them more efficient. By 1987, the company had cut its local work force to 1,400. American Optical sold off several divisions and, in 1992, moved its plastic lens manufacturing operations from Southbridge to Tijuana, Mexico.
"The ophthalmic industry is a global industry," said Mr. van Dyke. "Long term, we couldn't compete in a high cost labor environment."
In the late 80's, American Optical decided to begin marketing the portions of its mill complex that it no longer utilized. At that time, some 600,000 square feet of the 19th century complex was vacant.
While the complex is accessible to several major highways and is half an hour from Worcester and no more than an hour from Boston, Providence, R.I., and Hartford, marketing its space was hindered by a recession in the real estate market in the late 80's and early 90's, Mr. van Dyke said.
Michael Coughlin, a lawyer who has worked as a liaison between the Defense Department and Southbridge, said the process of seeking the project re-energized the community. "The citizens learned how to utilize the system, put aside their differences and work together," he said. "You have some of the best technology in the world concentrated in this area."

HEADLINE: Q & A

 BODY:

Decontrol At the End Of a J-51
 
Q I moved into a rent-stabilized apartment in 1978. Though I signed a lease for it, I asked to be put on the waiting list for another unit in the same building on a different floor. When the other unit became available in 1986 I was transferred to it. I was not given a new lease for that apartment until 1988, at which time I learned that the apartment was receiving a J-51 tax abatement. Does that mean that when the tax abatement expires my apartment will be decontrolled even though my first lease in the same building was signed in 1978? I am paying over $2,000 a month for the unit. Does this have any bearing on my situation? . . . Salvator Sciallo, Manhattan.
 
A Sherwin Belkin, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that in most cases, rent-stabilization rules apply to the housing accommodation rather than the tenant. Accordingly, he said, the fact that the letter-writer may have occupied another apartment in the building prior to moving to his present apartment in 1986 is irrelevant for regulatory purposes. 
 "Of course, the parties could have contracted for the tenant's rights in his former apartment to travel with him," Mr. Belkin said. "But absent such an agreement, the tenant would only have such rights as are attached to his present apartment."
Based upon the date the tenant moved into his present apartment, Mr. Belkin said, he would normally be subject to decontrol if each lease for the apartment contained a clause advising that the apartment would be decontrolled upon the expiration of the J-51 tax benefits, along with the approximate date of expiration.
"But the fact that the tenant states that he was not given a lease for the apartment until 1988, although he moved in in 1986, may create an issue as to the applicability of decontrol based upon J51 expiration," Mr. Belkin said.
The amount of the rent being paid, he said, would not have any direct bearing on decontrol of the apartment upon J-51 expiration. However, Mr. Belkin said, the tenant might be subject to decontrol if his household income for the past two calendar years exceeded $250,000 each year and the landlord has made the appropriate application with the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
 
Special Assessment Tax Deductibility
 
Q You recently answered a question concerning the tax deductibility of special condominium assessments by indicating that, while not deductible, such expenses would probably be for improvements to the common areas of the building and, therefore, allowable as increases to the unit owner's cost basis. Does this apply to co-op apartments also? . . . John P. Strang, Manhattan.
 
A "The rules are similar," said Fred H. Weinshank, a Manhattan tax accountant.
Generally, Mr. Weinshank said, shareholders in a co-op may deduct only that portion of their maintenance charges attributable to real property taxes and interest on the co-op's mortgage. Payments applied toward maintenance or capital improvements, he said, are not deductible.
Under certain conditions, however, a shareholder may be allowed to use his or her proportionate share of a capital improvement expense to increase the cost basis of the shareholder's apartment for tax purposes. (Increasing the cost basis of an asset, Mr. Weinshank said, results in a decrease in taxable gain when the asset is sold.)
For shareholders to be able to use capital-improvement costs to increase the cost basis of their apartments, Mr. Weinshank said, three conditions must be met: There must first be a special assessment for the improvement; the assessment collected must be specifically earmarked for the improvement and the money collected as the result of the assessment must be kept in a segregated account used only for the improvement.
Special assessments for maintenance items like painting, he said, would not qualify.
