HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
Across the State, Teachers Settle for a Slower Rise in Pay

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
New Jersey's teachers are among the best paid in the nation, with an average salary of $45,000. But in recent years, they have been settling for the smallest wage increases since 1968, when the state first allowed collective bargaining for teachers.
After more than a decade of contracts that provided annual raises of at least 8 percent, most teachers' unions have been accepting increases of 5 percent or less since 1993. Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, said the downward trend started in 1991, when the recession was at its peak. Since then, Governor Whitman's tax cuts and a growing dissatisfaction with public schools have increased pressure for unions to accept more modest contracts, he said. 
 "Communities have been telling boards of education that they want a firmer hand at the negotiating table," Mr. Belluscio said. "We're seeing settlement rates come further down every quarter of every year."
For 166 school districts whose teacher contracts expired in 1995, the average salary increase for 1995-96 was 4.52 percent, according to the School Boards Association. That amounts to about $2,050, based on an average teacher's salary of $45,350. For three-year contracts, the total wage increase has ranged from 9 percent in Riverside, a small Burlington County district, to 17.3 percent in Sayreville, a large Middlesex County district. A district's location and wealth does not seem to have much bearing on contract settlements -- teachers in the wealthy northern counties, whose salaries are usually higher, are generally getting the same raises as those in southern counties where the per capita income is lower.
"Teachers go to the bargaining table with a very real idea of what the economy is like," said Ed Gallagher, a spokesman for the New Jersey Education Association, which represents 130,000 teachers, bus drivers and other school employees. "Nobody ever went into this business to get rich."
But even though public school teachers are agreeing to more modest raises, they have been more successful at the bargaining table than professors at New Jersey's public colleges and universities. Last month, unionized faculty members at nine state colleges agreed to a 6.25 percent wage increase over four years. Meanwhile, the faculty union at Rutgers University is planning job actions because union leaders are so unhappy with the salaries and benefits that the administration is offering. The contract for that union's 4,100 members expired last summer, and mediators have not helped the two sides settle their differences.
Because school boards have adopted more rigid bargaining positions, new teacher contracts take longer to negotiate, and more local unions are calling for job actions to protest the delay, Mr. Belluscio said. In particular, he said, teachers have refused to attend after-school events, have taken unscheduled days off and, in a few cases, have refused to grade homework or write college recommendations. Teachers in two districts -- South River in Middlesex County and Monroe in Gloucester County -- went on strike for several days in 1995, but in both cases the school board did not meet all of the union's demands.
Along with smaller raises, teacher unions are accepting longer work days and school years, Mr. Belluscio said. In Metuchen, a Middlesex County district, teachers agreed this month to add one teaching day to the school year and 10 minutes of instructional time to each school day. And in Monroe, the Gloucester County district where teachers went on strike last September, the union agreed to 20 extra minutes of class time each day.
Mr. Belluscio said that none of the changes in collective bargaining were surprising, especially since New Jersey's 600 school districts are preparing for a new financing system that will force them to be more efficient than ever. The system, which is being developed by Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz, is intended to meet a court order requiring that students around the state receive a thorough and efficient education, regardless of how much money their district can spend. At a conference last weekend, members of the School Boards Assocation suggested that school districts should become even more prudent with salaries and benefits, which take up about 75 percent of the roughly $11.5 billion the state and local districts spend each year on education.
In particular, the association is recommending changes to the lifetime tenure system that was started in 1909 to discourage patronage hiring. Instead of granting all teachers automatic tenure after three years on the job, the association wants a system of "renewable contract employment," in which teachers would be re-evaluated every three to five years and districts would have the option of dismissing them.
Mr. Belluscio says the time is ripe for tenure reform because a disproportionate number of teachers are preparing to retire, and they will be replaced by young teachers starting from scratch. But Mr. Gallagher said the New Jersey Education Association would fight changes to the tenure system, because teachers already receive yearly evaluations and job protection is more important than ever if the Legislature approves the new financing plan.
"The Commissioner has not yet defined what he means by efficiencies," Mr. Gallagher said. "But all indications are that he equates efficient with cheap."

HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Paul J. McCarthy;
How Corporations Obtain a Bond Rating

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
WHEN a corporation or a government wants to issue bonds, it goes to a company like Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company. It is the job of the company to examine the would-be bond issuer, assess its credit worthiness and give the bonds a rating.
Paul J. McCarthy of Chappaqua is chairman and chief executive officer of Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, which has its main offices in Manhattan, a major office in Chicago and affiliates throughout South America. Some of the large area corporations whose bonds it rates are I.B.M., Nynex, Pepsico, Philip Morris, General Motors, Consolidated Edison, the Bank of New York and M.C.I. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. McCarthy: 
 Q. What exactly does your company do?
A. Let me first indicate what it does not do. We don't issue credit reports on individuals. We're a nationally recognized statistical rating organization by the S.E.C. We publish credit ratings or bond ratings on fixed-income securities; we're talking about notes or bonds or preferred stocks.
Q. Are you also involved with government bonds?
A. We do some government. But it's mostly corporation and asset-backed securities. Most of what we do are taxable fixed-income securities, but we do some ratings on municipal credits.
Q. Does a company come to you and choose you to rate them?
A. We do not do unsolicited ratings. We only do ratings where we have access to management and where we have the ability to get the information that we need in order to create the securities.
Q. Can a company shop around for a rating, so to speak -- meaning if it doesn't like the rating it gets from one firm, try another?
A. Well, basically there are very few statistical-rating organizations. One of the things that we do is that we tend to bring senior-level people to the ratings meetings and we tend to communicate our information to institutional investors. We have relationships with institutional investors who very frequently request our rating.
Q. Companies care about your opinion because their bonds are more marketable if you give it a good rating, correct?
A. Typically the higher the rating, the lower the interest cost that the company has to pay. Also it broadens the market. Higher rated securities have a broader market than, for example, a junk bond or a lower rated security.
Q. Aren't some bonds insured, in which case people might give less weight to the rating?
A. They are insured, but frankly people care about the quality of the insurer. It's part of our business to rate insurance companies.
Q. In judging a bond to determine its rating, what factors go into the equation and is the state of the economy a factor?
A. Let me first define what a bond rating is. It's basically an opinion of the bond issuer's long-term fundamental strength. I emphasize long term. What we are trying to assess is the likelihood that the corporation will make ultimate and timely repayment of the rated issue in accordance with the terms under which it was sold. We communicate that in terms of symbols -- double-A, triple-A, single-A, triple-B, and so forth.
Basically, what we are trying to assess is the issuer's ability to withstand whatever cycles it is likely to go through and its financial strength throughout that period. We look at things like its ability to generate cash flow relative to cash needs to assess whether it can repay its debt. So we would have to take into consideration whether the economy stinks or not. And we do expect that there will be certain stress points over a time span. We would expect for some companies that are cyclical that they would be stressed more during periods of economic instability.
Q. What's the methodology of analyzing?
A. We would get the financial statements of the company. We would have our analysts go through these statements, try to understand the basic business, what drives the business. We would probably have several meetings with management and go into strategic items as to how they intend to manage the business. After a series of ratings and evaluations of the indenture and the legal side of it, we would have a committee meeting and issue a rating.
Now some of the factors that we would look at would then be the type of company, the industry it's in, how stable its business is, how fast it's growing, what its capital requirements are, how they would intend to finance the business -- whether they'd use a lot of short-term debt or a lot of long-term debt. We would assess the equity part of it. And you have to assess the suitability of all those things and, given that structure, the company's ability to service its debt over time.
Q. What are the trends out there versus, say, 10 years ago?
A. There are some trends. A lot of the buyouts and financial engineering that went on 10 years ago has subsided. So, frankly, we see debt being used more for the basic businesses than we saw a number of years ago. We think there is a more rational use of debt than there was 10 years ago.
Q. Have you been very wrong on some companies you've rated?
A. Well, things do change. You make certain assumptions that a company is going to operate in a certain way and maybe a new management comes in and makes drastic changes. Those things are often surprises to us, but we do react. If we're not yet ready to change our rating, we put the bonds on a watch list and inform the general public.
Q. Does it become a hard decision to downgrade a bond, or is is really almost a mathematical formula?
A. It's not mathematical. We continually monitor these credit levels and when you set a credit level you hope to be able to maintain it over a long period. But frankly, from time to time and through the monitoring process, changes occur. You want to make sure you are right in what you do. So you ask a lot of questions, you go through a lot of projections, and you come up with whatever rating you feel is appropriate.
Q. What are the consequences of defaulting? Did people's lives change when New York City defaulted, for example?
A. I think -- and I'm not an expert on this -- that New York City has its own unique set of problems. The county of Westchester is one of the strongest credits in the municipal market so it would be a different situation. But one of the reasons New York City defaulted was that they weren't going to close down certain essential services that took priority over the bonds. So they had a restructuring of their debt. And they set up the Municipal Acceptance Corporation. But I think there was a change in how things were done after that -- they had to come toward a balanced budget, and certain austerity things were set in place. And it certainly did affect the level of municipal services for a certain period.
Q. If a firm fails to pay its bonds, say for a day or two only, does it really matter?
A. Yes, it matters. It depends on how it was rated, obviously. But you would probably have a very significant rating change, and it would very much impact their ability to sell bonds in the future. Investors would have a much lower confidence level. Investors want the issue to perform in accordance with the indenture, That means timely payment. If investors require interest at a certain point in time, they want to get it. Trust is very, very important.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 3208 words

HEADLINE: Muddy Water

BYLINE: By Thomas Powers; Thomas Powers is the author of several books on politics and current affairs. His most recent book is "Heisenberg's War: The Secret History of the German Bomb."

 BODY:

BLOOD SPORT
The President and His Adversaries.
By James B. Stewart.
Illustrated. 479 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25.
In the annals of greed and easy credit, few land purchases look dumber in retrospect than the one that closed at the Citizens Bank and Trust Company in the town of Flippin, Ark., at 10 A.M. on Aug. 2, 1978. It was dumb because much of the 230 acres was brush-covered and inaccessible by road; because only part of it fronted on the White River, which was its sole attraction; because the price of $203,000 was double what its sellers had agreed to pay for it only months earlier; because the entire purchase price was borrowed and the loan would have to be repaid or refinanced at the end of six months; because even a quick resale of the 44 projected lots promised at best a modest profit; because interest rates were about to go through the roof; because the principal active partner, James McDougal, had the attention span of a rat terrier; and because the principal passive partner, Hillary Rodham, was married to a man she expected to be President someday. 
 The fateful die had been cast one evening in a Little Rock restaurant called the Black-Eyed Pea when Ms. Rodham and her husband, Bill Clinton, who was running for governor of Arkansas that summer, chanced upon their friends Jim McDougal and his wife, Susan. Mr. McDougal was full of excitement about the piece of land he'd just seen; he invited the Clintons to join him in the deal -- no money necessary, he'd take care of everything. Mr. Clinton and his wife were both graduates of the Yale Law School, but they might have been rubes at a country fair. They said they'd love to go in on the deal.
The Clintons have now had 18 years to reflect on all the omens of failure that should have been obvious from the beginning. Their sole motive was hope of a quick buck. They knew nothing about real estate or land development or the financial strength of their partners. They never saw the land they were buying, never met the bankers lending them the money, did not attend the closing, had no money to pay back the loan if it was called and were potentially liable for the whole of the borrowed sum plus interest in the event that the project failed and their partners were broke.
The history of this ill-conceived and highly speculative enterprise, formally known as the Whitewater Development Company Inc., comes to splendid life in one of the best books on American politics in recent years, James B. Stewart's "Blood Sport: The President and His Adversaries." Mr. Stewart was invited to undertake the book in March 1994 by Susan Thomases, a friend of Mrs. Clinton who plays an occasional role in the story herself. But after one 90-minute meeting with Mr. Stewart, Mrs. Clinton apparently changed her mind, saw him no more and, according to recent Washington rumor, has been biting her nails in nervous anticipation of what Mr. Stewart will say.
It is not hard to see why she is worried. Hillary Rodham Clinton is at or close to the center of every episode gathered under the big tent called Whitewater. She supported the original Whitewater investment and tenaciously held on to the Clinton family half for 14 years. With the help of an Arkansas friend, she turned $1,000 into nearly $100,000 in less than a year trading cattle futures, then sought refuge behind the claim, ridiculous on its face, that she had made all her own buy and sell orders, basing them on her reading of The Wall Street Journal. As a partner in the prestigious Rose Law Firm of Little Rock she represented the savings-and-loan bank owned by Mr. McDougal, which went bust in 1989, costing the taxpayers $68 million. She brought her close friend and Rose partner Vincent Foster to Washington, and after he committed suicide she was suspected of ending up in possession of Whitewater files that had been in Foster's office when he died. An attempt to fire the seven employees of the White House travel office and give the business to a Clinton crony is said to have been prompted by Mrs. Clinton's demand that the job slots be made available for "our people." About all of these matters Mrs. Clinton and people speaking for her have said things that are thickly defended by lawyerly constructions like "As best I can recall. . . ."
Bill Clinton has weathered his share of hard questions about the past. In the 1992 Presidential primaries he was nearly knocked out by a one-two combination of tabloid sleaze involving, first, his alleged Little Rock girlfriend Gennifer Flowers and, second, a painfully extended deconstruction of his explanation of how he avoided the draft during the Vietnam War. But Mr. Clinton's reputation as a screw-up is cast into shadow by the chain of troubles centering on Mrs. Clinton, which Mr. Stewart lays before us in gripping detail, and the portrait of her character that emerges in "Blood Sport" is a troubling one.
In their single meeting Mr. Stewart found Mrs. Clinton an attractive person, vital and lively, and many others say much the same. But her responses to the public's questions about her motives and behavior reveal a closed, secretive and rigid personality. William Safire, a columnist for this newspaper, has called Mrs. Clinton a "congenital liar," and she has certainly made some statements that seem conspicuously unsupported by the available evidence -- the denial, for example, that she took more than a passing interest in the travel office affair; the denial that she ever did much legal work for Mr. McDougal's bank; the assertion (soon dropped) that she made all that money in cattle futures without help. But to label these claims lies is to miss the character trait that appears to inspire them. Mrs. Clinton seems to have carried into adult life the world view of a little girl determined to be perfect. She did not spill the milk; the cat spilled the milk, her friend spilled the milk, the milk only looks spilled, it is not actually milk. . . . With each question and response the jaw clenches tighter and the lips draw thinner.
Mrs. Clinton is not going to enjoy reading this book. But she may console herself that she was wise to let Mr. Stewart do his research and reach his conclusions on his own. "Blood Sport" is by far the most complete, the best and the fairest account of the Clintons and their troubles to date, and it concludes that the Whitewater grab bag of scandal, controversy and unanswered questions does not justify the attention it has received. The land deal was stupid but not criminal; the Clintons, and especially Mrs. Clinton, did many things in Arkansas and later that were stupid but not criminal; and their attempts to respond to the hailstorm of charges against them have been variously na<arrow up>ve, impetuous, evasive, foolish, misleading and stupid, but not criminal. If Mr. Stewart -- a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and the author of several books, including "Den of Thieves" -- were the independent counsel in the Whitewater affair, the Clintons could rest easy.
The story Mr. Stewart tells is simple in outline. The few Whitewater lots the McDougals managed to sell brought only a trickle of installment income, rarely enough even to pay interest on the loan. In the first year the Clintons were required to come up with $22,620 in working capital, thereafter with additional sums periodically; Mr. McDougal coughed up even more. The McDougals and the Clintons both lost all the money they put into the project, and the tax deductions they claimed (in some cases wrongly) at best only soothed the pain.
Easy credit is the mother's milk of real estate speculation, and like many another aspirant tycoon of the 1980's Mr. McDougal tried to secure a flow of ready cash through the purchase of his own bank, a recently deregulated savings-and-loan institution that he renamed Madison Guaranty. In the eight years he ran it Mr. McDougal managed to lend himself, his businesses and various friends and partners (but not the Clintons) quite a lot of money that could not be paid back. Along the way, probably at Mr. Clinton's request (although Mr. Clinton denies it), Madison Guaranty retained Mrs. Clinton's law firm to help it with a preferred stock offering and to perform other legal services.
In the years between the original Whitewater investment in 1978 and the company's formal dissolution in 1992, the McDougals and the Clintons encountered many opportunities for the commission of blunders, crimes and misdemeanors. Among the blunders, pride of place must go to Mrs. Clinton's rejection of three separate offers by the McDougals to take over her share of Whitewater with all its attendant troubles. In 1985, when Mr. Clinton called up furious about Whitewater's failure to pay property taxes, Mr. McDougal offered to assume all remaining liabilities and obligations in return for the Clintons' half of the company. "Fine with me," said Mr. Clinton. "Just run it by Hillary."
But Mrs. Clinton was convinced the McDougals were trying to pull a fast one. She was furious, Mr. Stewart says. "Jim told me that this was going to pay for college for Chelsea," she told Susan McDougal. "I still expect it to do that!" Her response was much the same again in 1990 and early 1992.
When Mrs. Clinton wakes up in the middle of the night to fret, she probably asks herself why, oh why, did she hold on to that worthless stock? Trouble has been the only reward.
But it isn't Whitewater, the land deal gone sour, that has haunted the Clintons since Jeff Gerth, a reporter for The New York Times, first brought it to public attention in March 1992. The real trouble began more than a year later with the suicide of Vincent Foster.
Mr. Stewart walks the reader through this tragic affair with great care and considerable narrative art. Books on current events are not often written with this much attention to effect. To cite only one example that I particularly admired: the book opens with the discovery of Foster's body in Washington's Fort Marcy Park. When the park police informed Foster's wife, Lisa, later that evening, she asked, with reference to the gun, "Did he put it in his mouth?" It is a chilling and disturbing question; the policeman (like the reader) immediately wonders why she has asked him that. The detail intensifies the air of violence and mystery that did so much to impress the whole Whitewater affair on the public imagination in the first place. That incident is on page 32.
On page 287 Mr. Stewart returns to this subject, but by now the air of ominous mystery has been largely dispelled and we understand fully the slow accretion of pain and self-doubt that led to Foster's suicide. Shortly before he killed himself, Mr. Stewart now tells us, Foster watched the film "A Few Good Men," in which one of the characters cannot bear to testify against an old friend in a murder case. Instead he puts a pistol into his mouth and fires.
This is narrative writing of a high order. It is representative of the book, which is rich with beautifully drawn characters and dramatic incidents. The obvious care with which Mr. Stewart has gone about his work lends weight to his conclusion that Foster's death was a suicide only tangentially connected to his White House duties. The effect is thoroughly to dampen the dark suspicions aroused when it was learned that one of Foster's White House jobs had been to prepare tax returns for the Whitewater project and, more ominous still, that the Whitewater files in Foster's office at the time of his death had been turned over to the Clintons. Mrs. Clinton's role in this matter, and especially what she and others in her employ have said about her role, have done as much as the relentless Senate hearings led by Alfonse D'Amato to keep the Whitewater affair alive. Contributing to the air of mystery surrounding Foster's suicide may have been Mrs. Clinton's biggest blunder of all.
But blunders are not indictable offenses. Those, if any, remain to be identified by Kenneth W. Starr, the former Federal judge appointed to serve as independent counsel in the Whitewater affair. Many observers seriously doubt that it is possible, either practically or constitutionally, to indict a sitting President for a crime. The President's wife, of course, is unprotected, but in any case the counsel's final report is not expected until after the election in November. In the meantime, the lesson relentlessly driven home by "Blood Sport" is that no progress to high political office in American life is proof against the determined scrutiny of an aroused press or an independent counsel with the scent of blood.
Craven White House attempts to placate critics were vigorously attacked by Bernard Nussbaum, President Clinton's first legal counsel. "All this will do is feed the beast," he warned. But none of the follies of appeasement alarmed Mr. Nussbaum more, Mr. Stewart tells us, than Mr. Clinton's decision to appoint an independent counsel. Mr. Nussbaum argued that the very institution of independent counsel was "evil," that even a saint in the job would find himself under "enormous pressure to come up with something" and that once he started to hunt he was inevitably going to find that "somebody did something wrong."
Mr. Clinton ignored Mr. Nussbaum's warning. He was desperate. "We can't get health care hearings, we can't pass a bill." Other advisers said appointing an independent counsel would satisfy the critics and make Whitewater go away. So Mr. Clinton asked Attorney General Janet Reno to find someone for the job. In a Greek play the chorus would break into wails of lament at this point. Soon Mr. Nussbaum and many other White House staffers were retaining their own lawyers to deal with questions -- all potentially criminal charges -- about their efforts to handle (hinder the investigation of?) the Whitewater affair.
The first independent counsel, Robert Fiske, opened an office in Little Rock and staffed it with 15 lawyers backed up by an investigative team of 25 F.B.I. agents. Whose conduct of business or professional life is so free of ambiguity and error that she might cock a snook at 15 lawyers and 25 F.B.I. agents? Soon Mr. Fiske was gone, replaced by Mr. Starr. By title Mr. Starr was independent, but one of the judges who chose him had lunch not long before with Senators Lauch Faircloth and Jesse Helms, both conservative Republicans from the judge's native state of North Carolina. Did they perchance discuss Mr. Starr's replacement of Mr. Fiske as independent counsel, which was announced shortly thereafter? The conversation, according to Senator Helms, was restricted to "Western wear, old friends and prostate problems."
"Blood Sport" ends with the resignation of Mr. Nussbaum in March 1994, and with an epilogue to summarize the story since. Mr. Nussbaum's fears of the independent counsel's "roving searchlight" have been fully justified, but Mr. Starr's independence has been questioned recently by the reporters Joe Conason and Murray Waas in The Nation. Not only has he remained as a senior partner at the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis, which paid him compensation of $1.1 million in 1994, according to Mr. Conason and Mr. Waas, but he failed to make public a presumptive conflict of interest of his own -- the fact that one of the targets of his investigation, the Resolution Trust Corporation (R.T.C.), was actively suing his own law firm for allegedly helping officers of a failed savings-and-loan institution to conceal a diversion of bank funds for their private use. According to documents obtained by Mr. Conason and Mr. Waas, Mr. Starr convened a grand jury to investigate the R.T.C. and other Whitewater matters in September 1994, one week before Kirkland & Ellis began negotiations with the R.T.C. to settle the suit against it. Last December the R.T.C. accepted a Kirkland & Ellis offer of $325,000 in return for the dropping of all charges. In the settlement agreement the R.T.C. promised to keep secret not only the terms but the fact of the settlement. Of course Mr. Starr would deny any wrongdoing in this matter, probably thinks Mr. Conason and Mr. Waas wrenched the facts out of context and will doubtless feel I am being unfair by repeating the case they have made. But if every detail of Mr. Starr's conduct over the past 18 months -- every conversation or exchange of memos with R.T.C. officials and his own staff, every meeting with his law partners -- were subject to the scrutiny of an aggressive independent counsel working under the full glare of national publicity, then Mr. Starr would be disclaiming all knowledge of who spilled the milk.
This fact, like the story of the Whitewater investigation unfolded in "Blood Sport," ought to raise serious questions about the power of the independent counsel and its role in our political life. The problem lies in Mr. Starr's charter, which is extremely broad. He has the right (and the resources) to investigate any "violation of Federal criminal or civil law relating in any way" to the relationship between the Clintons and Mr. McDougal or his bank. He may also investigate any other crime of which he learns in the course of the primary investigation; he may investigate any attempts to hinder or obstruct his own or previous investigations; he may further bring charges against others who may have conspired to participate in the primary or secondary crimes or to hinder their investigation; and finally, of course, he may bring charges of perjury against any of those suspected of lying about any of the above.
In the course of "Blood Sport" Mr. Stewart identifies several problem areas that may attract the attention of the independent counsel -- statements, some of them under oath, that a man as generous as Mark Twain would have called "stretchers." The committee hearings of Senator D'Amato, recently extended, have been getting most of the headlines, but Mr. Starr's quiet investigation offstage is far more important. His technique is the standard one, bringing cases against low-level figures in the hope they will "flip" and testify against those higher up. Several figures in Arkansas have pleaded guilty to felonies and agreed to cooperate with the independent counsel. Mr. Clinton's successor as Governor, Jim Guy Tucker, is currently on trial in a case brought by Mr. Starr. Webster Hubbell, a partner of Mrs. Clinton at the Rose Law Firm who followed her to Washington, is serving a 21-month prison sentence on charges completely unrelated to Whitewater, but he too has agreed to cooperate with the independent counsel. This spring Jim McDougal and his wife, Susan, are expected to go on trial on multiple felony charges of conspiracy, mail fraud, bank fraud and making false statements to financial institutions.
It is not yet clear whether convictions and guilty pleas in these and other cases will give Mr. Starr the witnesses he needs to go after Mrs. Clinton or her husband. Since it is customary to bet on the outcome of contests of sport, I am betting that Mr. Starr will go after the biggest quarry of all, that the chief defendant will take the witness stand under oath and that even Republicans will find little pleasure in watching the blood flow.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
2,500 Light Bulbs Waiting for Sponsor

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For 10 years, the huge Hitachi sign atop the Newsweek building just south of Columbus Circle told passers-by the time and the temperature "in Central Park." Before noon it also reported the day's weather, and after noon the forecast for the following day. But no more.
Last month, Hitachi America, the United States subsidiary of the giant Japanese conglomerate, decided to end its sponsorship of the sign, which went dark on Feb. 29. 
 A spokesman for Hitachi's advertising agency, Dentsu U.S.A., said the company now wants to include a product wherever the Hitachi logo is displayed. Hitachi's time, temperature and weather sign, with its 2,560 light bulbs, may have been eye-catching, but neither a big-screen television nor a notebook computer disturbed its symmetry.
Robert Dianuzzo, the electrical supervisor of Artkraft Strauss Corporation, which built the Hitachi sign in 1985, said it has proved so popular that after some needed repairs, Artkraft Strauss may relight it "as a public service." And the company is negotiating with another large corporation to sponsor the sign atop the 28-story Newsweek building at 1775 Broadway.
The sign cost Hitachi $1 million to build, and the company paid $800,000 a year to maintain it and to rent the space. Maintenance was expensive because of several factors. Each 25-watt bulb would last more than eight months under normal use, but the sign's bulbs blinked on and off continually, which reduced their life quite a bit. Vibrations from subway trains beneath Columbus Circle also took their toll, rattling filaments and hastening burnout. Bulbs usually lasted less than four months, Mr. Dianuzzo said, and 150 to 180 were replaced monthly.
On a sign as large as this one, 10 percent of the lamps, or 256, can burn out before it becomes unreadable, Mr. Dianuzzo said. But, he added, his company doesn't let that happen. Each night, an employee known as a night rider drives around the city acting as a troubleshooter. As soon as he "sees something amiss -- the message lamps are spotty, a letter is out," Mr. Dianuzzo said, "we're out there relamping." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hitachi America has turned off its sign. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Most Polite Pit Bull in Local Politics

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
IT is difficult, but important, to describe the devastating finality with which Betty Cooper Wallerstein says goodbye.
The tone is understated but unmistakable; friendly but nonnegotiable; sing-song, yet flat. Absent are the usual conventions of winding down a conversation: well, it's been nice talking to you; I guess that's about it; hope to see you soon. 
 There is no way to anticipate or preempt the ambush that precedes it: out of nowhere, the heavy-set woman with the helmet of white hair button-holes you on the street, traps you on the telephone, homes in on you at a public meeting. And then, just as suddenly as you were blindsided by a breathless stream of names, dates, times and to-do's, Betty Cooper Wallerstein is gone -- leaving you with leaflets to distribute in your building and little more than a tight, high-pitched "bye-bye."
Ms. Wallerstein may well be the busiest woman in New York City. Certainly, after 12 years of mobilizing her far-east stretch of the Upper East Side, she has earned a reputation as perhaps the city's most tenacious and effective community organizer. "She's a kind of sovereignty in her own locality," said Parks Commissioner Henry Stern. "She's so powerful that she intimidates some local officials. Nobody wants to tangle with Betty Wallerstein. She's rather formidable."
The 59-year-old Ms. Wallerstein knows how to make a meeting happen, how to reach an elected official on the telephone, how to attract the press's attention to a problem, how to line up speakers for a public hearing, how to raise money, how to bring a lawsuit, how to keep the pressure on.
In a city where people often find themselves mystified or cowed by bureaucracy as they approach a problem, Ms. Wallerstein has distinguished herself as a person who knows what it takes to prevail.
"If she is leading a battle, you know we're going to win," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney. "She just does not stop."
The East 79th Street Neighborhood Association -- which covers 76th to 82d Streets from the East River to First Avenue, as well as 79th Street west to Lexington Avenue -- provides the solid base of support that gives Ms. Wallerstein's leadership its weight.
Driven by a desire to establish Sunday service on "the Bloomingdale's bus," York Avenue's M31, Ms. Wallerstein and a businessman who no longer lives in the neighborhood gathered several members of the community in a dank basement in February 1984. Thus was born the association, which started out with two blocks and now encompasses 36 blocks, 60 buildings and an active membership of several hundred people and businesses.
With Ms. Wallerstein's training as a social worker, family therapist and community organizer -- the kind of person who sounded the alarm about dilapidated benches in her children's playground -- her activism has clearly played to her strengths. But Ms. Wallerstein says the personal sacrifices have taken their toll and has begun grooming two members of her association to take her place as president.
It has been a long time in the trenches. Ms. Wallerstein has lent her strength to battles like the monumental nine-year effort of the late 80's and early 90's to save the City and Suburban Homes, built at the turn of the century as model tenements between 78th and 79th Streets and York Avenue and the East River. In the face of plans by the developer Peter S. Kalikow to raze the 26-building complex, Ms. Wallerstein led the group of 200 zoning, tenant and political organizations that succeeded in designating the apartments as a landmark.
Ms. Wallerstein has also been in the vanguard in the kind of victories that matter most to her fellow far-East Side constituents, namely those related to transportation, preservation and consumer conveniences. She finally won a Sunday extension of the M31 after three years of trying; helped establish a new post office station with six-day service on York Avenue; played a role in keeping the York Avenue Sloan's supermarket from becoming a Rite-Aid, and helped reduce one of two new towers at 79th and First Avenue to 16 stories from more than 30.
Most recently, she helped organize a coalition of 16 organizations, the cunningly named Neighbors "R" Us, to fight the building of a Toys "R" Us superstore planned for 80th Street and Third Avenue. That litigation is still pending and has grown increasingly bitter.
Ms. Wallerstein can play hardball when she has to but prefers diplomacy. The dance of influencing people in power requires more graceful techniques, Ms. Wallerstein makes clear, and her particular repertory could serve as a primer for those aspiring to follow in her path.
Take timing, for example. Before taking on a major cause, Ms. Wallerstein makes sure that she has some kind of consensus behind her. "The issue that I will work on has to be an issue that affects a large number of people," she said. "Generally it's a precedent-setting issue, which means that it has the potential to impact other communities and other areas.
"You want to make sure it's an issue for enough people," she added. "If it's an issue for a few people that doesn't mean you don't do it. But if you have support then the job is easier."
Shoring up that support tends to be the hardest part of Ms. Wallerstein's work. People lead busy lives; politicians tend to be conservative about getting out in front on a controversial subject.
"Very often what happens is you have an opponent who is formidable and people are afraid to take that opponent on," she said. "And so they wait, and you're out there by yourself for a long time. And then you make some progress and you have a win.
"And once you've made a win, and once there's been an opening, then people come in. I'm always happy when we get help. I would love to have it at the beginning, but I'm happy to have it in the middle and sometimes we don't get it until the very end."
 
 
 
ONE HECTIC DAY
 Ms. Wallerstein's turf represents a particular slice of the Upper East Side -- more small-town than tony. On Park Avenue, people hurry in and out of their town cars; on York Avenue, they stroll and stop to say hello. The population ranges from the rent-control elderly who enjoy the river breezes in Carl Schurz Park to high-rise young professionals who order in and work long hours with an eye toward old-money addresses farther west. In large part, these residents are defined by their distance from mass transit: it gives them a sense of isolation at once galvanizing and unifying.
While Ms. Wallerstein's rules of engagement may be guided by a set of grand maxims, her leverage seems to lie in large part in a dogged tending of details. The approach pays off. People rarely get involved until a problem affects them directly; Ms. Wallerstein maintains an infrastructure that may preempt problems or at least prepare for them.
In any given day, the logistics can keep her moving till midnight: updating the association's bulletin boards in each of six banks, checking the post office box and spending hours on the telephone.
Ms. Wallerstein consistently stays in touch with the streets. She makes a point of getting to know the local merchants -- eating in every restaurant, shopping in each new store. Her gray vinyl bucket purse carries key supplies -- a calendar jammed with scribbled appointments, yellow 3-by-5 index cards, a compact Kodak camera.
"I might see a pothole," she said. "I'll see broken sidewalks, I'll see an illegal van. And the best way is often just to take a picture."
On one recent morning, she stood on York Avenue and 79th Street to monitor a taxi stand that takes East Siders down to Wall Street, four at a time. Ms. Wallerstein's association helped establish the cab service to ease what is usually a long commute.
But lately members of the community have complained about those cabs refusing riders bound for less distant -- and therefore less lucrative -- destinations. Ms. Wallerstein is working with the Taxi and Limousine Commission as well as the local precinct to put a stop to that.
Having climbed into a cab to test the taxi line herself, Ms. Wallerstein lectured the driver after he protested taking her to 77th Street and First Avenue on the ground that the quickest way there would require an illegal left turn.
She then set off on her rounds. She stopped in at the Tortoise and the Hare, a new children's haircutting salon on York at 78th to drop off fliers announcing a public meeting about a new law that enables police to seize bicycles ridden illegally on the sidewalk. There, she chatted with the owner, Joseph Panasci, who credits Ms. Wallerstein with helping him win approval for his store's permanent hunter-green awning.
Then she was off again -- past the fruit vendor at 78th and York who used to operate in front of a deli that also sold fruit until Ms. Wallerstein and her association made him move across the street.
She popped into the post office to meet the new part-time manager of the branch. He suggested she bring her concerns -- a full-time manager and a spot for the association's bulletin boards -- to his supervisor, and Ms. Wallerstein agreed to do just that. The moment seemed entirely casual; yet all the while, Ms. Wallerstein was making mental calculations.
Ms. Wallerstein knows she could take her problems over their heads. But, she explained later, "I need to work with this manager. So even though I could do a short cut, I'm not going to do it. Time is not of the essence here; the relationship is important."
While out on these rounds, Ms. Wallerstein, who has lived in the neighborhood for 20 years, could barely get from one end of the block to the other. In front of the post office, a longtime resident asked her advice about finding a home for his aging aunt. In a crosswalk, another man launched into the latest chapter of his landlord woes. This is typical. Moving on is an art all its own, and Ms. Wallerstein has mastered it.
"I have a hard time getting to the bus stop from my house," she said. "I don't get stopped for long. I try to be kind, I try to listen, but I also evaluate. There are people who are going to tell me things that are inaccurate. There are people who are going to tell me things that have a hidden agenda. You figure that out quickly. Certain people are chronic complainers -- they could stop and talk forever. And I don't get stuck."
 
 
 
A POLITICAL STYLE
 When holding court with these residents, Ms. Wallerstein tries to contract out their concerns to other community leaders or to elected officials. Often, she nudges people to play a role in solving their own problems, by assigning them some task or advising a possible angle of attack. And always, she urges her neighbors to air their issues at the next association meeting. Then she is off and running, often leaving her supplicants in mid-sentence.
Ms. Wallerstein's manner is part of her success: cold in that she cuts to the chase, warm enough to grease the wheels along the way. With hurriedly painted pink lipstick, stockings with runs in the knees and a canvas tote bag bulging with crime prevention pamphlets, tabloid newspapers and apple pancakes left over from breakfast, Ms. Wallerstein's physical presence is distinctly nonthreatening.
That is partly because she feels she has more important things to do than worry about how she comes across. So, she pulls on her pantyhose in the back of taxis, applies her make-up in elevator mirrors.
This aura of chaos gives Ms. Wallerstein a quaintness that is reinforced by her old-fashioned propriety. She is soft-spoken, exceedingly polite and philosophically opposed to call-waiting because she thinks it's rude and it makes her lose her train of thought -- a position that can be as maddening as it is charming, given that she works out of her home with only one phone line.
There are times when Ms. Wallerstein's single-mindedness can seem myopic. It is a criticism often leveled at fervent neighborhood leaders: that they are so concerned about their particular territory that they lose sight of the city's larger needs.
"I think it's important for all neighborhood zealots to understand that there are issues that the Mayor has to deal with, where he has to prioritize, such as police protection and public education," said Jack Lester, a lawyer who lives on the Upper East Side and represents Neighbors "R" Us. "When you talk about a distribution of scarce resources, choices have to be made."
At the same time, said Mr. Lester, who has represented a number of neighborhood groups, it is the radicals who get results. "It's almost a byproduct of being a neighborhood activist," he said: "obsessiveness about certain details and focus on things which may seem picayune."
Commissioner Stern added, "There is always a fine line between genius and madness, and she treads that fine line."
 
 
 
CHOOSING HER BATTLES
 There is an unspoken rule among the Upper East Side's elected officials: When Betty Cooper Wallerstein is on the telephone, you take the call.
"Woe betide the elected official who does not return her call, who is not responsive to her issue," said Councilman Andrew Eristoff.
They describe her as equal parts mosquito, pit bull and mother hen. While they may roll their eyes or smile at her pushy perseverance, Ms. Wallerstein is no light matter: they want her on their side. Although her association studiously avoids making public political endorsements -- people are not allowed to wear partisan buttons at the monthly meetings -- politicians know a phone call from Ms. Wallerstein is a phone call from a huge pool of potential political supporters.
It isn't just because she might mean votes or gets results or because she won't go away that Ms. Wallerstein gets their attention, officials say, but because she chooses her battles carefully and will not waste their time.
"She never picks a dumb fight," Mr. Eristoff said. "She gets involved in issues that matter, and she never cries wolf."
Some time ago, Ms. Wallerstein's Assemblyman, John A. Ravitz, volunteered to help survey the number of riders on the crosstown bus one Sunday. He received more than a few reminders from Ms. Wallerstein.
"I must have gotten 10 calls Saturday to make sure I was going to do it," he said. "Then Sunday she called to make sure I was up and out and ready to go to work and, 'John, when you've completed your forms, drop them off at my building.' God forbid I hadn't dropped off those forms. She would have stormed my house."
Developers, too, have reason to dread the dogged activist. When the City and Suburban stand-off was heating up, Ms. Wallerstein said Peter Kalikow himself came to talk compromise: you keep 20 buildings, I'll raze 6.
"I said, 'Mr. Kalikow, how do you tear down a piece of a landmark?' " Ms. Wallerstein recalled.
Ms. Wallerstein was also under pressure from her allies to make a deal. She said the Preservation League of New York State told her: "If you lose this one, you're not only going to lose it for City and Suburban, you're going to lose it for all the rest of us that are trying so hard. Because this will set a precedent that the Board of Estimate -- and now the City Council -- will be able to cut down landmarks if you don't win this."
"So that," Ms. Wallerstein said, "was a hard call."
She agonized all of 10 minutes and decided not to fold. Now the City and Suburban is a site on the Circle Line tour. "It's now a city, state and Federal landmark," Ms. Wallerstein says. "Cannot be torn down."
 
 
 
A NEW LIFE AHEAD
 Why does she do it? Because she loves doing it. And because not everyone has the time, money or temperament to devote so much of their lives to improving their quality of life. "I feel that much luckier if I can do it," she said.
Nevertheless, the costs of her unceasing vigilance have recently prompted her to re-examine her priorities.
On one level, there is the economic expense; in the heat of battle her phone bills are astronomical. Her husband of 30 years, a lawyer, supports Ms. Wallerstein's work financially, but not always philosophically.
"He does not share my commitment to giving so much time to community work," she said. "He would like me to spend more time on myself and home furnishings and to be more available in the evenings."
And then there is the personal price. Ms. Wallerstein, the mother of two grown children, has made sacrifices. She has lost sleep, gained weight, missed vacations, worked weekends. She would like more time for the opera and the symphony. As it is, she has barely been able to prepare for her own belated bas mitzvah, coming up in May.
"It's an enormous amount of time," she said. "There are lots of things that I want to have the time to do that I couldn't do because I had to be doing this if I wanted this to be done.
"It is now time for me."
 
Riding Out the Bus Issue: How One Meeting Went
IT is 1:20 on a Friday afternoon and Betty Cooper Wallerstein is in the back seat of a cab with two members of her neighborhood association, heading downtown to meet with the Transit Authority.
The agency plans to reduce service and change the routes of two weekday express buses that travel from the Upper East Side to Battery Park City and the World Trade Center, the X90 and the X92. Because of low ridership, transit officials say they have been losing money on those lines.
As president of the East 79th Street Neighborhood Association, Ms. Wallerstein is bringing with her Jeffrey Gold, chairman of the association's transportation committee, and Carlene Knowlton, one of the two association members Ms. Wallerstein has designated as her successors. On the way down in the hired car, they plot strategy.
First, Ms. Wallerstein lays out the purpose of the mission: they want to make a case for keeping the service in tact and to complain that the agency failed to adequately publicize the express line to increase ridership. But Ms. Wallerstein also makes clear that this visit may prove to be largely symbolic, a show of strength by the association in the presence of elected officials' representatives that may make an impact, but probably won't make a difference.
"They give us the time and courtesy to listen to us but the whole thing is a sham," Ms. Wallerstein says. "They have their minds made up. Their interest is really not in serving the ridership or in responding to the community. It will be frustrating, but it's something we have to do."
Ms. Wallerstein sets the impending scene: seven elected officials will be represented, and several people from the Transit Authority are expected to be present. She suggests that she and her cohorts -- who include an association member they are meeting there -- divide up the subject matter and, above all, stay focused.
Mr. Gold asks whether he should raise the issue of enforcing the bus lanes and Ms. Wallerstein vetoes that idea. "We're not going to bring up anything else," she says, "unless we get somewhere with what we have."
Because Ms. Knowlton has primarily come along to observe, Ms. Wallerstein makes an effort to fill her in on the historical subtext of what is about to transpire.
"Their strategy is to cut service in such a way that the death is done slowly," she says. "They cut the service, don't market it, change the routes and then -- when the ridership falters -- they use the low counts to make an argument to eliminate the service."
The meeting takes place around a conference table in the office of City Council Speaker Peter Vallone -- although Mr. Vallone himself is not present. (That A. Gifford Miller, the Councilman, was able to secure the room is, Ms. Wallerstein later explains, impressive for a freshman council member and something of "a coup" for the association; it says to the Transit Authority that the Upper East Side has clout and means business.)
Some sniping notwithstanding, the meeting seems to go smoothly. Ms. Wallerstein and her fellow association members say the express bus matters to their neighborhood and pass out examples of the questionnaire cards they distributed to East Side residents in conducting their own ridership survey -- as if to say they know from whence they speak.
The transit officials plead financial contingencies. "I feel like I'm in a waltz for eternity here," says Jack Lusk, senior vice president for customer services. "These things don't get done in a vacuum and the T.A. has corporate pressures. We end up butting heads over the same thing and I worry it ain't going away."
Ms. Wallerstein counters, "I never felt that we were waltzing," and insists that "taxpayers have a right to public transportation."
When the meeting ends, Ms. Wallerstein huddles with Ms. Knowlton for a post-mortem. "Do I think we're going to be successful?" she says. "No. But when they sit down in a month and they're going to have to cut again, maybe they'll think twice about the Wall Street lines."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Can the Schools Stand or Deliver?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
"THE answer to all our national problems comes down to a single word: education," Lyndon B. Johnson said in promoting his vision of the Great Society in the 1960's.
In that same spirit -- the eternal American faith that schools can solve all the nation's ills -- the nation's governors and top corporate executives are gathering this week in Palisades, N.Y., for what is being grandly billed as the Second National Education Summit. President Clinton is to address the governors Wednesday. 
 The gathering itself, occurring at a time of faint progress toward the "new era of education reform" that George Bush hailed after the first summit in 1989, reflects the prevailing belief that the nation needs to demand more from its struggling schools, teachers and underachieving students.
 
 
 
Too Much or Too Little
 But some historians and educators are offering the heretical notion that it can be as shortsighted to expect schools to do too much as it can be to accept when they do too little, particularly when enormous social and economic problems are seeping into the classroom and disagreement is rife over how the schools should respond. The critics argue that President Johnson got it wrong: that the nation's educational ills are more the result than the cause of its economic problems, investment decisions, violent culture and urban decay. And without adequate funds and realistic expectations and planning, periodic promulgations on how bad things are or how wonderful they can be will not improve education.
"Americans have always had very utopian expectations of what the schools can do," said David Tyack, a professor of education at Stanford University. "That can be a very positive way of recreating democracy. The problem comes when you promise too much and people get cynical. The danger with the utopian view of education policy is that it's a short jump from seeing education as the ark of the covenant to becoming cynical and disappointed enough to see schools as failures that don't matter at all."
Thus, this second summit is provoking two key questions: Is its agenda of higher standards and better technology the right one? And is America's faith in education realistic?
High expectations, as well as high achievement, have long been a central element of public education. From Horace Mann's millennial view of schools in the 1840's as mighty engines of moral and social uplift to the current view of them as pivotal to the nation's economic future, Americans have put so much faith in learning that a recent book, "Tinkering Toward Utopia" (Harvard University Press, 1995), by Mr. Tyack and Larry Cuban, calls education "almost a secular religion."
President Bush and the governors adopted ambitious national goals for improving schools over a 10-year period.
Since then, however, there has been little real progress in test scores or graduation rates and, worse, there have been some signs that education is sliding farther down in the national priorities. To revive momentum, the governors, each bringing along a major corporate executive, will try to move from the general goals of 1989 toward the establishment of specific, rigorous standards of what students must learn in different subject areas. The intent is to link mastery of those subjects with promotion to the next grade, something that is missing from many state systems. A high school diploma would be more than the worthless scrap of paper that many fear it has become. The other item on their agenda is to bring better computers and technology into the schools.
"The strength that standards have in other countries is that this is what your whole society expects of you," Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, says in materials put together for the conference. "It's so universal that it's not questioned."
 
 
 
School for Citizens
 Proponents of setting specific standards and holding children to them say they would be one antidote to grade inflation, so-called social promotions and institutionalized assumptions, including the widespread belief that many poor and black children cannot learn.
At a time of economic uneasiness and worries that the schools are failing to turn out adequately educated graduates for the workplace, the conference has an unapologetically utilitarian stance, and includes more corporate executives than educators.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado said: "The executives are saying, 'We're the customers for your products, meaning the graduates of the schools. We have something to say about what kind of products they ought to be.' And what in the world do you go to school for other than to become good citizens and get a job and raise a family?"
To some educators, that viewpoint, students as little more than future employees-in-training and the conference's emphasis on standards reflects a distressingly mechanistic image of education. Many see the focus on standards as overly simplistic, assuming high standards will overcome myriad social and cultural impediments to learning.
"The public debate and the political debate is mainly about all the wrong things," said Edward Miller, editor of the Harvard Education Letter. "People who actually work in schools are talking about completely different things than governors and politicians are."
While politicians are talking about vouchers and standards, Mr. Miller said, teachers are concerned about motivating children unprepared for and uninterested in learning, teaching disabled ones once routinely excluded or educating students unable to speak English well. Many say that a more useful approach to standards is to specify what money, technology or other materials should be available to all schools.
Few educators argue against standards, but there has been such a strong anti-Washington current since 1989 that few of them are advocating national standards. Many educators share a widely held belief that the sense of educational crisis and failure today represents a curious disconnect between what is wrong with education and how that fits into broader problems of American life.
 
 
 
It's the Culture, Stupid
 "The intellectual level of the schools can be no higher than the intellectual level of the culture in which they float," said Richard Gibboney, an education professor at the University of Pennsylvania and the former Vermont Commissioner of Education. "You look at TV. You look at our commercial culture. What you see in society is what you see in the schools."

HEADLINE: A Modest Strike;
For the U.A.W., It's Not the Revolution

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio

 BODY:
AT first glance, the basic relationship between labor and capital in the United States seemed to be changing last week.
A small band of workers, just 3,000 brake makers here, had shut down the world's largest auto maker, the General Motors Corporation, in the industry's biggest work stoppage since 1970. Some outsiders called for the United Automobile Workers to rally Americans under a banner of resistance to the broad forces of economic change that have produced so much insecurity across the country. And Robert Eaton, the chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, lamented, "Today, apparently the shame is raising a son who grows up to be a C.E.O." 
 Yet the U.A.W. never took up that banner, negotiating last week's settlement in total secrecy. Even while the Presidential campaign brings fresh attention to the plight of workers, corporate America remains in a season of downsizing. And the brake workers themselves -- with an average age of 50 and an average income of $69,000 a year from working six- and seven-day weeks -- were singularly unenthusiastic about playing the starring role in any social revolution.
 
 
 
Strictly Local
 "We didn't want to shake up the nation, we just wanted to shake up the people in here," said Warren M. Cooper, a 53-year-old picketer at the factory gate who put his three children through college on his earnings here.
Nor did the union have much to say about larger issues like corporate responsibility and economic inequality. In contrast to the U.A.W. of the 1930's and 1940's, this union went on strike here not to galvanize other workers or even to pursue higher wages or benefits, but to insist that G.M. live up to past promises to continue producing most of its brakes in Dayton.
And in the end, the workers here won some job security and cash for themselves while resisting G.M.'s demands for greater freedom to buy parts from outside, nonunion companies. But the union failed to put any new limits on these outside purchases, leaving the overall relationship with the company unchanged.
It was management, not labor, that was on the offensive during much of the strike. G.M. resisted bargaining with the U.A.W. for the first week of the confrontation, which lasted 17 days.
G.M. managers were trying to extract concessions on parts purchases that would boost the profitability of the company and its long-run ability to compete. In doing so, they provided a particularly vivid example of the broader shift of compensation away from workers and toward owners of capital.
"This is one of the skirmishes in one of the great battles over income share in this economy -- this is one of the great issues of how the product is divided," said James E. Annable, the chief economist at First Chicago NBD, the biggest bank in the Midwest. But it was management, not workers, that is trying to shift the balance at G.M., he added.
But the U.A.W.'s willingness to confront management might not be repeated elsewhere as long as Federal law continues to allow companies to hire replacement workers during strikes. The same U.A.W. that appeared invincible here last week lost a bitter 18-month strike at Caterpillar Inc. last year when the heavy equipment maker brought in replacements.
G.M. never even tried to train replacement workers because the company is simply too big to do so. Replacing its 240,000 U.A.W. workers would be a nearly impossible task even if G.M. were not in a market so competitive that a company's market share can melt away in weeks, never to be recovered.
But G.M. is also the nation's largest industrial corporation, with sales in the fourth quarter of last year that were 19 times greater, for example, than the sales of the Microsoft Corporation. Few other companies face the constraints that G.M.'s sheer size imposes.
 
 
 
The Public's Interest
 Labor experts said last week that while the immediate effects of the G.M. strike may have been spectacular, with several hundred thousand workers out of work, real changes in labor relations are more likely to come from political pressures than from strikes. To the dismay of corporate leaders like Mr. Eaton, business decisions affecting employees are increasingly the subject of public scrutiny, including criticism from politicians of both parties.
"Outsourcing and downsizing, those two issues which have to do with corporate behavior, are all out now in the public domain," said Barry Bluestone, a professor of political economy at the University of Massachusetts.
The prospects for political changes are murky for now. Republicans in Congress strongly favor allowing the replacement of strikers, while a Federal court has rejected President Clinton's effort to halt Federal contracts by executive decree for companies that hire replacement workers. Last week the Justice Department filed an appeal of the court decision.
So while a few of the U.A.W. workers here bemoaned the job insecurity and economic inequality that are changing the nation, their strike did not appear to have done much to halt either trend.
"When I got out of high school, there were good-paying jobs -- now, you've got people coming out of college and there aren't any jobs," said Jim Breen, a 48-year-old maintenance worker here who walked the picket line near his shiny black 1994 GMC Sonoma pickup truck. "I know people who have got 25-year-olds sitting on their couch who can't put the money together for the insurance on their car."

HEADLINE: When 'Ketchup' Is 'Tomato Achievement'

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE House passed the Immigration in the National Interest bill last week, while the Senate adopted the Common Sense Liability and Legal Reform bill. This week both expect to vote on the Contract With America Advancement bill.
Editorializing in bill naming is hardly a recent invention, even if it seems to have increased exponentially in this Congress. The Democrats who controlled the 103d Congress passed the Goals 2000: Educate America Act (to help states establish school achievement standards), and it tried to pass the Cesar Chavez Workplace Fairness Act (which would have barred hiring of permanent replacements for striking workers). 
 In the previous decade, a tax cut was called the Economic Recovery Act of 1981, while another measure, which preceded higher deficits, was called the Balanced Budget and Deficit Control Act of 1985.
 
 
 
The Best Defense
 Even before that, President Lyndon B. Johnson got a law enacted called the Safe Streets and Omnibus Crime Control Act, and President Dwight D. Eisenhower had both the National Defense Highway Act and the National Defense Education Act.
But in a quieter, less market-driven time, Social Security was good enough for Franklin D. Roosevelt. In those days, the bill could be passed without being called the Dignity in Old Age Act or the Keep Grandma Out of the Poorhouse Act.
Recently, the name game has picked up enormously. The Republicans' Contract With America Advancement bill, which would raise the Federal debt limit, allow line-item vetoes and ease regulation of small businesses, follows a pattern. Every item on the Contract With America had a tendentious name, too, from the Personal Responsibility bill (which would limit how long people could get welfare) to the American Dream Restoration Act (which would cut taxes).
Ed Gillespie, the communications director at the Republican National Committee, wrote those titles, according to Tony Blankley, press secretary to Speaker Newt Gingrich. Mr. Gillespie would not confirm or deny authorship. But he said, "People have a right to know what proponents are trying to accomplish."
The names aren't widely disseminated -- newspapers and television news rarely use them, though they can be found as written on the Internet. Still, using these highly descriptive titles "encourages members to talk about the bills in terms that mean something to people in the real world," Mr. Gillespie said.
As his favorite example of how a name can be changed to get attention, he cited the House Republicans' renaming of last year's Omnibus Budget Reconciliation bill, changing it to the Balanced Budget bill.
Mr. Blankley noted that political figures had always chosen names that they thought would confer an advantage. The most dramatic examples, he said, were Stalin (the former Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili), Lenin (Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov) and, of course, Hitler; "Heil Schicklgruber," after all, did not have much of a ring to it, Mr. Blankley added.
House Democrats take a dimmer view of this style of naming bills, at least when practiced by Republicans. Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr. of Indiana said the practice was an extension of a principle he first saw in action in the State Legislature: "Most evil is sold in the name of good."
 
 
 
Democratic Names
 Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, noting that titles could be amended, wondered aloud if Democrats should not have tried to change the name of the immigration bill to the Statue of Liberty Was Wrong measure.
But some of these critics are not bad at the tactic themselves. Mr. Jacobs sought for years to diminish the perks afforded retired Presidents. His bill was called the Former Presidents Enough Is Enough and Taxpayers Relief Act.
Indeed, he is still at it. With Representative Dan Burton, a very conservative Republican also from Indiana, Mr. Jacobs is promoting a bill to require football, baseball, basketball and hockey to use instant television replay. It is called the What Really Happened bill. He said his first choice for a name had been the It Wasn't a Touchdown, Stupid bill.
No matter how imaginative, however, Congress is in no danger of matching the worldwide record for legislative excess in this department, achieved in 1959 when the South African Parliament passed a bill to remove black students from those universities that would admit them. It was called the Extension of Higher Education Act.

HEADLINE: Canadian Mounties Accused of Failing to Protect Their Man

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 23

 BODY:
In his scarlet tunic, blue breeches with a yellow stripe and wide-brimmed hat, the Mountie has long been a symbol of Canada. But these days, that figure of fortitude and rectitude who always gets his man is likely -- at least in the nation's irreverent press -- to wear the face of Mickey Mouse.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have taken a drubbing lately over incidents that have raised questions about their ability to protect the Prime Minister. 
 In November an intruder armed with a knife broke into the Ottawa residence of Prime Minister Jean Chretien as he and his wife slept. After hearing footsteps, Mrs. Chretien, thinking it was one of their aides, confronted the man in a hallway. She quickly retreated, bolting the bedroom doors and sounding an alarm. The couple had to wait nearly 10 minutes before help arrived.
In February, during Flag Day ceremonies in Hull, Mr. Chretien found himself before a demonstrator protesting cuts in unemployment insurance who shouted in French, "Chretien to the unemployment line!"
Although Mr. Chretien, 62, easily shoved the protester aside, questions were again raised about the Mounties' inadequacies.
"It's deplorable that an incident like that occurred," Mr. Chretien said. "I should not be confronted with situations like that."
Canadians have long valued relatively easy access to their Prime Minister. But in the national soul-searching now under way, many are asking how long this will continue.
"The fact is that times have changed," said Bob Fife, Ottawa bureau chief for The Toronto Sun, "and we are as susceptible to loonies as the Americans."
After what the Mounties themselves identified as a "breakdown in supervision and communications," they have strengthened the chain of command and upgraded the Prime Minister's security systems.
Four junior officers and an inspector were suspended after the incident with the intruder, according to a Mounties report.
The report also said, "The policies are extremely weak relative to what is expected of a member when an alarm situation occurs."
In the Flag Day incident, the Mounties said that Mr. Chretien was never in danger. But his office was furious.
In fact Mr. Chretien, made a point of cutting back his personal security and on Flag Day had gotten in front of his moving security screen.
Corporal Moreau said that "the perimeter will be tighter in the future while still allowing him the accessibility he wants."
The Mounties' image has also been colored by an agreement last June with the Walt Disney Company. Tired of letting purveyors of keychains, T-shirts, dolls and coffee mugs profit from its stalwart reputation, the force sold Disney the merchandising rights for its image. The proceeds will help pay for community police work.
Canada is one of the world's safest countries in the world, so it spends less on security than any other industrial country, said Richard Chenoweth, vice president of Intercom Security Ltd., the country's largest security company,
But, Mr. Chenoweth added, with Canadian politics "heating up and getting more personal, the Mounties are not being given a level of resources appropriate to the task."
A University of Toronto historian, Robert Bothwell, said, "I have a certain sympathy for the Mounties." He said, "It's not always their fault that they don't have the right people at the right place at the right time."
But, he added, the latest incidents raise questions about the way the force is managed.
